abstract: The, in the South
snippet: The, in the South
lead_paragraph: The Southern papers that reach us these days, though almost destitute of all news, contain many evidences of a state of feeling throughout the South made up of desperation and despair; and an intelligent Confederate officer, just escaped from the rebel army at Richmond, informs us that the advance of SHERMAN's invincible force is looked upon with uncontrollable dismay. A letter in one of our cotemporaries, containing some information on this matter, says:

abstract: News of our Victories in; Our, News of, Abroad
snippet: News of our Victories in; Our, News of, Abroad
lead_paragraph: The news of the capture of the capital of South Carolina, and of the triumphal march of SHERMAN's army through the State which originated the rebellion, opened the war, and has been one of its main supporters, went to Europe by the steamship City of London, which sailed from this port on the 13th ultimo, and was doubtless published there yesterday or this morning. The news of the capture of Charleston was taken to Europe by the Australasian on the 22d, and probably by day after to-morrow, it will be announced to an astonished continent by the journals of London and Paris. Very quickly thereafter they will hear of the capture of Wilmington, the great entrepot for years of the European blockade-runners.

abstract: Magazines for March, the
snippet: Magazines for March, the
lead_paragraph: -- Harper's New Monthly Magazine (New-York: HARPER & BROTHERS,) opens with the conclusion of ROSS BROWN'S "Tour Through-Arizona." His papers are valuable, as containing the fullest account yet given by any traveler of that remote region, and the summing up of his impressions is no doubt near the truth. He regards it as "a territory wonderfully rich in minerals, but subject to greater drawbacks in the way of peaceable settled occupation than any of our territorial possessions." The new installment of WILKIE COLLINS' novel, "Armadale," preserves well the weird, mysterious atmosphere of the story. One portion -- the explanation of a dream --seems written with a recollection of EDGAR A. POE's peculiar analytical faculty. DICKENS' "Our Mutual Friend," progresses also, but the writer is entangled among three or four sets of characters, very slightly connected together, if at all, by any community of interest, so that his transitions from one to the other tax the memory, and display an utter want of the constructive power needed for the easy working of a good serviceable plot. "The Siege and Capture of Port Hudson, by Admiral FARRAGUT," forms the subject of JOHN S.C. ABBOTT's "Heroic Deeds of Heroic Men." The economic article is a full and exhaustive account of "Sugar-making in Cuba," each process described being illustrated with excellent wood-cuts. Three or four stories of the usual magazine calibre, "Mr. Raspton's Resurrection." "Poor Isabel," "Maud Molyneaux's Music-Box," will gratify the lovers of fiction. "Ultramarine Views" is a lady's clever account of the disagreeables of an Atlantic trip. "Our Lessons in Statesmanship" takes a cheerful view of the results of the late Presidential election. Some of Harper's fair readers will miss the usual fashion plate, this month conspicuous from its absence, but there is enough good matter in the number to make up for the omission.

abstract: Sensation Reports from
snippet: Sensation Reports from
lead_paragraph: -- It is surely almost time that the telegraph should cease to be burdened with startling rumors from Matamoras, circulated in New-Orleans, and received here by way of Cairo. The latest of these rumors represents the "Imperial Government of Mexico" as having forbidden the issue of clearances to American ports. Accompanying this is a story of the dismissal of our Consul from Matamoras. The intent of these reports may not be apparent to those who are made the instruments of sending them abroad by telegraph; they are perfectly understood among reflecting citizens here. They are conceived in the interest of the rebels, and like the sensation telegrams from Paris, are meant to intimate that we are daily and hourly threatened with a rupture of our relations with France, and with forcible intervention in behalf of the rebels. We have had quite enough of this sort of thing.

abstract: Ferris Wife-Murder Trial
snippet: Ferris Wife-Murder Trial
lead_paragraph: The case of Francisco or Frank Ferris, indicted for the murder of his wife Mary Ferris, came up for trial yesterday morning. The District-Attorney stated in his opening that this case was what the books call an old-fashioned grudge-murder. There were no circumstances in this case that would make it other than murder in the first degree. The prisoner and his wife had lived together unhappily for some months previous to the commission of the fatal act. He had frequently made threats that he would kill her, and she, by her whole conduct on the night of the murder, showed that she was aware of the danger to her life from the malicious vengeance of the accused, and fought to avoid her husband to secure her life.

abstract: Carriers' Liability; Nieman vs. Grand Trunk Railroad
snippet: Carriers' Liability; Nieman vs. Grand Trunk Railroad
lead_paragraph: Canada. -- This was an action brought for the recovery of a large quantity of tools which were shipped by the plaintiff for New-York, at a station on the Grand Trunk Railway, at or near Toronto, in February, 1863. The testimony showed that the Grand [???] Railway conveyed the goods in question to Portland, Me., and that they were there transhipped to a steamer of H.B. Cromwell's line, which delivered the property in question at her wharf in this city. No one calling for the merchandise within the period usual in such cases, it was sent to a storehouse with a view to its being sold. The Judge who tried the case, decided, after hearing all the testimony, that the only question was as to the construction to be given to the contract contained in some special regulations on the back of the receipt given to the consignor in Canada, by the defendant's agents, at the time of the delivery of the goods to them for transportation to New-York. One of the conditions printed on the back of the receipt was to the effect that the defendants agreed to convey the property for which they gave their receipt, to the end of their route, and upon its being delivered to another line of transportation, running thence to the place designated for the delivery of the goods, they were relieved from all responsibility. The Judge held that inasmuch as the plaintiff knew of these conditions at the time the goods were shipped, and the fact having been proved that Cromwell & Co. had delivered them in New-York, their place of destination though they could not be found by the plaintiff until near a year subsequent to February, 1863, the defendants were not liable as common carriers. The result would have been different, the court said, if the suit had been against Cromwell & Co., the owners of the line between Portland and New-York. The jury by direction of the court, therefore, rendered a verdict for the defendants. Leave was granted to plaintiff to take the case to the General term, without the usual security for costs.

abstract: News still Wanted from
snippet: News still Wanted from
lead_paragraph: The rebels still withhold from us all news about the progress of Gen. SHERMAN's army, and the only thing about SHERMAN that we feel sure of at present is that the rebels have had not even the slightest success over any part of his forces, else it would have been communicated to the Richmond press, to the rebel army and to us, very speedily. The probability is that Gen. SHERMAN is sweeping everything before him -- marching on, conquering and to conquer.

abstract: Desertions; Prevalence of
snippet: Desertions; Prevalence of
lead_paragraph: -- It has been noticed that whenever the rebel armies have abandoned any Southern State, we have invariably had from the troops of the State, wherever they were stationed, a great tide of desertion. One cause of the depletion of HOOD's army, on its retreat from Nashville, was in the desertion of thousands of the Tennessee soldiers, who declared they would never again fight out of Tennessee; and there have been very many other illustrations of the same phenomenon in the course of the war. The latest development of the kind has occurred since SHERMAN's army passed triumphantly across the State of South Carolina. The conscripts of that State, serving with LEE, are now passing over into our lines in large numbers. Our correspondent, writing from the right wing of the Army of the Potomac, on Saturday last, says: "Another lot of fifty-three deserters, from a South Carolina regiment, who also came in on Thursday night, reported themselves as 'peace commissioners.' One of this number declared that they had gone into this war to 'put down the heresy that a negro is as good as a white man;' but as that doctrine was now apparently about to be adopted at the South, and the negroes were, to be placed in the ranks there and made their equals, they wished to go North, where there were fewer of such equals to be found." Again, on the same subject, the same correspondent writes: "The number of deserters reported at army headquarters, in the last twenty-four hours, is one hundred and eleven. This makes an aggregate of over three hundred in three days, on this side of the Appomattox, and two hundred on the north side. Those received here generally hail from South Carolina and Georgia. Many of them bring their arms with them, and the cavalry, in some instances, horses and equipments."

lead_paragraph: There was a report in the city, yesterday, said to be based upon statements made in private let- ters, that the forces of Gen. SHERMAN had been joined by those of Gen. SCHEFIELD. There were no particulars given, and the main statement is at least doubtful. Gen. SCHOFIELD, who started from the coast for Goldsboro, N.C., or some other point on the Weldon Road, is, of course, expected to cooperate with SHERMAN, and we may look for news of his progress very soon, either through rebel papers, or directly by way of Newbern or Wilmington.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The second performance of "La Forza del Destino" was witnessed last evening by an exceedingly large and fashionable audience. It is still too soon to speak of the...
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The second performance of "La Forza del Destino" was witnessed last evening by an exceedingly large and fashionable audience. It is still too soon to speak of the p[???] acceptance of the work. Being unlike anything that VERDI has yet written, it required a new class of hearers to it full justice. Judging, however, [???] the frequent and discriminatory applause last evening, this class will be forthcoming, and the verdict will, we are sure, be that "La Ferza" is the most carefully written work that the composer has ever offered to the public.

abstract: Semi-Annual Exhibition; Lawrence, D, in Hester-street, by Bounty-brokers; Bounty-brokers' Crimes; Lawrence Murder; Bank of Commerce, of $10,000 in Gold; Isaacs, Bounty-Broker; Frauds by and Arrest
snippet: Semi-Annual Exhibition; Lawrence, D, in Hester-street, by Bounty-brokers; Bounty-brokers' Crimes; Lawrence Murder; Bank of Commerce, of $10,000 in Gold; Isaacs, Bounty-Broker; Frauds by and Arrest
lead_paragraph: A week ago one HENRY ISAACS, of Canal-street, masculine milliner and bounty broker, was summoned before Col. BAEER and required to remit $100 which he had withheld or stolen from a recruit. Isaacs at the time declared with emphasis that he was entirely innocent, and that he had been made the victim of a conspiracy, and on bidding the Colonel adieu he volunteered the offer of $1,000 to any detective who might find another case against him. He then went to his store and wrote a note to the TIMES, advertising his radian purity of character. Since that time Col. BAKER's detectives have ferretted out some information which gives them a clear idea of the man. One day last week Mr. WOLFF, a merchant, appeared at the Astor-house with a letter from Mayor GUNTHER introducing him to Col. BAKER, Mr. WOLFF's son, a lad of seventeen, was spirited away last Autumn, and his parent was unable to learn anything of his whereabouts until recently, when tidings were received from him in the army. He had been cheated, he said, by the person by whom he had been enlisted at Col. FOWLER's office in Brooklyn, Mr. WOLFF desired Col. BAKER to interpose in his behalf in getting the boy's bounty; and the Colonel, in compliance, sent a note to Col. FOWLER and received the following reply:

abstract: Inauguration of
snippet: Inauguration of
lead_paragraph: The new Court-house was thrown open for inspection last evening, to all who were provided with tickets -- the object being to give the ladies an opportunity to see all that was to be seen under the most favorable circumstances. The throng was so great, however, that the building could not be examined with any degree of satisfaction. There were, perhaps, 10,000 persons present up to 11 o'clock. The building was brilliantly illuminated, and with the flags on the pediments front and rear, presented a fine appearance, both without and within. The music was furnished by Conner's Band, and the opening passed off pleasantly. To-night the admittance will be without tickets.

abstract: Defenses; Col Jervois' Official Report
snippet: Defenses; Col Jervois' Official Report
lead_paragraph: -- By the European mail, last evening, we have the text of an important official report on the defences of Canada, addressed to the British Secretary of War by Col. JERVOIS, of the Royal Engineers -- an officer specially designated to examine and report upon the fortifications of the province. Col. JERVOIS recommends that £200,000 sterling be spent upon the defences of Quebec; £443,000 sterling upon forts at Montreal, and £600,000 sterling upon fortifications and armaments at Kingston, Toronto, Hamilton and other places in the Western Province. He likewise urges upon the War Department the necessity of not reducing the number of British troops stationed in the Provinces.

abstract: The House resolution to pay twenty-five thousand dollars for POWELL's picture of Perry's victory deserves killing in the Senate. No such price has ever been paid for any picture by any American artist; and yet as a work of art it is almost utterly without merit. DE SOTO's Discovery of the Mississippi from the same hand is a sufficient eye-sore in the rotunda without adding this as a companion-piece. Our people do not pay their heavy taxes to be squandered by their servants in any such way as this.

abstract: -- A monthly meeting of the Young Men's Christian Association was held Monday evening at their room, No. 161 Fifth-av., near Twenty-second-street. A large number of ladies and gentlemen were present, among whom were many of the old members. The choir was occupied by VINCENT COLYER, Esq., Vice-President. After some devotional exercises, led by Professor C.H. GARDNER, of the Gardner Institute, an interesting essay entitled "Diversity the Ground of Responsibility," was read by Rev. T. RALSON SMITH, in which he pointed out how the characteristics of each individual no matter how diversified his talents or acquirements, might be rendered useful in promoting the objects of the Association; that diversities of endowment were the bases of the grandest and most effective qualities in life -- every man having his place, his work, his obligation. Mr. MOSES POND, of the Boston Young Men's Christian Association, spoke at some length of the workings of the Boston Association, and its great moral and spiritual influences. Reports were read from the Committees on Visitation of the Sick, Employment, Boarding Houses, and Devotional Meetings, showing the work performed by the Association. The meeting closed with prayer and a hymn.

abstract: The New
snippet: The New
lead_paragraph: The fourh section of the new enrollment bill, as it passed the House, provides that, "no person of foreign birth who has resided in the United States for three years preceding his arrival at the age of 21 years, shall be exempt from enrollment and draft on account of being an alien." We do not know whether the measure is likely to become law in this shape or not. But we think very little would be lost in the way of filling up the quotas of the different districts by leaving the clause out; and it cannot have escaped the attention of members of the House, that the clause may possibly produce complications which would quite as well be avoided.

abstract: -- Miss EMMA HARDINGS will deliver a lecture at Cooper Institute on Thursday, the 2d of March, entitled "A Voice to the American People." Previous to the President at campaign, Miss HARDINGE, at the solicitation of the State Central Committee of California, delivered a series of lectures in San Francisco on political subject, speaking for twenty-eight nights on political subjects to the largest audiences ever gathered together in California. The only recompense for her arduous labors was the election of Mr. LINCOLN, and a most flattering letter from the Chairman of the State Central Committee. Miss HARDINGE will doubtless attract as large audiences here as in the Golden State.

abstract: State Soldiers' Depot; Vincent Colyer Appointed Superintendent
snippet: State Soldiers' Depot; Vincent Colyer Appointed Superintendent
lead_paragraph: Mr. VINCENT COLYER, of this city, has received from Gov. FENTON the appointment of Superintendent of the New-York State Soldiers Depot in Howard street. Mr. COLYER has been associated with our armies in different sections of the country ever since the opening of the war; and has held various important positions analogous to his present sphere of labor. He has had a large amount of experience, I thoroughly honest, honorable, intelligent, and efficient, and his appointment reflects credit upon Gov. FENTON. The United States Christian Commission which has done so much for the soldier, owes it origin and existence to Mr. COLYER.

abstract: Refuses Rebel Ram Olinda (alias Stonewall) Repairs at Corunna
snippet: Refuses Rebel Ram Olinda (alias Stonewall) Repairs at Corunna
lead_paragraph: -- Spain, it seems, has come to the relief of both the French and the Danish Governments in the matter of the rebel ram Olinda. On escaping from Copenhagen, the vessel was found to be entirely unseaworthy; and PAGE, her commander, therefore made for the Spanish port of Corunna. The Government of Her Catholic Majesty, it is reported, lost no time, after the vessel came to anchor, in asking information from the French Government as to her real character. At first, it is said, an evasive answer was returned by M. DROUYN DE LHUYS. But on more mature consideration the Spanish authorities were advised to refuse to the Olinda the privilege of making repairs at Corunna. The United States frigate Niagara, meanwhile, had taken up a position at the entrance of the harbor, so as effectually to prevent all chance of the pirate's escape. The Sacramento has likewise been sent to reinforce the Niagara, and thus the career of the Olinda, now christened the Stonewall, may be said to be as good as ended, before it had well begun.
headline: {'main': 'THE REBEL RAM OLINDA.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE REBEL RAM OLINDA.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Abandonment, The Ruin of Confederacy
snippet: Abandonment, The Ruin of Confederacy
lead_paragraph: It would seem that JEFFERSON DAVIS and ROBERT E. LEE and the Confederate Congress have determined at last to try and effect their flight from Richmond. The Richmond papers of Monday discuss the matter with great emotion and force, and we know for a certainty that it was discussed a month ago in secret session of the rebel Congress.

abstract: To-day, at 11 o'clock, a Board of Officers will convene on board the United States receiving ship North Carolina, at the Navy-yard, to investigate the facts relative to the recent loss of the United States steamer Marrimac.
lead_paragraph: To-day, at 11 o'clock, a Board of Officers will convene on board the United States receiving ship North Carolina, at the Navy-yard, to investigate the facts relative to the recent loss of the United States steamer Marrimac. Admiral PAULDING has issued an order that the officers of the ill-fated vessel report at that time and place to Capt. MCKINSTREY. The Merrimac was a side-wheel steamer of six guns and 686 tons burden. She was formerly a blockade-runner, and was captured by the Iroquois, near New Inlet, N.C., July 24, 1863. She was fitted oht soon after her capture at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, and had been in commission about a year and a half.

abstract: Hotel Keepers' Liability; Follet vs Leland
snippet: Hotel Keepers' Liability; Follet vs Leland
lead_paragraph: Dexter H. Follert vs. Simeon Leland et. al. -- This action was brought by the plaintiff against the Messrs. Lelands, proprietors of the Metropolitan Hotel, of this city, for the recovery of the value of a gold watch and chain, and $85 in money, which the plaintiff alleged had been stolen from a room of the hotel in which he was a guest in November, 1863. The testimony in the case went to show that plaintiff, when he retired to his room at night, turned the key in the lock, hung his watch and chain on a chair, and placed his wallet on a table. When he awoke in the morning the door was unlocked, and the watch and money gone. The defendants denied their liability, and gave testimony to show that they had posted a notice in the room, in a conspicuous place, wherein, among other things, they warned all guests to bolt as well as lock the door. The plaintiff admitted that he had not bolted the door, but maintained that neither the notice or bolt were conspicuous. The court held that the question was one of fact for the jury as to whether the notice was sufficient, and whether the bolt was so placed that a stranger in the room would naturally see it when turning the key in the lock. Judge LEONARD at the same time decided that the case did not come within the Act of the Legislature of 1855, when provides that if hotel keepers post bills in conspicuous places in the rooms of their guests, saying that they have provided a safe in the office where all valuables could be deposited, &c., they will not be held liable for loss. The money and watch in this case claimed to have been lost, the Judge said, was property which a guest had a right to carry about his person. The jury, after being out some time, returned into court saying they were unable to agree upon a verdict without seeing the lock of the door in question. By consent of parties, the court directed toe lock to be produced. The jury, after long consultation, rendered a verdict of $435 for the plantiff. The case will be appealed to the General Term.

abstract: Chambers Opened; Emperor's Speech, Outline of
snippet: Chambers Opened; Emperor's Speech, Outline of
lead_paragraph: The Papal Nuncio had had an audience with the Emperor, and expressed regret at the publicity given to private letteas addressed by him to the Bishops of Orleans and Poictiers. He assured the Emperor that he was fully sensible of the duties imposed on him by the diplomatic character of his mission, and had never any intention of falling in respect to the rules of international law. The Emperor graciously received his explanations.

abstract: Great depression prevailed in commercial and financial circles on the 15th, under the influence of the news of the peace negotiations brought by the Canada. The Liverpool cotton market was almost paralysed ...
lead_paragraph: Great depression prevailed in commercial and financial circles on the 15th, under the influence of the news of the peace negotiations brought by the Canada. The Liverpool cotton market was almost paralysed; prices were nominal at about 2d. decline. The London stock exchange was materially affected. Consols declined about 1/2 per cent., owing to fears that a sudden peace in America would cause a serious derangement in financial affairs by a fall in cotton, and also on account of political consequences. The prospects of peace were eagerly debated, and the likelihood of peace obtained greater credence than at any previous time. On the 16th, however, the announcement that the peace conference was a failure, received by the Hibernian, was published in the morning papers, and of course caused a reaction. The fall in cotton was almost, if not entirely, recovered, and consols also improved 1/2@1/2 per cent.

abstract: The rooms of the Volunteer Recruiting Committee were crowded all day yesterday by anxious inquiries after the bounty so liberally disbursed to all able-bodied recruits. The business of the day footed
lead_paragraph: The rooms of the Volunteer Recruiting Committee were crowded all day yesterday by anxious inquiries after the bounty so liberally disbursed to all able-bodied recruits. The business of the day footed up to some 80 accepted men, and reduced the quota by that number. On Tuesday, the committee were unusually successful, and paid bounty to 146 recruits. The committee have long been annoyed by the facility with which men could be enlisted in this city, mustered into the regular army and credited to other localities. The following letter shows that this last loop-hole for escape from the provisions of the ordinance of the Common Council is closed, and all the men now enlisted in the City of New-York will be credited where they enlist:

abstract: The Moravian brings news from Londonderry to the 17th ult. The Blair mission had made a commotion in trade, and even that slight prospect of peace caused a great decline in cotton and securities. Later news that the mission had failed brought prices up again. There was nothing important doing in Parliament. CARDINAL WISEMAN died on the 15th. The rebel ram or pirate Stonewall (the Olinda) was at Ferrol at last accounts, leaky, and in poor condition. The Emperor NAPOLEON, in his speech at the opening of the Chambers, did not even mention this country, but was quite enthusiastic over Mexico, representing things there in the most splendidly satisfactory condition. The Prussian Chamber of Deputies, in spite of Ministerial influence the other way, had agreed upon a resolution in favor of repealing all laws to punish coalition among working men. The new treaty between Spain and Peru has been signed. Peru is to pay 400,000,000 reals. From Brazil we learn that the city of Paysander was captured on the 2d of January by the Brazilian troops.
lead_paragraph: The Moravian brings news from Londonderry to the 17th ult. abstract: Advices from Western Mexico, by way of San Francisco, state that the City of Mazatlan is completely blocked up, and no one is allowed to go in. The Mexican guerillas are very daring, and give the French so much trouble that summary execution is the fate of all who are caught. Not long since the French burned a number of villages because their inhabitants failed to give warning of the approach of guerrillas. There is no prospect of a French expedition to Sonora, and nothing further is said about the fantastic project in which Ex-Senator GWIN's name has been used.

abstract: The signs on all hands augur well for a splendid celebration of the late Union victories, on Saturday next. The key struck by the Supervisors at their meeting yesterday, is precisely that which we should expect from loyal men of whatever party creed. The President of the board, in disavowing the belief that the 4th of March had been named for partisan purposes, administered a deserved and timely rebuke to those organs of his own party that have sought to give a sectional character to the celebration. And the resolution ultimately adopted by the board, recommending the closing of all the county offices at 12 o'clock on Saturday is a fitting corollary to the arrangements under which Gen. SANDFORD has ordered the militia to participate in the rejoicing of the day. The cordial response from all classes of the non-official population add a still further assurance that the malevolent intent of a petty opposition faction will not be permitted, in any degree, to mar the celebration or to disturb the harmony of those that take part in it.

SANDFORD has ordered the militia to participate in the rejoicing of the day. The cordial response from all classes of the non-official population add a still further assurance that the malevolent intent of a petty opposition faction will not be permitted, in any degree, to mar the celebration or to disturb the harmony of those that take part in it.

abstract: Press on Evacuation, Ruin to Confederacy
snippet: Press on Evacuation, Ruin to Confederacy
lead_paragraph: Our most important war news of this morning comes from the enemy, from the Richmond papers of Monday, which contain very important admissions. The Sentinel admits that the removal of guns and stores from Richmond is going on, and endeavors to quiet the apprehensions of the people. The Examiner says that the members of the rebel Congress have fled one by one until there is only a quorum left for business. Gen. LEE begs that Congress will not now adjourn and leave his hands fettered and unprepared for further resistance. The Examiner says the evacuation of Richmond is the death blow to the Confederacy, and that out of Richmond the rebel army becomes a mere bodyguard to enable a few men to cross the Mississippi River. The whole tone of the rebel press is one of the direct gloom, while SHERMAN's name is mentioned only with spasms of terror.

abstract: Fuller, J M, W B; Cane Presented by Commonwealth Lodge, Brooklyn
snippet: Fuller, J M, W B; Cane Presented by Commonwealth Lodge, Brooklyn
lead_paragraph: Last Tuesday evening, during the regular communication of Commonwealth Lodge No. 409, the usual proceedings were varied by a pleasant event, which was a "surprise" to at least one person, who was, nevertheless, specially interested in it. This was the presentation of a beautiful cane to W.B. JAMES M. FULLER, who, with the close of the past year, finished his fourth term as Master of the Lodge. The presentation was made in a neat and pertinent address by Senior Warden RILEY. who sketched briefly the valuable services rendered by Brother FULLER to the lodge, and closed with the wish, heartily responded to by all present, that he might long live to enjoy the friendship and esteem of the brothers, which was but feebly typified in the present which he had the honor to make in their behalf. Brother FULLER, though evidently totally unprepared for such an occurrence, responded in a happy manner, warmly thanking the brethren for the evidence of their regard; and closed with some fatherly and wholesome advice regarding certain points in the working of the lodge -- thus proving that its welfare was ever uppermost in his thoughts.

abstract: Griffin J M; Custody of his Daughter
snippet: Griffin J M; Custody of his Daughter
lead_paragraph: James M. Griffin sued out a writ of habeas corpus for the custody of his daughter, Mary Kate Griffin, nine years of age. Mrs. Harriet Griffin, the aunt of the child, set up a return, to the effect that the child had been placed in her custody by the mother, before she died; that the father had abandoned it, and never had contributed toward its support, and that he was an improper person to have its custody. The father traversed the return, denying all the allegations, and stated through his counsel that the child was being brought up under improper influences. In view of this conflict of statement, the court referred the whole matter to Ex-Judge Hoffman, to take testimony and report the facts and his opinion to the court on Saturday, the child to remain as the ward of the court in the meantime, in the custody of her aunt.

abstract: The Committee of Arrangements for celebrating our recent victories, on Saturday next, sit in permanent session at the Astor House. The invitations issued may be counted by hundreds, and favorable responses have in most cases been received.
lead_paragraph: The Committee of Arrangements for celebrating our recent victories, on Saturday next, sit in permanent session at the Astor House. The invitations issued may be counted by hundreds, and favorable responses have in most cases been received. Yesterday an invitation was extended to Gen. DURYEA, of Brooklyn, to parade with his division. The invitation will probably be accepted, several of the regiments having already signified their intention of participating. The United States troops in the harbor, under Gen. DIX, together with the invalid soldiers in the various hospitals, are also expected to join in the celebration. A full-rigged ship bas been offered by Capt. SIMONSON, and will be in the line. Admiral PAULDING has been invited to aid the committee, and it is expected he will detail a body of marines. The German societies will parade, and sing along the line of march, adding much to the novelty and interest of the scene. The procession will be headed by a large body of police, some of whom will be mounted.

abstract: of War; Mortality
snippet: of War; Mortality
lead_paragraph: The statistics of military-prison life on Johnson's Island, where 7,771 rebel prisoners have been received during the last two years, show a mortality of only 210, or little more than 2 1/2 per cent. The per centage of deaths among our prisoners confined at Salisbury, N.C., was more than nine times greater. That is, it reached to about one-fourth of the entire number.

abstract: Wiseman, Cardinal
snippet: Wiseman, Cardinal
lead_paragraph: The news by the Moravian includes an announcement, not unexpected, of the death of Cardinal WISEMAN. He died at his residence in London, on the 15th ult., in the 63d year of his age. He was born at Seville, in Spain, on the 2d of August, 1802. By his father's side he was of English origin. His mother was of Irish descent, and the Cardinal himself received his earliest education at Waterford in Ireland. He subsequently studied for eight years at a Catholic college in Durham, England, graduating as D.D. in 1824. Three years later he was appointed Professor of Oriental Languages in the Roman University, but he returned to England in 1835, where he became first celebrated as a preacher and lecturer, and also as a polemical writer of great industry and research. To the world generally, Cardinal WISEMAN is chiefly known in connection with what was called the "Papal Aggression" of 1850, when a number of ecclesiastical dignities were revived in England by the authority of the Pope, and when Or. WISEMAN became Archbishop of Westminster, with the title of Cardinal, which was conferred on him a few months later.

abstract: Doctrine that Repub form of Gov guarantees Universal (and colored) Suffrage; Sumner's Theory; Senator Sumner's Theory of
snippet: Doctrine that Repub form of Gov guarantees Universal (and colored) Suffrage; Sumner's Theory; Senator Sumner's Theory of
lead_paragraph: -Mr. SUMNER avows the doctrine in the Senate, that under the Constitution, it is the duty of Congress to secure the right of suffrage for all loyal men, in every State, irrespective of color. This is a new advance of the uneasy ultraism of the day. WENDELL PHILLIPS has urged an amendment of the Constitution, guaranteeing perfect equality of the races before the law. Mr. SUMNER, in his progressive illumination, has discovered that no such amendment is necessary to secure the object; that the "republican form of government" guaranteed to every State by the Federal Constitution, involves a guarantee of universal suffrage.

abstract: The Senate yesterday passed the Six Hundred Loan Bill without amendment. The difficulty about the extra pay for employes of the House was evaded by the adoption of an appropriation of $43,000 for the purpose of paying such contingent expenses as the House may direct. The vote was 21 yeas to 19 nayes. An important bill concerning the various Pacific Railroad Companies was passed. (For its provisions see our regular report in another column.) The Indian Appropriation Bill was passed, with a provision authorizing Indians who adopted civilized life and obtained a tolerable education to become citizens and enjoy the benefits of the Homestead Law. The Enrollment Bill was reported, with several amendments. The Tax Bill was taken up at the evening session.

abstract: Three Incendiary; at Avenue A, $100; at Avenue C, $800; and 512 Broadway
snippet: Three Incendiary; at Avenue A, $100; at Avenue C, $800; and 512 Broadway
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday evening a fire occurred in the building occupied by A. LUKACH, No. 143 Avenve A, doing damage to the amount of $100. Mr. LUKACH was insured by the Central Park Insurance Company for $500. On investigation by Fire-Marshal BAKER it was ascertained that the building had been set on fire in two different places, rags saturated with oil having been used for the purpose. LUKACH has been arrested on suspicion. WILLIAM LOGAN was arrested yesterday on suspicion of having set Mr. G.A. RAYMOND's woodyard on fire in Avenue C, near Sixteenth-street. Mr. RAYMOND's office and a stable adjoining were destroyed, with loss estimated at $800. Insurance $250, in the Arctic office.

abstract: It is not unsafe, though in the absence of all specific information, to conjecture that SHERMAN may now be directing his march straight upon Raleigh by way of Cheraw and Fayetteville. We learn from the Southern papers, that ...
lead_paragraph: It is not unsafe, though in the absence of all specific information, to conjecture that SHERMAN may now be directing his march straight upon Raleigh by way of Cheraw and Fayetteville. We learn from the Southern papers, that he is not moving on Charlotte, and that the alarm at that place has therefore subsided. There appears no reason to doubt the truth of this statement, and the obvious inference from it is, that he has turned in a northeasterly direction, deflecting his course somewhat toward Wilmington with the double object of cutting off HARDEE's progress toward JOHNSTON, and effecting a junction with SCHOFIELD. Moreover, this would be the shortest route to Raleigh, the State capital of North Carolina, where he would once more be planted on LEE's only line of communication with the South, and where he could establish an excellent secondary base, having direct railroad communication with Wilmington. If he began to move in this direction last week, there can scarcely be any doubt that he has by this time picked up SCHOFIELD, and that the combined force is now moving due north, with a weight that nothing within reach of the Confederacy can stop, or even delay.
headline: {'main': 'Sherman and Lee.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Sherman and Lee.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Preparations for
snippet: Preparations for
lead_paragraph: The success of the Celebration, to-morrow, is no longer problematical. Under favor of even moderately fair weather, the proposed holiday gives ample promise of being one which shall be specially memorable, by the cordiality with which all classes of our citizens are ready to join in its observance. To the hearty and prompt cooperation offered by the State militia authorities, by the regular military forces of the department, by the Board of Supervisors, by the Board of Brokers, by scores of our greatest mercantile and manufacturing firms, by numerous trade societies, by public clubs, Turnerbunds and Sangerbunds, the Celebration Committee were yesterday afternoon enabled to felicitate themselves in being able to add the formal concurrence and the practical aid of the Board of Aldermen.

abstract: A emeting of this society was held last evening at its rooms in Clinton Hall. A very interesting paper was read by Mr. J.W. FABENS, on the uses of the camel, considered with a view to the introduction of the animal into our Western Territories, Mr. FABENS said that the great want we now experienced in reaching our silver mines in Colorado, Montana, Idaho and Arizona was the want of a cheap and reliable means of transportation. He took the ground that the camel, from its powers of endurance, docility, strength and swiftness, was particularly well fitted for making the passage across the immense plains leading to the territory in which the mines are found. Mr. FABENS gave an interesting account of the habits and natural history of the animal, showing that it could travel from three to six miles per hour, live on the coarsest food, carry from 1,000 to 1 200 pounds in weight and endure the extremes of temperature. He predicted that if camels were once introduced here, camel-riding would soon become fashionable.

abstract: Mr. EZRA CORNELL, a citizen of Ithaca, some years since commenced, at his own expense, the enterprise of establishing a public library for the benefit of that city. He intended to give $50,000 for the purpose, but as he put up the building ...
lead_paragraph: Mr. EZRA CORNELL, a citizen of Ithaca, some years since commenced, at his own expense, the enterprise of establishing a public library for the benefit of that city. He intended to give $50,000 for the purpose, but as he put up the building himself he has spent $100,000 at it, and has thus erected a splendid edifice, containing a library, reading-room, lecture-room, farmers' club room, etc. He has now offered to the State Government a donation of half a million of dollars to endow a university at Ithaca, on condition that the State Government shall give to the institution the land fund granted by the act of Congress for the endowment of agricultural colleges.

abstract: Mr. SARGENT, the Commissioner of Customs,  has written to the Collector of this port, calling attention to the practice of smuggling in without paying duty, of large quantities of ready-made clothing. The most noteworthy portion of the ...
lead_paragraph: Mr. SARGENT, the Commissioner of Customs, has written to the Collector of this port, calling attention to the practice of smuggling in without paying duty, of large quantities of ready-made clothing. The most noteworthy portion of the letter is that in which he says: "Many seem to think it perfectly light to cheat or defraud their country, when in her utmost need; and I confess that I have not acumen enough to perceive the distinction between swindling the Government and swindling an individual; nor can I understand how one can take a false oath at the Custom-house without committing perjury." The simplicity of the commissioner strikes some people as little less than marvelous. But travelers may look for a more rigid examination of trunks and carpet-bags.

abstract: The Citizens' Committee of Arrangements was in session all day yesterday at the Astor House, and in the evening at the Fifth-avenue Hotel. The members of the committee have been indefatigable in their labors, which promise to result in one of the largest celebrations ever seen in this city.
lead_paragraph: The Citizens' Committee of Arrangements was in session all day yesterday at the Astor House, and in the evening at the Fifth-avenue Hotel. The members of the committee have been indefatigable in their labors, which promise to result in one of the largest celebrations ever seen in this city. The military display will be very imposing, while citizens have responded with commendable alacrity to the invitation of the committee to take part in the parade. There will be many veterans and wounded soldiers in the procession in carriages. The exhibition of mechanical skill will be interesting, including manufacture of segars, which will be distributed along the route; a self-operating sewing-machine and piano-makers at work. BARNUM will be represented by an elephant, walrus and a giraffe.

abstract: Loyal, to Members of U. S. Bar; Members of and Oath to be Taken
snippet: Loyal, to Members of U. S. Bar; Members of and Oath to be Taken
lead_paragraph: -In January last Congress passed an act requiring all attorneys and counsellors in the courts of the United States to take the oath of office prescribed by the act of July 2, 1862. The attention of the Bar was called to the act yesterday in Judge BETTS' court, and none too soon, for after the 4th of March no one can practice in the United States Courts who has not taken the oath. The oath is a pretty stringent one, requiring the individual who takes it not only to swear allegiance to the Constitution, but also among other things, that he has not "voluntarily given aid, countenance, counsel or encouragement to persons engaged in armed hostility" against the United States.

abstract: Dr. ZACHARIE having trodden somewhat severely on sundry official corns at Washington and elsewhere, has concluded to withdraw from politics and return to his professional practice in this city. The doctor acted quite a conspicuous part at New-Orleans in the early stages of the occupation of that city by the national troops, and has once or twice we believe visited Richmond in the interest of the Government. If Secretary STANTON should need his services we presume they would be cheerfully rendered at the lowest rates.

abstract: Service on N. Y.; Our good Understanding with; Church Service in New-York; Church, Service in New-York
snippet: Service on N. Y.; Our good Understanding with; Church Service in New-York; Church, Service in New-York
lead_paragraph: The Liturgy of the Orthodox Oriental Church was celebrated yesterday in Trinity Chapel by Rev. AGAPIUS HONCHARENKO. The service is perhaps more popularly known as that of the Russo-Greek Church. In itself this event may be regarded as historic, it being the first public celebration of the Russian (or Greek) Church, not only in this city, but on the American Continent. But throughout Christendom, and especially in Europe, it cannot fail to be regarded as an event of great religious and political significance. It is well known that the leading minds of the Episcopal Church both here and in England have for some years been earnestly engaged in an effort to establish intercommunion with the Russo Greek Church, and there are two committees of churchmen here and in England working conjointly with vigorous activity and very great zeal for this object. The ecclesiastical importance of establishing cordial fraternal relations, if not unrestricted intercommunion, between the Russo-Greek Church and the Protestant Episcopal Church of the United States, which most resemble each other in structure and historical antecedents, was distinctly recognized by the latter body in its last general Convention, held in the City of New-York in October, 1862. A motion made by Rev. Dr. THRALL, clerical delegate from California, was earnestly seconded by Mr. SAM'L B. RUGGLES, lay delegate from New-York, for a committee to inquire into the expediency of opening intercourse between the two churches. A committee of eight members, embracing three of the American Bishops, three other clerical members and two lay delegates, was accordingly appointed. Two of its members -- Rev. Dr. YOUNG and Mr. S.B. RUGGLES -- since their appointment have visited Russia, for the purpose of fully possessing themselves of the information, ecclesiastic and secular, necessary for their report to the coming convention in October next, embracing not merely matters of doctrine and ritual, but the more practical and secular questions, such as burial of the dead, visitation of the sick, &c., necessarily growing out of the rapidly increasing intercourse between the two great nations, in their respective territories on the Pacific. The Bishop of Oxford, in presenting a petition to the Upper House of Convocation from the Lower, in England, in July, 1863, on this subject, said: "If there is one matter upon earth which it would be a blessed thing to help forward, it would surely be the interchange of the visible acts of communion between our own branch of the church at home and in America with the orthodox branches of the Eastern Church. * * Those who have studied the controversy with Rome, know that there is nothing more important in maintaining our position against the usurpations of Rome than the independent position of the Eastern Church; and if we can strengthen the bonds of intercourse between that church and ourselves, it would be one of the greatest blessings that can be conceived." And now it might be said that if the great point in view is not attained by this service in one of the great Episcopal edifices of this city, it is easy to see how far the members of the Oriental Church are influenced by the efforts made in this direction on both sides of the Atlantic.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, committees were discharged from the consideration of petitions for more pay to naval officers, and from the petition to recognize the Almighty in the Constitution. A petition from the National Cemetery Association for $50,000 to go on with the Gettysburgh Monument was adversely reported upon on the ground that "a regard for economy and public welfare rendered present action inexpedient. On the Army Appropriation Bill, the Senate objected to the clause that no money should be paid to the Illinois Central Railroad for transporting troops and stores, and another conference committee was appointed. The credentials of Mr. GUTHRIR, the New Senator from Kentucky were presented i the credentials of Mr. HAHN as Senator from Louisana were also presented, but laid on the table. The tax bill was then taken up in committee. The motion to raise postage to five cents was defeated. Some changes were made in the rates on tobacco, and the petroleum tax was fixed at $1 per barrel. Many other amendments were made, and the bill was reported to the Senate, perfected and adopted. The bill increasing the pay of midshipmen was passed. The bill for the better organization of the Pay Department was passed. A number of bills concerning Indian affairs was also passed. The Senate agreed to continue the Committee on the Conduct of the War.

lead_paragraph: Catarrh is a disease of the mucous membrane of the nasal passages and those cavities of the head communicating with them. Insignifiacnt as it appears in its first stages, it is apt in its progress to become instrumental in causing the loss or impairment of smell, taste, hearing and sight, and of creating serious constitutional derangements, not unfrequently terminating in consumption.

abstract: is pub-  lished THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing.
lead_paragraph: is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many or which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Richmond papers of the 28th, received at this office, contain no positive intelligence of importance from either of the great fields of military operations. Vague rumors are given of an intended movement by Gen. GRANT against the rebel right. Gen. GRANT is said by the rebel pa- ...
lead_paragraph: Richmond papers of the 28th, received at this office, contain no positive intelligence of importance from either of the great fields of military operations. Vague rumors are given of an intended movement by Gen. GRANT against the rebel right. Gen. GRANT is said by the rebel papers to be massing troops on his left, and it was thought at Richmond that nothing but the recent heavy rainstorm had prevented an engagement from taking place. Gen. JOHNSTON has assumed command in North Carolina. Gov. BROWN, of Georgia, has issued a message, in which he fiercely denounces JEFF. DAVIS, and accuses him of bringing the Confederacy to the verge of ruin.

abstract: -- The two Baptist newspapers in this city, the Examiner and the Chronicle, have been consolidated into one journal, which makes its appearance this week printed upon an enlarged sheet. The combined paper is published by an asssociation, and is owned by the former proprietors of the separate journals. Rev. Dr. CHURCH, the editor of the Chronicle, and a gentleman who is widely known outside of his denomination as a writer of ability, retires from active editorial duty, but he is one of the chief proprietors of the Examiner & Chronicle. He thus gives to the paper the support of his name and influence.

abstract: The, Performed in New-York
snippet: The, Performed in New-York
lead_paragraph: For the first time in all history, the service of the Russo-Greek Church was performed on this Continent, in a public house of worship, yesterday. Through the comity of the Episcopal bishop of this diocese. Trinity Chapel was opened to the small band of the members of that communion, resident in this city; and the Greek liturgy was chanted by an ordained priest of the church now on a visit to this country, assisted by several of the chapel vocalists. A large number of Americans were present, both clerical and lay, and were all impressed with the simple grandeur of the music and solemnity of the service.

abstract: -The funeral of Mr. JOEL C. OAKS, of the Forty-fourth Police Precinct, and for some years detailed officer at the Third District Justices Court, took place on Tuesday afternoon, from his late residence, in Skillman-street. His death occurred on Monday. He had been connected with the Police Department since its organization. Detachments from the different Police Precincts, Fortitude Lodge of Free Masons, and a long line of carriages, containing friends and relatives accompanied the remains to their last resting place. Conner's Band preceded the procession, playing the Dead March. The body was conveyed to Cypress Hill Cemetery.

abstract: Bills were reported in the Senate to amend the Sunday Liquor Law; to incorporate the New-York University Club; to incorporate the Seventy-first Regiment; to give $125,000 toward improving the navigation of the Hudson River. Bills were passed relative to the Dry Dock, East Broadway and Battery Railroad Company; to facilitate the construction of the West Shore Railroad; authorizing plank and turnpike road companies to collect additional tolls; for the more speedy payment of laborers employed by heads of the departments of New-York. At the evening session the Metropolitan Paid Fire Department Bill was ordered to a third reading, without amendment. A motion to substitute the New-York Common Council plan was lost -- yeas 7, nays 19.

abstract: We learn that the House of Representatives has recently passed in secret session, by a vote of forty to thirty seven, a bill which not only authorizes the arming of negroes tendered for military service by their owners, but also authorizes the President to call on each State, whenever he thinks it expedient, for her quota of three hundred thousand troops, in addition to those subject to military service under existing laws, or so many thereof as the President may deem necessary for purposes mentioned, to be raised from such classes; irrespective of the color of the population, in each State as the proper authorities thereof may determine. It is further provided that nothing in the act shall be construed to authorize a change in the relation which slaves shall bear toward their owners as property, except by the consent of the ownern and of the States in which they may reside, and is pursuance of the laws thereof. The bill has not yet obtained the concurrence of the Senate; but it is said to have been framed with a view of obviating objections in that body to a proposition in another form of arming the slaves, and of obtaining a compromise of views on the subject.
lead_paragraph: We learn that the House of Representatives has recently passed in secret session, by a vote of forty to thirty seven, a bill which not only authorizes the arming of negroes tendered for military service by their owners, but also authorizes the President to call on each State, whenever he thinks it expedient, for her quota of three hundred thousand troops, in addition to those subject to military service under existing laws, or so many thereof as the President may deem necessary for purposes mentioned, to be raised from such classes; irrespective of the color of the population, in each State as the proper authorities thereof may determine. abstract: March of, Schofield, Cooporation
snippet: March of, Schofield, Cooporation
lead_paragraph: The anxiety of the rebels about SHERMAN is getting the better of the orders which their press have to keep mum about him; and through the Richmond papers of day before yesterday, we are enabled to get a partial, uncertain glimpse of his movements and those of the cooperative army of SCHOFIELD. They venture, at least, to tell us where he is not; they even go so far as to indicate, by indirection, certain points at which he has touched; and their remarks and speculations help us to infer, at least, what they now fancy his line of advance to be. There is an absence of dates; but we judge that their news concerning SHERMAN comes up to the opening of this week.

abstract: Macdougal-street; Schrick's Drug-store--$5,000
snippet: Macdougal-street; Schrick's Drug-store--$5,000
lead_paragraph: FIRE IN MACDOUGAL-STREET. -- At about noon, yesterday, Mr. THOMAS LOWNDES, a clerk employed in Messrs. SCHRICK & SHEOGGUE's drug-store, at No. 59 Macdougal-street, corner of Houston, accidentally dropped a bottle of benzine near a lighted lamp, and an explosion followed, injuring Mr. LOWNDES' hand and setting fire to the store. The flames communicated to Mr. JOHN JONES' drug-store, on the second floor, but were there checked. Messrs. SCHRICK & SHEOGGUE's stock, which was valued at $4,000, was destroyed; insurance $4,000 in the North American office. Mr. JONES, whose stock was damaged to the amount of $300, is insured for $2,000 by the North American Company. Mr. C.L. BARNES, photographer, on the third floor, sustained slight loss from a damage by water. The building, which is owned by Mr. JONES, was injured to the extent of about $500, and is insured for $5,000 in the Greenwich office.

abstract: This was a habeas corpus proceeding, commenced by the husband against his wife, for the purpose of obtaining the custody of a child, Warren L. Boughton, aged about eight years.
lead_paragraph: -- This was a habeas corpus proceeding, commenced by the husband against his wife, for the purpose of obtaining the custody of a child, Warren L. Boughton, aged about eight years. The parties were married in the year 1857, and lived together as husband and wife at the house of the husband's father in this city, until May, 1858, when Mr. Boughton left for Europe. In his petition upon which the writ was granted, he stated that before leaving he had provided a good home for his wife and child, and he had every reason to believe that she would remain contentedly there during his absence. Immediately after he left, however, she packed up her household goods, took the child, and went to live with her parents, where she has ever since remained; that she has since that time refused to live with him, or to let him have the care and custody of the child. That the latter is growing up without being sent to school; that he is allowed to associate in the streets with bad boys, and that he has been, and is, by reason thereof, greatly injured in his habits and morals. The petition and affidavits of the relator further alleged that the wife abandoned the home which he had provided for her without any cause or provocation whatever; also, that in consequence of her ill-temper, the mother is not fitted to have the care and education of the child.
headline: {'main': 'Habeas Corpus for the Custody of a Child.; SUPREME COURT CHAMBERS MARCH 3. Before Judge Barnard. James W. Boughton vs. Adelia M. abstract: THE WALLABOUT BAY LANDS. A committee of the Brooklyn Common Council are now at Washington with the view of consulting with the authorities in relation to a transfer of land in the Wallabout, between the Navy-yard and Naval Hospital, to the General Government, asking in return the privilege of...
lead_paragraph: THE WALLABOUT BAY LANDS. -- A committee of the Brooklyn Common Council are now at Washington with the view of consulting with the authorities in relation to a transfer of land in the Wallabout, between the Navy-yard and Naval Hospital, to the General Government, asking in return the privilege of extending Washington-avenue across the marshes and Wallabout Bay to some point in the Eastern District, and also to construct a basin for commercial purposes near the hospital grounds. The city proposes to cede Clinton and Vanderbilt avenues, and the roadway between the hospital and marine cemetery, to the Government for the right of making a short cut between the Eastern and Western Districts.

abstract: -- The bill establishing a Paid Fire Department in this city has passed the State Senate, and will undoubtedly pass the Assembly also. We are confident this measure will commend itself to the judgment and good sense of the great mass of our people. Even the members of the existing organization who look at the subject fairly, and lay aside the personal interest which their associations have naturally engendered, can scarcely fail to concur in its propriety. Indeed many of them do not hesitate already to express their preference for the paid system. The volunteer system, which might answer well enough in small towns, is utterly unsuited to the wants of a great city, and has been long since discarded in every such city except this in the country. Its apparent cheapness is deceptive, for the grants constantly made for new engines, for engine houses, for furniture, &c., &c., amount in the aggregate to a very large sum. The system is known, moreover, by its practical workings, to be loose, disorderly and utterly demoralizing. In spite of all efforts to prevent such results, it has been by far the most fruitful nursery of rowdyism and crime in this city. We trust it will speedily be superseded by a system better adapted to our necessities and wants.

abstract: The Columbus Enquirer has information which leads it to believe that the Yankees are moving a considerable force into the interior of Alabama, by way of West Florida, to cooperate in THOMAS' threatened advance from the North. The Montgomery papers have reports of large numbers of Yankee troops concentrating at or near Pensacola, and of transports heavily laden with Yankee troops passing down the Mississippi River for the last two or three weeks. It is not at all impobable that these troops were going to the Florida coast to undertake the movement said to be making from Pensacola.

abstract: A most noteworthy police trial this week was that of Officer HENRY SCHUCK, of the Twenty-second Precinct. On the morning of the 27th ult., Mr. McKINLEY, of No. 261 West Forty-sixth-street, found a policeman's cap, coat, shield and belt on the side-...
lead_paragraph: A most noteworthy police trial this week was that of Officer HENRY SCHUCK, of the Twenty-second Precinct. On the morning of the 27th ult., Mr. McKINLEY, of No. 261 West Forty-sixth-street, found a policeman's cap, coat, shield and belt on the sidewalk in front of his abode, and seeing no officer near, he sent a servant to the police station to inquire whether any member of the force had lost these articles. The reply was, that they belonged to Officer SCHUCK, and that he had not answered at the last roll-call. Commissioner ACTON asked the officer to explain, and he said that from 4 o'clock to 6 on the morning in question, he was unconscious, and that at the latter hour he found himself sick in bed at his abode, minus his cap, coat, shield and belt. A citizen appeared before the Commissioners, and deposed that on the morning of the 27th, he saw the officer in a stupor, but there were no signs of intoxication. Officer SCHUCK's record being good, the complaint was dismissed....Mr. NATHANIEL J. PERKINS, clerk in the employ of Messrs. SMITH & SANDERS, of No. 165 Chatham-street, appeared against Policeman RICHARD FLEMING, of the Fourth Precinct, and stated that on the 22d ult., Mrs. EMMA KOCH, of No. 1 Greenwich-street, lost her wallet, and called the officer into the store to arrest him. He declined to go with the officer to the station-house, and thereupon the latter took him without his hat. Hence the complaint. President ACTON told Mr. PERKINS that he should have gone with the policeman when requested to do so. Complaint dismissed.....JOSEPH MCGORRY, waiter in the St. Denis Hotel, complained that Officer MCARTHER, of the Broadway Police, had unnecessarily arrested him and taken him to the Tombs. MCGORRY had purchased, in the gift jewelry establishment, No. 178 Broadway, a watch-guard, and with it a ticket (No, 106,) was given him. Ticket No. 100 having drawn a gold watch, MCGORRY placed his thumb over the top of the figure six on the ticket, making it appear to be 100, and the watch was given him. The cheat having been discovered, he was called upon to restore the watch; but this he declined to do. Whereupon Officer MCARTHUR was called in, and MCGORRY was arrested. The commissioners dismissed the complaint....Complaint was entered against Officer EDWARD DEALING, of the Twenty-first Precinct, for disobedience of orders, and the use of profane language to a superior officer. DEALING said merely, in defence, that the complainant was in error as to time. Profanity not being permitted among the police force, the officer was convicted on his own showing, and may be required to pay a fine.....After other trials the commissioners adjourned to Wednesday morning next.

abstract: having passed several sleepless nights, disturbed by the agonies and cries of a suffering child, and becoming convinced that Mrs. WINSLOW'S SOOTHING SYRUP was just the article needed, procured a supply for the child. On reaching home, and acquainting his wife with what he had done, she refused to have it administered to the child, as she was strongly in favor of Homeopathy. That night the child passed in suffering, and the parents without sleep. Returning home the day following the father found the baby still worse; and while contemplating another sleepless night, the mother stepped from the room to attend to some domestic duties, and left the father with the child. During her absence he administered a portion of the Soothing Syrup to the baby, and said nothing. That night all hands slept well, and the little fellow awoke in the morning bright and happy. The mother was delighted with the sudden and wonderful change, and although at first offended at the deception practised upon her, has continued to use the Syrup, and suffering, crying babies and restless nights have disappeared. A single trial of the Syrup never yet failed to relieve the baby, and overcome the prejudices of the mother, 35 cents a bottle. Sold by all Druggists.

abstract: new and curious question concerning the jurisdiction of the Commissioner was raised in this case. The accused was brought up for examination yesterday morning for stealing a quantity of lead pipe from the Brooklyn Navy-yard.
lead_paragraph: new and curious question concerning the jurisdiction of the Commissioner was raised in this case. The accused was brought up for examination yesterday morning for stealing a quantity of lead pipe from the Brooklyn Navy-yard. The defence set up did not go to the merits of the case, but raised a question as to the jurisdiction of the Commissioner over an offence committed in Kings county. The prisoner's counsel maintained that by a recent act of Congress the Southern District of New-York had been divided, and a new district created embracing the courts of Kings and other counties, and including within its jurisdiction the Brooklyn Navy-yard, and that the courts and Commissioners of the new district alone had cognizance of offences committed within their jurisdiction.

abstract: Life Insurance as Collateral Security Rymax vs Hicks
snippet: Life Insurance as Collateral Security Rymax vs Hicks
lead_paragraph: The action was brought by plaintiff as administrator of the estate of John Rymax, to recover of the defendant the amount of a life insurance policy, the sum being $1,000. The terms of the policy were that in case of the death of the insured the proceeds were to be paid to his executors, administrators or assigns, but "for the benefit of Wm.T. Hicks as collateral security for the amount of his then subsisting pecuniary demands against the said Rymax, surplus if any, to go for the benefit of said Rymax's heirs and representatives."Upon the death of the insured, the defendant collected the sum due on the policy, and claimed that according to the stipulations, he was entitled to hold it for m[???]es advanced, and debts due to him from the estate of Rymax. The plaintiff proved the policy, the receipt of the money by the defendant, and that a demand therefor had been made, and there rested. The court held that the plaintiff must prove the further fact that the defendant had not pecuniary legal demands to the extent of the same received on the policy. The plaintiff thereupon proved by the defendant' that the amount of his demands consisted of an advance of money made before the date of the policy, a sale of some property which was not consummated by delivery on that date, and some small items subsequent to the date of the policy, together with an item of $200, for expenses incurred in proving the death, and obtaining the money from the insurance company. The court decided that the sale not having been completed, all subsequent items were not "then pecuniary demands," but allowed the defendant his expenses for collection, and the money actually advanced, and directed a verdict for the balance, $661 86 for plaintiff.

abstract: Proc. Inauguration Celebration; Celebration in New-York on Victories and Inauguration
snippet: Proc. Inauguration Celebration; Celebration in New-York on Victories and Inauguration
lead_paragraph: Up to the hour at which we write, everything -- even including the weather -- seems to conspire in favor of the great Celebration. The ample and varied programme shows how heartily and fully all classes and parties will be represented in the demonstration of the day. Its main feature promises to be the voluntary participation of the great body of our citizens in the rejoicings. Whatever is merely perfunctory in the Celebration will be overshadowed by the spontaneous congregation of the loyal masses. They are to turn out, because they think the time has come when our brave soldiers in the field, and our gallant sailors on the main, should be greeted with the lusty cheers of the loyal multitudes at home; and because, with the final overthrow of the rebellion already in sight, they desire to give a formal expression to their belief in the early and certain prospect of a restored and regenerated Union.

abstract: Fisher vs. Fisher. -- The suit is brought by the wife against the husband, for a limited divorce, on the ground of cruelty and inhuman treatment, and the motion was made by the wife for alimony pending the suit. Affidavits were read in opposition to the motion, in which it appeared that she had been guilty of much violence and ill-temper toward her husband. The court held that while it was the rule to grant an allowance, where the action was brought by the husband, there must be, when the position of the parties was reversed, as in this instance, some good and substantial reason shown by the wife for such an order. In this case there appeared to be none, and the motion must be denied.
lead_paragraph: Fisher vs. Fisher. -- The suit is brought by the wife against the husband, for a limited divorce, on the ground of cruelty and inhuman treatment, and the motion was made by the wife for alimony pending the suit. Affidavits were read in opposition to the motion, in which it appeared that she had been guilty of much violence and ill-temper toward her husband. The court held that while it was the rule to grant an allowance, where the action was brought by the husband, there must be, when the position of the parties was reversed, as in this instance, some good and substantial reason shown by the wife for such an order. In this case there appeared to be none, and the motion must be denied.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The third performance of "La Forza dej Destino" was witnessed, last evening, by all exceedingly full and brilliant audience. The work improves so rapidly on acquaintance that there is no longer a doubt about its becoming one of the most popular to Mr. MABETZER'S, extensive and singularly fresh repertoire.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The third performance of "La Forza dej Destino" was witnessed, last evening, by all exceedingly full and brilliant audience. The work improves so rapidly on acquaintance that there is no longer a doubt about its becoming one of the most popular to Mr. MABETZER'S, extensive and singularly fresh repertoire. The singers were in fair voice, and the judicious curtailments made since the first night enabled all to hear the end of the opera.

lead_paragraph: "No sane man now doubts that if, on assuming the Executive authority four years ago, Mr. LINCOLN, in his inaugural address, had proclaimed the sentiment recommended by Gen. abstract: Richmond papers of the 2d inst. contain very significant and important indications of the complete success of Gen. SHERMAN'S grand military combinations. We gather from the rebel statements that Gen. SHERMAN deceived the enemy as ...
lead_paragraph: Richmond papers of the 2d inst. contain very significant and important indications of the complete success of Gen. SHERMAN's grand military combinations. We gather from the rebel statements that Gen. SHERMAN deceived the enemy as to his real intentions by making feints against Charlotte and Florence, while with the main body of his army he pushed across the country from Columbia in the direction of Fayetteville, N.C. BRAGG was also induced, by a feint movement from Wilmington toward Goldsboro, to mass his troops on the line of the Northeast, Cape Fear River, leaving Gen. SCHOFIELD to move up the Cape Fear River toward Fayetteville, where he will probably form a junction with Gen. SHERMAN. This line of march will be protected by our gunboats, and by the rivers and swampy lands that lie between him and Gen. BRAGG's fosces.

snippet: McClellan's Method of Conducting the War; Close of Presidential Term; Policy of his Administration
lead_paragraph: The first Presidential term of President LINCOLN closes to-day. It is hard to realize that but four years have elapsed since that untried Springfield lawyer took upon himself his stupendous responsibilities. The nation has been subjected to dangers so appalling and so protracted, and has undergone such prodigious changes, that this brief olympiad, as we look back upon it, looms upon the imagination with almost the proportions of a century.

abstract: Foster and Wicks; Match for $100
snippet: Foster and Wicks; Match for $100
lead_paragraph: An interesting match between MELVIN FOSTER and WILLIAM H. WICKS, the well-known amateur, was played at GOLDTHWAIT CAHILLS's hall, on Thursday evening, the former undertaking to discount the latter the best of eleven games of 100 points each, caroms, on a four-pocket table. FOSTER won the two first games, and WICKS the six next successive games, the latter making the greatest number of points in the grand score. The following is the summary: Melvin Foster and William H. Wicks, best in eleven games of 100 points each, on a four-pocket Phelan & Collender table, with 2 2/8-inch balls, for $100, Wicks to receive discount. Wicks won the third, fourth, fifth, sixth, seventh and eighth games and the match; Foster the first and second games. Grand score -- Wicks, 702; Foster, 701. Innings -- Wicks, 61; Foster, 57. Average -- Winner, 11-31; loser, 12-17. Highest Runs -- Foster, 102; Wicks, 56. Time -- Three hours and ten minutes. Referee -- William Roberts. Umpires -- For Wicks, George E. Phelan; for Foster, T. Flynn.

abstract: The celebration to-day promises to be an event which will eclipse in magnificence and splendid novelties, all others of the many grand popular demonstrations which have been made in this city.
lead_paragraph: The celebration to-day promises to be an event which will eclipse in magnificence and splendid novelties, all others of the many grand popular demonstrations which have been made in this city. Expressing, as it does, the joy and gratitude of the people for the succession of brilliant victories that Providence has vouchsafed to our arms, no effort and no expense have been spared to make the pageant commensurately as imposing as the achievements and successes it commemorates are glorious. The fall of Charleston and Wilmington foreshadow the speedy overthrow of the rebellion. The dissensions of the chief rebels and the rapid disintegration of their one remaining host, still more completely justify us in rejoicing now, at least over the vast and brilliant achievements already complete, and thus made sure as portions of history. In full accordance with this joyful national crisis all our officials and citizens are heartily joining together, laying aside mere partisanships, in celebrating the national prosperity. Public offices and institutions are very generally to be closed; all the city will turn out; and rich and poor together, this vast metropolis, all gay with banners, processions and shouts, will fitly testify its deep delight at past victories, at the prospect of future ones, and at the beginning, amid every sign of strength and happiness, of a new four years' term, and let us hope an indefinite term, of the indivisible existence of our glorious United States.
