abstract: A PRECIOUS SCAMP. -- A genteel appearing man, about 30 years of age, and representing himself to be a Baptist minister, was arrested, a couple of days since, at his boarding-house, in Garden-street, Hoboken, charged with having robbed a Kentuckian named GRAVES of a suit of wearing apparel, $35 in money, and a watch and chain valued at $550. It appears that the accused recently went to board at a house in Hudson-street, New-York, and by his affable manners and pretentions to piety, gained the respect and friendship of the household. BALDWIN occupied a room with Mr. GRAVES, and a few mornings since decamped with the above-named property, leaving behind his cast-off garments. Unfortunately for him, he left a letter in his coat pocket addressed to his wife on Staten Island, directing her to send his trunk to a certain house in Garden-street, Hoboken, which gave a clue to his whereabouts and led to his arrest. Upon being taken before Judge POPE the accused owned up to the robbery, delivered up the watch, and would have delivered the clothing on the spot except for the lack of a change. The money, however, was spent. The matter was compromised by his agreeing to enlist, and with part of the bounty-moncy promising to make Mr. GRAVES' loss good. Mr. BALDWIN was passing himself off for a single man, and had a bit of a love-affair with a young lady at the house where he last boarded.

abstract: Col. HATCH, the Confederate Agent of Exchange, communicated with the Yankee authorities at Wilmington, on Monday last, and we are glad to learn that an agreement was made for the delivery of all Yankee prisoners in our hands in this State, at that point, at the earliest practicable moment. Some three or four thousand were paroled in Goldsboro' on Saturday, and were to be sent yesterday morning to the enemy's lines. Seven or eight hundred passed this place from Salisbury on Sunday morning for the same point, and we learn that all here are to be sent through as soon as transportation can be furnished. Several hundred were sent off yesterday.

abstract: A gentleman from the neighborhood of Hancock County, Kentucky, has just given us the following account of a most singular guerrilla outrage. The notorious guerrilla. COULTER, who is reported to have been killed in Nelson County, Kentucky, about two weeks ago, is the hero of our story. COULTER entered the village of Hawesville, and going to the clerk's office, compelled the deputy-clerk of the county court to issue a marriage license, authorizing any minister of the gospel legally qualified, to unite him (COULTER) in the bonds matrimony with Mrs. F., the beautiful young wife of a discharged Union soldier. (Her husband being in Louisville, afraid to return to the guerrilla infested neighborhood in which his dwelling is located.) The clerk, in his own justification, entered on his book, "compelled by force of arms to issue this license." Having obtained the license, COULTER next sought a clergyman, whom, with threats of death, he compelled to go with him to the house and perform the ceremony. Having lived with the doubly-married woman three or four date, the desperado, gave her five hundred dollars in gold, and set off again in search of adventures. Whether the lady was constrained by force, by gold or by romantic affection, to submit to the double marriage, our informant has not learned. It may be added, as favorable to the best construction which can be placed on the conduct of the bride, that when last seen in the neighborhood she was on board of a steamer which was bound for Louisville. -- Jeffersonville, (Ia.,) National Democrat.

abstract: The Committee on Municipal Affairs have reported the following bill to the Senate: Crude petroleum, earth or rock oil, or any of their products, may be stored in detached and properly ventilated warehouses, specially adapted for that purpose, by having raised sills, or the ground-floor to be at least two feet below the surface of The surrounding land, so as to effectually prevent the overflow of such substances beyond the premises where the same is stored.

abstract: The Senate sat all night, and then went into Executive session. The Civil Appropriation Bill was the main feature, to which several amendments were made. The report of the Conference Committee, on the amended Enrollment Bill, was concurred in. A number of private bills were passed. About 7 A.M., the Senate had a brief recess. Upon reassembling, the bill for the coining of three-cent pieces was passed. The question of admitting the Senators from Arkansas went over. While discussing [???] bill regulating Commerce between the States, the special matter being an amendment that no citizen shall be excluded from any public conveyance on account of color, the hour of 12 drew near, and preparations were made for adjournment. Vice President JOHNSON was introduced; Mr. HAMLIN, the retiring officer, made a brief address, the oath of office was administered to Mr. JOHNSON, after some remarks by him, and Mr HAMLIN pronounced tha Senate adjourned sine die. The Clerk immediately read the proclamation for an extra session, the new members were sworn in, and the Senate in a body joined in the ceremonies of the inauguration of President LINCOLN.

abstract: At a meeting of the City Inspector's subordinatessyesterday. Inspector BOOLE in the chair, reports were received from the deputy inspectors, and it was shown that the laborers who recently undertook
lead_paragraph: At a meeting of the City Inspector's subordinatessyesterday. Inspector BOOLE in the chair, reports were received from the deputy inspectors, and it was shown that the laborers who recently undertook the exhumation of the city were making commendable progress. The deputy from West-street first rendered an account of his stewardship. He commenced operations, on the 24th of December last, by clothing his employes in Goodyear's rubber marine-armor and advertising for a supply of diving-bells. There was some necessary delay in making ready, and it was not until the middle of January that he was able to effect the initial soundings. These, however, were highly gratifying, showing, as they did, that, with favorable weather and by indomitable perseverance, excavations may be completed and terra firma reached in the neighborhood of the Jersey City and Hoboken ferries by about a week from next Autumn. The inspector from Whitehall believed that he could exhibit the Broadway pavement to a curious public by the middle of July next, and his colaborers of Fulton-street and Roosevelt were in high glee in being able to state that in their recent soundings they had brought up several lost stages and discovered the whereabouts of the twenty-seven teams that were supposed to have gone astray on New-Year's night. The inspector from Ann-street thought it possible to reduce the glaciers between Barnum's and Nassau-street in course of the season, and suggested the propriety of presenting Barnum and the Historical society samples of Ann-street compost. The inspector from Mackerelville here entered with a regiment of bell-ringers in his train, and the proceedings were waxing warm and delightfully rich, when the City Inspector, learning that a reporter had surreptitiously gained admission, summarily adjourned the hearing.

abstract: on Systems of Government; Our System of, Don Campeon on
snippet: on Systems of Government; Our System of, Don Campeon on
lead_paragraph: The cosmopolite, Don RUFINO Ma DE ALFARRERO Y CAMPEON, asks space this morning for elaborating his favorite theory that this country has taken the high road, and ismarching with rapid strides toward centralization, or, in plainer phrase, despotism. He lays down, at great length, the proposition, that each year the Government will become less federal, less democratic, and less unstable in the tenure of office. He predicts -- and gives elaborate reasons to support the prediction -- that our present system is to be succeeded by what he calls a "real Government," founded "possibly on the consent, but certainly on the obedience of the governed."

abstract: Rebel Senate, calls on Davis to Resign
snippet: Rebel Senate, calls on Davis to Resign
lead_paragraph: -Mr. COLLYER, of the Virginia Senate, now in session at Richmond, is a man who has no mercy upon JEFF. DAVIS in this crisis of his fortunes. He delivered a senatorial oration, a few days ago, in which he took the rebel chief to task, pronounced his administration a signal and fatal failure, and called on him to resign. He showed how DAVIS had ruined the South, produced, universal loss of confidence in his management, and played the part of a tyrant and fool generally. JEFF. DAVIS' assertion that Richmond might be captured, and yet the rebellion succeed, is rhetorically characterized by Senator COLLYER as "another phosphorescent emanation from passionate imbecility which can float and flare only in the socket of a disordered imagination;" and "such delusive light," the Virginia Senator boldly declared, "ought to be put out." Senator COLLYER is right; and all good soldiers, sailors, savans, rhetoricians and patriots will gladly aid him in the extinguishment of that "phosphorescent emanation from passionate imbecility," JEFF. DAVIS.

abstract: The celebration of our recent victories which was to have taken place yesterday having been postponed on account of the rain storm which set in during Friday night, will be carried out according to the programme already published, to-morrow,, or in the event of the weather again proving unpropitious, on the first fatr day. Yesterday Jupiter Pluvius, as...
lead_paragraph: The celebration of our recent victories which was to have taken place yesterday having been postponed on account of the rain storm which set in during Friday night, will be carried out according to the programme already published, to-morrow,, or in the event of the weather again proving unpropitious, on the first fatr day. Yesterday Jupiter Pluvius, as if in disgust at not having been made Chairman of the Committee of Arrangements for the ceremonial, intervened of his own motion, with a very damp and peremptory veto. As, however, the meteorological possibilities of the question had not been overlooked, the readers of the TIMES at least received seasonable notice of postponement by the towering of the flags at the Astor House and elsewhere.

abstract: ANNA E. DICKINSON will repeat, in the Cooper Institute, on Friday evening next, the lecture on "Woman's Work and Wages," which she lately delivered in Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, and of which the Independent said: "Having heard Miss DICKINSON many times, we are free to say that we never knew her to be more impressive, sympathetic, and all-conquering than on this occasion. Certainly the most accomplished of public speakers might have been abundantly content with the charm and spell wrought by this young enchantress upon the large audience which laughed and wept at her discourse in Brooklyn. Such a speech, from such a speaker, was a salutary sermon; and we envy not the temper of mind of any man or woman in that audience who was not touched, quickened, and bettered by that womanly appeal in behalf of woman's work and pay."

abstract: The Issue in; Maximilian and Priesthood
snippet: The Issue in; Maximilian and Priesthood
lead_paragraph: The breach between MAXIMILLAN and the Mexican priesthood has become irreparable. The Church party no longer confine themselves to grumbling, but have actually taken the field and are waging a systematic guerrilla war against their former idol, whom they accuse of ingratitude, perfidity, heterodoxy and all the vices that Emperors are heirs to. The principal counts in their bill of indictment are two: First, that His Majesty refuses to restore to the clergy that portion of their property which has been secularized; and second, that he has given open encouragement to infidelity by granting freedom of conscience and toleration to the various religious sects.

abstract: The civil courts of this city will commence the March Term on Monday, (to-morrow,) with very full calendars. Some of them are unusually heavy. In the Supreme Court Circuit, Part 1, Judge CLERKE will preside.
lead_paragraph: The civil courts of this city will commence the March Term on Monday, (to-morrow,) with very full calendars. Some of them are unusually heavy. In the Supreme Court Circuit, Part 1, Judge CLERKE will preside. The court will be held as usual in the large brown-stone court-house building situated in the northeast corner of the Park, on the main floor. Part 2 will be held by Judge MULLEN, of the Eighth Judicial District, on the second floor of the building No. 73 Duane-street, which for some time past has been used as a court-room.

abstract: On National Development
snippet: On National Development
lead_paragraph: Prof. DRAPER delivered the last of the series on Thursday evening, at the rooms of the Historical Society. His subject was the "Natural Course of National Development." Prof. DRAPER said that from the book of nature we gather the progress of men. Throughout the whole world of organization, the scheme of nature is the same. The progress of society is always determined by natural laws. He cited the differences between the people of the North and the South, the result of natural laws. During the past four years the people had endured hardships, shed their best blood, and submitted to taxation for the maintenance of an idea, -- the determination that but one nation should exist on this continent. For a season they had relinquished those organic laws which are the foundation of liberty; have created a navy without a rival, and consider their debt as nothing, compared to the object in view. A few years ago, who could have foretold what has come to pass. The events of nations are controlled by invisible laws; the unseen are more powerful than visible causes. There is a stern logic of events; a natural course through which nations must go. When ALEXANDER was pursuing the conquest of Asia, he gave ARISTOTLE money for the purpose of writing a history of Athens. The views of ARISTOTLE however, fell out of sight after the fall of Greece, and not until our own century, have men been able to embrace his great ideas. In this, the morning of human intelligence, we begin to comprehend the course of nature. The lower order of insects are controlled by instinct; as we rise in the scale, animals are governed by intelligence. The course of nature is toward elevation, and the concentration of intellect. Advancing to the human family, the lecturer said that in the tower tribes, the acts of man were purely mechanical; in men the automatic and instinctive apparatus are combined. Another important part, the brain appears. In the nervous system of man there are three distinct parts; the automatic, instinctive and reasoning faculties. The brain is the theatre of ideas, the realm of thought, through which the mind acts. He said that in animals the advance was gradual and regular. The brain first appears in the fish, and increases in birds, therefore giving them more intelligence. The same gradual advancement is true of man. The life of the world corresponds to the growth of man. The end of the successive shares of life is intellectual improvement. The sciences, affirm that the great aim of nature is to reach intellect. Man is the archotype of society; his advancement is the mark of the social progress of the world. The body politic must be ruled by its intellect. A social machine is composed of parts, each of which has its duty to do. Education is a term of wide import; that demanded by modern times must embrace the knowledge of the cotempor[???]neous races. The defect of education is, that too much labor is devoted to the past. Talent is a God-given gift. Education, though a great thing, is not everything. For stability to be attained, a nation must submit to be controlled by its intellect. There are only three things that can govern -- science, literature and reason. No education can make all men alike; a large portion of our race must be devoted to labor. Governed by external influences. It drifts along to its destiny. In our nation, there has been a degree of prosperity which has had no parallel in the world. Wealth has poured upon us until we have had no idea of anything else. How true it is, that for a nation to be anything, it must be something beyond its animal nature. We are passing from the animal to the intellectual. We are gaining discipline, which we could not have acquired except by war. A race is rising which will submit to be controlled by its reason. In asserting that in all human communities, as their life advances there must be a concentration of intellect, he was but following the experience of nature. He asserted what in the nature of the case must inevitably come to pass. Too commonly do we believe that the acts of men are controlled by free will. Believing everything we do is determined to our own will, or those around us, not until we reach the winter of the do we realize that we have been floating down a stream. For stability to be maintained, a nation must be controlled by its intellect. Believing that man is an emblem of society, the speaker looked upon his growth as the foreshowing of the growth of it. Passing from childhood to youth, from youth to manhood, and then to old age, man gradually advances involuntarily; so it is with nations. He would be satisfied if he had [???]te[???] a taste for studying modern sciences. In conclusion, he said that human civilization does not take place fortuitously, but by given laws, ever moving, resistingly advancing in an inevitable succession of events.

abstract: on Slavery
snippet: on Slavery
lead_paragraph: In his last published letter on the arming of slaves, Gen. LEE makes a pointed commentary on the old pro-slavery theory, so long cherished by lay and clerical defenders of the peculiar, institution. That theory invariably represented the condition of the great body of the slaves as practically one of voluntary servitude. Their attachment to the patriarchal relation has illustrated many a score of texts from Hebrew history, and illuminated many a score of pulpit discourses that might otherwise have been dull and dismal. And yet, if Gen. LEE who may be presumed to have some acquaintance with the subject, had spoken a few years sooner, he would have made sad work among our modern patriarchs. He says. "I think those who are employed (in the rebel army) should be freed. It would be neither just nor wise, in my opinion, to require them to serve as slaves." Such a statement as this -- coming from such a source -- must be little less than startling to the venerable Bishop HOPKINS, and to those generally among us who have supported the "institution" out of a kindly regard for the negro, and for that alone. They will hardly, at least, understand Gen. LEE's philosophy of giving the slave his liberty as the prime reward of his becoming a soldier. It is evident that this war is working fearful havoc among a great many fine old theories.

abstract: DEVELOPMENTS OF A DIVORCE SUIT. -- PETER R. STRONG, a William-street lawyer, recently brought a suit against his wife for divorce, and the wife entered a counter suit, the particulars of which have been published. The testimony, however, in these suits revealed facts which have not been given the public, showing that ELECTRA M. POTTER, of Waverley-place, one of STRONG's tenants, with whom, according to the wife's allegation, the husband had been guilty of criminal intercourse, had also been guilty of malpractice, and, as alleged, had caused the death of ELIZABETH ADAMS. It is alleged that the woman POTTER, having operated on Miss ADAMS, sent for Dr. JOHN B. DENNIS, and that DENNIS gave a certificate of death from congestion of the brain, under which certificate the body of Miss ADAMS was interred in the New-York Bay Cemetery, in April, 1863. Another affidavit accuses Mrs. STRONG of malpractice; but this is immaterial. District-Attorney HALL, hearing of these deposition, and having already two indictments pending over the bond of Dr. DENNIS, felt it his duty to present the facts to the Grand Jury, and he accordingly did so, and that body found true bills against PETER R. STRONG, of No. 76 William-street, Mrs. ELECTRA M. POTTER, of No. 386 Sixth-avenue, and Dr. JOHN B. DENNIS, of No. 16 First-street, and under a bench warrant from Recorder HOFFMAN, Capt. JOURDAN and Sergeant WALSH, of the Sixth Ward, apprehended the accused. STRONG was held to ball in $5,000 and Mrs. POTTER and Dr. DENNIS were committed to the Tombs.
lead_paragraph: DEVELOPMENTS OF A DIVORCE SUIT. -- PETER R. abstract: A strange apparition flitted through Printing-house-square yesterday morning, a remnant of the masquerade carnival; a wonder to the unchins who have their habitat in the park and "blag your boots," or abuse you, if you refuse to have them blacked. "A part of the procession," says one. "Barnum's Arab," says another, "Ned Buntline," said the older ones to whom the face was familiar. The old boys were right; it was Ned Buntline returned to the scene of his former exploits in the costume of a modern Greek -- a red fez cap, white satin tunic reaching almost to the knee, white silk stockings, red merino leggings, laced up over the calf of the leg, red shoes, and a blue girdle around the waist, a classical and patriotic combination of the national colors, composed the dress of this extraordinary figure. Without much regard for the proprieties of gender, Mr. BUNTLINE remarked that he was the Goddess of Liberty, and was about to head the procession at the celebration of our victories. The original programme being set aside on account of the weather, the small boys of the neighborhood improvised a procession, and the "Goddess of Liberty," represented as a modern Greek, marched up Chatham-street at their head.
lead_paragraph: A strange apparition flitted through Printing-house-square yesterday morning, a remnant of the masquerade carnival; a wonder to the unchins who have their habitat in the park and "blag your boots," or abuse you, if you refuse to have them blacked. abstract: The stated meeting of the Board of Managers was held at the Bible House, Astor-place, on Thursday, the 2d inst., at 3:30 o'clock P.M., WILLIAM WHITLOCK, Jr., Esq., one of the Vice-Presidents, in the chair. The death of WILLIAM FORREST, Esq., one...
lead_paragraph: The stated meeting of the Board of Managers was held at the Bible House, Astor-place, on Thursday, the 2d inst., at 3:30 o'clock P.M., WILLIAM WHITLOCK, Jr., Esq., one of the Vice-Presidents, in the chair. The death of WILLIAM FORREST, Esq., one of the oldest members of the board, was announced by the Secretary, when Rev. Dr. HUTTON read the 90th Psalm, and offered prayer. Four new auxiliaries were recognized, of which two are in West Virginia, one in Michigan and one in Wisconsin. Communications were received from Mr. THOMAS M. WESTRUP. Monterey, stating that permission has been granted to our agent in Mexico to sell Bibles and Testaments; from Rev. DAVID TRUMBULL, n regard to Bible distribution in Valparaiso and Santiago, and sending the journal of the colporteur in Valparaiso, from Rev. Dr. VAN DYCK, Beirut, accepting the appointment to superintend the electrotyping of the Arabic Scriptures; from Rev. H.A. WILDER, Umtwalume, Africa, asking funds to print the scriptures in the Zulu language; from Rev. I.G. BLISS, Constantinople, with estimate of expenses for the coming year for carrying on the Bible work in his agency; from Rev. S.L. BALDWIN, Fuh-Chau, sending his book and fiscal account for the year past, and asking funds for the year now commencing; from Rev. W. TRACY, Madura, as to Bible work in the mission, and asking funds for the present year.

abstract: Celebration of
snippet: Celebration of
lead_paragraph: This Society celebrated the anniversary of the birth of the patron saint of all good Welshmes, St. David, on Wednesday last, at Curet's Hotel, Broadway. About seventy of the members of the society and their guests were present. Mr. HENEY N. MORGAN presided, and Mr. JOHN T. DAVIS acted an Vice-President. After ample justice has been done to the good things provided, Mr. MORGAN said he was happy to state that the funds of the society were in a flourishing condition, and that it was not on record that it had ever denied relief to a worthy applicant. Mr. MORGAN then spoke of the sentiments which must naturally animate all good Weishman on this day, and said: "We have the glorious history of a nation for a period of twenty-five centuries, ca[???]ing upon us to lay aside family, business and all other considerations on this day, and bear witness with feasting, with oratory, with song and sentiment to the honor and memory of those heroes of the olden time, as of later days, who were part of and descendan s from a race which, though one of the oldest among the races of men, never yet submitted to the yoke of a conqueror or allowed the fires of civil and religious liberty to be extinguished."

abstract: Ex parte Batlmann. -- A writ of habeas corpus had been issued to bring up the accused, who had been committed to the Tombs on the charge of "inducing a recruit to enlist out of this State in Connecticut." The question (said Mr. Edwin James) he desired to raise was whether the act was constitutional, as the President and Congress had power to raise armies from every State, and no State had any right to restrict enlistments to any particular State. In the absence of the District Attorney the case was adjourned, and in the meantime the Judge ordered the accused to be discharged upon giving ball in the sum of $500.

abstract: While our housekeepers in New-York have to pay the butcher from 25 to 35 cents a pound for ordinary joints, not less than one hundred and fifty thousand tons of excellent grass-fed beef -- the yearly product of the districts bordering on the Rio Grande and the River Platte -- can scarcely find a market at $2 a cwt.; that is, at two cents a pound. This vast supply -the surplus produce of two million well-fed bullocks and heifers -- does not represent the mere carcase weight of the slaughtered animal. It is solid beef, stripped from the bones of the carcase, allowed to cool, jerked or cut up into thin flitches and properly cured in that form for exportation. The chief markets heretofore sought for it, in this prepared state, have been those of Brazil and Cuba. But in both countries it has generally -- as we may judge from the price -- been a drug in the market. The mode of curing heretofore adopted may have had much to do with the limited demand. But if this is the prime drawback, we venture to believe that, at the present rate of things here, some ingenious enterprisers will be found before long, who will discover a way of bringing some portion of this vast South American surplus, in a wholesomely cured condition, into our markets.

abstract: Rebel Deserters to; Gen Stevenson's Order on
snippet: Rebel Deserters to; Gen Stevenson's Order on
lead_paragraph: TO BE CARED FOR. -- An important order, emanating from Brig.-Gen. STEVENSON, the new Commander of the Department of West Virginia since the capture of Gen. CROOK, has been placed in our hands. The order sets forth that the attention of the General commanding the Department has been called by the civil authorities of the State of West Virginia to the fact that great numbers of refugees and deserters from the rebel army are coming in and remaining at posts upon the border of the Department, and in towns and counties not directly under the surveillance of the military authorities, bringing with them horses, arms and military equipments in their desertion, or pretended desertion from the rebel army; and it being urged upon him by the civil authorities and citizens of undoubted loyalty, that their numbers, present bearing, and their past bad faith have created a well founded alarm in the midst of the loyal people, that with this dangerous element in their midst there is no security of either life or property, and under such circumstances that something should be done to relieve the people of this sense of insecurity, and at the same time confirm their confidence in the ability and determination of the Government to protect her loyal people; to prevent the return of these deserters, to swell the ranks of the rebel army when a new campaign shall be opened; to remove from the country the spies and guides who so readily furnish information to the raiding parties, and not unfrequently join them, sharing their plunder; it is ordered that all territory south of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, extending from Harper's Ferry to Grafton, and all territory south of the Parkersburgh branch extending from Grafton to the Ohio River, shall be considered as virtually without the lines of Federal occupation -- within the meaning of Special Field Order No. 82, Headquarters Armies United States, as far as relates to the safeguard allowing rebel deserters to return to their homes and remain under the protection of the armies of the United States. It is ordered throughout this department that, within five days after arriving within the lines, all persons, whether deserters or refugees, shall report at the nearest military post, to be sent to such point or points as may be demed necessary for their personal safety and the safety of the Government; and all who fail to report in compliance with this order shall be considered as spies, and dealt with as such.
headline: {'main': 'REBEL DESERTERS IN WEST VIRGINIA.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'REBEL DESERTERS IN WEST VIRGINIA.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: our Consul at, Ordered to Leave
snippet: our Consul at, Ordered to Leave
lead_paragraph: -- The latest advices from Matamoras would seem to confirm the report that our Consul has been ordered to leave that place. Matamoras, we believe, is garrisoned by a mixed military force of Imperialists -- chiefly French soldiers, however -- and as the so-called Government under which this force maintains its tenure of the place is regarded by the United States merely as a "belligerent," we cannot complain that our Consul has ceased to be recognized. He held his exequatur from the Government of President JUAREZ, and not from that of MAXIMILIAN. His position, therefore, became exceptional and anomalous, so soon as the invading army dispossessed the forces of the Republic at Matamoras. And, all things considered, perhaps it is less strange that our Consul should have withdrawn from his position at this late hour, than that he should have remained at his post so long.
headline: {'main': 'OUR CONSUL AT MATAMORAS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'OUR CONSUL AT MATAMORAS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Senate sat all Friday night, and then went into Executive session. The Civil Appropriation Bill was the main feature, to which several amendments were made. The report of the Conference Committee, on the amended Enrollment Bill, was concurred in. A number of private bills were passed. About 7 A.M., on Saturday, the Senate had a brief recess. Upon reassembling, the bill for the coining of three-cent pieces was passed. The question of admitting the Senators from Arkansas went over. While discussing the bill regulating Commerce between the States, the special matter being an amendment that no citizen shall be excluded from any public conveyance on account of color, the hour of 12 drew near, and preparations were made for adjournment. Vice President JOHNSON was introduced: Mr. HAMLIN, the retiring officer, made a brief address, the oath of office was administered to Mr. JOHNSON, after come remarks by him, and Mr. HAMLIN pronounced the Senate adjourned sine die. The Clerk immediately read the proclamation for an extra session, the new members were sworn in, and the Senate in a body joined in the ceremonies of the inauguration of President LINCOLN.

abstract: Inaugural
snippet: Inaugural
lead_paragraph: The President, in assuming the responsibilities of his second term, indulges in but few words. He makes no boasts of what he has done, or promises of what he will do. He does not reexpound the principles of the war; does not redeclare the worth of the Union; does not reproclaim that absolute submission to the Constitution is the only peace. All that he does is simply to advert to the cause of the war, and its amazing development; to recognize in solemn language the righteous judgment of Heaven; and to drop an earnest exhortation that all will now stand by the right, and strive for a peace that shall be just and lasting.

abstract: Effect of Peace on; Effect of on Mining Interests
snippet: Effect of Peace on; Effect of on Mining Interests
lead_paragraph: The public are continually theorizing and speculating, as to the effect of the surely approaching peace on the various material interests of the country. How soon the nation can resume specie payments, what the rate of gold will be the first six months, what the influence of a cessation of the enormous Government purchases on agriculture and manufacture, how far railroads will experience a diminution of traffic and freight, and how much their diminished expenses will counterbalance this -- all these are questions which arise constantly to all prudent persons, and which are by no means easy to answer.

abstract: Views on Seat in Cabinet; Cabinet, The; Gov Andrew's Views on
snippet: Views on Seat in Cabinet; Cabinet, The; Gov Andrew's Views on
lead_paragraph: -- Gov. ANDREW's position regarding the Cabinet changes and his wishes regarding a position in it are fully explained by the Boston Transcript. That paper says "Gov. ANDREW took an early occasion to put himself right in this respect. He stated emphatically, in a communication which was seen by every member of the Massachusetts delegation, that he 'was not anxious for a seat in the Cabinet for himself, but was willing to try to do anything which the best men who regard me with feelings of personal kindness, and regard the cause much more than they do myself, think I ought to do, and which I also think I can safely attempt.' That he 'earnestly desired not to have any place unless that of Attorney-General; that he would 'much prefer to serve out his year here;' that 'if there is any member of the Massachusetts delegation who will accept and on whom the delegation will unite now for any place whatever in the Cabinet, I will peremptorily refuse to be a candidate for any place. If Massachusetts can be properly represented in the Cabinet, she ought to be, and it is extraordinary that every member of our delegation should not see its importance.

abstract: Sheridan's Victory over Early
snippet: Sheridan's Victory over Early
lead_paragraph: The Lieutenant-General controlling all military operations, has determined to give LEE some extra work to do near Richmond, without giving him the trouble of going down to the Carolinas and to SHERMAN's front to find it. The official bulletin this morning conveys to the country the astonishing and unexpected information, that Gen. PHIL. SHERIDAN has again made his appearance a hundred miles up the Shenandoah Valley, has attacked his old foeman, Gen. EARLY, and has captured him and nearly the entire body of his command -- some eighteen hundred men -- between Staunton and Charlottesville. The dispatches from Gen. GRANT, incorporated by Secretary STANTON in his bulletin, are all based on statements derived through rebel sources, from rebel deserters and refugees; but they come from so many quarters, from so many persons, are so consistent in themselves, and doubtless agree so closely with the anticipations of Gen. GRANT, that he sent three telegrams on the subject at different hours yesterday, each confirmatory of the other.

abstract: -- Coroner CONLON impanneled a jury on Saturday, to inquire into the circumstances under which DANIEL LAWRENCE, a Norwegian sailor, was mortally wounded on Sunday the 26th Feb, last at No. 126 Hester-street. The testimony of several witnesses was taken; but that of EMMA WEILDS alone had any important bearing on the case. She deposed that she resided at No. 126 Hester-street, and that she knew the prisoner, WILLIAM SMITH; that she went out with SMITH on Saturday night, and that deceased followed them home and got into the room through the hall bedroom window, when witness ran away; a fight occurred between deceased and the prisoner, and on reentering the room witness found the prisoner there with his hands covered with blood; the prisoner stepped with witness during the night, and on the following morning they went to a boarding-house in Thirty-first-street, near Tenth-avenue, where they were arrested by the police. The case having been given to the jury, they found that "DANIEL LAWRENCE came to his death by stab wounds at the hands of WILLIAM SMITH, on the morning of the 26th February, 1865 at No. 126 Hester-street. SMITH, who is a Swedish seaman, aged about 25 years, was committed to the Tombs, and the Coroner held the witness, EMMA WIELDS, who is an attractive German miss of perhape 20 Summers, to bail to appear when required. LAWRENCE was 28 years of age.

abstract: Notwithstanding the unfavorable weather on Saturday, and the uncertainty concerning the procession, there was a good attendance at the opera matinee. FLOTOW'S opera of "Martha" was given" Fra Davolo" being impracticable with Mesdames KELLOGG and MORENSI in the principal roles, and Mr. MARETZEK conductig. To-night VERDI'S
lead_paragraph: Notwithstanding the unfavorable weather on Saturday, and the uncertainty concerning the procession, there was a good attendance at the opera matinee. FLOTOW'S opera of "Martha" was given -- "Fra Davolo" being impracticable -- with Mesdames KELLOGG and MORENSI in the principal roles, and Mr. MARETZEK conductig. To-night VERDI'S new opera. "La Forsa del Destino," will be given for the fourth time. It will also be given on Wednesday and Thursday. In consequence of the shortness of Mr. MARETZEK's season, these will be the last representations of this fine work.

abstract: Health Bill, a Report Wanted
snippet: Health Bill, a Report Wanted
lead_paragraph: -- WANTED, A REPORT. -- The eyes of thousands in this city are upon the committee of the Assembly having this bill in charge. The long delay in making a report seems unaccountable, and awakens solicitude. Let the committee report one way or the other at once. At the final hearing before that committee on Wednesday and Thursday last the only opponents of the bill were the Resident Physician and the "Registrar" of City Inspector BOOLE. One of these officials claimed that New-York was the healthiest city in the world, and that no legislation was needed, while the other alleged that immediate legislation was demanded, and proposed a new law, which would give all power to himself, the Mayor and some other city officials. This last scheme is received with general distrust in the city, and has not the slightest hope of success in either branch of the Legislature, as the committee must well know.

abstract: Palfrey's History of New-England; Vol III
snippet: Palfrey's History of New-England; Vol III
lead_paragraph: With the issue of the present volume Prof. PALFREY reaches the allotted term of his labors, and offers to his countrymen a complete work. There is but one opinion current among competent judges respecting the eminent ability, care, and research displayed by him, in the performance of a laborious task. It is remarkable that, with all that has been written on the subject, there had hitherto been published no single work which sufficed to trace the history of New-England, as a whole, during the period in question. On the contrary, the present tendency seems to be toward a minute division of historical investigation into its separate particles. The histories of towns, counties, families, &c., succeed one another with unexampled rapidity, all containing valuable material, and calling the more loudly, from their very number, for the general historian to work up into a finished picture of the scattered fragments of information so lavishly supplied by the industry of antiquarians, archaelogical societies, &c. Prof. PALFREY's third volume takes up the thread of history from about the year 1665, shortly after the restoration of CHARLES H., and carries it forward to the Revolution of 1688, consequently including some of the most stirring scenes of the colonial annals. He does not belong to the rhetorical school of historians; fine writing forms no waste portion of his book, but it abounds in facts based upon original authorities, and will rarely be consulted in vain by the historical inquirer. Some fac-similes of ancient maps form the appropriate illustrations to the volume. The book will undoubtedly take rank as a permanent addition to the stores of our libraries, the industry of the writer having availed himself of all existing material, so that there is little chance of its ever being superseded.

abstract: The Inauguration Ceremonies at Washington on Saturday were considerably marred by the state of the weather in the morning; the rain continued until nearly noon, and the streets were flooded with mud. The arrangements, too, seem to have been detective, one part of the ceremony taking place in the Senate Chamber, and other parts on the east portico of the Capitol. There was an immense gathering of strangers in the city, but a great many of them must have been disappointed. The procession got through the mud to the Capitol a little before noon; the new Vice-President was sworn in, and look his seat, after a speech, of course; the oath of office was then administered to President LINCOLN by Chief-Justice CHASE, and the President immediately delivered his inaugural address, a five minute document only. About this time the storm passed over, but not the mud. The procession then reformed and escorted Mr. LINCOLN to the White House, where the processionists separated. During the evening the President had a reception free to all, which of course drew an immense crowd. Although not reaching the splendor that would have marked it with better weather, the second inauguration passed off very smoothly without an accident or other untoward circumstance worthy of mention.

abstract: New-York to San Francisco, Direct Opened
snippet: New-York to San Francisco, Direct Opened
lead_paragraph: On Sunday morning, at 3 o'clock, the wires of the Western Union Company were connected with the Pacific lines, and communication established direct between this city and San Francisco. Though the weather was bad, rain falling at the time at many points on the route, the wires worked well, and a considerable amount of business was transacted. The distance is nearly four thousand miles, and the difference of time about four hours. This is unquestionably the longest telegraph circuit ever worked, and the fact that such a length of wire was telegraphed over in one circuit is a notable era in the history of telegraphing.

abstract: The signs all agree that the unpropituous weather of Saturday merely delayed, and will not in any degree mar, the success of the grand celebration of our national victories, upon which the people have resolved. The postponement, indeed, seems but to
lead_paragraph: The signs all agree that the unpropituous weather of Saturday merely delayed, and will not in any degree mar, the success of the grand celebration of our national victories, upon which the people have resolved. The postponement, indeed, seems but to have increased the enthusiasm, as it has unquestionably increased the number of the intending celebrants. Our readers have but to consult the extended programme, which the Isbors of the committee on Saturday have secured, to see that the forty-eight hours' adjournment promises to add immensely to the scope end effectiveness of the demonstration which to-day will witness. It needs no special power of forecasting events, to find in the energy, spirit, discretion and liberality, which the committee have brought to the task of perfecting the details of the celebration, the amplest assurance that it will be altogether the most imposing that has been seen in New-York for many years. Even what we might have been disposed to call the unseasonable rain-storm that caused the postponement, will doubtless prove a timely and most invaluable auxiliary in the essential matter of making the thoroughfares passable for the procession. Altogether, we see the best reason to expect a benignant fortune to-day; and right heartily, we trust, will every honest citizen give the rein to his loyal enthusiasm.

abstract: recent order of the State Adjutant-General, requiring that all bounties be paid to recruits on Hart's Island, meets with great disfavor. It is contended by those
lead_paragraph: recent order of the State Adjutant-General, requiring that all bounties be paid to recruits on Hart's Island, meets with great disfavor. It is contended by those familiar with the subject, that if the bounties are not paid at the Provost-Marshal's offices, as heretofore, that it will have the effect of retarding the business of recruiting, if not stop it altogether. At a meeting of the King's County Board of Supervisors, recently held, this subject was brought up, and a resolution was adopted to the effect that the Bounty Committee, or one of its number, be directed to proceed to Albany to communicate with the authorities in reference to the order forbidding the payment of moneys to drafted men except at the specified rendezvous. The committee will urge the State authorities to withdraw that portion of the order.

lead_paragraph: The dispute between the authorities of the City of Brooklyn and the General Government, in regard to the apportionment of the Wallabout Bay, lands has at length been settled. The city is to cede to the Government Clinton and Vanderbilt avenues, commencing at Flushing-avenue and extending over the marsh to the water's edge; also the roadway between the Naval Hospital and Marine Burying Ground. In return, the city is to receive a strip of land 80 feet in width for the purpose of extending Washington avenue across the flats, and a portion of Wallabout Bay to some point in the Eastern District.

abstract: At a very early hour it was apparent that NewYork was bent upon having a holiday. By ten o'clock the streets began to be uncomfortably thronged, the citizen in gala dress, the soldier in full regimentals, and the countryman in his best coat and smartest vest mingling amicably together. The
lead_paragraph: At a very early hour it was apparent that NewYork was bent upon having a holiday. By ten o'clock the streets began to be uncomfortably thronged, the citizen in gala dress, the soldier in full regimentals, and the countryman in his best coat and smartest vest mingling amicably together. The ladies, of course, seized the occasion for displaying their Spring bonnets and the pretty faces beneath, to the best advantage. Children ran about as if the procession was specialty got up for their benefits, and they were determined to enjoy it to the utmost. The sky was bright, and the air bracing, if not balmy, and New-York was in its very best humor and resolved to have, at least, one day of jubilee. On Broadway and the Fifth-avenue, every window of every house was filled with eager faces. Steps, balconies, doorways, gardens and even roofs had their quota of sight-seers, all well dressed, good humored and orderly. Every corner had its knot of gazers and every curb-stone its share of the living, moving multitude. In Broadway and the Bowery, windows had been engaged two or three days previously at fabulous rates, and in many of these places the chairs and sofas were numbered and ticketed, as though the establishment had been suddenly transformed into the dress-circle and upper tiers of a theatre. Many a humble vehicle, by the aid of a few chairs, two or three yards of canvass, and as many paper flags, became a desirable stand-point, to which access was obtained on the payment of a fee of fifty cents. These itinerant stands were usually placed at the corners of streets, thus rendering the movement of pedestrians, which had before been sufficiently difficult, almost impossible. But good humor prevailed, and these comparatively trifling annoyances were not permitted to interfere with the general harmony.

abstract: -- Dr. LEVEIT, of No. 832 Broadway, has perfected an invention by which the old cumbrous plate is dispensed with, and at the same time, the teeth are still more firmly secured in their place than has heretofore been possible. This is effected by a peculiar arrangement of air-cells, for applying the force of atmospheric pressure along the entire length of the socket which rests upon the gums. Also, in making the plate, a "raticulated gold web and rubber base," is used, so that perfect firmness is obtained with the valuable advantages of an extreme thinness, lightness and elasticity of the plate. Persons who have tried both the old and new inventions speak in the most enthusiastic praise of the superiority of the latter -- of its lightness in the mouth; the little space it occupies not interfering with speech or taste in the least; the ease with which it is adjusted, and the perfectness of the adhesion. Its greater naturalness, beauty and neatness of external appearance, are obvious to every one at a glance. -- Home Journal.

abstract: As if to make up in full for Saturday's inhospitable weather, yesterday was an absolutely perfect day for a great rejoicing. The rain had done much to clear the streets, and the civic carts and brooms had labored efficiently, too. And the sunshine and breezes that followed brought the ground beneath and heavens above to a capital condition for travel.

abstract: The announcement that there would be a fine pyrotechnic display, attracted an immense throng of people to Union-square in the evening. It is estimated that at least fifty thousand were present, the crowd extending from Fourteenth to Seventeenth streets, and from Fourth-avenue to University-place. The scene during the pyrotechnic exhibition was one of the most splendid ever witnessed in this city. The effect was much enhanced by the many illuminations around Union-square, some of which were beautiful. The Atheneum and the Union League Club houses were brilliantly illuminated, while the Union Square Hotel, and the two buildings corner of Fourteenth-street and Broadway, were hung with tri colored lanterns. The large eagle in front of the Maison Doree was lighted, forming an attractive feature of the display. At the corner of Fourteenth-street and University-place were two powerful calcium lights, which threw their rays over the up-turned faces of thousands of spectators, whose unceasing evolutions formed an interesting panorama. The exhibition of fireworks was considered to be the most beautiful ever witnessed in this city, while the number of pieces discharged was larger than has been displayed heretofore at one point. They were contributed by Messrs. J.G. & I. EDGE and J.W. HADFIELD. At 7:30 o'clock the firing of rockets began, which continued until 8 o'clock, when a motto piece with the words "The President, 1860-04," was discharged, and greeted with enthusiastic applause. Several beautiful pieces followed, when an illuminated design, with the word "Sumter," and the Confederate flag floating over it was lighted. During the burning of the piece an explosion took place which threw the rebel flag down and replaced it by the Stars and Stripes, amidst the huzzas of the multitude. This was one of the most successful pieces of the evening. The representation of the bombardment of Fort Fisher by the monitors and gunboats, terminating in the explosion of the fort, which was demolished and thrown down, was also very beautiful. The largest and most attractive piece contributed by Mr. HADFIELD was a design prepared for the occasion. It represented the eagle and shield, with the national colors festooned around. In the centres were the mottoes, "One Country, one People, one Destiny," while on either sids were the names of GRANT, FARRAGUT, THOMAS, SHERMAN, PORTER, SHERIDAN, and Atlanta, Savannah, Charleston and Wilmington. This piece burned brilliantly, and at the close was loudly cheered by the people. The largest piece contributed by Messrs. EDGE, and which closed the entertainment, was a representation of the naval engagement between the Monitor and Merrimac, in Hampton Roads. The Merrimac first attacks the frigates, when the Monitor appears and drives her back. The piece was excellent, and as the little Monitor obtained the victory, the enthusiasm of the people was intense. During the interval between the pieces, rockets, bomb-shells, illuminations, batteries, &c., were displayed. Several large tri-colored balloons, with lights, were sent off, some of which caught fire when two or three hundred feet high, producing much amusement among the spectators.

lead_paragraph: Soon as the procession had passed, which was half an hour after the time appointed for holding the meeting, the committee and invited speakers who had assembled at the Maison Dore proceeded to the three stands, which had been erected in Union-square. These were beautifully decorated with flags and emblems, and were rendered further attractive by the presence of the Seventh Regiment and other bands, which had by this time completed the prescribed route. The procession was of course the chief feature of the day. By it, chiefly, the attention of the people was occupied and their enthusiasm evoked. abstract: The Nord Deutche Allgemeinc Zeitung says: "After the resolutions passed by the committee of the Lower House there is no prospect that the majority will seek for the means of withdrawing from the state of affairs, created in 1862 by the representatives of the country, by an endeavor to come to an understanding with the Government. The present position of the Government without a budget, voted by the Diet, will probably continue for some time. The Government can wait, despite the attitude of the opposition."

abstract: Resources, Southern Opinion of; Arming by the Rebels
snippet: Resources, Southern Opinion of; Arming by the Rebels
lead_paragraph: A careful reading of the leaders which appear from time to time in those rebel journals which are influential in the South, will convince every thinking man that, were it possible for the rebels to view dispassionately their own position, they would conceive it to be nearly as hopeless as we ourselves perceive it to be. There are three great points to which they are now directing attention, and upon which they exhaust all their powers of logic and appeal -- negro conscription, the development of their internal manufacturing resources, and the raising of money to pay the expenditures of the war.
headline: {'main': 'Southern Opinions of Southern Resources.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Southern Opinions of Southern Resources.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Gen; Official Report; Capture of Fort Fisher; Official Report, Capture of Fort Fisher; Gen Terry's Report of Capture
snippet: Gen; Official Report; Capture of Fort Fisher; Official Report, Capture of Fort Fisher; Gen Terry's Report of Capture
lead_paragraph: -- We give to-day Gen. TERRY's official report of the capture of Fort Fisher. It is an admirable sketch of one of the most admirable operations of the war. From beginning to end, everything worked well. Not until the eight thousand infantry with the artillery were embarked on transports in the James, did Lieut.-Gen. GRANT, who personally accompanied Gen. TERRY down the river, inform the Commander of the expedition that Fort Fisher was the point against which he was destined to operate; yet so perfect were the preparations, and so minute the instructions of the Lieutenant-General, that everything was ready and the "vessels sailed at the appointed hour." And from that moment till the fall of the great fortification -- from the time that Gen. TERRY himself made a personal reconnoisance of the work, getting within six hundred yards of it, till the day after, when the assault was begun, and our gallant troops sprang from their trenches and dashed forward in line, onward till late in the night when the fort was captured, with 169 pieces of heavy artillery and 2,083 rebel officers and men -- the execution of every detail and of the whole operation exhibited consummate skill.

abstract: There was no independent demonstration in this city yesterday, and all, therefore, who could get away, visited New-York, to see the great procession. The streets were lined with people from an early hour till 3 o'clock in the afternoon, on their way to the different ferries, and it is estimated that Brooklyn contributed not less than 75,000 to the throngs which lined Broadway, the Bowery, and other thoroughfares through which the procession passed. Flags were displayed from the public buildings, liberty-poles, and private houses generally. The places of business were all closed after 1 o'clock, and everything presented the aspect of a holiday.

abstract: Celebration; The Great Loyal
snippet: Celebration; The Great Loyal
lead_paragraph: The least thoughtful observer that witnessed yesterday's celebration must have been struck less by the vast aggregate of the population that turned out for the occasion, than by the preponderating numbers of hale, hearty and vigorous young men represented alike in the military and in the firemen's part of the procession, and among the dense and countless multitude of onlookers. Looking to this salient feature of the celebration, it became difficult to realize that the country had passed through four years of warfare, -- warfare, in presence of which the greatest of modern conflicts become almost dwarfed by comparison. In and along side of the vast procession of yesterday -- a procession which barely found room in seven miles of thoroughfare, there must have been gathered at least two hundred thousand men as fit -- all but in discipline -- for service with GRANT or SHERMAN or SHERIDAN or CANBY, as the veterans of the Potomac, the Cumberland, the Tennessee, or the Mississippi Armies. Contemplating such a demonstration, in these purely physical aspects, it would perhaps be difficult to present to the ordinary class of outside observers a more tangible and appreciable proof than was offered yesterday, of the exhaustless material forces which, after a prolonged and stupendous war, the country has at its disposition. As a mere congregation of the masses -- from among a city and suburban population of two millions -- there is nothing in the history of New-York celebrations to compare with that of yesterday. And if every other element of success had been wanting, that grand and impressive feature -- the outpouring of a vast community -- would have made the demonstration memorable for at least a generation to come.

abstract: arrangements were admirable. At 10 o'clock in the morning the police Captains reported for instructions at the Central Department, No. 300 Mulberry-street. At 11 they were in their respective station-houses, ready to lead their men to the places which had been assigned them. The original programme was followed to the letter. In each downtown precinct three platoons were retained for duty in their own precinct, and one was drawn off to the line of march, and from precincts north of the Park three platoons from each were sent to the line, and one was retained for home duty. The Detective Police, under Sergeant JOHN S. YOUNG, were distributed along Broadway, at places which are known to be the favorite haunts of pickpockets. The procession was headed by ten mounted policemen, led by Inspector DANIEL CARPENTER and Sergeant SCHOONMAKER, and these were followed by the well-known Broadway Squad, under Sergeant VAN HAGEN. President THOS. C. ACTON, Superintendent JOHN A. KENNEDY, and Treasurer WM. MCMURRAY, chiefs of the Department, followed in a barouche, and then followed the military column. Arrived at Union-square, the force reported to Capt. T.S. COPELAND.

abstract: Imported from England; English Convicts arrived at Castle Garden
snippet: Imported from England; English Convicts arrived at Castle Garden
lead_paragraph: In the ship Plymouth Rock, which arrived at Castle Garden from London yesterday morning, were eight English convicts, who had been sentenced to serve terms of from three to four years in English prisons, but had been released before their time expired. From the statements made by these persons it appears that the Prison Aid Society of England paid their passage to this country, amounting to £4 sterling each, and also gave them each ten shillings for incidental expenses, the money being the proceeds of their overwork while in prison.

abstract: Convicts sent from England
snippet: Convicts sent from England
lead_paragraph: WANTED, -- Congress failed to pass the law we suggested and urged, to prevent the importation into this country of released convicts and ruffians from the prisons of Great Britain; but in the absence of a general law prohibiting the immigration, under any circumstances, of foreign criminals, we are glad to observe that the local authorities are exercising vigilance to prevent our being overrun by "ticket-of-leave" men, at least. Still another batch of these men arrived here yesterday from London in the ship Plymouth Rock -- five Englishmen, two Irishmen, one German -- four of them under conviction of felony, one of larceny, one for receiving stolen goods, and two for other crimes. They were all,on their arrival, promptly sent to Police Headquarters, and, it is understood, will be sent back to England.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: The day was observed in Jersey City yesterday by a general suspension of business, and a display of flags from the public buildings, shipping, and from private dwellings. The Cunard steamship was profusely decorated with flags and streamers, presenting a gay appearance, as was also the Jersey City and Hoboben ferry-boats. Immense throngs of people went to New-York to witness the procession, and probably there never was before a day when so many people crossed the river. The railroad trains were also crowded during the entire day.

abstract: We have Savannah and Charleston papers to the 2d inst. The main feature in the news is Gov. BROWN'S Message to the Georgia Legislature,  a brief synopsis of which we published a few days ago. The document is a vigorous and unsparing denunciation of JEFF. DAVIS' govermental policy.
lead_paragraph: We have Savannah and Charleston papers to the 2d inst. The main feature in the news is Gov. BROWN's Message to the Georgia Legislature, a brief synopsis of which we published a few days ago. The document is a vigorous and unsparing denunciation of JEFF. DAVIS' govermental policy. We have, also, a rebel account of the surrender of Columbia, the capital of South Carolina, and the subsequent destruction by fire of a large portion of the city. The rebel troops left on the 17th ult.; Gov. MAGRATH started on the 18th, and BEAUREGARD went on the same day. The public stores were thrown open and every one helped himself. Mayor GOODWIN surrendered the city to SHERMAN, and his troops forthwith began the destruction of all public property, such as depots, arsenals and Government shops. Several hours after this work begun, some sparks accidentally fired a lot of cotton, and from this the fire spread until the entire business portion of the city was destroyed. The Union troops were under strict discipline, and no outrages were perpetrated. The fine appearance of SHERMAN's army is noted by the rebel author of this account.

abstract: At a meeting of the Board of Aldermen, yesterday, the Committee on Ordinances reported an ordinance prohibiting the storage of petroleum, benzine, naptha, &c., either crude or refined, within the city limits, in quantities exceeding five barrels. The oil to be kept in cellars communicating with the public sewers. Refined petroleum to stand a fire test of 115 degrees; crude, 140 degrees. Penalty for violation of the provisions of the ordinance $500. The ordinance was laid over. An offer was received from the New-York Peoples' Gas-light Company, to light the City Hall Park lamps for $30 each, per annum. Mr. MCKNIGHT presented a resolution, directing the Comptroller to make a deduction from the Gas Companies' bills for public lamps remaining unlighted. Both papers were referred to the Committee on Lamps and Gas, and the board adjourned.
lead_paragraph: At a meeting of the Board of Aldermen, yesterday, the Committee on Ordinances reported an ordinance prohibiting the storage of petroleum, benzine, naptha, &c., either crude or refined, within the city limits, in quantities exceeding five barrels. abstract: New-Jersey R; Collision, Great Slaughter; New Jersey Railroad and great Slaughter
snippet: New-Jersey R; Collision, Great Slaughter; New Jersey Railroad and great Slaughter
lead_paragraph: ANOTHER RAILROAD CATASTROPHE. -- Another railroad catastrophe, scarcely more appalling from the number of killed and wounded, than from the utter and criminal indifference which caused it, is recorded this morning. It occurred at an early hour yesterday, on the Trenton (New-Jersey) Railroad, at Bristol Station. The story is a short one. What is called the "owl" train, bound for New-York, after having waited four hours (behind its time) for southern passengers at Trenton, started on its journey about one o'clock in the morning, and shortly afterward overtook a freight train which it pushed on ahead of itself; the conductor and engineer being evidently indifferent to two facts of the most vital consequence to the ill-fated passengers. The first of these facts was the great lessening of speed caused by the double train which the engine had to propel. The second was, that the Washington night train was all but due, and was rushing after the coupled trains with lightning speed. The story need go no further. About forty persons were injured to the extent of broken spines, arms, legs and so forth. Six, perhaps more fortunate, were killed outright. And thus the wholesale slaughter goes on, from day to day -- from week to week, and an innocent directory soberly shakes its head and thinks regretfully -- of diminished dividends.

abstract: Inauguration Bail
snippet: Inauguration Bail
lead_paragraph: The Washington "season" is past, and there certainly could not have been a more magnificent nor graceful finale; not alone to the Winter's gaities, but to the ceremonies which have made ABRAHAM LINCOLN our President again for the next four years, than the time-honored National Inauguration Ball which came off last night; and it is entirely appropriate that not alone with firing of cannon and waving of banners, in which men alone participate, but with music and dancing should we meet and celebrate this signal occasion, when the gentlemen are expected to be as gallant, and the ladies as lovely as possible.

abstract: Rebel, from Virginia to Alabama, all Moonshine; American Federation; Prospects of
snippet: Rebel, from Virginia to Alabama, all Moonshine; American Federation; Prospects of
lead_paragraph: A fitting sequel to the celebration of Monday would be the reappointment of the committee (whose labors did so much to make that celebration a success,) as an auxiliary, say for two or three weeks, of the County Volunteer Committee. Such a cooperative movement would tax the time of the gentlemen who took the leading part in the National demonstration; but it would first of all secure the funds necessary for recruiting purposes. It would next afford a convincing proof that the leading citizens of New-York take a practical view of the best way of doing honor to those who are fighting the national battles -- by sending them reinforcements, to make the work short, sharp and decisive. It would save the city from the draft. And it would set an example to other communities which would be imitated far and wide.

abstract: Gov Brown, of, Message on War; Gov Brown, Message on the War; Message on the War; Government, Tyranny of; Gov. Brown's Exposure
snippet: Gov Brown, of, Message on War; Gov Brown, Message on the War; Message on the War; Government, Tyranny of; Gov. Brown's Exposure
lead_paragraph: We have already given an abstract of the message of Gov. BROWN, of Georgia. From the complete copy, just received, we quote further. The Governor begins by complaining that Georgia was stripped of her troops by the Confederate Government, and had only a few boys and old men left to oppose SHERMAN's veteran army. The destruction of SHERMAN's army, he says, "would have reinspired our people with hope, depressed the spirits of our enemies, and might have prepared the way speedily for the negotiation of an honorable peace. It could have been done by the Georgia troops if permitted. It should have been done at the expense, if necessary, of the evacuation of Richmond, and the use of Gen. LEE's whole army thrown rapidly into Georgia for that purpose. No one would regret more than I do to see that city, which has been so long and so nobly defended, surrender to the enemy; but it must be admitted, since the devastation of the country beyond, that it is now only a strong outpost of little military importance, compared with the great interior. It must also be admitted that Richmond is rendered insecure by the successes of Gen. SHERMAN in the interior, and the position he has gained in the rear of that and other strongholds, which were relied on for defence. If his unobstructed movement through Georgia must result in the the loss of Richmond, how much better it would have been if we had given the evacuation of Richmond for the destruction of this army."

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The "Faust " performance last evening attracted a very brilliant audience sufficient demonstrate that GOUNOD'S great Opera has not yet lost its hold on the public. And it is
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The "Faust " performance last evening attracted a very brilliant audience sufficient demonstrate that GOUNOD'S great Opera has not yet lost its hold on the public. And it is right that it should not lose its hold on the public, for it is one of the few works that have brought the "many-headed multitude" to a consideration of something large, and out of the usual way. The performance last evening was excellent in all respects, and gave abundant satisfaction to the admirers of this standard work.

abstract: Forty days in the Wilderness, (S. C.)
snippet: Forty days in the Wilderness, (S. C.)
lead_paragraph: Gen. SHERMAN's army has been forty days in the State of South Carolina -- that is to say if he has not yet emerged from it. It was on the 27th of January that the last of the forces composing his left wing (which subsequently effected a junction with the right wing near Branchville) left the City of Savannah, and struck off boldly and baseless for the heart of the Rattlesnake State- Of his movements and operations for the first half of that time the rebels kept us pretty well informed. By the 17th of February he had worked his way through the swamps on the north side of the Savannah River, had taken Branchville and Orangeburgh; and on that day he entered the capital of the State. But since that time we may say that we know nothing whatever of SHERMAN's great army, except the fact that after two or three days it left Columbia and marched onward with its face to the North. It is certainly a remarkable circumstance that we should be in complete ignorance of the movements and fortunes of an army of such magnitude, and whose operations are of such supreme importance, when it cannot be at a distance of more than 400 miles due south of Washington, and when it is certainly less than a hundred miles distant from the seacoast, which is thickly covered with our naval ships. But the probability is that neither Gen. SHERMAN nor Lieut-Gen. GRANT is over-anxious to give the Northern public and the Southern rebels very prompt bulletins of our army's daily movements, its line of advance, or its ultimate objective. It would be no great gain to us to have SHERMAN do this; all the gain would be to the rebels. Were they to give us any information they may have, we should be obliged to them, even though much of it turned out inaccurate; but the rebel soul, speaking through the rebel press, has been ordered by the rebel authorities to keep from us every item of news on this subject; and hence for twenty days we have only been able to screw from them the unintelligible intelligence that SHERMAN was not at Charlotte, that he was not at Fayetteville, that his army was marching in directions as divergent as Chester and Cheraw, and that there was a rumor in Richmond that he had been killed and his "army routed and driven into the jungles." Now, the last item has at least the merit of being of some size; but when we recall their old story about SHERMAN's army "floundering through the swamps of Georgia," when, in fact, it was enjoying a charming promenade and daily dinners of turkey and chicken, we are inclined to take "driven into the jungles" with a considerable quantity of salt. As for the few rumors from our own side that have reached us during the past three weeks, time has already proven most of them to be incorrect.

abstract: THE NEW RAMS OF THE REBELS. -- Our Consul at Halifax has telegraphed to Washington a report that one of the French rebel rams has succeeded in making port in one of the West India Islands. The report is yet unauthenticated; but it will be wisdom in the Navy Department to act, and to act promptly, on an assumption of its truth. There ought to be no excuse for this new scourge getting among our shipping off the coast, or even getting clear of her present harborage.

abstract: Colonial Settlement of
snippet: Colonial Settlement of
lead_paragraph: In the House of Lords on the 23d February, Lord WHARNCLIFFE asked the Government what was the position of the question of the settlement of a crown colony in the northwest territory of British America, and when some report would be made to the House upon the subject. He stated that the territory between Upper Canada and the Rocky Mountains was at the present moment of great importance; and it was a matter of considerable interest to know what course was to be pursued with respect to it. Two methods had been proposed, namely: that the territory should be united to Canada, or erected into a separate colony. His own opinion was that it would be unwise to unite so large a tract of land, one so capable of improvement, to Canada, and that the best course would be to erect it into an independent settlement.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, bills were reported favorably incorporating the Union Hotel Company; incorporating the Manhattan Fire Insurance, Company; incorporating the New-York and Point Isabel Land and Emigration Company.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, bills were reported favorably incorporating the Union Hotel Company; incorporating the Manhattan Fire Insurance, Company; incorporating the New-York and Point Isabel Land and Emigration Company. Bills were noticed for the relief of Broadway by the construction of a railroad on parallel streets; to regulate the price of gas throughout the State; relative to the Court of Special Sessions in New-York. Bills were introduced incorporating the United States Petroleum Floating Storage Company; incorporating the Student Aid Association of the New-York Free Academy; incorporating the New-York City Law Societies. Bills were passed incorporating the Brooklyn Market Company; repealing the act to facilitate the closing up of disabled and insolvent Mutual Insurance Companies; also the Bank Enabling Act. At the evening session the Metropolitan Health bill was referred with power to report complete.

abstract: Duerios Don Francisco, elected Constitutional President; State Election, Aggregate Result of
snippet: Duerios Don Francisco, elected Constitutional President; State Election, Aggregate Result of
lead_paragraph: The grand effort to connect the Old and New Worlds by telegraph, by way of Behring's Straits, is now fairly commenced. On Tuesday the steamer Shubrick sailed from San Francisco for Sitka, or New-Archangel, in Russian-America, bearing the pioneer exploring company for the line. She will land a party at Victoria, whose business is to work up through the Frazer River region until they connect with the Russian-American branch. Thence they proceed through the unexplored regions between the regular Rocky Mountains and the Coast Range to the Youcan River, and so on to the neighborhood of Cape Prince of Wales. These cold and inhospitable regions are quite unknown, save from the dubious reports of the aborigines, and the reports of the lightning explorers' tolls will have all the charm of history from a New World. The line now running from San Francisco through Oregon will soon be completed to New-Westminster, and by this connection we shall get frequent reports of the progress of the great work.

abstract: A very interesting entertainment was given last evening by the Sunday School of the Statestreet Congressional Church of Brooklyn, at the Academy of Music, which was quite a success.
lead_paragraph: A very interesting entertainment was given last evening by the Sunday School of the Statestreet Congressional Church of Brooklyn, at the Academy of Music, which was quite a success. The entertainment consisted of singing, recitation, declamation and dialogue, the programme being most pleasingly gone through by the children of the school, upward of 400 of whom, boys and girls, were on the stage, beautifully dressed, and each bearing a miniature flag of the Union. The Academy was completely filled, parquet, boxes and galleries.
