abstract: Seaports of the Confederacy
snippet: Seaports of the Confederacy
lead_paragraph: We have practical evidence, from two widely-distant points, of the effect upon the fortunes of rebeldom of the capture of the last remaining ports of the South. The Richmond papers of Saturday announced the appointment of a special agent by Gen. LEE, to collect whatever in the shape of old muskets, swords, pikes, pistols and sabres could be found in any remnant of the Confederacy to which, he might be able to find access. The steamer Cuba, with news ten day old from Europe, brought word last night that the "Confederate Government" have countermanded large orders for torpedoes. These incidents convey to the world, in a far more pointed form than any official bulletin, the information that the Confederacy is and has been dependent upon importation for arms to make good the large stock that has fallen by capture, at different times, into the hands of our armies. They likewise advertise the complete exclusion of the rebels from commercial intercourse with foreign ports. Torpedoes are no longer a marketable commodity in the Southern market, because they can find no port of entrance and no blockade-runners to take them even as speculative freight. All the British blockade-running ports, from Nova Scotia to New-Providence, are filled with enterprising craft, laden with Confederate ammunition and stores, but unable even to venture within sight of the coast-line of the Confederacy. And the "neutral" interest on both sides of the Atlantic is drooping and despondent to a degree which has no precedent in the history of this war.

abstract: A concert and exhibition were given last evening at the Academy of Music, for the Sunday School of the State-street Congregational Church of Brooklyn, which proved to be an entire success.
lead_paragraph: A concert and exhibition were given last evening at the Academy of Music, for the Sunday School of the State-street Congregational Church of Brooklyn, which proved to be an entire success. The getting up was neat, the programme most pleasantly gone through, and the Academy was filled from parquet to roof-tree. On the stage, the children, numbering some 400. boys and girls, occupied seats. The white dresses of the latter, over which were worn red scarfs and red hoods, and each child holding a miniature flag of the Union, formed a very beautiful scene.

abstract: Virginia and North Carolina on Arming Slaves; Virginia and North Carolina Legislatures on
snippet: Virginia and North Carolina on Arming Slaves; Virginia and North Carolina Legislatures on
lead_paragraph: There is something significant in the opposite views taken in the Legislatures of Virginia and North Carolina, on the question of arming the slaves. The Virginia Legislature resolves almost unanimously in favor of arming. The General Assembly of North Carolina petitions against putting negroes into the army without the consent of the States. Such is the report of the Richmond Sentinel of Monday. It is clear, we take it, from this, that North Carolina is not anxious to see the depleted ranks of the rebel army filled up at all. She has less to lose from the partial emancipation which Gen. LEE says must accompany a negro conscription, than has Virginia. The mass of the citizens of North Carolina are far, less wedded to slavery as an institution, than the people of the rebel section of Virginia. The point is, that the latter believes Gen. LEE's declaration, when he urges that arming the negroes has become a necessity, if the South is to continue to fight; while the North Carolina Assembly apparently fails to see the necessity of continuing to fight, and, therefore, ignores, in a logical way, the other necessity -- of arming the negroes.

abstract: Reform Struggle in, the (Ed); Reform Struggle in
snippet: Reform Struggle in, the (Ed); Reform Struggle in
lead_paragraph: In our American struggle against a barbarous aristocracy, we are in danger of forgetting the great contest which is still going on in a distant country, between the last relics of a feudal caste and the representative of the progressive ideas of this century. In Russia, the Emperor acts and speaks for the great democratic masses, and the struggle which the last century witnessed in France, between the governing power of Paris and the rural noblesse, is repeated now between the Czar and the country nobility of Poland and Russia. The act of emancipation there, as here, has nearly destroyed a class. The gentry are in many cases, stripped of immense wealth; the emancipated serfs often refuse to pay rents for property which they regard as their own; the legal prerogatives of the masters are taken away, and their great privilege of selecting recruits for the military service is abolished by a new system of conscription. Some find themselves owners of large tracts of lands, forests and mines, which are unimproved and without laborers to work upon them. Others are entirely beggared and all have lost their prestige and high position with the peasantry. To add to the discomfiture of the smaller gentry, the law providing for the admission of delegates to one of the Provincial Diets, that of Moscow, required a certain amount of property, which these persons are deprived of by the Act of Emancipation, so that, after much discussion, they have been necessarily excluded from their own Provincial Assembly. So far has this deprivation of the nobility proceeded, that the representative of one of the oldest families of the Russian aristocracy, and holding the office of Grand Chamberlain at court, Count ORLOFF, ventured to say in open Diet that soon "the Emperor will be not only the first but the only gentleman in Russia."
headline: {'main': 'The Reform Struggle in Russia.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Reform Struggle in Russia.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The steamship Cuba brings three days' later intelligence from Europe. The late peace negotiations at Hampton Roads, and the shadowy hint by Mr. SEWARD that American arms might possibly find something to do beyond the lines of the United States, have excited a lively discussion in the columns of the English press. Strict neutrality is urgently advised by even the Times, while the propriety of looking to an increase of the military and naval power of Great Britain is a favorite text for leading editorials. The rebel organ in London, the Index, tauntingly adds that, "for the present, the army of Gen. LEE is the defence of Canada, but English statesmen ought to be aware by this time how very precarious is the duration of the war. A month or two might at any time suffice to settle the simple terms of peace, and if those months shall fall in the beginning of Winter, Canada would be at the mercy of Mr. LINCOLN's Government and Gen. SHERMAN's army." It is reported that France has given the American Government the assurance that no Mexican territory has been ceded. The Tycoon of Japan has agreed to a convention with the English Ambassador, guaranteeing the free navigation of the inland seas of his empire, and allowing the establishment of an English Consulate at Simonasaki. VICTOR EMMANUEL returned to Turin on the 23d ult., and was cordially received. The Austrian Minister of State is trying to force the lower house of the Legislature to stop talking, and vote upon the budget for 1865-66, but the Representatives send him word that they will discuss as long as they please. The Ducal Palace at Brunswick has been burned. Cardinal WISEMAN's funeral was celebrated with great pomp in London on the 23d. At a reform meeting in London, composed of delegates from the various trades unions, a reform league was formed, upon the basis of manhood suffrage and vote by ballot.

abstract: Col. BAKER learned, recently, that gross irregularities, if not outright frauds, had been tolerated in the Ninth District, under the Provost-Marshalship of Capt. DUNNING, and he accordingly sent thither a reconnoitering force of United States detective officers.
lead_paragraph: Col. BAKER learned, recently, that gross irregularities, if not outright frauds, had been tolerated in the Ninth District, under the Provost-Marshalship of Capt. DUNNING, and he accordingly sent thither a reconnoitering force of United States detective officers. The information which they gathered during their first essay assured the Colonel that the rumor which had reached him was well founded, and he bade his subordinates keep on the alert. One of the results of their further researches (which may now for the first time be printed) was the apprehension of one JACOB DEPEW, Assistant Provost-Marshal under Capt. DUNNING, for compounding a felony. It is alleged to have been DEPEW's practice to take bounty-jumpers and other prisoners from DUNNING's office, in Broadway, near Forty-seventh-street, and permit them to escape while on the route to Hart's Island or elsewhere, and he is supposed to have realized large profits from this source. The case on which he was arrested was clear -- Col. BAKER's instructions to his force being that they shall clinch every necessary fact before undertaking to seize any person. They took the prisoner to the Astor Mouse, and as he had in charge several prisoners that were to be taken to the island, Col. BAKER released him on parole until 4 o'clock in the afternoon of the day of his arrest-Monday of last week. Promptly at 4 o'clock the Assistant Provost-Marshal reported at the War Department Special Agency, and demanded a view of the affidavits upon which he had been taken into custody. Col. BAKER exhibited the affidavits, and DEPEW, having read and revised the papers, desired to know what Col. BAKER intended to do in the premises. "Send you to Washington for trial. Sir." quietly responded the Colonel. "Perhaps not," was the rejoinder of Assistant Provost-Marshal DEPEW, as he unfolded the order from Maj.-Gen. DIX, absolutely forbidding the taking hence of any officer within the limits of the Department of the East. Col. BAKER released the prisoner on the instant, resolved that if he was thus to encounter, at the hands of a truly loyal and highly esteemed officer like Gen. DIX, the obstacles which beset his path in the beginning in this city, and which obstacles he had scattered to the winds, he would yield his position.

abstract: I find there are many here who seriously believe that Gen. LEE contemplates the early evacuation of Richmond, and that he will probably seize upon the present opportunity for carrying out that intention. They reason somewhat congently that, as ...
lead_paragraph: I find there are many here who seriously believe that Gen. LEE contemplates the early evacuation of Richmond, and that he will probably seize upon the present opportunity for carrying out that intention. They reason somewhat congently that, as the roads are now in a condition to render it almost impossible for this army to follow him, he could take advantage of that circumstance, and, with the facilities afforded by his two remaining lines of railway communication, succeed not only in getting his army away, but in saving all, or nearly all, his military stores. Those who entertain this theory think it not unlikely that the sentiments expressed by the Richmond press, antagonistic to the evacuation of the capital city of their inchoate nation, are purposely assumed with a view to mislead our authorities until the move is accomplished. In support of their theory, they call attention to the fact that cars are constantly running on the Southside Railroad, and the whistle of the locomotives can be heard at all hours, night and day. It is plausible to suppose that, if evacuation is intended, it will be sought to consummate it while the present favorable circumstances continue; but from any facts known on this side, the entire theory must consist of mere speculation.

abstract: Cession of Territory to France
snippet: Cession of Territory to France
lead_paragraph: The news from France received by the Cuba is altogether of a less oracular, and of a decidedly more satisfactory character than we have received for many months. The Emperor's Government has given assurance to our representative, that no cession has been made to France of Mexican territory, and that the transaction in the matter of the Northern provinces resolves itself simply into a lien on the product of certain mines. His explanation, accompanied as it is by a denial of any intention to recognize the "Confederacy," is said to have caused intense depression in all the rebel circles of Paris. Although there may be some reasons for not accepting in its literal sense every sort of assurance, even if it comes officially, from this quarter, still there could be no greater error than to foster suspicions against the bona fides of a foreign Power, which has, thus far, given us no cause for an open quarrel, and even less cause for protest and remonstrance, than certain others. It is better to believe that the Emperor's Government says what it means, and to avoid the foolish business of discounting difficulties which, under sagacious management, need have no existence.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The fifth performance of "La Forza del Destino, attracted an exceedingly  good house last evening, notwithstanding the filthy condition of the streets and the abominable state of the weather. The artists, by that strange but happy coincidence which always signalizes a bad night, sang with unusual spirit, and were all in excellent condition. The opera has rarely been heard to greater advantage, and seldom has it been received with greater ...
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The fifth performance of "La Forza del Destino, attracted an exceedingly good house last evening, notwithstanding the filthy condition of the streets and the abominable state of the weather. The artists, by that strange but happy coincidence which always signalizes a bad night, sang with unusual spirit, and were all in excellent condition. The opera has rarely been heard to greater advantage, and seldom has it been received with greater favor. It is a pity, that a success so marked and acceptable in every way should be interrupted by the necessities of the ending season. The expense and care that have been bestowed on this work would justify a run of an entire season in any European capital. It would have been reserved, too, for the opening of the season, not prodigally bestowed on the end of it, as by Mr. MARETZEK.

abstract: Chatham-street, Clothing-store--$1,000; Biography
snippet: Chatham-street, Clothing-store--$1,000; Biography
lead_paragraph: THE CITIZEN. -- This journal, which was established some months since, under the auspices of the Citizens' Association, having for its special aim the promotion and advancement of the vast material interests of this city, came to us last week in an enlarged form, fall of evidence of ability in its editorial conduct, and very handsome in its typographical appearance. Its discussions of all topics bearing upon good government, public morals and the vital necessities of municipal reform, are thorough and practical, while the miscellaneous departments of current literary and art news, and domestic and foreign matters, are prepared with great care and excellent taste, making it take rank at once as a first-class family journal. The chosen field of the Citizen's labor is one which requires faithful and earnest workers, such as the proprietors promise to be, and their efforts should receive the hearty countenance of all persons who have at heart the best interests of the city.

abstract: The shocking disaster of Monday night, or rather Tuesday morning, on the Camden and Amboy Railroad, has aroused public feeling to a greater degree than any of the innumerable railroad accidents that have occurred for many months past.
lead_paragraph: The shocking disaster of Monday night, or rather Tuesday morning, on the Camden and Amboy Railroad, has aroused public feeling to a greater degree than any of the innumerable railroad accidents that have occurred for many months past. The large number of killed and maimed, (between fifty and sixty,) the recklessness and negligence of the responsible parties, and the heartrending circumstances connected with the affair, have combined to stir up the whole community, and to give the matter a very personal interest to each one of the vast multitude which are ceaselessly in transit over this great thoroughfare.

lead_paragraph: Richmond papers, of the 6th and 7th, are quite barren of news, but full of wonderful speculations and prophecies of great events about to burst into history. They acknowledge the close surveillance of the military censor, and, like sensible fellows, take it for granted that it is all for the best. Last night, however, we received some remarkable extracts from leading Richmond journals, indicating beyond mistake that the death-agony of the rebellion is now at hand. The articles will be found on another page.

abstract: We give from the Richmond Whig a very vivacious and vivid account of the scenes preceding and attending the entrance of SHERMAN's army into the Capital of South Carolina. His arrival there was utterly unexpected, and confusion and plunder on the part of the rebels reached its height. So terrible were the barbarities of WHEELER's rebel cavalry, that even this South Carolina writer declares that either the "Yankees or old Satan himself," would be preferable. SHERMAN's treatment of the citizens, we are told, was uniformly lenient and conciliatory. BEAUREGARD, it seems, had only a "little army." We are informed that in South Carolina and its capital, our troops march along "singing with tremendous energy Union songs." Such were some of the sights and scenes in South Carolina during the late eventful month of February.

abstract: Jersey City; Collision on
snippet: Jersey City; Collision on
lead_paragraph: The passengers by the train from Washington, Baltimore and Philadelphia, which arrived at 11 last night, were subjected to a long delay by an accident in crossing the river. The ferry-boat D.S. Gregory had just left its dock at Jersey City, when, in the dense fog, it was run into by the J.S. Darcie, going the other way, with great violence. The forward cabin of the Darcie was completely crushed, and all the forward wood-work on the Gregory was demolished. It was found also that the two boats were so closely locked together that they could not be separated, and both, therefore, drifted downward with the tide. They came almost immediately upon two schooners anchored in the stream, head up, one of which thrust her bowsprit with a tremendous crash entirely through the cabin of the Gregory, and the other just escaped a similar performance. All four then, drifted together upon four or five more, but without any further damage. Signal lights were immediately shown, whistles blown and bells rung, but it was not until half-past one that any assistance could be brought. The Jersey City, belonging to the same line, then came down and took off the passengers landing them at New-York dock at 2 o'clock. No one was injured, but the two ferry boats were considerably damaged. There seemed to be nobody in effective command of either, and it was not until Mr. WOOLSEY, the Superintendent, arrived, that anything practical seemed to be done toward relieving the passengers from their awkward predicament.
headline: {'main': 'Ferry Accident.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Ferry Accident.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: army in Sherman's front
snippet: army in Sherman's front
lead_paragraph: Our Charleston correspondent says that the army which BEAUREGARD took with him from Columbia, upon SHERMAN's entrance into that place, numbered eight thousand men. This is the nucleus of the force which JOE JOHNSTON has in North Carolina, in SHERMAN's front. Beside this, part of HARDEE's refugee army from Charleston may have gotten up with JOHNSTON, wherever he may be. Then there is HOKE's refugees from Wilmington, which, according to the great rebel policy of concentration, lately adopted, were to be sent to increase JOHNSTON's numbers; but which, according to our latest advices, were contesting SCHOFIELD's advance up the western side of Cape Fear River, by resolutely remaining on the eastern side of that stream. Then there are the three divisions which we have been fifty times told LEE has sent to North Carolina. Then we have been told, but do not believe it, that the remnant of HOOD's well-flogged veterans have made an astoundingly rapid march across the broad States of Mississippi, Alabama, Georgia and South Carolina, and have joined their old Commander, JOHNSTON, under whom they were so frequently whipped before HOOD superseded him. As for the North Carolina and South Carolina militia, if any such there be, we do not count them at all; for it was SHERMAN's experience in Georgia that the greater the number of rebel militia, the easier they were routed.

abstract: JOS. WIBEL, a substitute-broker, was brought hither from Elmira yesterday, accused of defrauding the Government. He was innocent, of course, Col. BAKER summoned two soldiers, and inquired whether WIBEL had seen them before. "Yes; he enlisted them at Elmira." "And have you ever seen this coat?" asked Col. BAKER, pulling off one of the soldier's coats and exposing the attire of a civilian. These soldiers were two whom WIBEL had reenlisted, knowing them at the time to be in the service; and the coat was one which WIBEL had given them to complete their disguise. WIBEL was sent off to the Old Capitol Prison last night. A.W. NATHANS, a bounty-broker, whose recent operations have been mainly confined to the purchase and sale of substitutes in Hoboken and Williamsburgh, was also sent to the Old Capitol Prison last night. NATHANS charged citizens $1,000 for substitutes, and paid the men about $200. Other arrests were made yesterday, and the prisoners were held, last night, at the Special Agency of the War Department.

abstract: Preservation of, Liverpool Shipping Gazette
snippet: Preservation of, Liverpool Shipping Gazette
lead_paragraph: "In proof of the anti-corrosive and anti-fouling properties of the GISBORNE paint, we are in a position to speak from actual observation, for we yesterday inspected the African Steamship Company's steamer Macgregor Laird, in the Sandon Dock, the one side of the bottom of which had been coated with the GISBORNE paint as a trial against another patent paint, when the ship was last in Liverpool. Since the paint was applied, the vessel has made a passage from this port to the West Coast of Africa, and now, on being docked, for the purpose of having her bottom cleaned, it was found that the side on which GISBORNE's paint had been used was not only free from all fouling by vegetable matter and marine animals, but there was no need for the use of the scraper or paint brush before the vessel again proceeds to sea. Not so on the other side, on which was used the paint that was to test the comparative qualities of Mr. GISBORNE's. Barnacles covered the bottom of the ship on that side, at stem and stern, where the two paints joined, and it was remarkable to see the one side comparatively covered with marine animals and the other completely free. This is the only Liverpool ship upon which the efficacy of the GISBORNE paint has been fairly tried and the result known, but she is not the only one on which it has been used. In addition to the satisfaction which the experiment on the Achilles gave, several London merchant vessels have been coated with the paint, and with equally satisfactory results. The best proof of the entire satisfaction given to the African Steamship Company's agents is that they have instructed the Liverpool agents of the GISBORNE paint to have the entire bottom of the Macgregor Laird covered with it before she leaves the dock."

The rebel authorities do not seem to tire of beseeching Heaven for favor on their wicked cause, though the only answers vouchsafed are new disasters and sharper suffering. Was there ever such infatuation?

abstract: News; Emigration authorized to
snippet: News; Emigration authorized to
lead_paragraph: We have some items of Mexican news to-day, but nothing to show that there is any material change in the situation. Some emphasis appears to be laid upon the fact that a number of emigrants had arrived from the United States, at Vera Cruz. These emigrants are represented as being the pioneers of an American Colony which, before the war closes, will include a population of 25,000 settlers. If we are to credit the reports from Vera Cruz, this emigration is largely subsidized. Those that have already arrived are furnished with money and provisions to enable them to take possession of certain lands appropriated for their special use. It is not easy to discover whence the subsidies for such a scheme of emigration as this can be drawn, in the present condition of the Imperial exchequer. Nor is it less difficult to found upon the report any theory of political advantage which can accrue to the "empire" from a large influx of American citizens, whose instincts, training and tendencies must necessarily be supposed to lean strongly toward republicanism. In the absence of any feasible theory to justify a vast scheme of subsidized colonization, we conclude that the scope of the enterprise has been magnified far beyond what the actual facts will warrant, or otherwise that the project is one of a different character from what it is represented to be.

abstract: Metropolitan Health Bill; Metropolitan Health Bill
snippet: Metropolitan Health Bill; Metropolitan Health Bill
lead_paragraph: -We regret to notice that this bill, which had been perfected with so much care, is undergoing serious changes at the hands of the Albany legislators. One of the most important features of such a measure is the construction of the board. All our present evils arise from the necessarily inefficient organizations which are to execute the health laws, and it is from this dilemma that we are endeavoring to escape. In a word, we need an intelligent, efficient and non-partisan Central Board, so related to the Police Department as to be able to avail itself constantly of its power and its vigilant inspection, while carrying on special sanitary inspection through its own skilled agents. The bill, therefore, created a Board of Health, composed of the four Police Commissioners and of four experienced physicians, with power (1) to establish a thorough and constant sanitary inspection of the city by skilled medical men; this inspection to extend to a constant search after the causes of unhealthiness, the existence of contagious diseases and the conditions upon which they depend, and all that relates to the internal sanitary state of our dwellings, with daily suggestions to the Central Board of remedial measures; (2) to direct a constant supervision by the police force of the streets, vacant lots, courts, alleys, cesspools and everything pertaining to the external sanitary condition of the houses of the people; (3) to execute any measures deemed necessary to protect or promote the public health.

abstract: Pacification of the South
snippet: Pacification of the South
lead_paragraph: There has probably been no result of the war so gratifying and reassuring to those who have been troubled with dismal forebodings as to the difficulty of pacifying the South, even after the rebels have ceased to be able to maintain large armies, as the revelation which it has made of the large vein of practicalness running through the character of the Southern people. There was probably nothing, for which, four years ago, we at the North were less disposed to give them credit. Their language as well as their acts, before and after the outbreak of the rebellion, fairly warranted the conclusion that they were a breed of crazy enthusiasts or romancers, -- moonstruck theorists whose conduct was not regulated by the ordinary rules or animated by the ordinary motives. The hairbrained speculations of their political philosophers upon the nature and objects of civil society, the wild rant of their orators and newspapers about slavery, the frantic style in which their politicians were in the habit of denouncing and threatening their enemies, the reckless disregard of parliamentary convenances displayed by their Congressmen, and the Indian ferocity and contempt for consequences which marked their mode of avenging private injuries -- all justified the belief that, if once roused into war, we might look for exhibitions of desperation that would throw Carthage, Thermopylae, Saragossa, Moscow, and even the defence of Holland against Louis XIV., into the shade. Many people expected that their resistance would not be regulated by policy; that passion -- and such passion! -- would preside over it from first to last, and that even the abolition of slavery would only be accomplished through the extermination of the white race.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- To-night VERDI's Opera, "La Forza del Destino," will be given for the last time during the present season, and, in consequence, for the last time until next Fall. The work has proved so acceptable to the public, and is now rendered in such a thorough manner, that the bare announcement of its withdrawal will suffice to fill the house to overflowing. There will be a Matinee to-morrow, (Saturday,) and subsequently (at the Brooklyn house) an evening performance of "Linda," for the benefit of Miss KELLOGG.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Revolutionary Frenzy in
snippet: Revolutionary Frenzy in
lead_paragraph: The extraordinary intelligence of the state of affairs at the rebel capital, which we get through the latest Richmond papers, indicate that the counter-revolution there has already assumed a very definite and decided character, and embraces on its side many of the leading and original rebels and fire-eaters of the Confederacy. There is a universal uproar on all hands. There is a panic at the approaching doom. The Richmond rebels appear to be so excited as to be almost unable to write coherently, There is no faith in anybody or anything. The Confederate Congress is giving way. JEFF. DAVIS and his henchmen are giving way. It would seem that even LIE is ready to consider terms. The questions which the Enquirer puts into the mouth of a correspondent, are doubtless questions put by the editor himself; and it is hard to say whether his queries or his responses are most significant. The Sentinel, which, as DAVIS' official organ, has always been so self-possessed in times of panic, is profoundly and madly moved. But let the reader observe the rebel statements and articles, and judge of the condition of the Confederacy and the state of its capital.

abstract: the New Rebel; Tax Law; The New
snippet: the New Rebel; Tax Law; The New
lead_paragraph: -Among other provisions of the Tax Bill passed by both Houses of the rebel Congress, on Tuesday, was one imposing a tax of eight per cent. on all property not specially taxed at a different rate. Following this, however, was a clause enacting that "all property within the enemy's lines is to be exempt from taxation." Considering where these "lines" extend into the Confederacy to-day, there is likely to be a considerable population exempt from this property tax in DAVIS' dominions.

abstract: Whiting, Gen W H C, Late of Fort Fisher
snippet: Whiting, Gen W H C, Late of Fort Fisher
lead_paragraph: -Maj.-Gen. W.H.C. WHITING, of the rebel army, who surrendered with the garrison of Fort Fisher to Gen. TERRY and Admiral PORTER, died yesterday at Governor's Island. The deceased was a native of Mississippi, about 45 years of age, and was educated at West Point, receiving his appointment from President TYLER. When he graduated (in 1845) he was assigned to duty, and remained in the United States service until Feb. 20, 1861, when he resigned his commission and joined the rebels in Georgia, having removed to that State after receiving his military education. He was soon afterward appointed a Brigadier-General by the rebels, and served under BEAUREGARD at Bull Run. He was in the Seven Days Battles, and was promoted to be a Major-General. Afterward he was sent to Wilmington, and the defences of Cape Fear River were constructed under his direction. He was considered, next to BEAUREGARD, the ablest engineer officer in the rebel service. The funeral will take place to-day at Trinity Church.

lead_paragraph: The United States vs. The Bark Augusta, Her Tackle, &c. -- This libel is predicated upon the first section of the Act of 22d March, 1794, and on the Act of April 20, 1818. It charges that the bark Augusta was fitted out and equipped in the port of New-York, on the 10th of November, 1861, for the purpose of carrying on a trade and traffic in slaves, and sailed from that port for that purpose.

abstract: By the arrival of the Dudley Buck, which left Newbern on Monday afternoon, the 6th inst., at 4 o'clock, we learn that up to Saturday night, the 4th inst., warm showers had been falling for a week, which had made the roads bad. It cleared off on Saturday night, and when the Dudley Buck left there was promise of good weather. The soil being sandy, the roads will be hard and good in a few days.

abstract: Proc to Deserters; President's Proclamation to
snippet: Proc to Deserters; President's Proclamation to
lead_paragraph: Whereas, The twenty-first section of the Act of Congress approved on the 3d inst., entitled "An Act to amend the several acts heretofore passed to provide for the enrolling and calling out the national forces and for other purposes," requires that in addition to the other lawful penalties of the crime of desertion from the military or naval service, "all persons who have deserted the military or naval service of the United States, who shall not return to said service of report themselves to a Provost-Marshal within sixty days after the proclamation hereinafter mentioned, shall be deemed and taken to have voluntarily relinquished and forfeited their rights of citizenship and their right to become citizens, and such deserters shall be forever incapable of holding any office of trust or profit under the United States, or of exercising any rights of citizens thereof; and all persons who shall hereafter desert the military or naval service, and all persons who, being duly enrolled, shall depart the jurisdiction of the district in which they are enrolled, or go beyond the limits of the United States, with intent to avoid any draft into the military or naval service duly ordered, shall be liable to the penalties of this section; and the President is hereby authorized and required forthwith, on the passage of this act, to issue his proclamation, setting forth the provisions of this section, in which proclamation the President is requested to notify all deserters returning within sixty days, as aforesaid, that they shall be pardoned, on condition of returning to their regiments and companies, or to such other other organizations as they may be assigned to, until they shall have served for a period of time equal to their original term of enlistment.

abstract: Secretary MCCULLOUGH has undertaken, at the suggestion of the Senate, a task which promises at once to signalize his accession to the Treasury, and to render a most essential service to the commercial and financial interests of the country. He is preparing a compact statement of our import and export trade, up to January of the present year, distinguishing the movement of gold and of other export staples. The report will furnish a comparison of the trade of the country for a period of four years previous to the war, with that of the last four years. The Secretary's statement will also supply a reliable basis on which to estimate the present financial condition of the country. We cannot too strongly commend this departmental undertaking, and no one will doubt the thoroughness with which it will be carried out.
lead_paragraph: Secretary MCCULLOUGH has undertaken, at the suggestion of the Senate, a task which promises at once to signalize his accession to the Treasury, and to render a most essential service to the commercial and financial interests of the country. abstract: Everything still remains quiet, up to the present time of writing; but the whole air, both on land and water, is filled with signs of that coming final struggle, which every one feels, from the very vastness of the preparations, must be decisive when the hour comes for striking. What these signs and preparations are, I do not consider fit for newspaper publication, or even speculation.

abstract: Interior, Secretary of; Mr. Harlan's Antecedents; Hostile Indians Mostly on Mo River, above Heart River; Appointed Minister, to Spain; Rebel Legislature Adjourned at some place unknown
snippet: Interior, Secretary of; Mr. Harlan's Antecedents; Hostile Indians Mostly on Mo River, above Heart River; Appointed Minister, to Spain; Rebel Legislature Adjourned at some place unknown
lead_paragraph: We have the following items of Indian news from St. Paul: Gen. SIBLEY has received late advices from Fort Wadsworth. Dispatches from the scouts' camp on the James River represent that all or a greater portion of the hostile Indian tribes are at Painted Wood, on the Missouri River, thirty miles above Heart River. About two hundred lodges of Teton Sioux are at the Forked Butte, a short distance from Swan Lake. Between fifty and sixty lodges of Yanktons and Yanktonais are on the Missouri Coteau near the head of Elm River, coming down toward the James M-DO-KA, a Yanktonais chief, is on Snake River, which is tributary to the James, with eighty lodges. One hundred and twelve lodges were at Oak Grove, on the James, on their way to Elm River for a hunt.

abstract: The First (Gen. GRIFFIN'S) and the Third (Gen. CRAWFORD'S) Divisions of Gen. WARREN'S corps were reviewed, yesterday, by Maj.-Gen. MEADE. The day was a delicious one, and the spectacles were both brilliant and imposing. The glancing gleams of the shining bayonets, the massive waving of the old and tattered banners, the dark masses of men, and the brilliant and dashing staffs, all made up a scene of surpassing beauty.

abstract: A private letter from a member of the Twenty-ninth Regiment Illinois Volunteers, (veteran,) dated at Fort Games, Ala., Feb. 17, states that the regiment was then encamped on Dauphin Island, at the mouth of Mobile Bay, having left Kenney (above New-Orleans) on the 11th. The regiment were luxuriating on oysters, which were gathered on the beach when the tide was out. Several thousand troops had left within a few days previous for points along the coast near Pensacola, from which it is interred that the principal part of the expedition against Mobile would move up on the east side of the bay. Deserters from Mobile were arriving every day. They report about seven thousand men there, about half being veterans and the remainder old men and boys. Gen. GRANGER's raid around the city a few week ago, with only 3,600 men, produced great consternation there. -- Springfield (Ill.) Journal, March 7.

abstract: It appears that DEPEW, of whose arrest and committal to the Old Capitol Prison an account was given in the TIMES of Thursday morning, was not an Assistant Provost-Marshal in the Ninth District, but merely a special detective, whom the Provost-Marshal had authorized to apprehend deserters and others.
lead_paragraph: It appears that DEPEW, of whose arrest and committal to the Old Capitol Prison an account was given in the TIMES of Thursday morning, was not an Assistant Provost-Marshal in the Ninth District, but merely a special detective, whom the Provost-Marshal had authorized to apprehend deserters and others. Capt. DUNNING, on taking the Marshalship of the Ninth District a year ago, found DEPEW acting in that capacity, and as he displayed marked ability in the peculiar business of a detective officer, Capt. DUNNING retained him in that capacity. It is not true that subsequent to DEPEW's arrest he hastened to Capt. DUNNING, and, with that officer, went to Gen. DIX, or that Capt. DUNNING knew anything of the application to Gen. DIX for an order forbidding any officer to remove DEPEW from the Department of the East. Capt. DUNNING accepted the office of Provost-Marshal at the solicitation of many substantial citizens of the Ninth District, and having taken the position, he entered upon the work with a resolve that he would pursue and punish the same class of rogues that Col. BAKER has so successfully trapped of late, and the Captain's annual report to Provost-Marshal-Gen. FRY shows that up to the 1st of January last he had arrested 215 persons, of whom 148 were deserters and 67 civilians; that of the alleged deserters 107 were sent to their regiments, 36 were discharged, and 5 only escaped the guard, and that during his administration in the Ninth District he has sent to regiments in the field an average of nine deserters a month. Of the civilians whom he arrested during the year many were bounty brokers, whom he compelled to restore the money of which they had defrauded recruits; and it is to this class that he traces any reports that may have been set afloat prejudicial to his character, and he further believes, as do many other officers, that affidavits may be obtained by the cord at a shilling apiece from bounty brokers and bounty jumpers and detective officers, testifying of their own personal knowledge to the most calumnious and absurd statements.

abstract: North Atlantic Squadron; Com. Radford to command James River Division; Arizona, U. S. S.; Burned near New Orleans
snippet: North Atlantic Squadron; Com. Radford to command James River Division; Arizona, U. S. S.; Burned near New Orleans
lead_paragraph: The United States steamer Arizona, one of the finest vessels in our navy, was destroyed by fire, 30 miles below New-Orleans, on Mondav night, Feb. 27. Five of the crew perished. She had just been fitted out as flagship of the Gulf Squadron when this untoward event finished her career. The Arizona was a side-wheel steamer, of 5 guns and 950 tons burden. She was put in commission at Philadelphia, and made her first cruise March 11, 1863. Shortly after, on the 23d, she captured the sloop Aurelia. She assisted in the destruction of the rebel steamers Queen of the West, Diana, (both captured from the United States Navy,) and Hart, in Berwick Bay, April 18, 1863. She participated in the capture of Fort De Russy, May 9, 1863. She has also done extensive blockade duty on the Atlantic and Gulf coasts.

abstract: Weather and Local Uncleanness
snippet: Weather and Local Uncleanness
lead_paragraph: The approach of genial weather, which will soon be so eagerly anticipated and gratefully hailed in every homestead of this broad country, brings with it to the dense and overburdened population of this island only the forecastings of aggravated disease, if not of widespread pestilence as well. The mere removal of the accumulated filth in our streets, twenty or thirty days from hence, when we may look for steady and warm sunshine, must carry with it a fearful penalty in the all-pervading malaria which it will generate. Surely the time for some action in the matter of our present sanitary status has arrived. Delay at this hour is worse than madness. It is crime.

abstract: It is officially announced that the draft will begin in this city on Wednesday, the 15th inst., unless orders are received from Washington in the meantime countermanding it. The Provost-Mar-
lead_paragraph: It is officially announced that the draft will begin in this city on Wednesday, the 15th inst., unless orders are received from Washington in the meantime countermanding it. The Provost-Marshals will meet at the office of Maj. DODGE, Acting Assistant Provost-Marshal, on Monday, when they will receive their final instructions. Their arrangements are nearly perfected, and by the 15th they will be ready to proceed with the drawings. It is not yet known whether the draft will be made in all of the districts on the same day. The number of names to be drawn in the six districts will be about thirteen thousand. The original quota was twenty-one thousand, from which twenty-five per cent. was deducted by Gen. FRY. A few men were credited to the city at the time the quota was apportioned, which, with two thousand one hundred and fifty-one recruited by the Volunteer Committee within the past twenty-two days, reduces the number of men required of this city to thirteen thousand. It is claimed that the quota of this city is excessive, having been based on the enrollment of 149,000, which has been reduced by the new enrollment to 90,000. Gen. HAYS signified his willingness to allow the revised enrollment, and it is understood that Gen. HINKS admitted its justness. If allowed by the Government, the new enrollment would have reduced the quota of the city to 14,000 men, which, with the credits, would have further reduced it to between eleven and twelve thousand. Recently, the Volunteer Committee has secured over one hundred men a day, and sometimes one hundred and fifty. The committee desire a postponement of the drawings, believing that the quota of the city could be filled sooner by volunteering than by a draft. Since the recent order for the draft, very many persons have deposited money with the County Volunteering Committee to procure substitutes.

abstract: Trotting Season Reopens
snippet: Trotting Season Reopens
lead_paragraph: There was a very large attendance at the Hone-house Friday night, when entries for the various stakes and purses offered by the proprietors of the Fashion Course, L.I., for the Spring season were advertised to close. All the leading owners of trotting stock, trainers, and drivers of trotting horses were present, and the opening of the envelopes containing the nominations for the various stakes, and purses, created quite a furore among the host of interested parties present. The greatest excitement, perhaps, was manifested concerning the entries for purses numbers one and two, each of $1,000. The first being mile heats, best three in five in harness; the second, to wagon. The entry of Dexter, whom HIRAM WOODRUFF asserts can outtrot any thing on four legs, elicited a buz of applause. Then came the beautiful mare, Lady Emma, for the same stakes -- next the gallant black stallion, Gen. Butler, whereupon people began to discuss the probabilities of the result, whilst the entries for the otherstakes were progressing, toward the bottom of the box containing the enveloped entries, there was one which caused the reader of the nominations to pause ere he pronounced, with sonorious voice, "GEORGE WILKES enters for purses numbers one and two, the bay mare Flora Temple." A bomb-shell thrown among the crowd could not have created greater consternation. There was silence for a moment, and then, as if by common consent, all present rose to their feet and gave three rousing cheers of welcome to the return of the Queen of the Trotting Turf to the scene of her many triumphs, after so lengthened an absence. It need scarcely be added, that the faces of the owners of the other horses entered for these valuable prizes elongated considerably when they discovered that the peerless Flora Temple had emerged from her long-time obscurity, to contest the trotting-laurels once more with them. The entries for the different stakes and purses were so numerous, and of such sterling quality, as to warrant the conviction that the coming Spring meetings will be affluently productive in sport.

abstract: New-York; Effect to have postponed; Draft; Effort to have Postponed
snippet: New-York; Effect to have postponed; Draft; Effort to have Postponed
lead_paragraph: -- At the present progress of enlistment the City of New-York is furnishing volunteer recruits for the national army at the rate of 45,000 men a year. This rate can and will be kept up, we are assured, if the supply of bounty-money continues. There are men, healthy, vigorous, willing men to be had in abundance. But the bonus must be paid them promptly, and in view of this the Volunteer Committee must be kept in funds by some means. That secured, we can see no occasion -- either of military necessity or any other -- why the draft, which has been set down for Wednesday next should take place at all. If every other community within the loyal States were contributing to the recruitment of the national army at the same rate as New-York, the daily enlistments would reach three thousand. That is at the rate of nine hundred thousand a year. These are facts, to which we have no doubt the delegations about to visit Washington to urge a postponement of the draft will give due prominence in their interview with the Secretary of War. But they are facts which might be rendered far more impressive, if the delegates were enabled to give the military authorities the assurance that the State Bounty Bonds were all subscribed for, and the County Volunteer Committee in a position pecuniarily to prosecute their task from day to day, until the requisition of the city was met.

abstract: Hicks' Paintings, on Exhibition
snippet: Hicks' Paintings, on Exhibition
lead_paragraph: -A collection of paintings by THOMAS HICKS is now on exhibition at No. 548 Broadway, (the old Dusseldorf Gallery,) and will be sold at auction on the evenings of the 14th and 15th inst., by LEEDS & MINER. The collection consists of studies, sketches and finished pictures, the result of many years of most industrious labor of one of our most eminent and worthy artists. The portrait of MARGARET FULLER, valuable for its fidelity, artistic excellence and rarity -- for it is the only authentic portrait extant -- will doubtless be eagerly sought for by the admirers of that distinguished woman. The famous picture of BOOTH in the character of Iago, perhaps the most ambitious, as it is the most excellent work of Mr. HICKS, is also include in the sale. The collection, however, for the most part, consists of studies and sketches of European scenery, which are painted with great and unaffected truth to nature. The street views are distinguished for a masterly rendering of gray tints, a quality which is as rare as it is estimable. Portraits of President LINCOLN, WM.H. SEWARD, (an excellent likeness and picture,) LONGFELLOW, HOLMES, BEECHER and other distinguished men, contribute to a great variety of subject, which includes marines, landscapes, figures, historical and fancy pieces, displaying a remarkable versatility of subject, as well as treatment.

abstract: Bridgeport; Benjamin and Hewins
snippet: Bridgeport; Benjamin and Hewins
lead_paragraph: The first game of a home-and-home match, between RALPH BENJAMIN of Bridgeport, and M.H. HEWINS of Hartford, came off in presence of a fine audience, including many ladies, at Franklyn Hall Bridgeport, on the evening of Wednesday last. The game was most remarkable for its tediousness, as both parties, but more particularly BENJAMIN, seemed to regard generalship in leaving the balls safe, of much more importance than scoring; thus a game of one thousand points up was spun out to 144 innings, consuming nearly six hours of time, BENJAMIN played 40 times, and HEWINS 22 times for safety. From the 70th to the 76th innings there were thirteen safe miss shots in succession; but HEWINS was finally ashamed to continue this useless skirmishing, and played to count. In difficult shots BENJAMIN gave evidence that he still possessed much of the brilliant prowess he was celebrated for in days of yore; while the manipulations of HEWINS, who by the way, is not in good health, was in no way equal to his former efforts.

abstract: The Senate are said to be satisfied with the present shape of the Metropolitan Sanitary Bill, and its passage is looked upon as certain. Bills were introduced yesterday to authorize the construction of a tunnel under Broadway. For the...
lead_paragraph: The Senate are said to be satisfied with the present shape of the Metropolitan Sanitary Bill, and its passage is looked upon as certain. Bills were introduced yesterday to authorize the construction of a tunnel under Broadway. For the relief of the New-York Dispensaries. Relative to sewerage and drainage in the City of New-York. To authorize the formation of a pneumatic railway and express company in New-York. Incorporating the New-York City Transit Company. Report was made in favor of the bid for the more effectual cleaning of the streets in New-York.

abstract: -A meeting of the New-York Typographical Society will be held this Saturday evening. Mr. C.A. ALVORD will deliver an address on the importance of physical education, with a view to the establishment of a printers' gymnasium in connection with the New-York Typographical Society. The trade is invited to attend at the rooms of the society, No. 3 Chambers-street. Admittance free.....The Purim Ball takes place at the Academy of Music next Tuesday evening, the 14th. The tickets have already been all sold, and a very brilliant entertainment is expected....The same evening, the second annual ball -- fancy-dress and civic -- of the Theatrical Mechanical Union, will take place at Irving Hall....Mr. FRANK H. NORTON, one of the assistant librarians of the Astor Library for ten years past, has resigned his position....Mr. HORACE GREELEY will deliver his celebrated lecture, entitled "Self-made Men," at Cooper Institute, this evening -- the net proceeds to be expended in printing the lecture for distribution among the soldiers. Persons are requested to bring with them to the lecture-room any papers, magazines or other reading matter they may wish to send the soldiers, which will be received by the Masonic Mission and forwarded free of cost....The Twenty-second Regiment N.Y.S.N.G. give a promenade concert at their armory this evening....The German pastors of New-York and vicinity have unanimously resolved to unite in a religious service to-morrow (Sabbath) evening, in the Cooper Institute. The exercises will commence at 7:30 o'clock, and be conducted in both German and English. Rev. Dr. MANN, of Philadelphia, will make the principal address in German.

abstract: Lazarus Murder; McDonald and Clark Admitted to Bail

lead_paragraph: The application to admit to bail James McDonald and James Clark, indicted as accessories to the murder of Henry Lazarus, was renewed yesterday morning, on motion of Mr. GEORGE M. CURTIS. The court said that the papers in the case showed that the offence was bailable, and he should grant the motion, fixing the bail at $2,500 in each case.

abstract: Progress of
snippet: Progress of
lead_paragraph: We ask the special attention of our readers to the progress made yesterday in the seven-thirty loan. The amount received merits notice. It reached the sum of $4,521,300. But this is even less deserving of record, than the fact that of the receipts for the day, there were 3,165 individual subscriptions for sums under $100. Results like these not only supply the best proof we can have that the people have unquestioning faith in the stability of the Government and the Union, but they are the surest guarantee that the Government shall faithfully redeem its obligations. To popularize our great loans, is to insure beyond the possibility of cavil or of doubt, the payment of the interest on these loans, and the ultimate redemption of the principal.

abstract: Progress of, and Rebel News
snippet: Progress of, and Rebel News
lead_paragraph: EXTRACTION OF NEWS FROM THE REBELS. -- The severe self-denial which the rebels are exercising in withholding all news about SHERMAN, ought to be an excellent discipline for their souls; and the subjective influence of the virtue need not be lessened by the fact that its main purpose is to annoy and damage us. But the thing fails of its due effect, both as regards them and us. The lofty and imperturbable temper which they ought to exhibit under the circumstances, is altogether lacking; and, instead of it, we find the most delirious ravings and railings; we see them quarreling ferociously with each other; we behold Richmond panicstruck; we are told by them that the rebel "Congress is defunct;" that there has been a plan on foot to force JEFF. DAVIS to resign; that there have been "rumors that LEE is ready to consider terms for laying down arms;" that this is the "hour of agony;" and that the "cowed, cowardly and miserable wretches who brought the war upon the country, would now surrender to the enemy."

abstract: Gen, to Command District of Kansas
snippet: Gen, to Command District of Kansas
lead_paragraph: A letter from an officer on the Niagara, dated Ferrol, Spain, Feb. 18, says the rebel ram Stonewall was in port, lying near enough to the Niagara to hear her band play "Yankee Doodle." The Captain of the Stonewall (PAGE) had asked the Spanish authorities for permission to repair her, as she was leaking badly. The Spaniards allowed him to make limited repairs only. He also asked permission to leave her in port while he went to Paris, in order to annul the contract of sale, and throw her back on her former owners. The Niagara had kept on excellent terms with the authorities, and showed them every courtesy, which was reciprocated. The workmen of the Navy-yard had been withdrawn from the Stonewall. Capt. PAGE said his officers and men refused to go to sea in a leaky vessel, which would be exposed to a fight. The Niagara was ready for the rem and eager to engage her, irrespective of the odds of wood against iron. She was in hopes of having the reinforcement of another Union ship-of-war, in which case there could be little doubt of the result of the contest, should a fight take place.

abstract: Thomas-street, Tobacco; Incendiary
snippet: Thomas-street, Tobacco; Incendiary
lead_paragraph: -- ATTEMPT AT INCENDIARISM. -- On Thursday evening, Deputy Collector VINCENT DE LA MONTAIGNE, of the Eighth District, who had been given charge of a stock of tobacco which Collector GEORGE P. PUTNAM had seized at No. 41 Thomas-street, surprised two men in the premises in question, and on entering found that they had saturated the tobacco and bagging in the building with alcohol and benzine. He summoned Officer BRADY, of the Fifth Ward, and one ISRAEL LEVI was arrested to await examination by Fire-Marshal BAKER. Prior to the seizure by Collector PUTNAM, this stock belonged to EDELS & BERKOVITCH, tobacconists, of Seventeenth-street, and they had been assessed as its owners, but had recently moved it from the Eighth District without notifying Mr. PUTNAM, and stored it at No. 41 Thomas-street, and there insured it, in the Pacific office, for $3,000. Mr. PUTNAM learned on Monday last whither the tobacco had been taken, and thither he went and seized it, leaving Mr. DE LA MONTAIGNE in charge. It is supposed that EDELS & BERKOVITCH, having insured the stock for about double its value, employed LEVI to fire the place.

abstract: Secret Sessions of Rebel Government; Government; Secret Sessions of
snippet: Secret Sessions of Rebel Government; Government; Secret Sessions of
lead_paragraph: There has probably been nothing in the proceedings of the rebel Congress which exhibits more clearly the rapid progress which that body has made toward pure oligarchy, than the practice in which it now constantly indulges, of transacting all business of importance in "secret session." In the earlier part of the war, nothing was discussed in this way, except matters actually pertaining to, or affecting the movements of the armies in the field; but during the last two years, nothing, or next to nothing, has been debated with open doors, except declaratory resolutions, addresses, and proclamations. As soon as a bill is brought up, which promises to affect any important interest, or introduce any important change, the first whimper of opposition to it is a signal for going into "secret session," and from this moment nothing more is heard of the measure until it has been either enacted or rejected.

abstract: On Constitutional Amendment; Gov. Bramlette Urges Ratification Constitutional Amendment
snippet: On Constitutional Amendment; Gov. Bramlette Urges Ratification Constitutional Amendment
lead_paragraph: Gov. BRAMLETTE, of Kentucky, has sent a message to the House of Representatives in that State, in reference to its rejection of the Constitutional Amendment. After showing that the rejection only remits the question to the people and the succeeding Legislature, and that nothing but ratification forecloses the right of action, Gov. BRAMLETTE expresses his earnest dissent from the Legislative resolution rejecting the amendment, on the ground that slavery is irrevocably doomed to speedy extermination; that no one can entertain the faintest hope of its possible continuance; that it has ceased to be valuable, and has become burdensome to the people, and must grow more and more so until relieved of it; and that compensated labor taxing the place of present slave labor can only restore Kentucky to advancement and prosperity. Gov. BRAMLETTE argues that the true policy and real interests of the State would be observed by an unconditional ratification of the proposed amendment, with a concurrent but independent enactment emancipating the slaves in Kentucky, to take effect and be declared when Congress shall have appropriated and secured to the State the last assessed value of slaves (in 1864) to enable the State, in conformity with the Constitutional requirement, to make "compensation," and declare immediate emancipation, thus leaving the onus upon Congress of retaining slavery in Kentucky for an indefinite period, or immediately relieving her of it by enabling her to emancipate by making compensation. This last proposition, to say the least of it, is a cool one, but coming from Gov. BRAMLETTE will excite no surprise. He concludes his message as follows:

abstract: Fire Department; Meeting of, >amp;c.
snippet: Fire Department; Meeting of, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: -A meeting of the representatives and officers of the Fire Department of this city was held on Friday night to express their opposition to the bill now in progress through the Legislature, to create a Paid Department. With all respect to the gentlemen participating, we submit that their confessions are very excellent arguments in favor of the change. Taking their resolutions, prepared (so said our report) by Mayor GUNTHER, we find them complaining that the new movement is going to put an unmerited degradation upon the present organization -- a statement entirely gratuitous, and as far as possible from the fact. They further complain that the movement was a surprise. If it were, an organization so virtuous and so perfect as they tell us theirs is, should have been proof against any such trick. But we distinctly remember that the idea of a Paid Fire Department has been discussed at times for a dozen years. Their resolved complaint winds up with the stale cry of Legislative interference; with the assumption that this city is possessed of civic rights peculiar to itself; that anything may be done in any other section of the State, but here there must be no meddling; that the people of this city have such a superabundance of Roman virtue, such a solemn appreciation of the rights and duties of sovereignty, that they should be permitted to do all their own lawmaking; that the enactment of bills by the State Legislature, (without first consulting the knot of men who run the machine here,) is an outrage not to be tolerated.
headline: {'main': 'THE FIRE DEPARTMENT.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE FIRE DEPARTMENT.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Infanticide in Goerck-street, New-York
snippet: Infanticide in Goerck-street, New-York
lead_paragraph: ALLEGED INFANTICIDE. -- Coroner COLLIN held an inquest, yesterday, upon the body of a female infant that was found in a slop-pail in Mrs. PHILAPOENA CONRAD'S variety store at No. 8 Goerck-street. The testimony of several witnessess was taken, and a clear case of infanticide was established. DORA WHITTAKAR said: This morning the store was closed: the people were trying to get in by knocking at the door and windows; I came down to see what was the matter; [???] Mrs. Conrad to open the door; she told me through the door that she had been out the night [???], did not feel well, and wanted to sleep; I told her if she did not open the door in half an hour I would get a no iceman; she disguised her pregnancy, so that I did not perceive it; when she opened the door she had a shawl on her head, and tooked [???]h[???]er than usual; she seemed to have chills, and I told her that she ought to make a fire; I entered the back room and told her that she had better tell me what was the matter, as I might help her; I then asked her where the babe was, and she replied, "in here;" she brought a sloop-pail from the closed, and a late was [???], head cown in water. Philapiena Conrad, sworn: I am mother of the child; my husband is a prisoner; I have not seen him since he entered the army, two years ago. Dr. THOMAS ROBINSON made a post-mortem examination, and, on applying the hydrostatic test, found that the child had been born alive, and probably died of strangulation.

abstract: colored men on jury at Providence

lead_paragraph: A colored man has been drawn as a juror in Providence, R.I., and will take his seat among the others. Hitherto it has been customary, when a colored man's name was drawn, to pass it over, but now a new course is to be pursued. A similar case occurred in Brooklyn a few weeks ago. A colored man, possessing a considerable amount of property, was drawn as a juror, but he was permitted to retire, as no negroes had served in that capacity.

abstract: In Cumberland Valley; Petroleum in
snippet: In Cumberland Valley; Petroleum in
lead_paragraph: It is now pretty generally conceded that there are abundant indications of the existence of petroleum underlaying the coal measures and sandstone strata of the Cumberland coal field. And so convincing are the more recent discoveries, a company has already been formed, comprising some of our most practical and sagacious citizens, to commence at once the sinking of welts. Oil has been found (and exhibited in our city) at Wellersburgh, near the Cumberland coal basin, if not forming a continuation of it. Should these developments result in success, as from what we learn seems almost certain, it would be difficult to fix a limit, even in imagination; to the vast wealth about to be poured out from the Cumberland region. The product of the coal, sent from the region for the year 1864 about 300,000 tons only, measured in value by its present price at tide-water, is about $3,000,000. That product is likely to be nearly, or quite double the present year. Now, if, as seems very probable, inexhaustible supplies of Petroleum underlies our great Coal Basin, who shall be bold enough to fix a limit to the wealth and prosperity of Allegany County, within whose limits is embraced the entire coal field of Maryland? We understand that the large coal companies, owning in the aggregate the great bulk of the coal lands in the Cumberland Basin, such as the Cumberland Company, the American Company, the London Mining Company, the Central Consolidation and others, are declining to sell any of their lands, although all of them, and especially the Cumberland Company, are the owners of very large tracts beyond their capacity to work for a century to come. We shall anxiously but hopefully watch the progress of the developments now taking place, and at an early day take up the subject again.
headline: {'main': 'Petroleum in the Cumberland Region.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Petroleum in the Cumberland Region.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We have a telegram from Philadelphia stating that news has reached Washington, from Wilmington, the 6th inst., (Monday last,) to the effect that a scout from SHERMAN's army had come into Gen. TERRY's lines. He left SHERMAN on the 1st inst., as we guess, in the occupation of Cheraw, S.C., and intending to march at once over the border into North Carolina. The army had subsisted very well off the country covered by their march, and were in fine condition. There had been no fighting of greater consequence than cavalry skirmishing. The scout who brings this news started for Newbern, but hearing of the capture of Wilmington, he made for that point.

TERRY's lines. He left SHERMAN on the 1st inst., as we guess, in the occupation of Cheraw, S.C., and intending to march at once over the border into North Carolina. The army had subsisted very well off the country covered by their march, and were in fine condition. There had been no fighting of greater consequence than cavalry skirmishing. The scout who brings this news started for Newbern, but hearing of the capture of Wilmington, he made for that point.

abstract: Peterhoff Case; French Attack out of U S.; Memorial Diplomatique on Prize Courts; United States and English Prize Courts, >amp;c .
snippet: Peterhoff Case; French Attack out of U S.; Memorial Diplomatique on Prize Courts; United States and English Prize Courts, >amp;c .
lead_paragraph: The Memorial Diplomatique returns to its attack upon our Prize Courts. The immediate occasion of it is a decision in the English Court of Common Pleas in the case of HOBBS vs. HEMMING, which was an action on a policy of insurance on certain goods which were on the steamer Peterhoff, on her last voyage from London, which had so different an ending from that which was intended for her. The insurer undertook to set up the decision of Judge BETTS as a defence to the action, and the plaintiff having demurred to his plea, the Court gave judgment on the demurrer in favor of the plaintiff -- and thereupon the Memorial Diplomatique has "much satisfaction in announcing that the Judges of the English Court of Common Pleas have, after mature deliberation, unanimously declared the condemnation of the United States Prize Court to be unsound and illegal, and have confirmed in every point the views we have expressed."

abstract: Whiting, Gen W H C; Funeral of; Rebel Army; Funeral in New-York
snippet: Whiting, Gen W H C; Funeral of; Rebel Army; Funeral in New-York
lead_paragraph: The funeral of the late Major-Gen. W.H.C. WHITING of the rebel army, who was captured at Fort Fisher and died at Governor's Island on Friday, took place yesterday at Trinity Church, in the presence of a large assemblage. The coffin, on which were placed beautiful wreaths of immortelles, was placed immediately in front of the chancel. The impressive burial service of the Episcopal Church was conducted by Rev. Dr. DIX and Rev. D. OGILBY. The remains were taken to Greenwood Cemetery, where they will remain in the receiving vault until removed by the family of the late General. On the coffin was a large silver plate, bearing the following inscription: "Maj.-Gen. W.H.C. WHITING, C.S.A., born in the State of Mississippi. Died in Governor's Island, New-York Harbor, March 10, 1865, aged 40 years, 11 months and 18 days." The mother, sister and brother of the deceased were present at the funeral.

abstract: New-York; March 15; Districts and Provost-Marshals
snippet: New-York; March 15; Districts and Provost-Marshals
lead_paragraph: The Special Agency of the War Department had been established in this city but a short time before Col. BAKER discovered that he was in the midst of the greatest and most audacious band of robbers, murderers, and felons generally, that ever disgraced a civilized community. He found nearly a thousand bounty-brokers; distributed throughout New-York and Brooklyn, with agencies throughout the country; and on extending his investigations he became aware of the presence in this city of more than ten thousand deserters, nearly every one of whom was a tool of the bounty-brokers. These persons were the offscourings of the city's slums, old prison birds, graduates from the city Institutions on Blackwell's Island, and Tombs "repeaters."

abstract: Vicksburgh,Near; Garrity,by Deserters
snippet: Vicksburgh,Near; Garrity,by Deserters
lead_paragraph: The Vicksburgh Herald of the 24th relates the particulars of a most horrid crime, perpetrated in that vicinity. A short time since, at about 10 o'clock at night, two negroes went to the residence of Mr. GARRITY, who is superintendent of DICK CHRISTMAN's plantation, about sixty miles above that city, on the Mississippi side of the river, and, knocking at the door, demanded admittance. Mr. GARRITY at once opened the door, when they demanded his money and pistols. He replied he had neither, but had scarcely spoken when he was fired upon by both the ruffians, the shots striking him in the back of the neck and completely paralyzing him. Passing over what they supposed to be his dead body, they entered the house, murdered Mrs. GARRITY and two children, and shot through the shoulder a little girl. She fell, and though enduring intense pain, she feigned death so well that the inhuman monsters really thought her dead, and proceeded with their work of plunder without noticing her further. After plundering the house of everything valuable that they could carry off, they set fire to it and went away. The little girl, thus wounded and alone in the burning building, got up, and going to her father, who was dying, near the door, with desperate courage and strength, she managed to drag him outside of the house into the yard. The rain, which was falling, revived him, and with the assistance of his little daughter he managed to crawl to an out-house. The little girl then returned to the house to attempt to get her mother from the burning building. She failed to accomplish her object, though her severely-burned s[???] leaves evidence of the heroic devotion with which she struggled to rescue the dead body of her beloved mother from the flames. Returning to her father, she made a little [???] and sat watching by his side. He conversed with her until daylight, when, to me her own pitiful expression, he stopped talking and she thought he was dead. When daylight came the poor child, wounded as she was, by the assassin's bullet and by the flames, made her way to the house of a neighbor, some two miles distant, and related the horrible story. This gentleman got others of his neighbors and proceeded to the scene of murder and arson. Mrs. GARRITY's body was not entirely consumed, and was taken from the ruins and buried with those of her husband. The bodies of the children, had been entirely consumed. From the little girl's description of the officers of a gunboat near the place were of the opinion that they were two deserters from that vessel.
headline: {'main': 'HORRIBLE MURDER--A HEROIC LITTLE GIRL.--', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'HORRIBLE MURDER--A HEROIC LITTLE GIRL.--', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Peru Agrees to Investigate Talambo Case; Peruvian Difficulty; The; Peru Agrees to Investigate
snippet: Peru Agrees to Investigate Talambo Case; Peruvian Difficulty; The; Peru Agrees to Investigate
lead_paragraph: If the Spanish-Peruvian difficulty has been settled, it certainly has not been on the basis of compromise. Compromise implies mutual concession; but all the concession in the present instance has been on the side of Peru. Her submission to the dictation of Spain has been, in fact, most abject. By the treaty of peace recently made between the two Powers, Peru, in consideration of receiving back the Chincha Islands, and for the sake of avoiding war, agrees to allow an investigation of the Talambo case, to indemnify all Spaniards for the losses and confiscations sustained by them during the struggle for independence, and to pay Spain the $3,000,000 which this expedition to the Pacific is said to have cost her. These terms are equally hard and humiliating, and by assenting to them the Lima Government has evinced an utter disregard of its own dignity and the national honor. Submitting the Talambo case to judicial arbitrament gives a color to those calumnies which the Spanish agents have been reiterating against the Peruvian Executive and President; undertaking to indemnify Spanish subjects for the pecuniary losses which their grandfathers suffered amid the turmoil of revolution, affords scope for interminable litigation and fraud; while the repayment to Spain of the cost of the expedition, will be a virtual admission that the enterprise was necessary and just. It would not be easy indeed to parallel the pusillanimity displayed by President PEZET in this matter, nor the extortionate arrogance of the Spanish ambassador.
headline: {'main': 'The Spanish-Peruvian Difficulty.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Spanish-Peruvian Difficulty.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: King George of, Troubles of; Troubles of
snippet: King George of, Troubles of; Troubles of
lead_paragraph: King GEORGE, of Greece, is evidently a believer in that scriptural aphorism which affirms that "in a multitude of counsellors there is wisdom." In other constitutional countries the sovereign generally contents himself with one political adviser at a time; but in the land of the Hellenes, the monarch who watches over its destinies must have two -- Admiral KANARIS his Prime Minister proper, and Count SPONNECK, who is not a minister at all, yet who is retained about the person of royalty in order to correct the indiscreet suggestions of the Governmental Coryphaeus. Now, it is beyond question that this bicephalous system is pernicious as well as anomalous. It places all responsibility on the shoulders of the Admiral, and all power in the hands of the Count, who, though sans portefeuille, is virtually the master-spirit of the Administration. This, certainly, is not the way in which a Constitutional King should treat a Constitutional Minister, and the opposition, or Bavarian party, are well disposed to turn the blunder to account.
headline: {'main': 'The Troubles of a King.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Troubles of a King.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
