abstract: American Federation; Progress of
snippet: American Federation; Progress of
lead_paragraph: -- The late news from Quebee will be apt to mislead those who have not followed the history of the proposed Federal Union. The Canada Assembly has done what was certain from the first -- passed the confederation resolutions by an overwhelming majority. But New-Brunswick and Prince Edward's Island have, informally, rejected the measure. Newfoundland has postponed it; and Nova Scotia shows scarcely any sign of acquiesence. The "Union," therefore, is practically as far off as it was before the late conference was held. New-Brunswick is the keystone of the whole projected fabric. Without the cooperation of that province, the relations of the colonies must remain essentially what they have been. The minority of thirty-three that have opposed the scheme in the Canada Assembly are mostly rouge in their politics, and during debates have openly expressed their preference for annexation to the United States.

abstract: Guille >amp; Allen, Paints, >amp;c; Twenty-seventh-street--$6,000; Jackson's Planing Mill, Thirty-ninth-street--$20,000
snippet: Guille >amp; Allen, Paints, >amp;c; Twenty-seventh-street--$6,000; Jackson's Planing Mill, Thirty-ninth-street--$20,000
lead_paragraph: Messrs. JACKSON & STEARNS' planing-mill, No. 122 East Thirty-ninth-street, was destroyed by fire at about 9 o'clock on Saturday evening, and THOMAS MATHER, a runner connected with Hose Company No. 37, fell from the roof of one of the adjoining buildings, and was seriously injured. He was taken to his abode, at No. 107 West Twenty-ninth-street. The planing-mill, stock and machinery were valued at $20,000, and insured for that sum. Some damage was done by water in the tenement-houses Nos. 118, 120 and 124 East Thirty-nintb-street. The fire originated in a detective furnace in the cellar of the planing-mill.

abstract: GEN. JAMES WATSON WEBB AND CAPT. JOHN CODMAN. -- We mentioned, the other day, the sale of the steamship Cotopaxi, Capt. JOHN CODMAN, at Rio de Janeiro, as a gunboat, and we learn, under date of Jan. 24, from a correspondent who is, and has been for years, a resident at Rio de Janeiro, that the steamer, which was unarmed, was on its way round to Valparaiso with provisions, probably on a speculation, with an eye to the Chillan or Peruvian Governments, or any power that wished to buy a steamer. Gen. WEBB, stirred up by the Spanish and Peruvian, Ministers, in the language of our correspondent, "declared the Cotopaxi contraband of war and sold the ship to the Brazilian Government. Capt. CODMAN, I believe, would have had no objection if the General had concluded the transaction manfully and above board, but to break his charter and sell his vessel without his consent was too dishonorable, so old 'Ring-bolt' refused to acknowlege the sale. Then the General mounted his high horse. He threatened to send the Secretary of Legation, the American Consul and a squad of police force to seize the ship. Capt. CODMAN laughed in the General's face, and said that he would pitch the Secretary of Legation into the sea. The Consul, a man of sense, good naturedly refused to have anything to do in such business, and the Chief of Police said that he could not interfere in a dispute between the American Minister and an American sea Captain. So his Excellency in high dudgeon retreated to Petropolis, forty miles away, but first prohibiting, in writing, the Consul to give up the ship's papers; threatening to put the cargo on shore. There the matter rests." -- Boston Journal.

abstract: Sillman, Prof. on Mising in Pacific States; Mining in. Prof Silliman on; Prof Silliman on Mining in
snippet: Sillman, Prof. on Mising in Pacific States; Mining in. Prof Silliman on; Prof Silliman on Mining in
lead_paragraph: Prof. SILLIMAN, in his recently-delivered and most instructive lecture, an the "Mining Resources of California," touched on a number of problems of profound economical interest. It has always been a matter of wonder to investigators into the resources of this country, that such great stores of wealth were continually derived to the nation from the auriferous regions of our western coast, and yet that so few individuals are ever known, who have made fortunes from mining; with a yield of bullion, which it is expected during the present year, will reach $75,000,000 from California, there seem to be so few private fortunes of great extent made from it, and so many companies which are failures. So notorious is this fact, that capital is drawn with great difficulty into mining operations on the Pacific Coast, and in a business which will pay from two to three per cent. a month on good security for loans and advances, our eastern capitalists cautiously stand aloof.
headline: {'main': 'Mining in the Pacific States.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Mining in the Pacific States.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Secretary S tanton's Abstract of War Department Reports; U S. Statistics of
snippet: Secretary S tanton's Abstract of War Department Reports; U S. Statistics of
lead_paragraph: Anticipating Lieut.-Gen. GRANT's report of last year's operations in the field, Secretary STANTON, in submitting to the President the reports of the various branches of the War Department, has also furnished a brief but well-digested abstract of their contents. The different branches surveyed in Mr. STANTON's retrospect include the departments of the Adjutant-General, the Paymaster-General, the Surgeon-General, the Quartermaster-General, the Judge-Advocate-General, the Provost-Marshal-General, besides the ordinance and engineering bureaus. And the subjects touched upon embrace, among others, those of recruiting and drafting, of military railroads and telegraphs, of the Sanitary status of the army, of the exchange of prisoners, of the colored element, and of many subjects besides, which are of the highest practical interest.

abstract: In Senate on Saturday, favorable reports were made on the Bath and Coney Island Bridge bill; also for a steam ferry between New-York and New Jersey; also, the Broadway Railroad bill  a majority report. Among the bills passed were:...
lead_paragraph: In Senate on Saturday, favorable reports were made on the Bath and Coney Island Bridge bill; also for a steam ferry between New-York and New Jersey; also, the Broadway Railroad bill -- a majority report. Among the bills passed were: The Battery Extension bill, requiring Registers of cities and counties to provide an official seal, relative to deposits of Savings Banks, incorporating the New-York Union Yacht Club. Mr. COOK moved for the appointment of a Select Committee of nine for the advancement of bills on general orders, which was carried. Adjourned.

abstract: March of--Lees Dispatch on; Dispatch on Sherman's March
snippet: March of--Lees Dispatch on; Dispatch on Sherman's March
lead_paragraph: We consider the brief dispatch from the rebel Gen. LEE of some importance, not as being indicative of any sort of success over the little body of Union troops which were pushing inland from Newbern, to distract the enemy's attention from the vital movements of SHERMAN and SCHOFIELD in the vicinity of Wilmington and Fayetteville, but as furnishing information of the whereabouts of the rebel forces in North Carolina under BRAGG, HOKE and HILL, concerning which we have been for some time in the dark. It is perfectly justifiable, also, from this dispatch of LEE, to infer the continued and victorious advance of SHERMAN's army through the State of North Carolina.
headline: {'main': "Lee's Dispatch Sherman's March.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Lee's Dispatch Sherman's March.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Pulpit and Public Health; Discourse on Public Health of New-York; Discourse on Public Health; McClintock, Rev D, on Public Health of New-York
snippet: Pulpit and Public Health; Discourse on Public Health of New-York; Discourse on Public Health; McClintock, Rev D, on Public Health of New-York
lead_paragraph: In accordance with previous announcement, the deplorable sanitary condition of the city, and the absolute necessity of measures looking to a salutary change, were made the subject of the sermons delivered in many of the churches on yesterday. Facts were adduced clearly showing that New-York is one of the most unhealthy cities on this continent, and, perhaps, in the civilized world -- the death-rate, in spite of the almost unparalleled advantages of our location, comparing unfavorably with that of Philadelphia, Boston, Paris, Vienna and London. Next Sunday the theme will be again taken up in other churches, and it is hoped that this united effort on the part of the clergy to bring about a healthful change, will result at least in arousing our citizens to efficient action. The sanitary condition of New-York should not be a reproach and a bye-word, when proper care would soon place its tables of mortality in favorable juxtaposition with those of any city of its size in the world.
headline: {'main': 'THE PULPIT ON THE PUBLIC HEALTH.; Facts and Suggestions Concerning the Sanitary Condition of the City. Discourses by Rev. Drs. Vermilye, McClintook, E.D. Smith and Jos. P. abstract: Fifty-sixth Regiment of, accepted by Gov. Fenton; to New-York Volunteers; New-York Volunteers; Governor Fenton's Address to; and G. W. Curtis; Article, Remembering the Soldiers
snippet: Fifty-sixth Regiment of, accepted by Gov. Fenton; to New-York Volunteers; New-York Volunteers; Governor Fenton's Address to; and G. W. Curtis; Article, Remembering the Soldiers
lead_paragraph: MY DEAR SIR: I am in receipt of your favor of the 10th instant, and thank you for evidence therein of kind appreciation of my efforts for the welfare of New-York soldiers and sailors. I am not without hope that these efforts will soon assume a form of greater efficiency. I have been giving careful attention to the New-York military agencies, and by the time of your next issue the organization will, I trust, be in a systematic working condition. It is my earnest desire that our soldiers and sailors, in the varied emergencies that confront them, whether in the field, on shipboard, in hospitals, or in transit, shall not fail to find, in the performance of their hard duties, and in their hour of need, representative agents of their State to furnish material aid, hearty cheer and God-speed. We should be worse than ungrateful, if we should do less for those who are battling in our behalf for the freedom and security of our common country. It is not enough that we cherish their heroic deeds in our hearts, our hands should be ready to perform the duties that the heart is so honest and ready to acknowledge.

abstract: Gen. SHERMAN has not only destroyed JEFF. DAVIS' facilities for getting news from those parts of his so-called Confederacy which lie beyond the limits of North Carolina; but he...
lead_paragraph: Gen. SHERMAN has not only destroyed JEFF. DAVIS' facilities for getting news from those parts of his so-called Confederacy which lie beyond the limits of North Carolina; but he has also greatly damaged our opportunities for obtaining intelligence from those distant but important points on the Gulf of Mexico, where military and naval movements of magnitude are in progress. It is altogether likely that the city of Mobile is now under the flag of the Union; but so uncertain or roundabout is communication with that quarter, that neither JEFF. DAVIS nor President LINCOLN could furnish the news. Up to a recent date the rebels had telegraphic communication between Mobile and some point in Central or Eastern Georgia, probably Augusta; but between there and Charlotte, in North Carolina, there is a great gap, or series of gaps, over which there is neither railroad line nor telegraph wire in working order, and across which the transmission of news is slow and uncertain -- so slow that the very latest Mobile advices in our last-received Richmond papers are ten days old. Through our own means of communication, either by the seaboard or the Mississippi River, it takes, ordinarily, from ten days to a fortnight to get news from New-Orleans or the vicinity of Mobile.

abstract: Comparative Charges Against; New-York, Discipline of; Fire Department; Discipline of
snippet: Comparative Charges Against; New-York, Discipline of; Fire Department; Discipline of
lead_paragraph: -- One of the arguments by which the friends of the Fire Department defend it against the charge of insubordination and want of discipline, is the singular one that while the Police Commissioners had examined five thousand charges of drunkenness and other misconduct against members of their force in a single year, the Fire Department had examined only two hundred and eleven charges against its members in three years. We need hardly say that nothing whatever is proved as to the comparative state of discipline in the two bodies by these figures. The fact that there are so many charges preferred and passed upon before the Police Commissioners may prove that the men are guilty of many delinquencies, but it also proves that the commissioners do make constant and steady efforts to enforce discipline. In fact it would be difficult to cite a fact affording stronger evidence of the efficiency with which the force is administered. The very number of charges, prove that offences are punished, for if they were not, people would soon get tired of complaining of them. Moreover, there is no doubt in the public mind of the excellent condition of the police force. The policemen are not angels, but we can safely say, that if they were neater in their dress, they might compare favorably in every respect with any similar body of men in the world. We doubt if all things considered, there is any police at this moment more efficient in preventing crime and arresting criminals, thanks to the very vigilance and rigor of the Commissioners, which is made a matter of reproach to them.

abstract: Impurities, Discourses on; Discourses on N Y, Impurities of
snippet: Impurities, Discourses on; Discourses on N Y, Impurities of
lead_paragraph: -- We have abstracts to-day of several timely pulpit discourses delivered, yesterday, and illustrating with great force the physical and moral impurities of this great city. One chief drawback to reform instituted from this influential quarter arises from the fact, that many of those city officials who most need reproof are too hardened to go to church, and too ignorant to be able to read a church discourse, or any other discourse, when it appears in print. Still, we cannot afford to disparage any agency -- least of all that of the church -- that aims to rouse whatever remnant of civic virtue there is left among us, to an appreciation of the fearful dangers of our present sanitary condition. Next in evil to the all-pervading municipal corruption to which our present wretched situation is primarily due, is the astounding indifference of the great mass of our citizens to the real peril of the situation. To these the solemn and earnest appeals of the clergy, we should trust, will not be made in vain. This business needs an uprising of the people. It needs agitation in a hundred popular assemblies. And the efforts of yesterday are appropriate beginnings in that great agency of reform.

abstract: And Brokers; Col Baker's Great Haul at Hoboken; Hoboken; Great Haul of Deserters by Col Baker
snippet: And Brokers; Col Baker's Great Haul at Hoboken; Hoboken; Great Haul of Deserters by Col Baker
lead_paragraph: The brilliant feat of Col. BAKER and his men, and the model recruiting office in Hoboken, of which an account was published in yesterday's TIMES, were talked of everywhere yesterday; and everywhere the trapping of the bounty-jumpers was conceded to be the greatest detective job of the century. Even the bounty-brokers, who were in high glee over their hairbreadth escape, applauded the work for its audacity; and the barkeepers, who have lost more than five hundred of their most constant, if not most profitable customers, spoke admiringly of Col. BAKER as the "smartest man in New-York." Everybody wished to learn something of Col. BAKER's biography; and the conjectures that were to be heard on street-corners, at the threshold of the church, in the hotel reading-rooms, indeed, everywhere, were amusing, to say the least. The roughs thought him the notorious LEW. BAKER; Western men believed him to be a citizen of Chicago; Californians, who certainly could not have read the newspapers, wondered whether he was not the illustrious and lamented Col. BAKER, who fell in the slaughter-pen at Ball's Bluff. But nobody's curiosity was gratified, and the inquiries everywhere closed as they began, "Who is Col. BAKER?"

abstract: Post Boy, Steamship, Burst Boiler, March 5, on Tennessee River; Disastrous Overflow of Tennessee River
snippet: Post Boy, Steamship, Burst Boiler, March 5, on Tennessee River; Disastrous Overflow of Tennessee River
lead_paragraph: There was a dispatch on Friday last from New-Orleans, dated the 1st inst., which announced that Maj.-Gen. CANBY and Staff had left that city for the vicinity of Mobile. Our army in that Department, which has recently been greatly enlarged by the arrival from Tennessee of the splendid corps of Gen. A.J. SMITH, has been reorganized, and now consists of two compact and powerful corps -- the Thirteenth, Gen. GORDON GRANGER, and the Sixteenth, Gen. A.J. SMITH -- the whole army being under control of Maj.-Gen. CANBY, commanding the Department of the Gulf. Beside this infantry force, there is a strong cavalry division, under command of Gen. KNIPE. The army is thus a very effective one, both as regards numbers, material and commanders. Part of the army has been for some time at Fort Gains, in front of Mobile, part at Pensacola, last of the city, and the remainder at New-Orleans, but the probabilities are that the whole of it is now encamped within the city of Mobile.

abstract: Rev. Dr. JOHN McCLINTOCK preached this mornning, at St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, Fourth-avenue and Twenty-second-street. The church...
lead_paragraph: Rev. Dr. JOHN MCCLINTOCK preached this morning, at St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, Fourth-avenue and Twenty-second-street. The church was crowded with a large audience, among whom we noticed the Chairman of the Senatorial Investigating Committee, Hon. Judge MUNGER. The sermon, while very eloquent, was eminently practical and full of common sense. Reverend gentleman took for his text: "Therefore glorify God in your body." I Cor., vi. 20, and proceeded to speak of the importance of activity in all the affairs of life. Nature, he said, taught us this lesson. The law of activity is the law of force, and force is action. This law is seen everywhere in nature where the action of nature is healthy. The river flows on without stoppage: or, if the water stops, it becomes sickly and makes those sick who partake of it. We hear the voice of activity in the roar of floods and the rush of storms; it is seen in the swell of the heaving sea, or in the gentlest ripple on the surface of the river. The life of the Son of God was activity itself -- the exemplar of mankind, ever working, ever doing good. The active man shall get ahead of the slow man. The slow man may be very good, very conscientious, and very pious; the active man may be a very bad man, but he will beat the slow man in the race. The tradesman understands this; and he studies the laws of trade if he wants to succeed; the slow tradesman, because he is religious, does not study the laws of trade. He thinks God will do his work for him, and he fails. The former fulfills so far the conditions of the laws of God. And so it is with government. Those who would be rulers are active. They understand their business. There are powers, and powers are forces; they get the powers and grasp the prizes; and so long as good men are idle bad men will rule. Christianity, some think, is a medicine, but it is a discipline, a duty, a life, and it is a religion of the body as well as of the soul. The pagans understood this religion of the body -- the culture of the body in constant baths -- in the training of the boxer, the racer, the gymnast, in order to give physical development. It was just as necessary to be physically as morally developed. Greece understood this. Over that land the spirit of beauty, as well as physical culture, held sway. If we wanted to get the highest types, the ideals of beauty, as far as they can be seen in marble, we must go to Greece. The same principle was enunciated by the philosophers of Greece. The stoics, which Zeno was the apostle, hold that a man's powers should be strong, vigorous. But there was a weakness as well as a strength in philosophy. It might make a good pugilist, a strong man, but never a loving, kind-hearted member of society. Christianity settled all that. In the Old Tetament, the care for the body was set forth in innumerable forms and passages. The purification of the body was deemed coeval with the purification of the soul; and it was laid down as the ancient law, that a person afflicted with any physical taint or defect should not come to serve at the altar. This calling required specimens of the highest type of God's creatures, in body, mind and soul. The aptness of those prefatory illustrations were applicable to the object of his sermon. The object of every man's life was real, stern work. There was no mystery, no spiritualism, in the work of Christ. It was as much temporal as spiritual. "Glorify God in your body."

abstract: Police; Tours of Duty
snippet: Police; Tours of Duty
lead_paragraph: -On Saturday night JOHN MCNEAL, of No. 66 Cherry-street, attempted to commit suicide by cutting his throat with a razor. He was taken to the New-York Hospital ...... JOHN WOOD, of No. 30 Frankfort-street, was mortally burned, his clothing having taken fire from an overheated stove. He died at the New-York Hospital, and an inquest was held by Coroner GOVER......PATRICK MCDERMOTT, of Eighteenth-street, fell into a cellar-way at No. 93 Oliver-street, and was mortally injured. He was taken to the Fourth Precinct Police-station, where he died at 3 o'clock on Sunday morning......ELIZABETH GILBERT, aged 30 months, was burned to death, her clothing having taken fire from a stove during the absence of her parents from their abode in Fifty-second street, near Seventh-avenue......JANE FULTON, an aged washerwoman, who lived at No. 174 West Nineteenth-street, was found by Officer DINSMORE in Twenty-first-street, near Fourth-avenue, sick and speechless. She was taken to a neighboring drug-store, where she died......JOHN BOARDMAN was stabbed in the left side by PATRICK SHEA, in Thirty-second-street, between Tenth and Eleventh avenues. SHEA was apprehended by Officer MCCULLOUGH, and taken to Jefferson Market Police Court, where he was committed by Justice DODGE.

lead_paragraph: Richmond papers of Friday, l0th inst., contain the important intelligence, that on the 8th Gen. BRAGG attacked a Union force, four miles is front of Kinston, N.C., and drove them back three miles to another line, where, apparently, they maintained their position. Gen. BRAGG admits that the ground was "obstinately disputed," but claims that his own loss was small, while he asserts that we lost heavily in killed and wounded, besides 1,500 men taken prisoners. The news of this battle was received in Richmond just in season to shed a dim light over the "darkness visible" of the day appointed for humiliation and prayer throughout the South. This news is important as showing the exact position of the rebel Generals HOKE and HILL, with their commands, who are commended by BRAGG for "exhibiting their accustomed gallantry." So it is evident that these Generals are not in SHERMAN's immediate front. Union accounts will probably show that the rebel General exaggerated the importance and extent of the whole affair.

lead_paragraph: BROOKLYN CITY MORTALITY. -- The total number of deaths in this city last week was 133, the mortality by the principal diseases being as follows: Consumption, 11; scarlet fever and convulsions, 10 each; dropsy and bronchitis, 8 each; inflammation of lungs, 9; diphtheria, 7; debility, heart disease and congestion of brain, 6 each; marasmus and small-pox, 5 each; congestive fever, 2; puerperal fever, 1; nervous fever, 1, &c. Under one year of age, 35; natives of the United States, 108; Ireland, 17: Germany, 15: England, 3.

abstract: LOSS OF SCHR. HARRIET, OF YARMOUTH. -- Capt. Crowell, of the above schooner, arrived this morning in the Hamburg ship Gallert, and makes the following report of the loss of his vessel: Sailed from Yarmouth Dec. 18, for Antigua, and on the 20th, took a gale from W.N.W., in which lost both masts, bowsprit, and had decks swept, which caused the vessel to leak considerable. Feb. 9, in a gale from W., lost rudder. Feb. 25, lat. 24, lon. 45, was spoken by the Hamburg ship Gallert, Capt. Bohn, and we being in a sinking condition, and short of provisions; was taken off with my crew, five in all, and was brought to this port. The Harriet was 55 tons. British register, four years old, and owned by Wm.M. Bond, of Yarmouth.

abstract: Emperor, on Religious Toleration
snippet: Emperor, on Religious Toleration
lead_paragraph: The English mail packed Eder arrived yesterday from Tampico and Vera Cruz, with dates from the latter place to the 3d inst., and from the City of Mexico to the 28th ult. The most important items of news are the decrees of MAXIMILIAN, one granting religious liberty, and the other approving of the secularization of the Church property ordained by the Republican Government. The capture of [???]a is confirmed, and full particulars are published. JUAREZ, at last accounts, was still in Chihuahua, and continued exercising his power, in accordance with the advice of his Privy Council, in whose opinion the legal end of his Presidency would not end until November, NEGRETE was acting as Secretary of War, having succeeded in raising an army of about 7,000 men. The news of the submission of Gen. ECHEAGARAY and of the ex-governor of Colima, DON JULIA GARCIA, to the new order of things, has it appears been confirmed.

abstract: Sunday Mercury; Action against,for Libel
snippet: Sunday Mercury; Action against,for Libel
lead_paragraph: John H. McCabe vs. William Cauldwell and Horace P. Whitney. -- The action was brought by Mr. MCCABE, as plaintiff, to recover the sum of $25,000 damages, which he alleges that he has sustained by reason of a libel upon his character. The defendants were at the time mentioned in the complaint, namely, on the 12th of October, 1862, the editors and proprietors of the paper, known as the Sunday Mercury. The complaint goes on to recite that on the day mentioned, the defendants published a highly libelous, defamatory and scandalous story in their paper concerning the plaintiff, whereby he was exceedingly damaged in his good name, fame and reputation. The defendants, in their answer, admitted the publication of the article in question, but claimed that the matter therein contained was true, and that it was published from good motives, and for purposes which, they alleged, were justifiable. The defendants, through their counsel, contended, moreover, that the published matter, which is by the plaintiff alleged to be libelous, was such as they had a right to publish, in consequence of its having been the report of judicial proceedings.

abstract: The United States vs. Henry Pinchard. -- The defendant was brought up for examination upon complaint of Julia Goddard, who charged him with passing upon her two counterfeit twenty-five cent currency notes. The defendant showed that he was a retail grocer in New Chambers-street, and that he did a large business, sometimes having several hundred customers a day, in his store, and taking in a large amount of money in small sums; that in the hurry of business, he might have paid out this money but knew nothing about it. The Commissioner held that there was no evidence of guilty knowledge of the character of the money, or intent to commit a crime, and discharged the accused.
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. Henry Pinchard. -- The defendant was brought up for examination upon complaint of Julia Goddard, who charged him with passing upon her two counterfeit twenty-five cent currency notes. abstract: Proposition to Transfer Government to Duchy of Augustenberg Rejected by Prussia
snippet: Proposition to Transfer Government to Duchy of Augustenberg Rejected by Prussia
lead_paragraph: A dispatch from Vienna of Feb. 26, says: "It is stated that the Prussian note which arrived here yesterday, rejects the proposal of Austria provisionally to transfer the Government of the Duchies to the Duke of AUGUSTENBURG until the succession question. Prussia must make the ultimate form of government in the Duchies dependent on certain conditions, and must also receive sufficient compensation. In conclusion the note enumerates five points upon which it is essential for Austria and Prussia to agree before a final solution can be arrived at. These points would not be contrary to the interests of Austria, and would advance the general interests of Germany."

The causes of the increased heaviness have been various. The market opened with..
lead_paragraph: The Times City Article of Tuesday says: "The English funds experienced a further fall on Monday of 1/4 cent., and are now more than 2 1/2 cent. below the point at which they stood at the corresponding date of last year, when the bank rate was 6 cent. The causes of the increased heaviness have been various. The market opened with flatness, consequent on the doubts engendered as to the possible maintenance of peace in the world by any policy, however temperate and prudent, when it is found that the head of a great nation can, without apparent scruple, avow participation in a discussion as to whether the proper way of settling an internal struggle would not be to combine and fall upon some wholly neutral people. Subsequently an increase in the demand for money, coupled with a partial confirmation of the recent rumors of mercantile difficulties in China, aggravated the adverse tendency, and Console closed at 88 7/8@89.

abstract: -- The decree of MAXIMILIAN, of Mexico, in favor of full religious toleration, which we publish in another column, lacks but one element to make its worth apparent to us all -- his power to enforce it. The Church is against him on principle, and the Pope has pronounced against this measure in advance. The Republicans regard his presence and his decrees as mere temporary expedients for the aggrandizement of French influence. And the best of his Imperial edicts are thus in a measure divested of any essential value.

abstract: Sheridan's Bulletin
snippet: Sheridan's Bulletin
lead_paragraph: The most remarkable point about Gen. SHERIDAN's victorious bulletin is its date line. It will be observed that it is dated on Friday last, at Columbia, Virginia. Now, as will be seen by the map, Columbia is in Fluvanna County, and is but fifty miles west of Richmona. Here, on the flank of the rebel capital, on the northern bank of the James River, was Gen. SHERIDAN, with his splendid cavalry force, four days ago. He doubtless sent his dispatch directly forward to Lieut.-Gen. GRANT from that point, and thus communicated with our army in front of Petersburgh.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen met at 2 P.M. yesterday. The ordinances appropriating $500,000 for the relief of families of volunteers, creating the office of Superintendent of the City Telegraphs, and Sergeant-at-Arms to the Mayor, were all laid..
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen met at 2 P.M. yesterday. The ordinances appropriating $500,000 for the relief of families of volunteers, creating the office of Superintendent of the City Telegraphs, and Sergeant-at-Arms to the Mayor, were all laid over. The resolution authorizing the City Inspector to contract for the removal of night soil, the city receiving $4,000 per annum from the contractors, was concurred in. A report of the Committee on Ferries was adopted, directing the Comptroller to sell at public auction the right to run a ferry from the foot of Spring-street to Hoboken, was adopted, and the Board adjourned to to-morrow. The Board of Councilmen also met, but transacted no business of importance.

abstract: and Schofield--Significant Operations
snippet: and Schofield--Significant Operations
lead_paragraph: While Gen. SHERMAN is undoubtedly developing, and his army are assuredly executing, some startling movement somewhere in North Carolina -- which is entirely hidden both from us and from the enemy -- our troops in another part of the State are keeping the rebel forces very busy. We have had not only the fight near Kinston on the 8th, in which our advance line was momentarily repulsed, and which LEE made such extraordinary haste to report as a rebel success; but our troops had other encounters with the enemy on the two days following, which LEE has not been so quick in reporting, but of which we have accounts, official and unofficial, from our own side, and in which the rebels under BRAGG were defeated and very severely punished. Gen. SCHOFIELD himself has arrived at Kinston from Wilmington, and had command in the victory of the 10th.

abstract: Its Grievance Want of Capital
snippet: Its Grievance Want of Capital
lead_paragraph: -- It will be seen by the European news, received last night, that the British Premier has at last discovered what is the prime grievance of the people of Ireland, the cause of her industrial decline, and the source of her social misery. It is not an obnoxious State Church, the want of a local Parliament, the absenteeism of landlords, the uncertain tenure of tenants, the potato rot, nor the wholesale emigration from large pastoral districts of the country. It is simply the want of capital. This, Lord PALMERSTON thinks, the Government of the United Kingdom cannot undertake to supply; but he would have been willing that a Parliamentary Committee should sit for another year to endeavor to discover where the capital necessary to redeem Ireland could be found. And that is the latest phase of the Irish question in the British Parliament.

abstract: A large number of Col. BAKER'S prisoners were held at Odd Fellows' Hall, Hoboken, over Sunday, awaiting the filling of a requisition for uniforms, and, that they might not be deprived of religious instruction and advice, the Colonel invited Rev. Mr. GARDNER to address them in the afternoon. It is...
lead_paragraph: A large number of Col. BAKER's prisoners were held at Odd Fellows' Hall, Hoboken, over Sunday, awaiting the filling of a requisition for uniforms, and, that they might not be deprived of religious instruction and advice, the Colonel invited Rev. Mr. GARDNER to address them in the afternoon. It is said that the prisoners did not worship devoutly on the occasion. At nightfall on Sunday everything was in readiness for the voyage down the harbor; but it was deemed prudent to postpone the start until 5 o'clock yesterday morning. At that hour the prisoners were ironed in couples, and a chain was made last to every iron, rendering the escape of any one prisoner utterly impossible. The line was then taken up for the boat, which lay at a pier near the ferry, and the gang was put aboard under an escort of well-armed regulars, and taken off to the fort. There were very few spectators, the hour at which the prisoners were marched down Washington-street being rather earlier than suited the convenience of our neighbors over the river. The chain-gang went off, as a whole, in good humor, some laughing and bandying jokes, others smoking, and only one or two giving utterance to profanity.

abstract: Police-Station Lodgers; Statistics
snippet: Police-Station Lodgers; Statistics
lead_paragraph: BARNUM's temperance drama is very good in its way, but it is all tame recital when compared with our daily morning reports from the police stations. At the Tombs, every morning at 6 o'clock, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, or at the Police Court on the East side, may be seen the real drama, and in it all the actors are up in their parts. But even here in the police courts the story does not fully appear; for among all the prisoners there are no station-house lodgers. This class -- a large one, as will presently be shown -- includes no felons that policemen drag to the bar of justice; the lodgers find shelter over night in the cells of the police stations, and are dismissed in the morning to go whither they will. Nobody knows them by day; they spring to the surface like mushrooms at night. They are masculine, feminine, of youth, of middle age, and of the sere and yellow leaf; but they are mainly in appearance males of middle age -- young men who have grown prematurely old, females of twenty-two, whose haggard or bloated visages are not be described. The aged and very young are seldom of their number; for their vagabond life is not conducive of age, and rum rarely does it work so rapidly as to drag children down to the necessity of seeking lodgings in the police stations. The males are in this time of draft seemingly excellent subjects for army duty in place of men of sedentary habits and comfortable incomes. But ask a Police Captain why he does not enlist them, and the almost invariable reply is, that they have offered to enter the field as substitutes and been rejected by the Surgeons. Theirs is a story of tippling, and they are Satan's own.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: The Hansa brings us three days later news from the Old World. Lord LYONS, who has long suffered from ill health, has resigned the post of Minister from Great Britain to the United States, and Sir FREDERICK BRUCE, who has been Minister to China, is to be his successor. Blockade-running has become poor business, about twenty-five fine steamers in that trade being lain up at Nassau. Queen VICTORIA has emerged from her retirement, and held a grand court on the last day of February. Louis NAPOLEON's Preface to the Life of Caesar is a novel and interesting feature by this arrival. The Pope has given his expurgators orders to examine this biography closely for contraband matter. The latest vote from Prussia to Austria about the Duchies demands the right to levy sailors in said Duchies; the cession to Prussia of land for the canal from the Baltic to the German Ocean; the control of post-offices and telegraphs, and a homogenous commingling of the armed forces of the two countries. The King of Italy has signed an amnesty for all the Turin rioters.

abstract: Kennedy, R C; Sentenced to Death
snippet: Kennedy, R C; Sentenced to Death
lead_paragraph: Gen. DIX has not yet fixed the day for the execution of the spy and incendiary ROBERT COBB KENNEDY, alias Stanton, but will do so as soon as the action of the court-martial has been approved by the Secretary of War. At the conclusion of KENNEDY's trial, which was published exclusively in the TIMES, the court was cleared for deliberation, and after a fair and candid consideration of the entire matter, the prisoner was found guilty of each charge and specification; guilty of being a spy, of irregular warfare, and of setting fire, in company with six confederates, to hotels and places of amusement, which were crowded with men, women and children. Gen. DIX approved the verdict and adopted the sentence, which was: "That the said KENNEDY shall be hung by the neck until he be dead, at such time and place as the Commanding-General may direct."

abstract: The Germans pastors and congregations orf New-York held a meeting at Cooper Institute, on Sunday evening, for the purpose of promoting the better observance of the Lord's Day. The hall was crowded by a devout and respectable audience.
lead_paragraph: The Germans pastors and congregations orf New-York held a meeting at Cooper Institute, on Sunday evening, for the purpose of promoting the better observance of the Lord's Day. The hall was crowded by a devout and respectable audience. On the platform were the German pastors of all denominations, many of the most prominent English ministers, the members of the New-York Sabbath Committee, and a number of distinguished laymen connected with the various benevolent movements of the city. The exercises were in the German and English language, and characterized by deep interest and solemnity to the close.

abstract: -- It should stand to Gov. JOHNSON's credit that before he left Nashville, he telegraphed to Washington that he was not fit to make the trip, and that he would rather remain at home to assist in the regeneration and restoration of Tennessee, than to be Vice-President of the United States. But after a council held among his friends here, it was deemed right that he should be present to particimate in the august ceremonies of Mr. LINCOLN's inauguration for a second term. In obedience to their earnest request, he came, and when he reached Washington was so enfeebled as to be compelled to take to his bed at once. Gov. JOHNSON appeared in the Senate yesterday morning, in company with his friend. Hon. PRESTON KING, of New-York, who is staying with him at the residence of our hospitable fellow-citizen, FRANCIS P. BLAIR, Sr. His health is entirely restored. He was as cheerful as any man could be after having recovered from so severe an indisposition. We have no doubt he will fully justify the warmest anticipations of his countrymen. During his stay in the Vice-President's room a large number of the Senators called to pay their respects, and we observed with much satisfaction that they were pleased to see him well. -- Washington Chronicle.

abstract: Lieut.-Com. LEONARD PAULDING, (son of Rear-Admiral PAULDING) who has held the responsible position of Lieut.-Commander at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, is, on the reporting of his relief, ordered to command the Monocacy, 10 guns and 1,030 tons capacity. Lieut. Com. JAS. E. JARRETT will hold the position so long and ably filled by his predecessor, and will assume his duties this week. It is expected that the Monocacy will depart for European waters. Both of these gentlemen will share alike in the regrets and congratulations of their numerous friends in naval circles -- regrets from the friends they leave behind, and congratulations from the friends that receive them in their new positions. It is reported that Capt. CASE, Executive Officer of the Yard, will be relieved from command and ordered to the Mediterranean as soon as the Colorado has been thoroughly overhauled, which may be in June next. The famous 52 gun ship Colorado will be his flagship in those waters.

lead_paragraph: The people of this city have wondered at the developments of rascality made by Col. BAKER'S bureau, and have in the main indorsed his actions. Quite naturally, however, considerable qneationing has been raised as to the arbitrary nature of the arrests, and the apparently irresponsible power in the Colonel's hands. A few facts in regard to this branch of the matter will settle the question in the mind of every honest man. Desiring that nothing illegal (technically speaking) should be done, the Secretary of War desired Hon. L.E. CHITTENDEN, Ex-Registrar of the Treasury, to sit with Col. BAKER and advise him in all matters of doubt, and to determine the bearings of the law in all cases of uncertainty. Since that time Mr. CHITTENDEN has been in constant consultation with Col. BAKER, and not a case has been passed upon either hastily or without regard to the law.

abstract: Sheridan at
snippet: Sheridan at
lead_paragraph: Official dispatches have been received from Gen. SHERIDAN, dated at Columbia, Va., March 10th. This place is on the north side of the James River, about fifty miles west of Richmond, and very nearly midway between that city and Lynchburgh. The destruction by SHERIDAN's men has been wide-spread and important. While at Charlotteville they destroyed two large iron bridges, one over the Rivanna River, the other over Morse's Creek, and also the railroad for eight miles southwest, in the direction of Lynchburgh. On Monday, 6th inst., Gen. DEVINS was sent to the James River, at Scottsville, and worked along the river and canal to Dugurdsville, 15 miles east of Lynchburgh, destroying as he marched all the bridges, culverts and locks of the canal, and the tracks of the railroads in the way. He intended to cross the James at Dugurdsville, doubtless to strike the Southside Railroad, but the rebels destroyed the bridges. In the meantime, another division moved down the direct railroad from Charlotteville toward Lynchburgh as far as Amherst, ruining the road as far as they went, burning and breaking down a great many large bridges. The sweep of these two divisions spread over a triangle of thirty or forty miles on a side, and within that space the destruction of railroads and other public property is complete. The James River Canal, which (says SHERIDAN) had been the great fender of Richmond, was cut at Rockfish River, and at New-Canton, where the dam is across the James, the guard-lock was destroyed, and the river let in, carrying away the banks and washing out the bottom of the canal. Gen. SHERIDAN says that the weather has been very bad, but he has, nevertheless, done excellent work. He reports the capture of fourteen guns and a few prisoners, Commodore HOLLINS, of the rebel navy, was shot near Gordonsville while attempting to make his escape from our advance.

abstract: Ministry at Washington; Change in; Sanitary Reform and the Pulpit; The, and Sanitary Reform
snippet: Ministry at Washington; Change in; Sanitary Reform and the Pulpit; The, and Sanitary Reform
lead_paragraph: We rejoice that the Christian ministry of this city are at last lifting up their voice also for sanitary reform. It is high time. The long silence of our pulpit on this subject has been amazing. It almost passes comprehension that those whose business it is to admonish the people of Christian duty, should not long ago have spoken in tones of thunder against the wholesale murder that has for years been going on in this city by the poisoning of Heaven's atmosphere.

abstract: New British Minister to U S.; Lord, Retirement of British Embassy, United States
snippet: New British Minister to U S.; Lord, Retirement of British Embassy, United States
lead_paragraph: When Lord LYONS left Washington a few months ago, it was announced in these columns, on sufficient authority, that his retirement would be permanent. He himself, made no concealment of the fact; and his retention of the nominal position of Minister to the United States during the intervening period, was due only to his desire to give his Government time to find a suitable successor. This end has, we believe, been secured, and Lord LYONS has been relieved.

abstract: The anniversary of the birth of Ireland's patron saint will be celebrated on Friday next by a grand parade of civic societies, thirty-three of which will take part therein. The Sixty-ninth and, Ninety-..
lead_paragraph: The anniversary of the birth of Ireland's patron saint will be celebrated on Friday next by a grand parade of civic societies, thirty-three of which will take part therein. The Sixty-ninth and, Ninety-ninth Regiments, under Cols. BAGLEY and MAHONEY, will head the procession, and the line of march will be down East Broadway and Chatham-street to the east gate of the Park, where the procession will pass in review before the Mayor and Common Council; thence up Broadway to Fourteenth-street, Fourteenth-street to Seventh-avenue, Seventh-avenue to Thirty-fourth-street, Thirty-fourth-street to Second-avenue, down Second-avenue to Twenty-third-street, Twenty-third-street to First-avenue, First-avenue to Eighth-street, Eighth-street to Cooper Institute, and there dismiss. In the evening, a grand banquet will be given by the Knights of St. Patrick, and also by the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick. The banquet of the former will take place at the Metropolitan Hotel at 7 o'clock precisely, and the latter at Delmonico's, Fifth-avenue and Fourteenth-street. Mr. W.R. ROBERTS will preside at the Knights' dinner, and Mr. RICHARD BELL at that of the Friendly Sons. The President of the Knights, Mr. W.R. ROBERTS, will wear for the first time a splendid gold badge, which will be the distinguishing mark of that officer at all future banquets. The tickets for both banquets are nearly all disposed of. The parade promises to be the grandest that has yet taken place on any similar occasion.

abstract: -The European mail brings us the full text of the French Emperor's Preface to his Life of Caesar. The announcement of this portion of the work, it seems, was anticipated with considerable alarm at Rome, and the "Index" Revising Committee were warned to be ready to make the necessary expurgations before it should circulate within the States of the Church. We are not sufficiently familiar with the general views of this committee to know whether the dreaded Preface, now that it has made its appearance, will be considered heterodox or not. But to secular readers, we should say, it sounds most uncommonly like a string of the Imperial Author's famous New-Year's utterances, tied together with a few scraps of historical reference. Our readers will find it elsewhere and may judge for themselves.

abstract: Fort Lafayette is full. The captured host sent there, on Monday, by Col. BAKER, has monopolized the famous rooms Nos. two and three, in which Gen. LEE, Maj. Gen. GARDNER, Mr. President BICKLEY, K. G.C., and other noted men were confined, as well...
lead_paragraph: Fort Lafayette is full. The captured host sent there, on Monday, by Col. BAKER, has monopolized the famous rooms Nos. two and three, in which Gen. LEE, Maj. Gen. GARDNER, Mr. President BICKLEY, K.G.C., and other noted men were confined, as well as the batteries Nos. four, five and six, in which blockade-runners, neutral Englishmen and contractors innumerable have slept and smoked and cursed. Col. MARTIN BURKE, the jolly and sui geneeis Commandant of the post, sits, as is his cheerful custom, on the porch and smokes his pleasant pipe, but no longer does his eye fall on Foreign Ministers, on Major-Generals, on rich contractors, or on civil prisoners of gentle birth; he now sees none but dirty-faced bounty-jumpers and nimble-legged deserters, who peer at him from behind their doors and windows, and would hang, draw and quarter him for breakfast. They are not permitted the privilege of the parade-ground, but are locked up closely in the batteries from which the partitions have been knocked, leaving one long room in place of the former three. The scene upon the arrival at Fort Lafayette beggars description. The roughest, devil-me-carest set of fellows ever seen, handcuffed and chained together, some grumbling, but the majority of them swearing and joking as if they had been the victims of a great practical joke, whose point they not only saw, but appreciated. Col. BURKE was for once surprised. All classes of men, all grades of society, had been under his look and key, as he supposed, but it was left for Col. BAKER to astonish him with a new phase of humanity, whose peculiarities he is now studying and enjoying. The men will be kept there for a short time and then sent to the front. On the return of the boat the rebel Gen. PAGE, Col. MONTGOMERY and others, were brought to Pier No. 1 North River whence they went to Fort Delaware, while all the State prisoners were sent to Fort Warren.

abstract: MARY DALTON, a young and interesting Canalstreet milliner, was called to the bar at Jefferson Market, and Mrs. OTILLIE MAAS appeared and accused her of picking her pocket in Canal-street.
lead_paragraph: MARY DALTON, a young and interesting Canalstreet milliner, was called to the bar at Jefferson Market, and Mrs. OTILLIE MAAS appeared and accused her of picking her pocket in Canal-street. Officer GILLMARTIN, of the Ninth Ward, who arrested the prisoner, testified that he found the complainant's wallet in the gutter, whither the accused had thrown it, and upon this testimony Justice DODGE committed the prisoner in default of $1,500 bail.

lead_paragraph: -Statistics just issued by the Department of Agriculture, show that while the farms of the loyal States, in 1863 produced, crops worth $955,764,322, those of 1864 yielded no less than $1,504,543,690. This is certainly a satisfactory increase, and a remarkable one, considering the circumstances.

abstract: Our position at
snippet: Our position at
lead_paragraph: The temporary check which COX's forces received last Wednesday at Kinston, was succeeded, two days later, by a decisive repulse of BRAGG, who was rash enough to attack our troops in their intrenchments. In the former affair, with about equal loss in killed and wounded, the enemy, according to BRAGG, captured three guns and 1,500 prisoners; in the latter he was driven off with severe loss, leaving his dead and badly wounded on the field, and several hundred prisoners in our hands; and eventually he retreated across the Neuse River. The balance of victory, therefore, is in our favor, for we hold the field. The first day's issue excited some apprehension, because it was an anomaly in the unchecked series of victories with which the year has greeted our arms thus far. Some ill-informed people supposed that Newbern straightway itself was in danger. That was impossible. With Fort Totten sweeping the entire area between the Neuse and the Trent, which make their confluence at the city, with the other earthworks protecting both banks of each river, and the numerous gunboats patrolling them for long distances, the capture of Newbern by an army of forty thousand rebels was impracticable, even with its ordinary garrison. With the number of troops of late concentrated there, Newbern was as safe as New-York.

abstract: Clark vs. James and Erastus Brooks. -- The defendants in this case made an application to stay all proceedings herein until the decision of the General Term upon the appeal which has been taken. The court in deciding the motion said: As the appeal will bring under review all the questions decided in the case, there is a propriety in granting a stay of proceedings until the appeal can be heard at General Term. It can probably be heard and disposed of at the next term, I do not deem it necessary therefore to modify the stay by directing the accounting to be taken before the pending appeal is decided.

abstract: Newark; C Stickler, by soldiers
snippet: Newark; C Stickler, by soldiers
lead_paragraph: MURDER IN NEWARK. -- On Monday night a German named CHRISTPHER STICKLER was shot and killed by a soldier of the Veteran Reserve Corps, under the following circumatances : STICKLER had just left a grocery-store on the corner Mulberry and South Canal streets, and while engaged in a conversation with a young woman on the sidewalk, was accosted by two soldiers named EDWARD COOTE and JOHN ROLLINS of the Veteran Reserve Corps. STICKLER was ordered to leave, which he declined to do, when COOTE drew a cavalry revolver and fired, the ball taking effect on STICKLER's left temple, penetrating to the brain. The injured man was removed to the police station where he died yesterday morning, having remained unconscious from the time the wound was inflicted. COOTE and ROLLINS, two other soldiers and the young woman with whom deceased was in conversation, were subsequently arrested and are held to await the result of the Coroner's inquest. COOTE admitted the deed and alleged that he was acting in self-defence. Deceased was a single man about 45 years of age.

abstract: Whiting, Virginia Loring, Prima Donna; Steinway, Henry
snippet: Whiting, Virginia Loring, Prima Donna; Steinway, Henry
lead_paragraph: VIRGINIA LORINI WHITING, the once favorite prima donna, died on the 28th of February last at Santiago de Cuba, of an attack of hemorrhage. Madame LORINI was the wife of M. LORINI, now with MARETZEK's company, and the daughter of WHITING the comedian. As an artist the deceased enjoyed a wide reputation. After making her debut in this city, she went to Europe, where she won on enviable position as an artist. Though not a great tragic actress, Madame LORINI was capable of playing such parts as Norma and Lucrezia in an acceptable manner She leaves a large family, to whom she was devotedly attached.

abstract: Patriotic Action on Draft
snippet: Patriotic Action on Draft
lead_paragraph: -We dare say there are many exemplary things done by the citizens of the Tenth Ward, when they take counsel together. But we are specially bound to notice one movement in that ward, and to commend it as one altogether worthy of imitation. The ward has appointed an active, intelligent, and patriotic committee to act with committees from the other wards of the Fifth Congressional District, as auxiliaries of the County Volunteer Board, in the business of recruiting, and thus save the district from the disparagement of being visited with the draft. Who shall say that this movement is not wise, timely, and patriotic? The Tenth Ward, herein, points out the highway of duty. It is for others, on this occasion, to follow.

abstract: Sheridan and Schofield's March
snippet: Sheridan and Schofield's March
lead_paragraph: A thousand canards are brought low, a thousand falsehoods set at rest, a thousand fears dispelled, by a single sentence from the pen of Gen. SHERMAN. It pricks the bombast of the Richmond newspapers, explains the reticence of the rebel authorities, and, we hope, will, for a time, bring shame and silence to the rebel sympathizing organs in this city, -- one of which has been for weeks insisting that SHERMAN was in full flight backward from JOE. JOHNSTON, and the other, only yesterday, devoted several columns to showing that his campaign was a failure, and his army retreating to Charleston. The ink that gave visible existence to this nonsense was not dry when the bulletin of Secretary STANTON converted it into the material for irrepressible laughter.

lead_paragraph: Up to a late hour last evening, complete uncertainty prevailed about the draft ordered for the city to-day. Maj. DODGE, the Provost-Marshal, was at Washington, for special and final orders. In quarters where official position ought to afford the means of judging, it was thought during the afternoon that the draft would be enforced in all districts where recruits are not coming in fast enough to keep the enrolling boards busy, and not elsewhere. The County Volunteer Committee seemed to think that the draft would be enforced generally. Apparently the orders in the hands of the District Provost-Marshals might be construed to command either a draft, or to be in readiness to draft. Orders from Washington might, however, decide the whole matter in any way at any moment.

lead_paragraph: The public mind was rejoiced yesterday as by the receipt of official dispatches direct from Gen. SHERMAN. He was, on the 8th inst., at Laurel Hill, N.C., going ahead finely. This place is in Richmond County, about thirty miles southwest of Fayetteville. No particulars are given of his march, but it is certain that he has received not the slightest check.

abstract: -We doubt if the official intimation of Gov. FENTON respecting the draft, which we published yesterday, can be held to signify its indefinite postponement. We should regret to learn that it meant anything of the kind, unless we have first of all, the fullest assurance that volunteer recruiting makes satisfactory progress. It is well for us to remember that our quota in any event must be filled, and that steady exertion is needed to that end.

abstract: Tobacco Exchange Opened
snippet: Tobacco Exchange Opened
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning the new Tobacco Exchange, located in the Merchants Building, Nos. 50 and 52 Pine-street, was formally opened, a very large representation of tobacco growers, merchants and manufacturers from all parts of the Union being present. The halls elected for the Exchange is spacious and well lighted, and thoroughly adapted for the purpose to which it has been appropriated. By 11 o'clock the hall was thronged. One of the novelties exhibited was a quantity or fine, leaf tobacco from Connecticut, suitable for cigars.

abstract: Dey-street, Berg >amp; Co.--$100,000
snippet: Dey-street, Berg >amp; Co.--$100,000
lead_paragraph: DESTRUCTIVE FIRE IN DEY-STREET. -- A fire, the origin of which is unknown, was discovered about 7:3O o'clock last evening, on the third floor of No. 17 Dey-street, occupied by Messrs. BERG & CO., manufacturers of patent cigarettes. The flames spread with great rapidity, and entered the fourth story before the firemen had adjusted their machinery, and by the time when the engines had got fairly at work the fire had made such progress as to render it doubtful whether any part of the building could be saved; but at about 10 o'clock the firemen had gained the mastery, and checked the fire on the second story, leaving Messrs. RICH & BREWSTER's hardware establishment, on the first floor, uninjured, except by water. Messrs. LEHMAN & FERST's stock of clothing, on the second floor; Messrs. BERG & CO.'s stock of tobacco, on the third floor; Mr. WILLIAM MCGUIRE's boot and shoe manufactory, on the fourth floor, and Messrs. RICH & BREWSTER's hardware, stored on the fifth floor, were entirely consumed. The building in the rear of No. 17 Dey-street, and known as No. 14 Cortlandt-street, was entered by the firemen, and hose-pipes were put through to reach the fire in the rear, and the occupants of this building -- Messrs. MEADE, TOWNSHEND & ANDREWS, IRA SHEPARDSON, and CHARLES H. CARPENTER, all wholesalers of boots and shoes, suffered trivial loss by water. The entire loss is roughly estimated at $100,000.

abstract: New-Hampshire held her annual election yesterday, for Governor, Legislature, and Members of Congress.
lead_paragraph: New-Hampshire held her annual election yesterday, for Governor, Legislature, and Members of Congress. Two years ago there was no choice of Governor by the people. EASTMAN, the Democratic candidate, had 32,833; GILMORE, Republican, 29,035; and HARRIMAN, Union and Independent, 4,372. GILMORE was, however, elected by the Legislature. At the same time the Democrats succeeded in electing one Member of Congress -- DANIEL MARCY, in the First District -- by 80 majority. Last Spring there were but two candidates for Governor, and the vote was: GILMORE, (Republican,) 37,006; HARRINGTON, (Democrat,) 31,340; Republican majority, 5,666. In November, LINCOLN had only 3,529 majority. Yesterday, the Republicans did better than in 1864. Although the vote was rather light, and the interest (outside of the First Congressional District,) nothing like that of last Spring, they carried the State by more than 6,000 majority. Their best work, however, was the defeating of Gen. MARCY, who was again the Democratic candidate for Congress; and that defeat was achieved in spite of a split in our own ranks, which threatened an easy victory for the other side. As we write we receive returns from 127 towns, giving 24,665 Republican to 18,313 Democratic votes. Gen. MARSTON's majority over MARCY is about 1,500; the other Republican Congressmen, have each about 2,000 majority; all of the Councillors, nine of the twelve Senators, and about three-fourths of the members of Assembly are Republicans. Altogether, New-Hampshire has done well, and nobly responds to the great military victories now being won almost daily in the heart of JE[???]F DAVIS' dominions.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon a young man of undoubted Teutonic extraction, entered the War Department rooms, at the Astor House, and desired to learn what course the Government would pursue if one of his friends, who had deserted, were to surrender to Col. BAKER.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon a young man of undoubted Teutonic extraction, entered the War Department rooms, at the Astor House, and desired to learn what course the Government would pursue if one of his friends, who had deserted, were to surrender to Col. BAKER. The reply was that he might assure his friend that the Colonel would treat him with perfect fairness under the President's late proclamation, and return him to his regiment. Thereupon the Colonel's visitor vanished, and the matter was forgotten. But later in the afternoon he reappeared, and told his story as follows: "I overstaid my furlough more than a year ago, and, fearing to return to my regiment, sought employment in the country; but this recently failed me, and yesterday I found myself in this city, penniless and unable to find work. The brokers offered me $600, $700, $800, and even $900 to enlist, out I didn't want to take too many oaths, because they might not be easy of digestion. I accidentally read in the newspapers the President's Proclamation, offering full pardon to deserters, and came here accordingly." The man, who rendered the name of NATHAN WEST, of Company F, Fourteenth United States Infantry, was sent to Col. BAKER's "lock-up," and is to be forwarded to his regiment's headquarters, at Fort Trumbull, Conn., this morning.

abstract: -The great items (tea, sugar, coffee and the like) of the house-keeper's grocery account were not a fraction higher -- we speak of the smaller retail dealers -- when gold sold at 280, than they were yesterday, when gold could be had in any quantity at 180. Yet a little while, and this thing will cease to be. Trade combinations, trade conspiracies, and high prices have had their day. We shall see them broken up with the break-up of the combinations and conspiracies of the Richmond rebels.

abstract: The fourth annual masquerade ball of the Purim Association was given last evening at the Academy of Music. The society is composed...
lead_paragraph: The fourth annual masquerade ball of the Purim Association was given last evening at the Academy of Music. The society is composed exclusively of Jews, and the proceeds are to be devoted to charitable purposes. The Purim Ball is held to commemorate one of the great epochs o-Jewish history -- the deliverance of the chosen people from the machinations of Haman, Prime Minister to King Ahasuerus, of Persia. The first-Purim Ball was held at Irving Hall, and the succeeding ones have been at the Academy of Music. That they are very popular was proven by the fete of last evening.

abstract: Edinburgh Review on our Generals; Edinburgh Review on; Edinburgh Review on our Generals; Edinburgh Review on
snippet: Edinburgh Review on our Generals; Edinburgh Review on; Edinburgh Review on our Generals; Edinburgh Review on
lead_paragraph: An article in the last Edinburgh Review, apparently from a military authority, pays at length the proper tribute of respect from the candid critics of Europe to our military operations during the last two years. The usual picture presented by the correspondence and the editorials of the London Times of our great, struggle, has been of wide and aimless enterprises by the "Federals," where thousands were butchered without purpose, and where no military genius or comprehensive plan ever threw any light on the ghastly scene of slaughter. The Confederates alone showed strategical ability and heroic daring, and the only military leaders which the contest had brought forth, worthy of appearing on the page of history, were Stonewall JACKSON, and Gen. LEE. The whole confused mass of movements was pronounced "not war but bushwhacking on a large scale."

abstract: Ticonderoga, Wreck of; Imposter's Story
snippet: Ticonderoga, Wreck of; Imposter's Story
lead_paragraph: A sailor wearing the naval rig made his appearance at the Union Volunteer Refreshment Saloon, on Saturday afternoon, and represented that he had been wrecked in the United States sloop-of-war Ticonderoga, off Cape Fear, on Tuesday night last. He said that the vessel was bound for Newbern, and that she encountered a violent storm, which began on Sunday and continued up to. Tuesday night, when the vessel was driven on a bar, and in about fifteen minutes had seven feet of water in the hold; that in a few minutes the boats were lowered, and officers and men took to them. A raft, he says, was constructed and launched, on which the rest of the crew took refuge. Rockets were fired as signals of distress, and the steamer Ellsworth, for Boston, took them all off and brought them to this port. All escaped, according to his story, but the Chief Engineer, an assistant and the coal-heaver, who were in the engine and boiler rooms when the vessel struck. Though the man tells a very plausible story, there are good-reasons for believing that the whole thing is a fabrication. He represents the Ticonderoga to have been a side-wheel steamer, which is not a fact; nor does he give the proper name of the commander of the vessel. He Says that she carried eight guns, whereas her armament consists of twenty guns. Besides, no one about the Navy-yard has heard of her loss, nor have officers or sailors from her been landed there. It is not probable that the man could have been mistaken in the character of the vessel, if he had been, as he says, several months on board of her, nor in the name of the commander. -- Philadelphia Ledger, March 13.

abstract: Teachers' Salaries in Brooklyn Increased; Brooklyn Board of Education, Officers of
snippet: Teachers' Salaries in Brooklyn Increased; Brooklyn Board of Education, Officers of
lead_paragraph: INCREASE OF TEACHERS' SALARIES. -- The Brooklyn Board of Education last evening increased the salaries of female teachers of the Public Schools to the amount of $75. Heretofore the teachers received an average salary of $312 per year. The number of female teachers in the city is 456. The board also elected officers for the ensuing year. The following were chosen: President, Cyrus P. Smith; Vice-President, J.S. Thorne, M.D.; Superintendent, J.W. Bulkley; Secretary, G.W.A. Stewart; Clerk, Henry Dean; Messenger, Nathaniel Creswell.

abstract: -Since  the advent of Col. BAKER, the military subordinates attached to the Department of the East have been slightly aroused to the importance of their duty, and have of late exhibited more energy in dealing with cases where soldiers of the United States army have been robbed of their bounty.
lead_paragraph: -- Since the advent of Col. BAKER, the military subordinates attached to the Department of the East have been slightly aroused to the importance of their duty, and have of late exhibited more energy in dealing with cases where soldiers of the United States army have been robbed of their bounty. A case occurred last October, which should have been attended to at least three months ago, where a mere child was kidnapped by a notorious bounty-jumper named THOMAS HEANEY, residing at No. 15 Prince-street, Brooklyn. HEANEY, it is stated, is a member of a gang of bounty-jumpers, who, practiced their nefarious profession all last Summer at Elmira -- some of them taking the rounds as often as two or three or four times. A gambling-house was established by this gang at the corner of Hudson-avenue and Johnson-street, where they assembled nights to dissipate their ill-gotten gains. This HEANEY, as represented, induced a boy, named WM. MCCLOSKEY, to accompany him to Staten Island for the purpose of enlisting, promising to give him $1,000 as soon as he was examined by the doctor. He was handed $300, as stated, and immediately thrust into the guardroom without giving him time to remonstrate. HEANEY being acquainted with the premises, went to a window looking into the guard-room and induced a boy to give the money to a brother-in-law in Brooklyn. The money was intrusted to the boy but never returned. Complaint was made to Gen. DIX, and after considerable trouble the applicant succeeded in having an order of arrest granted which was placed in the hands of Detective CHARLES FROST, who brought the culprit before Gen. DIX yesterday. The case was submitted to Major JOLINE, and the matter appears to have been compromised.

abstract: New-York City; Fares, Laws of June 30, 1864
snippet: New-York City; Fares, Laws of June 30, 1864
lead_paragraph: By an amendment to the law of June 30, 1864, our city railroad companies are fully authorized to add one cent to their fares, on and after the 1st of April next. When the companies raised their fares, some months ago, the public resisted on the ground that the companies were only authorized by law to add the Government tax of two and a half per cent., and not to increase the fares to six cents. The amended law does away with this objection, as appears from the following:

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- AUBER's charming opera of "Fra Diavolo," will be given here to-night, for the last time this season. It has proved so generally successful that there can hardly be a doubt about the attendance which will greet its final rendering tonight. Mr. MARETZEK's subscription season terminates most positively on Saturday, with a grand matinee performance of "La Forza del Destino."

abstract: Operations of; His Generalship Estimated
snippet: Operations of; His Generalship Estimated
lead_paragraph: ROBERT E. LEE, just appointed to the supreme command of the rebel armies, has the name of being a military genius. The rebels, from the beginning of the war, have glorified him as such, and the North has never been much inclined to dispute it. Yet there is good reason to doubt whether, after all, his ability is not rather relative than absolute --whether he is not great as the one-eyed man in chief among the blind.

abstract: Divorce, Kaiser J and A; Curious Deed of Separation
snippet: Divorce, Kaiser J and A; Curious Deed of Separation
lead_paragraph: -- We have in our possession a somewhat remarkable document, issued by a German Justice of the Peace of this city, and dated June 13, 1861. It is entitled "Articles of Separation," and sets forth that, whereas, divers unhappy differences and disputes have arisen between JACOB KAISER and ANNA KAISER, his wife, they have agreed to live separate and apart from each other during their natural life. The document then goes on to state that JACOB doth covenant, promise and agree with ANNA, his wife, that he will allow her to be in such a place and family as she may from time to time choose; that he will not interfere with her or with any person for harboring her, provided she leaves the city of Detroit and State of Michigan within eight days from the date above given, and that he will not interfere with any of her possessions, provided she accepts from him the sum of $35 in full for all demands and claims against him. ANNA, on her part, covenants with JACOB, in consideration of the sum of $35, in hand paid, to renounce all claims on him, and agrees that she will not in any manner disturb him henceforth nor claim any share of the real or personal estate which he may acquire, and that she will treat him henceforth as though she had never been married to him. The document is signed and sealed in the presence of witnesses, for which it is said that the justice received a fee of $20. Truly a novel and original method of divorce. The separation lasted but a few months, when the parties lived together again and continued to do so until JACOB enlisted into the army, where he now is, fighting the battles of his adopted country, -- Detriot Tribune
headline: {'main': 'NOVEL METHOD OF DIVORCE.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'NOVEL METHOD OF DIVORCE.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Rome and Modern Reform
snippet: Rome and Modern Reform
lead_paragraph: -- The Cardinal Vicar of Rome, according to to-day's European news, has followed up the Encyclical by another rescript, in which modern views of reform are severely, stigmatized. From the terms and the tone adopted by the Cardinal Vicar in this missive, it is not difficult to see that both MAXIMILIAN and NAPOLEON are specially aimed at. The error of regarding "liberty of conscience" an a legal right it stigmatized with severity, as is also the doctrine of the freedom of religious worship, and the still more heterodox theory, that the will of the people is the supreme law. If there is not much policy in this disposition of modern liberalism, there is at least courage displayed in the ennuciation of the principles to which the church holds itself bound. It will remain to be seen how far these repeated assaults on popular systems of government tend to promote Roman Catholic unity. The Archbishop of Baltimore has already openly declared -- in opposition to the views of Rome -- for every one of the rights denounced in the Encyclical, and anathematized in stronger terms by the Cardinal Vicar. The American prelate not only holds liberty of conscience, and the freedom of religious worship to be legal rights, but their guarantee by the Constitution of the United States, he regards an act of supreme wisdom. These political lectures from Rome, however, are probably not intended for this country. Certainly they will disturb the views of no one fit to exercise the rights of a citizen, or entitled to the heritage of a freeman.
headline: {'main': 'ROME AND MODERN REFORM', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'ROME AND MODERN REFORM', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Sophia Maurer by her Guardian, &c., vs. Andrew Veuli. -- This action is brought to recover the sum of $10,000 damages for an alleged breach of a marriage contract. The parties to the suit are Germans, and have the appearance of being very respectable. The promise to marry was proved on the part of the plaintiff, and the fact that defendant for a long time refused to comply with his promise, although often requested so to do.

abstract: We still continue in the full and uninterrupted enjoyment of most delicious weather, and it will in all probability last for some days. The roads and camps are now in very good condition. A ride round the army yesterday evidenced the fact that a move may take place at any day, so far as regards the state of the ground, but it is extremely difficult to make any prophesy in the premises.
