abstract: -- There is no such malignant or offensive type of non-resident foreigners among us as the herds of unemployed knaves that have been thrown on our streets by the collapse of the blockade-running business. They are insolent in proportion to their filth and raggedness, and they fancy that their flag is specially intended to cover insolence. They will be taken altogether by surprise on learning that the Secretary of State has given them just twelve days to pack up and leave the country in a body. This measure is altogether commendable. Our citizens generally would have gladly seen it introduced sooner.

abstract: New York; Charities in War Time; Operations
snippet: New York; Charities in War Time; Operations
lead_paragraph: To the historian, one of the most remarkable features of the civil war in America, will be the fact that during all its absorbing ex citement, its immense sacrifices, and its fearful evils and passions, the great work of civilization in the Free States of the West went steadily on. Our system of education has been constantly improving and enlarging, and never before were those especial branches of charity, which are the highest evidence of the humanity of a people, so liberally supported or so efficient. The proof of this could be taken from hundreds of different sources, but a fresh evidence has just been furnished in the annual report of a charitable association to which we have recently referred -- the Children's Aid Society.

snippet: The New-York, Commencement of
lead_paragraph: -- A Partial misapprehension of the terms of Gov. FENTON's announcement respecting the draft, no doubt led most of our citizens to believe that the wheel would not be put in operation yesterday. The deputies of the Provost-Marshal-General, however, seem to have had their cue, and the drafting process, as our ample report shows, was commenced in several wards, and proceeded without interruption through the day. The victims an probably eased in their minds by the official announcement from Gen. FRY, that none of the drafted will be required to report for duty as long as volunteer recruiting makes the same satisfactory progress that it does of the present time. The theory of the War Department, doubtless, is that those liable for military duty, whose names appear in the conscript list, will henceforth have strong inducements to become active recruiting agent. If this theory is correct, the County Volunteer Committee will be kept busy to an unprecedented degree from this day out.

lead_paragraph: The Syracuse Courier reports a sad case of suicide at that city on Saturday evening. LEWIS B. SEYMOUR, a young man of respectable character, employed as a clerk in SABEY's hat-store, took a dose of strychnine at his boarding-house, which resulted in death. He had made attempts upon his life before, and was subject to fits of despondency akin to insanity. He was cheerful when with a party of companions, but became dejected when alone, or with a single companion. He left letters addressed to his brother, which indicate that he was fully resolved upon ending his career by his own hands. The following are the letters:

abstract: -- The partial removal of muck from the gutters, which is in progress here and there, through the city, is effected by a cool and deliberate effort on the part of the laborers, which challenges notice. The heaps are so gently stirred, and the process goes on by such imperceptibly gradual degrees, that it might almost be supposed the honest workmen had some personal interest in prolonging the job for weeks, or, peradventure, months. Possibly, the real reason for carrying on operations among the dirt heaps in the manner noticed, is to prevent the sudden escape of the offensive gases they may happen to contain. We live in the days when sanitary science has come to be understood so generally that even the unskilled laborer no doubt begins to appreciate it.

abstract: The determination, which Mr. LINCOLN is said to have announced, not to make any removals amongst his subordinates in office, except for incompetency or misconduct, will be a source of sincere satisfaction for everybody who has any regard for the efficiency of the public service.
lead_paragraph: The determination, which Mr. LINCOLN is said to have announced, not to make any removals amongst his subordinates in office, except for incompetency or misconduct, will be a source of sincere satisfaction for everybody who has any regard for the efficiency of the public service. In fact, one of the reasons which attracted the people in retaining Mr. LINCOLN himself for a second term, forbids all changes which can possibly be avoided amongst those who serve under him.

abstract: The brigs Eunice and Sarah Flagg which arrived here a few days ago, brought as passengers, five hundred persons, most of whom have been engaged in running the blockade of the insurgent ports. Among these men, fifty-one had certificates of discharge from British vessels, nearly all of which have been engaged in the contraband trade with the vessels. A few had passports, and others had ...
lead_paragraph: The brigs Eunice and Sarah Flagg which arrived here a few days ago, brought as passengers, five hundred persons, most of whom have been engaged in running the blockade of the insurgent ports. Among these men, fifty-one had certificates of discharge from British vessels, nearly all of which have been engaged in the contraband trade with the vessels. A few had passports, and others had papers certifying that they were subjects of the Queen of Great Britain. A number of them claimed to have gone into the business for the purpose of escaping from the Southern States, but on being closely questioned, admitted that the statement was only partially true. The passengers on the Sarah Flagg threatened to shoot the Captain, on the arrival of the vessel in this port, because be prevented them from going on shore previous to the examination of their papers. They were quieted by the assurance that they would be promptly passed, all having regular papers. The steamer Owl, a blockade-running vessel, sailed from Havana, a few days ago, with seventy-six blockade-runners on board. According to the statements of the men on the Eunice and Flagg, the blockade-runners had chartered the Owl to come to New-York; but the Consul at Havana knew them, and declined to give the required facilities.

lead_paragraph: CITY NOTES. -- St. Patrick's Day will be celebrated to-morrow by a grand civic and military parade, and by banquets in the evening. In the morning, at 10 1/2 o'clock, the Most Rev. Archbishop MCCLOSKY will celebrate Pontifical High Mass in the Cathedral, and Father DEALY, of St. John's College, will deliver a discourse on the Life of ST. PATRICK. The streets through which the procession is to pass will be thoroughly cleaned....Hon. FREDERICK A. CONKLING will deliver a lecture before the Geographical Society this evening. Subject -- The "Production and Consumption of Cotton....Miss EMMA HARDINGE lectures at Cooper Institute this evening Her lecture is entitled "Politics vs. Principles."....The College of Pharmacy celebrates its thirty-fifth annual commencement at the chapel of the University, Washington-square, this evening.

abstract: The depression, yesterday, in the flour and grain markets was sufficient to indicate that the speculative prices can no longer be maintained. Wheat had a fall of from five to seven cents a bushel. Corn shows the same tendency. Good butter, at wholesale, went off as low as thirty cents a pound. The pork market is described by the reporter as "panicky," everybody anxious to sell, and prices very much lower. Sugar shows the same downward course. And even coal has lately taken a tumble. The signs, indeed, on all hands, are better than they have been for a twelvemonth or more, that the extreme boundary of high prices has been reached, and that the long-suffering consumer will by-and-by have his turn.

abstract: -- Messrs. RICH & BREWSTER, dealers in hardware, on the first floor, $25,000; insurance $15,000, in Jefferson, Clinton, and Equitable offices. Mr. D. NEWGASS, dealer in cigars, on the second floor front, $7,000; insurance $3,500 in the Central Park and $2,590 in the Firemen's Fund offices. Mr. B. CAIN, dealer in clothing, on the second floor, rear, $5,000; insurance $1,000 in the Excelsior, $2,500 in the Globe, and $2,000 in the Denox. Messrs. BERG & CO., cigarettee manufacturers, on the third floor, lost $7,000, and was insured for $1,000 in the Firemen's Fund, $1,500 in the Star, $3,500 in the Brooklyn and $3,000 in the Relief. Messrs. HAUSMAN & GUMPERT, looking-glass frame makers and gilders, on the fourth and fifth floors, lost $3,000, but in what offices they are insured we have not learned. The Merchants' Company had insured looking-glasses on storage on the fifth floor, for $2,500. The building, which was owned by Mr. JAMES FELLOWS, was valued at $15,000, and insured for $8,000 in the Niagara office and $4,000 in the Home. Total loss, as estimated by the insurance companies agent at about $60,000.

lead_paragraph: Complete returns of the cotton supply in England for 1864 have been made up. They show the receipts of the year to have been 893,304,720 pounds. That is about the same as the imports of 1855; but less than two-thirds of the receipts either of 1860 or 1861. The increase is very marked over the years 1862 and 1863.

abstract: Root, Hon. J. M , ap. U. S. Dis't Attorney, Northern District
snippet: Root, Hon. J. M , ap. U. S. Dis't Attorney, Northern District
lead_paragraph: Our war news yesterday, Or rather up to 1 o'clock this morning, was very brief, but good as far as it went. By way of Fortress Monroe, we learn that on the morning of the 11th inst., scouts from Gen. SHERMAN reached Wilmington, with the news that his army reached Fayetteville, N.C., and were encamped in its immediate vicinity. Another dispatch, dated Washington, says: "The Navy Department has received advices by the steamer Lehigh, at Fortress Monroe, that Gen. SCHOFIELD occupied Kingston, N.C., on the 15th inst., Gen. BRAGG and his army retreating." This is seemingly corroborated by advices from Newbern to the 12th, at 4 P.M., which, after speaking of BRAGG's retreat to Kinston, says: "The enemy will not be able to remain in Kinston long, even if they decide to make another stand, of which there is much doubt." The same dispatch reports that SHERMAN has opened communication with Wilmington, by way of Fayetteville, but does not say that he is in the latter place.

abstract: United States vs. Charles Mamelocke. -- The prisoner was charged with using and selling counterfeit revenue stamps for cigars of the denominations of ten and fifteen dollars, and his examination was set down for 12 o'clock yesterday. On Tuesday night, however, a box full of these spurious stamps, which had been taken from the prisoner at the time of his arrest, was stolen from the Inspector who had them in charge, and for want of these as evidence, the case was put off until Monday.

abstract: Margolf vs Miller; Attorney's Fees
snippet: Margolf vs Miller; Attorney's Fees
lead_paragraph: George Margolf vs. Joseph Miller and Eliza Miller, his Wife. -- The action was brought to recover the sum of $700 damages for an alleged breach of contract. In June, 1864, the parties to the suit entered into a written agreement, whereby Miller and his wife agreed to sell to the plaintiff a house and lot in the Eighth-avenue for the sum of $16,000. The negotiations of sale were conducted through a real estate broker. By the terms of the contract $500 was to be deposited with the broker, and all the necessary disbursements and expenses attending the examination of the title were to be defrayed by the defendant. The stipulated $500 was deposited with the broker, and subsequently an attorney for plaintiff searched the title to the house and lot, and found it, as he claimed, defective; he therefore advised his client not take it. The attorney alleges that for attention to the searches, and for disbursements therein, he is entitled to $200, and for the recovery of this amount, and the $500 deposited, the suit was brought. Some of the witnesses on the trial testified that $75, exclusive of disbursements, was a reasonable fee for such services. At the conclusion of the evidence, the court, on motion of defendant's counsel, excluded from the consideration of the jury the $500; he holding that plaintiff had failed to show a defective title. The jury rendered a verdict of $175 damages.

abstract: -- Col. BAKER's business has increased rapidly of late, and at length driven him to seek more commodious quarters. These he has found on a second floor in Vesey-street, near the Astor, and thither he will move to-day. Among the visitors at the Colonel's rooms last evening, was Hon. DANIEL S. DICKINSON. The venerable Ex-Attorney-General called to introduce one of his neighbors, and solicit the Colonel's aid in restoring a boy of seventeen to his parents, the boy having been spirited off by bounty-brokers, who gave him only $30 of the $600 or $900 that the county paid.

abstract: Sunday Mercury, McCabe Libel; Motion to Dismiss Denied
snippet: Sunday Mercury, McCabe Libel; Motion to Dismiss Denied
lead_paragraph: John H. McCabe vs. Cauldwell and Whitney. -- At the opening of the court, yesterday morning, this case was called up, and the Judge, in giving his decision refusing to grant the dismissal of tha complaint asked for by defendant's counsel on Monday last, said that as to some of the points raised he had had doubts. One of the questions argued on the motion for a non-suit, was whether the body known as a Grand Jury was a judicial body, and whether the proceedings and investigations which take place in the Grand Jury room were of such a nature as came within the statute of 1854 of this State, which in substance provides that no reporter, editor or proprietor of a newspaper shall be held accountable for fair and correct reports of proceedings in any judicial or administrative body. The Judge said that while he disapproved of the manner in which the secret sessions of Grand Juries were by law held, and while he knew that in many instances the characters of innocent persons were often blackened by reason of the ex parte proceedings of a Grand Jury, he did not like to establish a precedent, whereby it might become possible for a Grand Jury room to be thrown open to reporters of the public press. He thought it better that, inasmuch as the case had been already spread to some extent before the public, that the whole matter should be allowed to go to the jury. The defendants would be permitted in their defence to give testimony as to the truth of the alleged libelous publication. According to the law, as it now exists in this State, the defendants are permitted to prove the truth of the matter which is charged to be libelous, and in the absence of any malice being shown this constitutes a valid defence. In conclusion, the Judge said, the trial must go on.

abstract: Edwards, Amelia B; Ballads; Barton's Culture of Observing Faculties; Savarin's Handbook of Dining; Williams, J, B; Leaves from Note-book Detective; Woodward's Country Homes
snippet: Edwards, Amelia B; Ballads; Barton's Culture of Observing Faculties; Savarin's Handbook of Dining; Williams, J, B; Leaves from Note-book Detective; Woodward's Country Homes
lead_paragraph: M. BRILLAT SAVARIN is an acknowledged authority of world-wide renown on all questions connected with the pleasures of the table, and their bearing on the higher faculties of man. His principal work is the "Physiologie du Gout," a book remarkable for its brilliancy of style as well as for the sound sense and hygienic wisdom of its precepts. On it Mr. SIMPSON's book is founded or adapted, with a reference rather of an ad captandum sort, to the questions of corpulency versus leanness, now regarded with great interest in England, through the publication of Mr. BANTING. This gentleman is a retired London tradesman, who, finding himself more unwieldy than was comfortable, reduced himself to a moderate size by adherence to a regimen, when none of the regular faculty were able to relieve him. From a fellow-feeling for others in the same cause, he printed a simple account of the method that had succeeded with himself, and in so doing, raised a storm of controversy that still resounds through the public press. The doctors, probably, were irritated at his unprofessional interference, and continue to denounce fiercely the dangerous consequences of adopting his system. There is little chance that Mr. BANTING ever heard o BRILLAT SAVARIN, but, curiously enough, the experience of the two exactly agrees, and may be expressed as briefly as possible. If you would avoid fat, partake not of farinacious or saccharine matter, as these two articles -- flour and sugar -- are the chief component parts of the "too, too solid" adipose tissue that clothes the ribs of those disposed to corpulence. The Hand-book of Dining is not confined to this topic, but reproduces much of the airy epicurean philosophy and gastric learning of the Physiologie, where the veteran gourmand rambles on in a mingled strain of theory and reminiscence, recalling the good dinners he has eaten, or explaining the principles involved in their conception. It is a book to provoke an appetite, while it confers a dignity on the function of eating, derived from the earnestness and attention employed on a consideration of the subject in all its bearings. The translation is idiomatic and correct, but scarcely reaches the fine ironical tone of its original.

abstract: Miscellaneous and Literary; Items
snippet: Miscellaneous and Literary; Items
lead_paragraph: -- Dr. Livingston's proposed expedition to the district between the north of Lake Nyassa and the south of Lake Tanganyka, assumes a substantial form. The Royal Geographical Society have held out the prospect of £500, the Foreign-office are understood to promise a similar sum, and a private friend and admirer of Dr. Livingston's has given anonymously the magnificent sum of £1,000. In addition to all this, it appears that Dr. Livingstone's position as Consul to the native races of Eastern Africa, with a salary of £500 a year, remains unmodified, though his duties as Consul at Quillimane have ceased. Adequate funds are therefore in existence for the maintenance of the expedition, conducted, as it is proposed to be, in a simple and economical manner.

abstract: Our occupation of
snippet: Our occupation of
lead_paragraph: -- Our forces have several times occupied Kinston, and it was once before the scene of an engagement as obstinate as that of last week. FOSTER carried the city, two years and three months ago, taking twelve cannon and over five hundred prisoners after a sharp battle. Another successful engagement at Whitehall enabled him to press on to Goldsboro. This city, perhaps, might have fallen then under a resolute attack. But his only purpose was to cooperate with BURNSIDE's assault on Fredericksburgh, by cutting railroad communication with Wilmington and Charleston. This his cavalry accomplished at Everettsville and Mount Olive. The present success of SCHOFIELD shows that what has been done once can be done again.

abstract: Board of Education, Appropriation for 1865
snippet: Board of Education, Appropriation for 1865
lead_paragraph: The Board of Education met on Tuesday evening, President MCLEAN in the chair, and nearly all the commissioners present. Mr. MILLER, of the committee whose duty it had been made to visit the school edifices in the Eleventh Ward, reported that of eight school buildings which they had visited, five were utterly unfit for school purposes, and three were barely tolerable. Of these, Grammar School No. 36, which was erected in 1847, was the most noteworthy as having a basement below the level of the sidewalk, under which tide water flows. In this ill-ventilated, ill-lighted room an average of seven hundred pupils are imprisoned daily, and on days of storm it is found necessary to take them to the attic to find light and air. The committee experienced great difficulty in reading the school-books in this dismal dungeon on the occasion of their visit, Grammar School building No. 15 was built in 1838, on a lot to which no play-ground was attached. The primary department is in a basement below the sidewalk level, and is dark and noisome. Here more than seven hundred children are imprisoned daily. Upon the committee's recommendation, the board authorized the Trustees of the Eleventh Ward to erect an additional story on this building, and recommended that the present primary department be converted into a play-ground. Primary School No. 31 is a rear building, of wood, combustible, dangerous and altogether unfit for a school-house. Primary No. 3 has only a narrow passage through which the pupils enter, and may escape in the event of fire, and the Board of Trustees asked power to construct a staircase on the street. The committee reported favorably, and the board authorized the work. Grammar School No. 22 is incomplete, in having no play-ground, and Primary No. 39 is unsuitable for a school.

lead_paragraph: W.A. BURLEIGH, Indian Agent for the Yancton and Sioux of Dakota, and delegate elect from that Territory, will soon return to his home, having succeeded in securing an appropriation of $10,000 to indemnify white citizens for outrages inflicted on their persons and depredations on their property, and also an appropriation of $20,000 for negotiating a treaty of peace with the hostile Sioux of the Upper Missouri. He has made an elaborate report to the Commissioner of Indian Affairs connected with his agency, from which it appears that the late military expeditions have been failures, and that most shameful wrongs have been committed by the friendly Indians in that part of the country. He says that peace may be secured with the hostile Indians at a comparatively small expenditure of money, and the settlement of the territory will be thus promoted.

abstract: Route of, through North Carolina; and Virginia, the Battle-ground
snippet: Route of, through North Carolina; and Virginia, the Battle-ground
lead_paragraph: North Carolina bids fair, at length, to divide with Virginia the field of conflict during the grand, final campaign of 1865. In these two States, the great bulk of the military forces of the Union are now gathered. South Carolina has been triumphantly fought over by us, and is already abandoned by both combatants. The movement on Mobile is to be regarded, in a broad view, rather as the very best method of employing the troops necessarily stationed as the garrison of the great Mississippi Valley, than as an integral part of the eastern combinations. The other forces stand in equipoise. KIRBY SMITH, PRICE and MAGRUDER, west of the Mississippi, are held in check by our various forces in Arkansas and Louisiana. A line of fortified posts in Tennessee defends that region from the threatened raids of FORREST.

abstract: Strong Divorce Case; Affidavits for Defendant
snippet: Strong Divorce Case; Affidavits for Defendant
lead_paragraph: This already somewhat noted case came up again yesterday afternoon before Judge MCCUNN, of the Superior Court. We published in the TIMES, a few days since, the affidavit of Mr. Peter R. Strong, the plaintiff, which was read upon a motion made by Mr. Cram, his counsel, to postpone the trial until the ensuing May Term, on the ground, principally, that there were certain indictments pending, the trial of which was about to be had in the Court of Special Sessions, against some of the important witnesses in the case. It was urged that the rights of the plaintiff and the ends of justice demanded the postponement. Mr. McKeon, counsel for defendant, at that time, contended that he had been taken by surprise by the production of Mr. Strong's affidavit, and asked for time to prepare affidavits to oppose the motion of the plaintiff. The court accordingly adjourned the further hearing of the motion until yesterday. The following are the affidavits read in opposition:

abstract: The Africa brings dates from Queenstown to the 5th inst. The news of the fall of Charleston sent Confederate stocks down and United States stocks up -- the former four, the latter two per cent. The English press generally look upon the position in this country as indicative of the early collapse of the Confederacy. The rebel pirate Stonewall was still at Ferrol, closely watched by Union cruisers. The seizure and disposal of neutral vessels by Confederate cruisers, without the formalities of a prize court hearing, has attracted the attention of Parliament. Mr. LAYARD replied that proper steps had been taken to prevent injustice. The Peruvian treaty of peace was officially laid before the Spanish Cortes a few days ago. The peace news from America created a decided panic in the cotton market in India. At Calcutta the change was greatly in favor of the buyer.

abstract: Count Johannes vs. Fiske; Judgment by Default
snippet: Count Johannes vs. Fiske; Judgment by Default
lead_paragraph: George M., The Count Joannes vs. Stephen R. Fiske -- The Count brought this action to recover the sum of $25,000 damages, which he contended he had sustained by reason of an alleged false and malicious article published some time since in the Leader. The defendant is charged with having written and published the libel, and in his complaint, the Count recites various ways and means whereby he was injured in his good name and fame. The defendant not contesting the case when called on for trial at the Special Term, the Court ordered that judgment be taken for the plaintiff by default, and directed that the whole matter be taken before a Sheriff's jury where the damages sustained by plaintiff could be assessed.

abstract: Sketch of the Prisoners in
snippet: Sketch of the Prisoners in
lead_paragraph: The occurrences of the past four years have made Fort Lafayette and its commandant, Col. MARTIN BURKE, historic and memorable. For obvious reasons it has not been deemed desirable hitherto that newspaper historians should have the run of the Fort, as their zeal might now and then get the better of a discretion which would suggest reticence rather than publicity. Within the past week, however, a vast change has taken place. Gen. DIX, the commander of the Department of the East, has removed from the dreaded Lafayette all the prisoners of war, all the prisoners of State, and all the noted men whose names figure on its roll, and their places are now filled by men whose trade for months has been the swindling of the people out of moneys untold, and the country out of soldiers and fighting material. The facts are well known, and there can, therefore, no longer be any necessity for the exclusion of visitors, professional or lay, to the most famous "House of Detention," thus far produced by the exigencies of the war.

abstract: Press on Fall of Charleston, >amp;c.
snippet: Press on Fall of Charleston, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: If there is nothing so difficult to believe in as human consistency, there is nothing so easy of belief as the thorough inconsistency of that which takes the indefinite name of public opinion. Reading such a telegraphic abstract of the views of the London press as we publish to-day, we are forced either to the conclusion that some of the foremost of these British organs are only now, for the first time, in actual possession of the real facts of this rebellion, or that, as some one concludes, "the puff of accidents carries most of us along with them, according to its ow nproclivity."

abstract: knew Inciters of Riots of 1863
snippet: knew Inciters of Riots of 1863
lead_paragraph: -- Mr. ACTON, one of the Commissioners of Police, has stated several times that he knew the parties who incited the riots of 1863; and day before yesterday he repeated this assertion before the Senatorial Committee, and declared that he could put his hand on the man who was at the bottom of the outrage and prove his guilt. Would it not be well for Mr. ACTON to place his information before the Grand Jury? It would be much more useful to that body than to the Senate Committee. Mr. A., moreover, would then have a chance to prove what he can now only assert. We commend this suggestion to his attention.

abstract: The Friendly Sons were not untrue to their traditions though it must be allowed that many of those whose names are inseparably connected with the history of their organization, and who have, in latter times, been the faciles principes at the annual banquet, have taken to "fresh fields and pastures new." Yet the society was not by any means lacking in talent at their dinner at Delmonico's last night.
lead_paragraph: The Friendly Sons were not untrue to their traditions -- though it must be allowed that many of those whose names are inseparably connected with the history of their organization, and who have, in latter times, been the faciles principes at the annual banquet, have taken to "fresh fields and pastures new." Yet the society was not by any means lacking in talent at their dinner at Delmonico's last night. The talent that constitutes not alone the pride, but the resource of Celtic fellow-citizens, was well represented by such men as Hon. C.P. Daly, Hon. John R. Brady, Hon. Edmund Hearne, Hon. Henry Alker -- (all Judges) -- Francis Byrne, Esq., John B. Fogarty, Esq., Wm.C. Traphagen, Esq., Joseph Choate, Esq., Wm.H. Ryan, Esq. -- (all lawyers) -- P. Mulvihill, John W. Webber, Wm. Watson, Eugene Kelly, Alexander Stuart, Joseph Stuart, Chas. Wilman, Wm. Hogust, Wm. Whiteside, J. Rice, Arthur O'Donnell, Wm. Dempster -- (all civilians of good standing and repute) -- and, as a representative of the lighting element, Gen. Van Vilet.

abstract: Times; Altered Tone of; Press; New Tone of
snippet: Times; Altered Tone of; Press; New Tone of
lead_paragraph: The London Times, and other Anti-Liberal journals of England, have exhausted deception. They are beginning to give out that the rebellion will fail. They no longer call us stark mad for persisting in a war that had no chance of success. They are getting into quite a complimentary vein, and are commending both our wisdom and our courage. They report events with some conformity to the truth; make deductions with some regard for reason. At this rate, their readers will soon be undeceived.

abstract: Carrier's Liability; Thatcher vs. Baltimore and Ohio Railroad; Telegraph Companies, Liability of
snippet: Carrier's Liability; Thatcher vs. Baltimore and Ohio Railroad; Telegraph Companies, Liability of
lead_paragraph: Thomas Thatcher vs. The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company. -- The plaintiff is a merchant in this city. In the spring of 1861, he received through the mail, a bill of lading from the firm of Messrs. G.C. Paoli & Co., of Chicago, with whom he had been dealing for a few months; the bill being signed by one M.C. Hale, the only authorized freight agent of the defendants at Chicago. It was in the usual form of a bill of lading, and stated that he, (Hale,) as freight agent of the company at Chicago had received 250 barrels of alcohol from Messrs. Paoli & Co., consigned to the plaintiff in New-York, and to be transported thither in good condition, &c. Accompanying the bill of lading was a draft of $2,500, drawn by Messrs. Paoli & Co. on the plaintiff. The latter, on the strength of the bill of lading, accepted the draft, and it was paid. The alcohol never came to hand, and plaintiff brought the suit to recover the money advanced, with interest, he claiming that defendants were liable for the acts of their agent, Hale, who gave the bill of lading upon which the money was obtained. It also appeared in evidence that Hale was a copartner with Paoli & Co., in Chicago, though that fact was unknown to the plaintiff at the time the advance was made. It furthermore appeared that Hale had no express authority from the company to sign the bill of lading in question.

Before Justice Robertson.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'LAW REPORTS.; Liability of Common Carriers The Question as to Advances Made on Bills of Lading SUPERIOR COURT. abstract: Clark, Jerome, (Sue Mundy) Hung at Louisville; Flag Replaced by Maj. Hennesy, Fifty-second Pennsylvania Volunteers
snippet: Clark, Jerome, (Sue Mundy) Hung at Louisville; Flag Replaced by Maj. Hennesy, Fifty-second Pennsylvania Volunteers
lead_paragraph: We have news direct from SHERIDAN to the 15th inst. He writes from the railroad bridge across the South Anna, a few miles north of Richmond. He reports that he destroyed the James River Canal as far eastward as Goochland, then marched North to Tolersville, on the Virginia Central Railroad, then easterly along that road, destroying it for 15 miles. From Beavers Dam Station he sent Gen. CUSTER to Ashland and Gen. DEVINS to the South Anna, and they destroyed all the bridges over that river. This cuts off all communication between Northwestern Virginia and Richmond, while the breaking up of the canal does the same for the western part of the State, thus reducing the rebels to the Southside and Danville Railroads as their only means of supply -- or escape, as things now look. The rebels made a feeble attempt to save the very important bridge on the Central Railroad over the South Anna, but they were easily repulsed, and three pieces of their artillery were captured.

abstract: The festivities of St. Patrick's Day passed off yesterday with entire success, and without any inauspicious circumstance. About 15,000 persons marched in procesaion, including the military, temperance societies and benevolent associations. The streets were very full of quiet and pleased spectators. The Mayor and Common Council reviewed the procession as it passed the City Hall.
lead_paragraph: The festivities of St. Patrick's Day passed off yesterday with entire success, and without any inauspicious circumstance. About 15,000 persons marched in procesaion, including the military, temperance societies and benevolent associations. The streets were very full of quiet and pleased spectators. The Mayor and Common Council reviewed the procession as it passed the City Hall. High mass at St. Patrick's Cothedral, morning services at the other Roman Catholic churches, elaborate dinners in the evening by the Knights of St. Patrick and the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick, with speeches and songs, and a sacred concert at the Church of the Immaculate Conception, concluded the observances of the day. In Brookly the St. Patrick's Society gave a dinner at the Academy of Music, at which Mr. RICHARD TERNAN presided, and the St. Patrick's Social Club gave a ball at Gothic Hall. There was an independent parade in Brooklyn.

abstract: -- We congratulate eastern travelers on the announcement that the New-Haven night boat (11 o'clock P.M.,) commenced her trips for the season last night. The splendid steamer Elm City, is the pioneer of the line this year. Unless there is a speedy reform in the management of railroads generally, the steamboat routes that enter into competition with them will, unquestionably, be more largely patronized than ever. It is worthy of note that there has been no accident on this New Haven route within the memory of "the oldest inhabitant." And it is also deserving of special mention for the benefit of the people of Connecticut, that by the facilities of this night line, they may spend the entire day and evening in New-York, and reach home next morning well refreshed, and in time for business. The management here is popular and efficient.

abstract: There has been very little activity in the American publishing trade during the present year, so far as the production of novelties is concerned. With a general state of business acknowledged to be highly satisfactory, there exists an apparent hesitation to venture upon new enterprises among the ...
lead_paragraph: -- There has been very little activity in the American publishing trade during the present year, so far as the production of novelties is concerned. With a general state of business acknowledged to be highly satisfactory, there exists an apparent hesitation to venture upon new enterprises among the prominent houses, that seems difficult to reconcile with the steady demand that all good books of standard character readily meet with at the present time. Undoubtedly, the increased cost of material and manufacture has something to do with this state of apathy, in connection with the presumption that any change occurring in these particulars must be toward lower prices. The public, however, have readily met the advanced cost of books, and there is no complaint on that score, so long as the article furnished is of good quality and execution. Even announcements for the future are scanty. Good historical literature seems in the ascendant, most of the important works forthcoming being of that description, as DYER's History of Modern Europe, and Prof. GEORGE LONG's History of the Decline of the Roman Republic, to be issued by Messrs. HARPER & BROTHERS, who have also, we believe, secured the courtesy-right of republication of LOUIS NAPOLEON's Life of Julius Caesar, at a somewhat less price than the extravagant sum at first demanded for the early copy sent over here on speculation by the English publishers, Messrs. CASSELL & Co.; Mr. C. SCRIBNER's edition of FROUDE's History of England from Henry VIII, to the Death of Queen Elizabeth, shows the prevalence of the same taste for historical research. It will be comprised in the same number of volumes as the English edition, beautifully printed in post 8vo, at the Riverside Press. FORSYTH's Life of Cicero, in two volumes octavo, is also in progress at this establishment, for the same house, and will speedily appear. An original translation of TAINE's History of English Literature, undertaken with the cooperation of the author, will be published by Messrs. SCRIBNER later in the season. Messrs. WALKER, WISE & Co., of Boston, have met with success for their first installment of Miss BOOTH's translation of HENRI MARTIN's History of France, containing the age of Louis XIV., in two volumes; and have announced the completion of the entire work, to form seventeen volumes octavo. Their reprint of Miss MARTINEAU's History of the Peace of 1845-'46 has also been well received, and the first edition disposed of. The Spring trade-sales are now approaching, but, from the expense of manufacturing, there is no surplus stock of books on hand in any quarter, and prices are consequently expected to rule "high."

lead_paragraph: ELON COMSTOCK, well known in the editorial profession, died rather suddenly, on Thursday, in Albany. He edited and published the Rome Weekly, and afterward the Daily Sentinel -- having a publication office for the latter at both Rome and Watertown, N.Y., and conducting also at the latter place the Jefferson Union. He afterward edited the Daily Argus, at Springfield, Mass. In 1857 he became connected with the New-York Journal of Commerce, as leading political writer, and remained in that position until the change of ownership in the paper. In the autumn, the proprietors of the Atlas & Argus transferred their weekly paper to New-York, under the title of the New-York Argus, of which Mr. COMSTOCK took charge. After two years it was consolidated with the New-York Daily World, and the deceased remained in editorial connection with that paper until his last sickness. He was 50 years of age, and leaves a wife, an aged mother and an only brother, (Mr. COMSTICK of the Atlas & Argus.

abstract: caused by Anti-Slavery Struggle; Sanitary Condition of; Struggle Injured Northern People by Absorbing Public Attention; Uselessness of
snippet: caused by Anti-Slavery Struggle; Sanitary Condition of; Struggle Injured Northern People by Absorbing Public Attention; Uselessness of
lead_paragraph: We published, on Thursday, one of the most shocking pieces of reading that has fallen under the eyes of any Christian community in our day, in the shape of an address recently delivered by Dr. STEPHEN SMITH, on the sanitary condition of New-York, before the joint committee of the Senate and Assembly at Albany. The picture there drawn of the condition of the poor in New-York, and verified by extracts from the reports of the medical volunteers who examined it, ward by ward, last Summer, considering that it describes a state of things existing in one of the richest cities on the globe, in a new country, amongst a people preeminent for their intelligence and religious feeling, and under "the best Government the world ever saw," is certainly somewhat disheartening for what are called "the friends of progress." What is worst about it all is not so much the amount of physical misery it reveals among the poor, though this is revolting enough, but the decay of public spirit -- the growth of a shameless and cynical indifference to what concerns the public fame and credit among the well-to-do classes. There are forty-four "Health Wardens" in New-York, persons whose duty it is to inspect our streets, alleys and houses, and see that the proper sanitary precautions are taken. A large number of these are liquor dealers; all are grossly ignorant, and many disreputable in character, and it has been ascertained that they do not visit infected districts through fear of contagion. Dr. SMITH asks, and he may well ask it, "To what depth of humiliation must that community have descended, which tolerates as its sanitary officers men who are not only utterly disqualified by education, business and moral character, but who have not even the poor qualification of courage to perform their duties?"

abstract: Foreign Views of; Views of Length of the War
snippet: Foreign Views of; Views of Length of the War
lead_paragraph: Our foreign critics still argue that even if the large armies of the Confederates be broken up, the country will still be filled with guerrilla bands, and that then our real difficulties will only begin, in the large spaces of the Southern States, and the impossibility of holding such vast tracts and such a scattered population, in subjection. These views produce no impression here, from our better understanding of the true problems to be solved, and our more accurate knowledge of the constitution and temper of Southern society. If the South were united in their desire for independence, and if their cause were based on immutable principles, we, of the North, would admit the impossibility of subjugating such a country. We might occupy all the strong strategic points with garrisons, and close and hold all the ports; but the people and country would be practically unconquered, and all the immense wealth and the best blood of the United States would be poured out without avail, in the effort to subdue the Confederate States.
headline: {'main': 'Foreign Views of the Length of the War.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Foreign Views of the Length of the War.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

The proceeds of the entertainment were devoted to the relief of the sick and wounded soldiers now under ...
lead_paragraph: ENTERTAINMENT BY THE SIXTEENTH BAPTIST SUNDAY SCHOOL. -- A very pleasing entertainment was given on Friday evening by the teachers and scholars of the Sixteenth Baptist Sunday School, at the rooms of the New-England Relief Association, No. 194 Broadway. The proceeds of the entertainment were devoted to the relief of the sick and wounded soldiers now under the care of the association. Quite a large audience was present. The entertainment commenced with the chorus of "America," which was followed by a number of songs, recitations and dialogues. The ballads of "Barbara Frietchie," and "Scott and the Veteran," were recited by Master GEORGE ROMAINE, in a very spirited manner. Miss JOSEPHINE EISENPRICE gave a recitation of "Reenlisted," with much archness, and a full appreciation of the spirit of the piece. "I'm Lonely To-night," and the "Three Fishers," were sung by Miss CARRIE JACOCKS and Miss MARY A. SIMMS, and elicited great applause. The entertainment was very appropriately concluded by all present joining in the "Star Spangled Banner."

abstract: Officers should be Reappointed
snippet: Officers should be Reappointed
lead_paragraph: - Several of the heads of departments have had interviews with the President on the subject of renewing the commissions of civil officers whose term is about to expire. We are prepared to hear that the Postmaster-General has the largest list of recommendations for reappointment. The duties proper of the Postal Department can only be assigned periodically to new sets of officers at the expense of the public service. And if the new money order system is to have a fair trial, it is absolutely necessary that men of tried integrity of business habits, and thoroughly acquainted with the technicalities of this branch of the department, should be retained in office, to the exclusion of all minor considerations of party engineering or sectional expediency.

abstract: Relief for--Col Woodford's Appeal
snippet: Relief for--Col Woodford's Appeal
lead_paragraph: Immediately upon the occupation of Charleston by our forces, the American Union Commission sent an agent to inquire into the the necessities of the remaining population of the city, and of refugees arriving from the intorior. After careful investigation, acting under the advice of the military Commandant, the agent invited the cooperation of loyal residents in the work of supplying the wants of the poor in the city, and an auxiliary of the Union Commission was formed, of which Col. JOHN PHILIPS is President, and Gov. WILLIAM AIKEN, Dr. ALBERT G. MACKAY, and other gentlemen of known worth and integrity, are members. The following letter from Col. WOODFORD sets forth the facts in the case, and is a powerful and conclusive appeal to the generosity of our citizens. Money in aid of the Union Commission may be sent to its Treasurer, A.V. STOUT, Esq., President of the Shoe and Leather Bank. Supplies may be sent to No. 14 Bible House, marked "American Union Commission."

abstract: Judge BOSWORTH entered upon his labors, on Friday, as Col. BAKER's assistant, in place of L.E. CHITTENDEN, Esq., whose professional duties have compelled him to resign. The Department Agency has been removed to No. 12 Vesey-street, and thither, henceforward, all communications must be sent to insure attention. Anonymous correspondence cannot be noticed. Col. BAKER went to Fort Lafayette, on Friday, and released four bounty-brokers and one of the enlisted men who claimed exemption as a refugee. The bounty-brokers who are now in the Old Capitol Prison are to be tried in Washington, and not in New-York, as certain gentlemen of the legal profession desired. We learn in a roundabout way that the Hon. ABRAM WAKEMAN was told, on Friday, at the War Office, that the millionaire ITELL is not to be paroled except on the application of Col. BAKER, the remark of a distinguished official being: "BAKER's services have been equivalent to adding 40,000 men to the army, and he must be sustained."

abstract: JACK SHEPPARD AT THE TOMBS. -- Detective Officers FARLEY and GOLDEN found concealed in MICHAEL NEWMAN's place, at No. 82 Mercer-street, about $700 worth of fancy cassimeres which a party of burglars stole on Monday, night from Mr. CHARLES ANSTATT's tailoring establishment at No. 914 Broadway. These goods, according to NEWMAN's account, were sold to him for $120 by a youth of nineteen, whom the police know as WILLIAM JONES, alias Charles Woods, alias Jack Sheppard. The detective officers took a minute description of JONES, and after diligent search contrived to trap him on Friday in Prince-street, just as he was entering one of his hiding-places. He was taken to the Detectives' Office, and on his person was found a watch which he had stolen from the bathing-rooms in Broadway, corner of Spring-street, and this was detained by the officers to await the owner's demand. JONES, hoping to be mode State's evidence, now confessed that since November last he had sold, more than $10,000 worth of goods to HERMAN NELSON, pawnbroker, of No. 172 Canal-street, MICHAEL NEWMAN, above-named, and others, and these persons, he alleged, knew that he had stolen the merchandise. A fortnight or more ago he employed a carman to take from the sidewalk, at No. 45 Warren-street, a case of roods, valued at $1,000, belonging to Mr. A. MULDNER and there were, opened in Jersey City, repacked, returned to New-York, and sold to NELSON for $120, and on Wednesday he had engaged a carman to remove a case of goods from the front of Messrs. G. W. MOORE & CO.'s warehouse at No. 331 Broadway, but a watchful clerk prevented this theft. Upon this statement NELSON and NEWMAN were arrested, and the three were committed by Justice DOWLING.

abstract: The Swedish screw steam frigate Venadis, Capt. MELANDER, arrived yesterday morning from Matanzas, in nine days. She carries 22 guns, has a crew of 301, officers and men, and her engine is of 400 horse power.
lead_paragraph: The Swedish screw steam frigate Venadis, Capt. MELANDER, arrived yesterday morning from Matanzas, in nine days. She carries 22 guns, has a crew of 301, officers and men, and her engine is of 400 horse power.

abstract: On the night of the 27th of January last, Officer JACKSON, of the Eighth Ward, apprehended KATE GORMAN, of No. 104 Prince-street, on complaint of JOSEPH PETTY, of the Broadway Theatre, alleging that, as she was passing from that place of entertainment, he saw her steal a lorgnette from the pocket of a lady. The lorgnette was found on the sidewalk at the feet of the accused at the moment of her arrest, and the lady to whom it belonged identified it. The case was clear, and the prisoner was held on Mr. PETTY's complaint at the Eighth Ward Station-house, and on the morning of the 28th she was committed by Justice DODGE, without bail. Four days subsequently, however, $1,000 bail was accepted, and the accused was liberated. A fortnight or three weeks thereafter, Capt. PETTY, of the Fifth Ward, who had repeatedly tried to send this KATE GORMAN to State Prison, went to the District Attorney's office to ascertain what disposition had been made of her case, but nobody appeared to know anything about it, and the papers were nowhere to be found. But the Captain pressed the case, and Mr. HALL bade him to summon the witnesses and have their statement given to Mr. WHITE, that he might send it before the Grand Jury, with the District Attorney's request that they bring in an indictment. Capt. PETTY acted upon this advice, and an indictment was found, and a bench warrant was issued by Recorder HOFFMAN and delivered to Officer FIELD, of the Fifth Ward. The officer then sought KATE GORMAN, and at length took her into custody, but as the Court of General Session was nor sitting, the prisoner was held two nights at the Fifth Ward Station-house. While here, she offered Capt. PETTY a $600 diamond ring of he would liberate her; but he declined and sent her to court, and on her appearance there the papers were suddenly found. Mr. HALL accepted CHARLES MITCHELL, a wealthy liquor-dealer, who transacts business on Wooster-street corner of Prince, ad her bondsman for $1,000, and releasing her from imprisonment, agreed with Capt. PETTY to try her himself and try to accomplish a conviction. Nothing further was heard of the case until the 7th inst., when Capt. PETTY received a note from Mr. HALL, inquiring whether he wished KATE GORMAN tried in March, before City Judge RUSSEL, or in April, before Recorder HOFFMAN. It was then arranged that the prisoner should be tried on the 13th or 14th inst., but on Friday, the 10th, Capt. PETTY happened to be in court, and found Mr. GUNNING S. BEDFORD, Jr., addressing a jury, Mr. ROBERT C. HUTCHINGS in conversation with Judge RUSSEL and KATE GORMAN and her associate, HENRIETTA HUNTINGTON, outside, talking with ex-Judge STUART. The upshot of the matter, Capt. PETTY learned, was that a plea of guilty of petty larceny was accepted, and KATE GORMAN went abroad snapping her fingers at the officers of the law, repeating her old tale about having friends at court. It is said that this female was treated thus tenderly in furtherance of the ends of justice -- that through revelations which she may make, thieves whom our law officers are pursuing may be caught and punished. KATE GORMAN is twenty-eight years of age, and has been fourteen years a pickpocket. She was at one time worth $35,000, and every dollar of this money was realized from her nefarious trade. "The largest haul," she says, "that I ever made, was $7,000, which I picked from the pocket of a countryman at a county fair." She left her husband in Boston about two years ago, and is now married to a man whose name she conceals. Our policemen have repeatedly apprehended her for larcenies from the person and for other high crimes, but she has ever contrived to escape State prison. Who knows how and why?

abstract: Forrest, Guerrilla Chief; History of
snippet: Forrest, Guerrilla Chief; History of
lead_paragraph: After the storm of this Revolution has swept over the insurgent States, and the institution that struck so fierce a blow at the national life has been itself trampled under the heel of victory, it will remain for some future BANCROFT to analyze and portray the features of that old plantation style of civilization which is already a thing of the past.

snippet: Gorman, Kate, Evading Justice
lead_paragraph: died suddenly, yesterday afternoon, at No. 233 East Twelfth-street, after taking a dose of salts and senna, with which a deadly poison is supposed to have been mingled. The prescription was from Dr. SIMPSON's drug-store, at No. 163 Avenue A. Deceased was 22 years of age....CHARLES LOGAN, a youth of 13, was accidentally shot and instantly killed, yesterday afternoon, while playing with another lad, CHAS. GALLAGHER by name, at the foot of Third-street. The body was taken to the parents' abode, No. 324 Third-street....At about 8 o'clock, last evening, an unknown man was ran over and killed by a Fourth-avenue car, near First-street. The body was taken to the Seventeenth Precinct Police Station, by Officers MINTURN and KEARNON.

snippet: Banishment of Union Families from
lead_paragraph: News has come by the last arrival from the mouth of the Rio Grande that the rebel authorities have ordered twenty six Union families to leave Corpus Christi and its vicinity, and cross the Rio Grande into Mexico. No doubt exists as to the fact.

abstract: On the 7th instant, a boat belonging to the steamer Juniata, Commander JOHN J. ALMY, having in it Acting Master CHARLES H. HAMILTON, Acting Master's Mate ARTHUR F. TAAFE, and ten seamen, was capsized at Georgetown, S.C., while crossing the bar in a gale, and all were drowned except one  seaman. The Juniata has been ordered to the Bra- sillan station.

abstract: The Siamese Twins have been lost from public view for the last few years. It was well known of them that they had married two sisters, and settled down near Salisbury, in North Carolina, on a well-stocked plantation. In addition to this, they have ample funds invested through their agent in New-York. Through a North Carolina medical gentleman, now within our lines, we had the opportunity of minute and full particulars in regard to them. Ever since the war began, they have continued to reside on their plantation, and lived in the same quiet and harmony as ever until within two years. Of course no one ever thought of drafting them, and their negroes prospered, except that when out of temper from any cause, it was apt to work itself off in striking the first one that came to hand, from which the best escape was to keep out of the way. The brothers probably never would have had any difficulty, but that their wives, though sisters, turned away their hearts, and children were the cause of this estrangement.
lead_paragraph: The Siamese Twins have been lost from public view for the last few years. abstract: Scarcely a day passes that complaints are not made at Police Headquarters, or at some of our Police Courts, by unfortunate persons, who have been relieved of the contents of their pockets, either while walking the streets, or riding in stages or railroad cars. In one case, perhaps, out of fifty, the perpetrator of the theft is caught, but in the majority of instances the light-fingered gentry practice their nefarious trade so adroitly that the victim is either unconscious of his loss, or is unable to take any efficient measures for the recovery of his property. Selecting a crowded car or stage, the pickpocket ascends, and choosing his victim by an intuitive perception, peculiar to himself, he places himself near him, or her, as the case may be, and soon succeeds, by a series of imperceptible manipulations in relieving his neighbor of the contents of his pocket. He usually has a confederate, who engages the victim in conversation, if possible, or, failing that, treads on his toe, or contrives to stick his elbow in his ribs or face -- anything, in fact, to distract his attention -- while his comrade possesses himself of whatever his nimble fingers can get hold of. Their work being completed, the pickpockets take an early opportunity of leaving, before their victim is likely to discover his loss. But this is not the only method they employ. Jumping on the platform of a crowded car, they push against those near them, and thus oblige them to keep their hands fully employed in retaining their perpendicular. Their pockets being thus left unguarded, the result, of course, is that wallets and watches change owners with lightning celerity. There are still other methods, however, employed by the professional pickpocket which he does not hesitate to put in practice when all others fail. The professional prefers, if possible, to do his work quietly and without attracting attention, and as a general thing it is only the clumsy inexperienced operator that works openly and takes by force. But the professional occasionally resorts to this method. Mr. GEORGE JONES, of No. 353 West Thirty-fourth-street, was relieved of $45 and a valuable opera-glass on Friday night, in this manner: Mr. JONES had just left the opera, and had got on the platform of one of the Fourteenth-street cars, which was much crowded at the time, when three men, whose appearance indicated that they certainly did not obtain their living by honest industry, placed themselves near Mr. JONES, who very soon found one of their hands in his pocket. He of course seized the hand and collared its owner but his confederates obliged Mr. JONES to let go his field and the rascals escaped with $45 and an fine opera glass. A few nights before an intoxicated Irishman, who got into a stage in the upper part of the city, was robbed of a $50 bill by three fellows, who were in the stage at the time the man got in. The Irishman, who was very tipsy, handed up a $50 bill to the driver, with a request that he would change it. This, of course, the driver could not do, and handed it back. But instead of the owner receiving it one of the three roughs took it from the driver, and immediately left the stage, his retreat being covered by his confederates. The cutting open of pockets is also a common practice. Ladies are usually the victims of this operation, their clothing being better adopted for it than that of gentlemen.

abstract: Brittan vs. Chase; Unlawful Appropriation
snippet: Brittan vs. Chase; Unlawful Appropriation
lead_paragraph: Alfred B. Brittan vs. Ira Chase, Jr. -- The action was brought to recover the sum of about $10,000 damages, which the plaintiff alleged he had sustained by reason of the wrongful taking and converting to his own use, by the defendant, of a large amount of property belonging to the plaintiff. The goods consisted of army bedsteads made of iron, divers articles of household furniture, and a quantity of shafting and other machinery. It is claimed that a portion of it was taken from a foundry at the foot of Forty-sixth-street, and other portions from a store at No. 522 Broadway. The complaint set forth, and plaintiff's testimony went to sustain it, that twenty-five loads of the goods in question had been removed under and by the direction of the defendant from Forty-sixth-street to his store in Mercer-street, and about five loads had been taken to the latter place from No. 522 Broadway. On the other hand the defendant's witnesses testified that not more than ten loads had been removed at any time from either place to defendant's store in Mercer-street. The evidence was very conflicting, and from among the great amount of testimony taken, the court, in charging the jury, said he found it very difficult to distinguish the true from the false. A bill of sale, dated Feb. 11, 1863, had been put in evidence, and he charged them that if they found that any or all the goods had been transferred to Mercer-street subsequent to the last-named date, they were to give a verdict for the plaintiff accordingly. The plaintiff was entitled to recover for those goods taken from his two establishments after the bill of sale was made. The questions involved were purely those of fact, and he could give them very little aid in coming to a right conclusion. The jury were directed to bring in a sealed verdict. For the plaintiff, Messrs. Ford and Baldwin; for defendant, Gen. Sandford and Mr. Billings.

abstract: British and Australian Colonies; Australian Colonies and Convicts of British Government
snippet: British and Australian Colonies; Australian Colonies and Convicts of British Government
lead_paragraph: -- The conflict which has been going on for many months between the South Australian colonists and the British Government on the subject of the transportation of convicts, has terminated in favor of the former. The colony is no longer to be a penal settlement. Some less powerful and less contumacious province will probably be found -- possibly some district on Hudson's Bay or the Island of Anticosti. Both have been spoken of not unfrequently. The probability, however, is that the colonies that, have the most interest in the Hudson's Bay settlements and in the unsettled Island of Anticosti, would be as little disposed as Australia to receive the vast convict population of England. Besides, neither of these places would be likely to supply the necessary means for any profitable employment of convict labor.

abstract: from Le Follet
snippet: from Le Follet
lead_paragraph: Although the temperature at the present time might lead one to imagine the Spring weather very far in the future, it is our duty, as chroniclers of fashion, to give our readers an idea of what toilettes should be prepared for the bright days which we may hope will cheer us before the month of March has passed. Foulard -- perhaps one of the most suitable materials for such dresses -- is now being made in plain colors, particularly green and mauve, a mixture which hitherto has been considered impossible. It is also made with the pattern on a ground of very narrow stripes -- blue and white, green and white, mauve and white, cerise and white, &c. It would be impossible to describe the different designs, on account of the great variety; but there is no doubt that quite plain shades or small patterns will be the most in vogue, as with them a paletot of the same material can be worn. We cannot deny, however it may shock the good taste of some, that the rage for bright, sparkling, or tinsel-like trimmings and ornaments is very great just now. Steel is still much in favor. Crystal is also employed as an ornament, not only in the hair, but little drops of it are dotted over the blonde on dresses, or upon the ribbons trimming them; sometimes sewn on black velvet or ribbon, in the form of a grecque on the body of the dress, especially when made of velvet. It is placed at the bottom of tulle dresses, or in the centre of blonde trimmings. We have also ribbons and galons of gold blonde, embroidered with beads; blonde embroidered with beads or crystal in dew-drops; with satin or velvet ribbons, for dresses. We give an example how these ribbons are used. For instance, on a tunique of tulle, ends of satin ribbon, red or blue, about an inch and a half wide, are placed at equal distances all round, commencing at the waist and finished off by a bow fringed with silver rain (plule d'argent), or white beads. Gold, silver, beads, or steel rain, and feathers are in mode this season for trimming evening dresses -- both bodies and skirts -- and also upon the chignone, and nets in the hair. Peacocks' feathers form a truly elegant trimming, especially used for ball dresses or bonnets. For visiting dress, satin and velvet dispute the palm. Moire antique is no longer so fashionable as it formerly was; partly, perhaps, because with the two former may be worn a paletot or mantle of the same.

abstract: Western Metropolis, Steamship, from Havana, Threatened Capture by Passengers
snippet: Western Metropolis, Steamship, from Havana, Threatened Capture by Passengers
lead_paragraph: The steamship Western Metropolis, Wm.B. HILTON, Master, which left this port on the 20th ult., arrived at Greytown, Nicaragua, on the 3d instant, after a smooth but long passage, which was owing to an accident to the port boiler, making it necessary to reduce the steam to three or four pounds. At Greytown, took on board 704 California passengers, consigned to the Central American Transit Company, the Western Metropolis being chartered to take the place of the Golden Rule. Left Greytown 6th at 6:45 P.M., and being short of water, sailed direct for Havana. Had a heavy cross sea in the Carribean Sea and a norther in the Gulf. Arrived at Havana at 9 A.M. on 11th. On 11th, the Confederate steamer Wren came in with 700 bales of cotton, from Galveston. There were numerous threats from the shore that the Western Metropolis would be burned before she got to New-York. They were so prevalent, that the American Consul sent off word that the officers must be on the lookout. The watches were doubled and armed for all emergencies. Twelve suspicious and, as was afterward learned, very dangerous characters were found on board, some of whom were sent on shore. Their sympathizers had a desire to give trouble, as Capt. HILTON captured in this same steamer, while in Government service, a blockade-runner, in the Gulf, owned at Havana. The Western Metropolis sailed from Havana on the 12th, at 2:10 P.M., and throughout the passage had very heavy weather, with high cross seas.

abstract: Retail Prices not Corresponding to Wholesale Reductions; The Prices Compared
snippet: Retail Prices not Corresponding to Wholesale Reductions; The Prices Compared
lead_paragraph: Every careful housekeeper in town ought to consult the brief comparative statements of wholesale prices in the breadstuff and provision markets, published among our "General Markets" yesterday. The dates brought into comparison are the last day of 1864, and Friday, March 17, 1865. And the articles comprised in the statements include those of the most ordinary honsehold consumption. An examination of the figures in the tabular form in which they appear, will enable any housekeeper to determine how far the retail dealer's current prices have been made to correspond with the great decline at wholesale within the period which the statement covers.

abstract: Official dispatches from City Point give us news from Richmond papers of yesterday (Friday) morning. The rebel Congress had adjourned sine die. Vice-President STEPHENS had been in Georgie for about ten days, and the Richmond editors are anxious to hear from him. The tone of their inquiries implies that they have a suspicion that he has quit the Concern.
lead_paragraph: Official dispatches from City Point give us news from Richmond papers of yesterday (Friday) morning. The rebel Congress had adjourned sine die. Vice-President STEPHENS had been in Georgie for about ten days, and the Richmond editors are anxious to hear from him. The tone of their inquiries implies that they have a suspicion that he has quit the Concern. Great efforts are being made to repair the damage done by SHERIDAN to the James River Canal. The organization of negro troops was being tried at Richmond, but with what success the dispatch does not state. Union forces are closing around Mobile, and the rebels look for an attack upon that city at any moment. On the 11th inst. there were 21 vessels in sight, nearly all heavily laden with troops. The exchange of prisoners at that point, however, was still going on.

snippet: Results at Wilmington, Jan, 1863, to Dec, 1864; Blydenburg, Miss, Will, Sustained; Guernsey, O; J B Cook, Deputy Provost Marshal, Shot; Origin of Application to Negroes; India, >amp;c.; Rates for Messages; Exchanged; Miss Barton, Annapolis, will g...
lead_paragraph: An offcial statement of the result of blockade-running at the port of Wilmington from January, 1863, to December, 1864, appears in the Manchester Guardian. The total ventures made by English capitalists and speculators, counting the values of ships and cargoes, amounted to more than sixty-six millions of dollars (£13,241,000.) The returns are made in six different tables, covering various periods, the shortest being ten months. The general result are as follows: The quantity of cotton exported from Wilmington in twenty-two months (Jan. 1, 1863, to Oct. 31, 1864,) was 137,937 -- or 62,860,463 pounds, of which the larger part was Sea Island. The value of the export and import trade of Wilmington in one year (July 1, 1863, to June 30, 1864,) was $65,185,000; the rebel Government rating exchange at five for one. The number of vessels which ran blockade in fifteen months (Oct. 1, 1863, to Dec. 31, 1864,) was 397.

abstract: Policy in Mexico
snippet: Policy in Mexico
lead_paragraph: The Austrian successor of MONTEZUMA is evidently ambitious of distinguishing himself as a ruler. But the policy which he is now pursuing in Mexico, though excellent in the abstract, may prove suicidal in his very peculiar circumstances. It is dangerous for even an old-established sovereign to bid defiance to public opinion, yet how much more perilous is it for a ruler, who holds his seat by the most precarious tenure, to do so? By issuing those decrees (liberal and just in themselves) confirming the secularization of church property and proclaiming universal religious toleration, MAXIMILIAN has alienated the only party among the Mexican people which was at first disposed to sustain him, without conciliating any large number of that national party which has been waging war to the knife against him from the beginning; and, as a consequence, he at present stands divested of any really solid basis for his power, save that French army that originally established it. The Ultramontanists and the Republicans may not yet have made up their differences and entered into combination for the purpose of overthrowing the new dynasty, but it cannot be doubted that both are equally emulous in watching the opportunity to give his Government the coup de grace.
headline: {'main': 'The Policy of Maximillan in Mexico.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Policy of Maximillan in Mexico.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- We learn that the vote for ratification received up to this time reaches over 35,000. But a small portion of East Tennessee has been heard from. The vote on the Gubernaturial and Legislative ticket is smaller than the vote for ratification, though but very few counties ties have been heard from in, regard to the election of the 4th inst. As there was no opposition to the ticket the people felt but little interest is the election, knowing that it could terminate only in one way. The Legislature will convene on the 1st Monday of April next, which falls on the 3d of the month, and a deeply interesting session may be looked for, as exciting political and personal questions will come before it, As the reorganization of the State may form the precedent for that of the other revolted States, it is of the utmost importance that discretion and patriotism should control its counsels. -- Nashville Times, March 9.

abstract: Normal School; Presentation of Diplomas
snippet: Normal School; Presentation of Diplomas
lead_paragraph: At 9 o'clock, yesterday morning, more than a hundred female pupils of the City Normal School, many of their friends, and many gentlemen and ladies who feel interested is the cause of education, gathered in the Twelfth-street School building to witness the interesting ceremony of presenting diplomas to eleven female teachers of the class to whom the Normal School Examining Committee had awarded certificates of the highest grade of scholarship. Among the gentlemen present were Messrs. Neilson, Roosevelt, Hastle, Miller, Small and Farr, of the Board of Education, Inspectors Gerard, Moore, Hecker, Perkins and others.

abstract: In Produce and Merchandise, on Saturday, transactions were restricted, though, in most instances, the tendency of prices was decidedly downward. Medium and high grades of Flour declined 10c.@20c. bbl. New Mess Pork, which opened at $32 50@$32 62 , fell to $31 bbl., under reports of a panic in some of the Western markets, particularly in Chicago. Petroleum was firmer, but not active. The Freight engagements were on a limited scale.
lead_paragraph: In Produce and Merchandise, on Saturday, transactions were restricted, though, in most instances, the tendency of prices was decidedly downward. abstract: The, Gov. Brown's Remedy; Military Policy; Gov.Brown on; Remedy for the Confederate Condition; Conscription Act; Gov. Brown on
snippet: The, Gov. Brown's Remedy; Military Policy; Gov.Brown on; Remedy for the Confederate Condition; Conscription Act; Gov. Brown on
lead_paragraph: It is not an unfrequent sign of a patient's approaching dissolution that the friends of the sick man are ready to leave the regular family phyiscian and betake themselves to the use of this or that nostrum, which some quack has recommended, or which some old woman says has been found to be beneficial in another case. This symptom accompanies the last hours of the Southern Confederacy. The mode of treatment which has been pursued for the past four years has not saved the patient from a speedy decline; and now in approaching extremity, his friends are recommending, one this thing and another that, each sure that his own remedy is the panacea which will restore the health, and set the patient once again and speedily on his legs.

abstract: Exemption Bill
snippet: Exemption Bill
lead_paragraph: The Congress of the Confederate States of America do enact, That so much of the act to organize forces to serve during the war, approved Feb. 17, 1864, as exempts one person as overseer or agriculturist on each farm or plantation, upon which there were at specified times 15 able-bodied field hands between the ages of 16 and 50, upon certain conditions, is hereby repealed; and said persons shall be liable to military service upon the expiration of the time for which they secured exemption, by reason of having executed bonds for one year from date thereof; provided that exemptions of persons over 40 years of age may be granted under the provisions of the act aforesaid.

abstract: NORTHERN ALABAMA. -- About twenty counties of Northern Alabama, comprising all that region running from North Mississippi to the northern part of Georgia, are now and have always been at heart loyal to the United States. The people anxiously look for the time when they shall be delivered from rebel rule, and enabled to shall their faith by their deeds. Nearly seven regiments of loyal Alabamians are already in the service of the United States, and thousands are hiding in the mountains, avoiding the terror of the rebel conscription, which is now more remorseless than ever. Nine rebel deserters were shot in Blount County two weeks ago, by men under STEWART's command, and several others in Winston County. Many deserters and refugees are picked up by the Upper Tennessee gunboats, but the woods are so well guarded, that but a small number, comparatively speaking, reach the borders of the land of promise. Under all these difficulties the people are striving to reorganize their State, and should they succeed, they will merit lasting honors. -- Nashville Times, May 9.
lead_paragraph: NORTHERN ALABAMA. -- About twenty counties of Northern Alabama, comprising all that region running from North Mississippi to the northern part of Georgia, are now and have always been at heart loyal to the United States. abstract: New-York; Suspended
snippet: New-York; Suspended
lead_paragraph: The draft in this city was not resumed yesterday, surprising the public as much as did the unexpected revolutions of the wheel on Wednesday. The surprise in this instance, however, was an agreeable one, eliciting warm commendations from everybody. Although no official order has been promulgated suspending the draft, it is understood that it will not be resumed until our citizens have had an opportunity to fill the quota by volunteering.

abstract: Policy; Our, Condition of Roads; N. Y., on Railroad Legislation and Policy
snippet: Policy; Our, Condition of Roads; N. Y., on Railroad Legislation and Policy
lead_paragraph: We hope the question of relieving the State railroads from existing legal restrictions as to fares may be discussed, before it is decided, on some higher grounds than those thus far generally assumed. Whether the New-York Central Road is or is not a party machine -- whether its directors and managers get too much or too little for their services -- whether it divides among its stockholders more or less than its legitimate earnings -- whether it pays too much or too little for the fuel, oil, &c., which it uses, may be important questions; but they have very little to do with the only point we have presented for public consideration -- namely, the general policy by which the State can best serve the public interest, as that interest is involved in the safety and good management of our railroads.
headline: {'main': 'Our Railroad Policy.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Our Railroad Policy.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Damage by Rebels--Gains $25,000
snippet: Damage by Rebels--Gains $25,000
lead_paragraph: The secessionists of East Tennessee who, at the outset of the war, practiced every imaginable outrage on their neighbors, are beginning to suffer the just penalty of their action. The Union men, the courts having been reestablished, are prosecuting their former persecutors for damages sustained, and the juries, so far as cases have come to trial, indicate a disposition to see full justice done to all concerned. Parson BROWNLOW has just recovered $25,000 damages in the United States Circuit Court at Knoxville, from three persons who had made him the object of their malice; another loyalist has obtained a verdict for a similar amount; while the heirs of a third have recovered the large sum of $40,000 in a similar manner. BROWNLOW, in his paper, advises all Union men who have suffered to commence suite at once; and the verdict in the cases named will, no doubt, influence very many to follow his advice. The fighting parson says on the subject, in language which is vigorous if not polite:
