abstract: Underground Railroad Bill; N. Y., the
snippet: Underground Railroad Bill; N. Y., the
lead_paragraph: The Underground Railroad Bill is again before the Legislature, and there is no conceivable reason why it should not pass. The only persons to whose interests it can prove in the slightest degree prejudicial are the street railroad companies, and omnibus proprietors. To all complaints made against these worthies for the shameful and indecent overcrowding of their vehicles, their reply is that it would be impossible for them to put on conveyances enough to give seats to all the passengers, or even carry them all, who now pour up and down this city; and yet whenever any attempt, like this underground railroad, is made to relieve them of a portion of their burden, they rush up to Albany and use every means, fair and foul, to defeat it. The health, as well as the prosperity of this city, depends in a great measure upon the discovery of some means of lightening the pressure of population in the middle and lower part of the island. Whatever brings Westchester County within half an hour of the City Hall, may fairly be said, to all intents and purposes, to double the size of the island. The underground railroad will do this, and nothing else will. Horse railroads take so long to get up to Harlem, that they cannot afford any great aid in the distribution of population, and all the avenues will shortly be so laden with traffic, that we cannot look forward to any such increase of the means of locomotion on our streets as will bear the needful ratio to the probable increase of population.

abstract: Public Measures and Party Action (at Albany); Democratic Party against Fire Department and Health Bills; Health and Fire Department Bills and Democratic Party
snippet: Public Measures and Party Action (at Albany); Democratic Party against Fire Department and Health Bills; Health and Fire Department Bills and Democratic Party
lead_paragraph: Some eight or ten Union men "bolted" a caucus at Albany a few evenings since, because the party decided to support the Health Bill and the Paid Fire Department Bill for this city. Why these gentlemen do not support those bills we are not aware. It would be very difficult, in our judgment, for any man of any party to assign any good reason for not supporting them. If there is any such thing as demonstration in public affairs, it has been proved, beyond all possibility of doubt, that the public welfare imperatively demands the passage of both these bills. The array of testimony on their behalf is perfectly overwhelming; and, as a matter of fact, we believe, no man not directly interested in perpetuating existing evils, has ventured to oppose them.

abstract: The March winds of Saturday brought good cheer to Mr. MARETZEK, for thousands of storm-pressed damsels took refuge in the Academy as in a kindly port of safety. The house was filled to its greatest capacity, even the lobbies ard staircases being crowded. With the exception of the "Faust" matinee of last season, there never has been any thing like it. The opera was "La Forza del Destino," which was given for the first time at these popular day  entertainments, and there, as at the evening representations, asserted its hold on the public fancy and taste. The artists were in good voice, and the performance gave general satisfaction.

abstract: If we are to credit the word of a lady, Mobile has gone up -- caved in. The lady above alluded to is the wife of a former editor of the New-Orleans Crescent. She has been residing at Mobile since the commencement of the war, but left there on the evening of the [???]th instant. According to her tale, STEWART's entire corps of infantry and two divisions of FOREST's cavalry arrived at Mobile in the early part of February. An extra force of negroes were again placed upon the fortifications. BEAUREGARD made a flying visit to Mobile about the middle of the month, and in a speech assured the citizens of that city that at all hazards it should be defended and held -- that under no consideration would it be given up without a fight. But she says, during the latter part of last month and the early part of the present, these same troops were very quietly removed, and with them SMITH's division of MAURY's command. She also says that at least half of the heavy artillery has been taken from the defences west of the city. She winds up her story by saying that the Federals can walk right into the city, without opposition.

abstract: Securities and Pacific market; Market for U S Securities
snippet: Securities and Pacific market; Market for U S Securities
lead_paragraph: It is probable that the news of prospective shipments of gold from London to New-York has induced the Philadelphia agent of the Government to send part of the last seven-thirty issue to San Francisco. There is quite as great a plethora of gold on the Pacific coast as there is in Lombard-street. And in the present condition of the London market the hoarders of bullion in the Pacific States and Territories are likely to find their account by large investments in the national stock. On broad grounds of national policy, it is altogether desirable that the bulk of our public debt should be owing to citizens of the United States. It will become an additional bond of Union between East and West, North and South. It will unite the outlying members of our Federal system to the Central Government by a new tie of interest. It will make our national securities, every day, more valuable by multiplying the guarantees that faith will be kept with the public creditors. In these regards it is of the highest consequence that the efforts to open a large market for our securities on the Pacific should be attended with success.

abstract: We publish this morning a graphic and interesting sketch of Gen. PHIL. SHERIDAN'S magnificent and destructive raid on LEE'S communications. It will be seen that previous accounts have understated rather than exaggerated the importance of the work accomplished by the gallant General. Miles and miles of railroad were destroyed.
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning a graphic and interesting sketch of Gen. PHIL. SHERIDAN's magnificent and destructive raid on LEE's communications. It will be seen that previous accounts have understated rather than exaggerated the importance of the work accomplished by the gallant General. Miles and miles of railroad were destroyed. The Kanawha and James River Canal was rendered useless beyond the hope of repair. Gen. EARLY's army was utterly broken up and scattered among the mountains -- EARLY himself very narrowly escaping capture by our troops. It is estimated that the supplies consumed by our forces, or issued to the starving poor of the country, would have kept LEE's army for at least three months. And all this has been accomplished without the loss of a dozen men! Altogether, the raid is without a parallel in the history of the war.

abstract: Situation at
snippet: Situation at
lead_paragraph: The military pressure within and without the rebel capital has sadly spoiled the fine variety and pungency of Richmond newspaper literature. But there is some compensation in getting what is still left to us fresh. There is now but one daily to record what it formerly needed half a score to get up with the proper inflections. And it is probable that the Saturday's contents of the surviving sheet were transmitted to us in full, in the official telegrams from Mr. DANA, which we published yesterday. It is, at least, specially noteworthy that the gist of all the rebel war news allowed to be published in Richmond may be reproduced, twenty-four hours later, in the New-York TIMES.

And these misgivings, by all appearances, were confirmed, rather than allayed, by the detailed report of his mission. The Paris news clubs have already given GWIN's statement shape. And if we were at liberty to credit what is thus rumored as conjectures, the Emperor MAXIMILIAN apprehended as much internal trouble as extrinsic danger from GWIN's colonization scheme. That gentleman, however, has a fair expectation of being paid for his labor, if his enterprise, in other respects, should turn out a failure, and, if he is to be judged by his antecedents, Dr. GWIN will probably find his account in this arrangement quite as well as in any other.

abstract: Question; The, in French Legislature; Legislature; Slavery in the
snippet: Question; The, in French Legislature; Legislature; Slavery in the
lead_paragraph: -- The occasion of moving the Address in the Corps Legislatif, in answer to the Emperor's Speech, promises to be marked by a singular episode. It will be remembered that the Speech itself contained no allusion whatever to American affairs. By ordinary usage, therefore, the Address could only be made to include a reference of a supplementary character, on American or any other topics, by a motion which should take the form of an amendment. Such a motion would naturally imply a quasi censure of the Imperial utterance. It would thus, necessarily, fall into the hands of the Opposition. The immediate question at issue, however, in this instance is one on which there can scarcely be said to be a divided opinion in France. And to surrender such a question to the manipulation of the small minority of Liberals in the Corps Legislatif is, in a measure, throwing away an Imperial card. The subject of the proposed amendment will take form in an expression of general felicitation upon the constitutional steps taken by the United States Congress, toward the abolition of slavery.

abstract: Ram at Ferrol to attack U. S. Fleet
snippet: Ram at Ferrol to attack U. S. Fleet
lead_paragraph: Included in the interesting budget of news from Paris, which we publish to-day, is a report which promises a sensation equal to the famous fight of the Kearsarge and Alabama. At a rebel Council, composed of the chief emissaries of the Confederacy, and which closed its sittings at Paris, on the 2d inst., it is understood that a decision was come to, authorizing PAGE, the commander of the ram Stonewall, to attack the United States fleet in Ferrol harbor. That fleet is composed of the Niagara, the Sacramento, and (it is presumed) the Iroquois. There are, at all events, three of our national vessels watching the Stonewall in Ferrol harbor. These vessels are bravely manned, are subject to the orders of a commander -- Capt. CRAVEN -- who will take up the challenge the moment it is given, and should speed become an element of account in the expected engagement the Niagara can, with ease, out-distance (at seventeen knots an hour) any armed vessel afloat. But in the matter of armor-plating, unless Capt. WINSLOW's invention has been extemporized, our fleet would stand at a considerable disadvantage. The rebel ram, moreover, has a formidable 300-pounder on board. Such an engagement as is anticipated would, of course, be a violation of the neutral rights of Spain. But if the rebels commence the fight, there will be no alternative left Capt. CRAVEN but to return their fire.

abstract: Inauguration Speech as Vice-President
snippet: Inauguration Speech as Vice-President
lead_paragraph: from the Congressional Globe a report of the remarks made by Vice-President ANDREW JOHNSON, on taking his place as President of the Senate, on the day of the Inauguration. There may be differences of opinion as to the timeliness and good taste of some of the topics which he introduced on that occasion, -- but few will venture, we presume, to question publicly the justice of the sentiments which he expressed. Still less will any basis be found in the speech for the unmeasured and intemperate vituperation of the Vice-President for which it was made the occasion. Two years ago the same journals which have been specially vehement in denouncing Mr. JOHNSON, teemed with similar charges upon Secretary SEWARD, and subsequently Gen. GRANT was subjected to the same ordeal. Indeed, it would not be easy to name any prominent member of the Government, who has not, at one time or another, been visited by personal assaults of the same general character, if his opinion on certain phases of public affairs happened to conflict with those of the parties in question. One would suppose that to the Secession and Copperhead journals of the country might safely be left the task of demolishing the character and influence of the men to whom the people have intrusted the duties and responsibilities of office. It is consoling, however, to know that whenever there is any appearance of shrinking or hesitation in that quarter, there are "friends" of the Administration not only ready but eager to come to the rescue. No man in this country has rendered, within his sphere, more substantial service to the Union cause, or earned more thoroughly the gratitude of the Union party than ANDREW JOHNSON; and we venture to predict that, in the future as in the past, he will abundantly vindicate himself from the slanders of his enemies, and the ungenerous misconstruction of some who have claimed to be his friends.

abstract: Recruiting in Illinois, Indiana, Iowa and Wis consin is very brisk, and the men received from those States are of an excellent description, many of them having already seen considerable service. Very little volunteering is going on in Michigan. Some sections of New-York and Pennsylvania are also very negligent.
lead_paragraph: Recruiting in Illinois, Indiana, Iowa and Wis consin is very brisk, and the men received from those States are of an excellent description, many of them having already seen considerable service. Very little volunteering is going on in Michigan. Some sections of New-York and Pennsylvania are also very negligent. The steady stream of reenforcements is beginning to tell materially upon the army in front of Richmond. Recruits have been leaving the general rendezvous at New-York at the rate of about fifteen hundred per day for the last ten days, and gentlemen who have just returned from an unofficial tour of inspection through the greater part of Gen. MEADE's army, say that it never was in better condition.

abstract: Johnson, Rev Evan M.
snippet: Johnson, Rev Evan M.
lead_paragraph: -- This venerable minister of the Gospel departed this life at his residence in Pearl-street, near Myrtle-avenue, yesterday morning shortly after 9 o'clock. His complaint was general debility consequent upon old age. The deceased was born in Newport, R.I., Jane 1792, and was consequently in the 73d year of his age. He was ordained to the ministry in Trinity Church, Newport, by Right Rev. A.V. GRISWOLD, July 8, 1813. Removed to New-York City in 1814 and became assistant Rector of Grace Church; which position he held for one year, when he took charge of St James' Church, Newtown, L.I., as Rector. In the year 1824, he settled in Brooklyn, and built St. John's Church, situated on the corner of Johnson and Washington streets, two years thereafter. This thickly built portion of the city was then a farm, owned by Mr. JOHNSON himself. In this church he preached the free gospel until 1847, when he retired and hired a little place in Marshal-street, near the Jackson Ferry, for the purpose of continuing his services for the benefit of the poor, for a short time. The building proving inconvenient for the purpose, he established St. Michael's Church, in High-street, of which he remained Rector up to the day of his death. During the years of Mr. JOHNSON's ministrations he united nearly 4,000 couples in marriage, and christened nearly 10,000 children. He was, at the time of his decease, the oldest settled Episcopal clergyman in the State of New-York. The last ministerial rite he performed was the baptism of one of his grandchildren. Mr. JOHNSON was twice married. The only child by his first wife was the Hon. SAMUEL E. JOHNSON; and by the second, HENRY B. JOHNSON, EVAN M. JOHNSON, Jr., and two daughters, (both dead.) One was the wife of Capt. RICHARD THORNE, and the other of Mr. F.E. HAGERMEYER. Mr. JOHNSON's second wife died in January, 1860. He leaves property valued at about $200,000, mostly in buildings on Fulton-street, Myrtle-avenue, Adams, Washington, and Pearl streets.

abstract: Proc on Arms to Hostile Indians
snippet: Proc on Arms to Hostile Indians
lead_paragraph: Whereas reliable information has been received that hostile Indians within the limits of the United States have been furnished with arms and munitions of war by persons dwelling in foreign territory, and are thereby enabled to prosecute their savage war fare upon the exposed and sparse settlements of the frontier, now, therefore, be it known that I, ABRAHAM LINCOLN, President of the United States of America, do hereby proclaim and direct that all persons engaged in that nefarious traffic shall be arrested and tried by court martial at the nearest military post, and if convicted shall receive the punishment due to their deserts.

abstract: Wants a Man; Resigning. Who can succeed?--Richmond Enquirer; The Coming Man
snippet: Wants a Man; Resigning. Who can succeed?--Richmond Enquirer; The Coming Man
lead_paragraph: The Southern Confederacy, like Diogenes, seeks a man. Time was, when its chief anxiety was to levy taxes; to conscript men; to stamp paper into money for its treasury; to fabricate powder and ball, guns, sabres, and bayonets; to gather food and forage from its vast corrals in Florida and Texas, and its granaries in Georgia and the Shenandoah. These were the ordinary and natural means and appliances of war, and to these accordingly the rebellion bent its attention. But now its shafts have all been sunk, and its mines explored and exhausted. Stripped of resources, beggared of material and supplies, with its interior communications all cut, impoverished in men, money, ships, guns, and in food itself, girdled about by a daily contracting circle of fire, the Confederacy shrieks for a man, to evolve safety out of its imminent peril.

abstract: Tallahassee at Bermuda, with changed name
snippet: Tallahassee at Bermuda, with changed name
lead_paragraph: Our exchange papers bring us elaborate and graphic accounts of the destruction of property consequent upon the great floods of last week along Central New-York and Central Pennsylvania. We have already given, and are still giving, (by telegraph,) the main facts embraced in these accounts, and must now content ourselves with saying that the circumstances as set forth in the newspapers are even more serious than as represented by the usually exaggerating wires. Indeed, the flood of water is only equalled by the flood of words wherein it is described. There is, doubtless, an immense loss of property, and possibly some suffering will follow, all of which, we hope, will be promptly relieved by the more fortunate upland dwellers in the innundated regions.

abstract: Rebel Senate Refuses to Suspend
snippet: Rebel Senate Refuses to Suspend
lead_paragraph: The rebel Senate, by a vote of nine to six, has rejected DAVIS' proposition to suspend the writ of habeas corpus, (which was accepted by the House of Representatives,) The supporters of the measure included only the so-called "Senators" from Missouri, Tennessee and Kentucky -- fellows that have been hanging around Richmond for two years or more, without venturing within sight of their respective constituencies. The solid men of the rebel Senate, such as HUNTER, voted against suspension -- a significant hint to DAVIS.

abstract: New-York; Ward Meetings to Fill Quotas; Hudson River Open; Albany Boat Started March 20
snippet: New-York; Ward Meetings to Fill Quotas; Hudson River Open; Albany Boat Started March 20
lead_paragraph: The citizens of the Twentieth Ward held a meeting last evening at the corner of Eighth-avenue and Thirty-third-street, for the purpose of taking measures to fill the quota of the ward with volunteers. Speeches were made by D. HARRISON REED, JOHN B. GRIDLEY, NELSON J. LUCKY, JOHN RILEY, Mr. DITTENHOFFER and others. A committee was appointed to confer with the citizens of the Eighteenth and Twentieth Wards to take measures to fill the quota of the Eighth Congressional District. A committee was also appointed to call a mass meeting of the Twentieth Ward, at the same place, on Thursday evening.

abstract: The motion which was made some days since, to postpone the trial of this cause until the ensuing May term was decided yesterday by the court. It is postponed for the present month, by order of the Judge, and will doubtless be brought on the first week of the April Term. One of the principal reasons assigned in the affidavits, which have been publishedin the TIMES, and on which the motion to postpone was based, was that some indictments were pending in the Court of General Sessions against two of the important witnesses. If these indictments should be disposed of the present month, the divorce suit will no doubt come on in April.

abstract: Henry Allen vs. Alonzo P. Bitten. -- The action was brought to recover the sum of $960, with interest -- money which, the plaintiff alleged, defendant had collected for him as his agent, but had neglected and refused to pay it over to his principal when called upon so to do. The tact that Bliven was plaintiff's agent, and that he collected the amount of money above named, was proved to the satisfaction of the court and jury. The defendant undertook to show that, by no fault of his, he lost the plaintiff's money and a quantity of his own, in a car in which he was riding. The fact that he had kept the money in his possession a month after he received it, induced the belief that he had been guilty of negligence, if nothing worse, and the jury accordingly reneered a verdict for the full amount, with interest.

abstract: Adjourned March 18
snippet: Adjourned March 18
lead_paragraph: Richmond papers of Saturday have been received at Washington. The most important fact is that the Confederate Congress adjourned at noon of Saturday, without having passed any of the measures of relief asked for by JEFF. DAVIS, and which he alleged to be imperatively necessary to enable the Confederacy to maintain the struggle. Most of the members had left in a panic, lest they should be cut off from return to their homes by SHERMAN's advance, and there was no quorum remaining to do business. Insinuations are made in the Richmond papers that Vice-President STEVENS has neither stood by JEFF. DAVIS, nor raised his voice in Georgia to "fire the Southern heart," as was expected after the failure of the peace mission. So JEFF. DAVIS is left alone in his glory, to deal as he best can with the difficulties thickening around him.

abstract: Brownlow, Gov. Advised to moderate his language; Gov. Brownlow, Advice to
snippet: Brownlow, Gov. Advised to moderate his language; Gov. Brownlow, Advice to
lead_paragraph: As Parson BROWNLOW is now Governor of Tennessee, it is greatly to be desired that he should make some attempt to infuse a little moderation into his language and demeanor. A great many things that were pardonable in the persecuted East Tennessean loyalist, really do not look very becoming in the highest civil functionary of the State, and we would, therefore, earnestly entreat the Parson, if only for the sake of the cause for which he has suffered so much, to make a thorough revision of his manner of expressing himself. The public both North and South is now familiar with his sentiments on the subject of secession and the war, as well as with regard to his rebel neighbors, and we believe we express the opinion of the best portion of the community when we say that nothing that Gov. BROWNLOW can add to what he has already said about them could increase our abhorrence of these persons and their doings. The loyalists whom they plundered and outraged while secession was in the ascendent, are now bringing actions against them in the civil courts, and are obtaining heavy damages against them; and quite right, say we; but we think there is no occasion for the Governor to comment on the matter in this style:

abstract: Dictator, Monitor; Arrival; List of Officers
snippet: Dictator, Monitor; Arrival; List of Officers
lead_paragraph: The United States monitor Dictator, Commodore JOHN RODGERS, arrived at this port yesterday, from Hampton Roads, under convoy of the United States gunboat Rhode Island, having left on the evening of the 19th inst. She returns here for completion, and to receive a new engine for hoisting the anchors. Her officers speak of her in the highest terms, both as regards her sea-going qualities and rate of speed, she having a portion of the time attained 12 knots an hour, using only 24 furnaces out of 56. Her steering apparatus is now in complete order, two men managing her with perfect ease.

abstract: Fagnani, Mr. Returned to New-York
snippet: Fagnani, Mr. Returned to New-York
lead_paragraph: We have carelessly neglected to mention that Mr. FAGNANI, whose established reputation as an artist is well known both here and in Europe, has returned to New-York, and has his studio at No. 10 Clinton-place. His fine portrait of Mr. COBDEN which was on exhibition at the grand fair of the Sanitary Commission, and is now in possession of the Chamber of Commerce, will be remembered by all who saw it. Mr. FAGNANI spent the most of last Summer in Turkey, where he went upon invitation, to paint the Sultan and some of the most distinguished members of his court; he painted one, also, of Sir HENRY BULWER. Why does not the Chamber of Commerce order a portrait of JOHN BRIGHT to match that of Mr. CORDEN?

abstract: IN ARTIFICIAL TEETH. -- Dr. M. LEVETT, No. 832 Broadway, has always ranked among our first dentists, and dentistry owes much to his scientific researches and inventions; but his new Patent Atmospheric Pressure Plate comes nearer to perfection than any method of the kind that we have ever seen. The plate is made of reticulated gold-web and india-rubber base, which is so light as hardly to be a weight in the hand, and is at the same time strong and extremely elastic. By a series of air-cells it is held immovable in the mouth, and is so small and compact that it does not interfere with speech or taste. It is, in short, the lightest, the most cleanly, the firmest and the most comfortable denture that was ever put in the mouth, and consequently we commend it over all others. -- Watson's Art Journal.

abstract: Runners Arrested; Supplied Ram Stonewall with Arms; Stonewall; Pratt and Green Arrested for Supplying Armament
snippet: Runners Arrested; Supplied Ram Stonewall with Arms; Stonewall; Pratt and Green Arrested for Supplying Armament
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF BLOCKADE-RUNNERS. -- ERNEST W. PRATT and ROBERT GREEN, passengers on the steamer Corsica, which arrived on the evening of the 17th inst. from Nassau, are in custody on charges of being officers of the steamer which furnished the Frenchrebel ram Stonewall with her armament. The passports of the prisoners were imperfect. It is charged that PRATT was mate, and GREEN steward, of the City of Richmond, which was loaded with arms and fitted out at London, by CRANSHAW, the rebel agent in that city, and cleared from that port on the 3d of January last, for Bermuda, or any of the West India Islands, with the understanding on the part of the prisoners that she was to run the blockade. After leaving London she took on board between sixty and seventy officers and men, and about three hundred barrels of gunpowder and many small arms, at a place called Greenhithe. The regular crew comprised about forty-five officers and men, who went on board at London. The vessel steered for the coast of France, and reached Belle Isle in about seven days, where she met the rebel ram Olinde, (Stonewall,) to which she transferred all the officers and men taken on board at Greenhithe, besides a large quantity of provisions and small arms. The City of Richmond then steamed for Bermuda, anchored in the harbor of St. George, landed some of her provisions and the remainder of her gunpowder, and sailed for Nassau, N.P., where she arrived on the 4th or 5th of March. After remaining in port four days, Capt. SCOTT, of the City of Richmond, ordered the officers and men on shore. The order was enforced by an officer from the town, some difficulty having occurred between the officers and crew and Capt. SCOTT, owing to the mannner in which the Captain had discharged the crew from the ship. Capt. SCOTT subsequently gave the vessel into the hands of Capt. DAVIDSON, not a British subject, the agent of the owner, CRANSHAW, and who had come out in the vessel from London. The City of Richmond was still at Nassau when the Corsica left. The prisoners were taken to Gen. DIX's headquarters, and subjected to a rigid examination by Col. LUDLOW, of Gen. DIX's staff. It is not yet known what disposition will be made of them.

abstract: The anticipated collapse of the rebellion is producing its natural consequence, in the fall of gold. Yesterday gold went down to 154, though it subsequently went up again. This is a fall of fifty per cent. within a month. So sudden and serious a change in the recognized standard of value naturally produces confusion, failure and disaster in every department of business. Even Government securities, like everything else, feel the shock, and yesterday some of the very best Government stocks sold at from eight to twelve per cent. discount. There may be persons who fancy that this state of things is desirable; but nothing, in our judgment, could well be more disastrous. Any great financial crisis, whatever may be its cause, shakes and, shatters the whole business fabric of the country. What the country needs is such a gradual decline in the price of gold as will, enable all branches of business, public and private, to adapt themselves gradually and safely to the necessities which it creates.

abstract: Perversion of American facts; Saturday Review,unscrupulous and unprincipled
snippet: Perversion of American facts; Saturday Review,unscrupulous and unprincipled
lead_paragraph: The malignant and persistent ingenuity with which the leading British newspapers distort every event of the war to the prejudice of the United States, finds fresh illustration with every steamer. At the interview between DAVIS' Peace Commissioners and Messrs. LINCOLN and SEWARD, the suggestion was made by the former that the two armies should unite in the adoption of some "extrinsic policy." The English papers assume, probably, with justice, that this means a foreign war; but instead of holding its authors responsible for it, the blame of it is actually cast upon the Government of the United States. The Times makes it the occasion for one of its characteristic and chronic onslaughts upon Mr. SEWARD; and the Saturday Review, which is habitually and ostentatiously more unscrupulous and unprincipled in its discussion of American affairs than any other English journal can be, finds in the necessities of the rebels an excuse for having made the proposition, and visits all its wrath on the Government of the United States for listening to it! Governments certainly are not responsible for the language and temper of the press; but he must be very silly and shortsighted who does not see that studied and habitual injustice like this will produce a public sentiment against which Governments will be powerless.

snippet: Position in North Carolina; the Situation in
lead_paragraph: We do well, perhaps, to receive with allowance the statement of passengers that arrived yesterday at Washington from City Point, bringing reports, without date, as second-hand from SHERMAN's army. These reports, which we publish in another column for what they are worth, would make it appear that scouts sent forward last week by Gen. SHERMAN (to Kinston, we presume,) were in a position to announce positively the arrival of our forces at Goldsboro without opposition.

abstract: The
snippet: The
lead_paragraph: The wholesale prices of provisions yesterday, as compared with the quotation on the 31st of December last, continue to show an extraordinary decline. Mess pork by the barrel sells for half what it did three months ago. Prime pork is quoted at 80 per cent. below December rates, and cut meats are from 20 to 25 per cent. lower. Butter, taking the average qualities, costs considerably less than half what it did at the close of the year. These, however, are wholesale rates. There is no such reduction of cost to the great body of consumers. In meats, butter and potatoes, there still exists evidence of a combination among petty retailers to extort from their poorer customers profits of the most inordinate character. Until small housekeepers learn to club together for the purpose of wholesale purchases, we see no remedy against illicit trade leagues among the petty dealers.

abstract: Central National Bank, N Y, Robbed of $69,000
snippet: Central National Bank, N Y, Robbed of $69,000
lead_paragraph: On Monday afternoon a young man of genteel address entered the Central National Bank, in Broadway, at the head of Pearl street, and observing two packages of United States five-twenty and ten-forty bonds on a tin box on the cashier's desk, snatched them, and made a hasty and successful retreat. These bonds, nearly all of which are the property of persons who deal with the bank -- the institution owning only $19,000 of the $69,000 that were in the two bundles, were of small denomination of $50 and $100; and as the number of every bond is on record at the bank, and by this time has been made known to nearly every banker or broker in our principal cities, the thief will probably find his prize as valuable as the traditional elephant. The bank offers $10,000 reward, or a proportionate sum for the recovery of any number of the bonds. If this liberal offer does not induce the thief to restore the now worthless bonds, the bank will, of course, apply for duplicates, and the total loss to the institution, instead of reaching the large figure of $69,000, will be merely the cost of advertising, employing defective officers, &c., and perhape one year's interest, at five and six per cent., gold, on $69,000. Mr. W.H. FOSTER, Cashier of the bank, says that no person was in his office when he inadvertently left the bonds on his desk, and went for a moment into an adjoining room to consult with a clerk, and on his return he saw no one, and was unable to account for the mysterious disappearance; but a boy, who was on the street, witnessed through the window the movements of the thief, as he dodged into the bank and seized the packages, ran out and up Broadway, and this boy has given our detective policemen a minute description of the fugitive. The numbers of the bonds are given in another column.

abstract: Lines of Defence; Successive Abandonments of; onward march of; War with; Rebels, not Federals, proposed
snippet: Lines of Defence; Successive Abandonments of; onward march of; War with; Rebels, not Federals, proposed
lead_paragraph: -- The armies of the nation have advanced, within the last ten months, in prodigious strides, toward fulfilling that duty which President LINCOLN so simply, but comprehensively laid down four years ago -- the repossession of the seaports, forts, arsenals and territory of the nation, wrested away by insurrectionary forces. If the Richmond Confederacy, however, keeps on much longer in its present course of advancing backward, it will reduce itself to a single State. Within the brief period already mentioned, the line of the Ocmulgee, the line of the Oconee, the line of the Ogeechee, the line of the Savannah, the line of the Edisto, the line of the Santee, the line of the Great Pedee, and finally the line of the Cape Fear -- all great rivers, forming the water-sheds of three great States, stretching between the Blue Ridge and the Atlantic -- have been successively announced by authority as the Southwestern defensive line of the Confederacy, successively fortified as well as time allowed, and successively abandoned. Now, at last, in obedience to that compulsory retreat, which, by a polite euphemism, is called the "policy of concentration," the line of the Cape Fear has been abandoned for the line of the Neuse. Even this last water-course bids fair to be abandoned for the line of the Roanoke, on which certain information assures us that elaborate works are going up. Should that also follow the suit of the rest, then "the Western army" of the Confederacy has nothing left but to march "onward to Richmond."

abstract: At a recent general meeting of master printers of this city, it was decided to organize a permanent association for the general benefit of the trade and the improvement of the typographic art. A constitution was adopted, and the name of "Typothetoe" was given to the new association. The Executive Committee were directed to make arrangements for the inauguration of the Typothetoe, and they accordingly engaged Dodworth Hall, No. 806 Broadway, where last evening a large number of gentlemen interested in the improvement and elevation of the art of printing assembled to listen to some very interesting speeches explanatory of the objects of the association, and to pass a few hours in friendly converse and enjoyment. A most appetizing banquet and some excellent music added to the attractions provided by the Committee of Arrangments. The meeting was called to order by Mr. C.A. ALVORD, who briefly explained the objects which the association had in view. The following officers were then elected:
lead_paragraph: At a recent general meeting of master printers of this city, it was decided to organize a permanent association for the general benefit of the trade and the improvement of the typographic art. A constitution was adopted, and the name of "Typothetoe" was given to the new association. The Executive Committee were directed to make arrangements for the inauguration of the Typothetoe, and they accordingly engaged Dodworth Hall, No. 806 Broadway, where last evening a large number of gentlemen interested in the improvement and elevation of the art of printing assembled to listen to some very interesting speeches explanatory of the objects of the association, and to pass a few hours in friendly converse and enjoyment. A most appetizing banquet and some excellent music added to the attractions provided by the Committee of Arrangments. The meeting was called to order by Mr. C.A. ALVORD, who briefly explained the objects which the association had in view. The following officers were then elected:

abstract: Minister to United States, M de Montholon
snippet: Minister to United States, M de Montholon
lead_paragraph: The City of London arrived yesterday, with Queenstown dates to the 9th. The English papers were anxiously discussing the effect of the fall of Charleston, and reluctantly confessing that the rebel cause was fast becoming hopeless. The probabilities of trouble between England and the United States were another topic of leading editorials. The trouble in the iron-making districts of England will probably throw 70,000 persons out of employment. Parliamentary business is unimportant. M. DE MONTHOLON has been appointed French Minister at Washington, and M. DANO Minister at Mexico. The Pall Mall Gazette says that, in conformity with public opinion in France, the Emperor NAPOLEON will leave Mexico to her destiny as soon as the French troops have returned. There was a rumor, however, that a reinforcement of 5,000 troops was to be sent shortly to Mexico. The answer of Austria to the Prussian dispatch relative to the Duchies had reached Berlin. Report says that Austria declares the proposals of Prussia entirely unfitted to be the basis for further negotiations. A new ministry had been formed in Portugal with the Duke DE SOULE as President of the Council and Minister of Foreign Affairs, and the Marquis DE SA DA BANDIERA as Minister of War.

abstract: McEntee vs Noble; Assault on Ferry Boat
snippet: McEntee vs Noble; Assault on Ferry Boat
lead_paragraph: Charles McEnlee vs. Ralph Noble. -- The action was brought to recover damages for assault and battery. At the time of the grievance complained of -- namely, the early part of the year 1863 -- the plaintiff was a Custom-house officer, and the defendant was, and still is, a Sandy Hook pilot. Early one rainy morning the two were crossing in a Brooklyn ferryboat to New-York. The testimony given showed, that the gentlemen's cabin was filled. The defendant took a seat in front of the wheel-house, and placed a small bundle, which contained his slippers, on a vacant seat beside him. Plaintiff came in immediately after, looked around and concluded that the slippers occupied the only seat not taken. He took up the bundle, and, as one witness besides himself testified, asked the persons sitting on either side if it was their property. Receiving no answer, he either gently placed, or violently threw it on the floor. The testimony on this point was conflicting. Plaintiff took the seat, however, and in a few seconds the defendant asked him if he knew whose bundle that was. Plaintiff said no, nor did he care. Defendant said. "For aught you know it may contain articles of value, and you have thrown it upon the wet floor;" whereupon the latter caught up the bundle, and with a sudden movement struck plaintiff with it a violent blow in his face. The result was a profusion of blood from plaintiff's nose and great excitement among the passengers in the cabin, the most of them insisting that it was a great outrage for a large man like defendant to strike a small old man like the plaintiff. One passenger insisted on defendant's taking $10 from him and then fighting a man of his size. When the boat reached the New-York side, defendant was taken into custody by a policeman, and conveyed to the Tombs. After a hearing in the case the magistrate fined defendant $20, and severely reprimanded him for having made an assault so unprovoked. In the Police Court, and also on the trial yesterday, the defendant admitted having struck the blow, but he insisted that plaintiff gave him great provocation for doing so. Defendant and his witnesses testified that plaintiff did not ask to have the package removed from the seat, but threw it violently into the mud and filth of the gentleman's cabin.

abstract: Dano, M, Appointed Minister to Mexico
snippet: Dano, M, Appointed Minister to Mexico
lead_paragraph: The Pall Mall Gazette says that, in conformity with public opinion in France, the Emperor NAPOLEON will leave Mexico to her destiny as soon as the French troops have returned. There was a rumor, however, that a reinforcement of 5,000 troops was to be sent shortly to Mexico. The draft of the address to the Emperor, which is principally a paraphrase of the speech from the throne, had been read in the Senate. The address applauds the proposed measures of home policy. Speaking of the relations existing between the Church and the State, it says: "France will not allow the law of 1802, which is a defence against possible abuses, both from within and without, to fall into abeyance." It approves the Emperor's foreign policy, and hopes are expressed for the consolidation of the new Mexican Empire, and, however serious may be the questions that are still to be settled, the Emperor MAXIMILIAN will be able to decide them by prompt and energetic action. France will learn, from the testimony of her soldiers, soon to return to their country, that MAXIMILIAN reigns over a people sheltered henceforth under the banner of order. Alluding to the words of the Emperor, that the temple of war shall be closed, the address says: "Peace will be the policy of the future. Let us work in concert, to render plentiful this lasting peace."

abstract: The citizens of the Eighteenth Ward held a meeting at the Grammercy Park Hotel, on Monday evening. Provost-Marshal MANNIERE said the Eighteenth Ward was short about three hundred men; not more. If the ward could raise through its committees about $6,000, and offer additional hand money to the amount of $25 or $30 per man, the deficiency would be made good in a very short time. A mass meeting of the citizens of the ward will be held at the Medical College to-morrow evening.

lead_paragraph: The extraordinary floods which have done such extensive damage in New-York and Pennsylvania, have greatly subsided, and travel begins to assume tolerable regularity. The Erie road has now but one gap, between Chemung and Addison, and that will soon be repaired. The Pennsylvania and the Northern Central roads are in working order. The New-York Central is also running trains as usual. Our exchanges are filled with accounts of inundated valleys and towns, and the wide-spread destruction of moveable property which followed. The oil region of Pennsylvania and the valley of the Susquehanna appear to have suffered most severely.

abstract: The meeting to fill the quota of the Ninth and Fifteenth Wards, at Metropolitan Hall, No. 93 Sixth-avenue, last evening, was crowded, earnest, practical and successful. It was called to order at 8 o'clock, and Ex-Alderman CHIPP chosen Chairman, with Vice-Presidents as follows: Orison Blunt, E.C. Benedict, J. Flynn, J. Houghtaling, Mathew Fullam, J.W. Fowler, Thomas Lawrence, J.W. Floyd, Washington Murray, Robert Merkle, Col. C.W. Darling, Capt. E.R. Coster, E.V. Black and Abraham Cowless Secretaries -- W. Jarvis Adams, J. Gumbleton, Dr. B.Z. Vosburgh and A. Vredenburgh. After reading the call, the appeal from Maj. DODGE, addressed to Mayor GUNTHER, and a letter from Hon. R.H. MCCURDY, who could not be present but expressed his hearty sympathy in the object of the meeting, an order from Maj. DODGE was read, dated March 21, and directing the district Provost-Marshals to report progress daily to him, such progress to decide the question or a draft.

abstract: Passengers from City Point who arrived in Washington yesterday, say that SHERMAN had been joined by SCHOFIELD, and had occupied Goldsboro without opposition. This news came through SHERMAN'S scouts, who left him some time last week.
lead_paragraph: Passengers from City Point who arrived in Washington yesterday, say that SHERMAN had been joined by SCHOFIELD, and had occupied Goldsboro without opposition. This news came through SHERMAN's scouts, who left him some time last week. The Richmond Sentinel, of Monday, has a report that four divisions of SHERMAN's army were repulsed near Fayetteville on the 17th. Our own Government, however, has later information, showing that instead of being repulsed, SHERMAN is still pursuing his triumphant march. The result of the battles in front of Kinston last week will not be far from 2,000 killed, wounded and prisoners on our side, and all of 3,000 on the enemy's side, whose dead outnumber ours five to one.

abstract: new French Minister to United States
snippet: new French Minister to United States
lead_paragraph: Among the news from Europe which we publish to-day, is the bald announcement that M. DE MONTHOLON has been appointed French Minister at Washington, and M. DANO Minister to Mexico. This disposes of the speculative theories founded on the non-arrival of M. DE CHATEAURENAND, the minister first nominated as the successor of M. MERCIER. The new Ambassador may be presumed, from his residence here in the capacity of French Consul-General, not less than from his more recent position in Mexico, to bring to his new mission at least a familiarity with American continental affairs, which may facilitate his performance of the duties on which he is about to enter. It is a curious coincidence that France should send us a Minister raised from the rank of Consul at New-York, just as we send them one formerly Consul in Paris.

abstract: Union New-York, First Annual Ball
snippet: Union New-York, First Annual Ball
lead_paragraph: -- The NEW-York District National Telegraphic Union gave its first annual ball last evening at Irving Hall. The room was decorated with much skill, reflecting credit upon the committee. On the stage was one of MORSE's repeating instruments, beneath which was an excellent profile likeness of the great inventor, in bronze. At each end of the stage was also likenesses of MORSE. The galleries, walls and stage were tastefully trimmed with festoons of flowers and bunting, while suspended from the galleries were beautiful baskets of flowers. The attendance was large and select, the music excellent, and the ball a great success.

abstract: The movement of citizens toward filling the quota of the city without recourse to draft is progressing with every prospect of success. Acting Assistant Provost-Marshal DODGE acknowledges his satisfaction at what has been thus far accomplished, and the recruits who yesterday ...
lead_paragraph: The movement of citizens toward filling the quota of the city without recourse to draft is progressing with every prospect of success. Acting Assistant Provost-Marshal DODGE acknowledges his satisfaction at what has been thus far accomplished, and the recruits who yesterday presented themselves to be mustered in at the offices of the District Provost-Marshals, kept those functionaries "reasonably busy." To-day in most of the wards recruiting agencies will be open, and the committees will be ready with the ward bounties of $100 hand-money for able-bodied men.

abstract: Eastern Judicial District Court, Act Creating; Letter on Starters of New-York Riot, 1863; Eastern Judicial District Court, Opening of, and Act
snippet: Eastern Judicial District Court, Act Creating; Letter on Starters of New-York Riot, 1863; Eastern Judicial District Court, Opening of, and Act
lead_paragraph: The United States Circuit and District Courts for the new Eastern District of New-York were formally opened yesterday in Brooklyn. The sessions of the courts had been ordered to be held in the Governor's room in the City Hall at twelve o'clock, and there collected quite a large gathering of members of the bar and other spectators. It was found, however, that the room was in an entirely unsuitable state, all the furniture having been taken out of it, and a bare floor with holes in it where the railings had been secured, and only a table and three or four chairs in the middle of the room, furnishing no accommodations for the proceedings. Gen. Crooke, one of the Supervisors, therefore invited the Court to the Supervisor's room in the County Court House, and thither all repaired.

abstract: Colorado, Panama Mail Steamship Co's Steamship, on Exhibition
snippet: Colorado, Panama Mail Steamship Co's Steamship, on Exhibition
lead_paragraph: The Pacific Mail Steamship Company's new steamship Colorado, lying at the foot of Canal-street, North River, was thrown open to the public yesterday, and is to be on exhibition to-day and to-morrow, and on Friday and Saturday, from 10 o'clock in the morning until 4 o'clock in the afternoon. The Colorado is one of a fleet of floating palaces that Messrs. WILLIAM H. WEBB, HENRY STEERS, and other eminent marine architects have constructed within a year for the Pacific Mail Company. She is 363 feet in length, 45 feet in width, 31 feet 6 inches in depth, measures 3,890 tons, and cost about $1,000,000. Her engines, which were built at the Novelty Works, have cylinders of 105 inches diameter and 12 feet stroke, and are of the finest workmanship. The cabin accommodations on the Colorado are not inferior to those on the great Cunard steamship China, there being on the main deck fifty-two commodious state-rooms for families, and in the second cabin comfortable berths for fifteen hundred passengers. In fire apparatus the ship is completely equipped. From the main boilers several great tubes extend to stem and stern, and to these are attached twenty-four hose-pipes, with inch and a quarter nozzles, capable of flooding every part of the ship at five minutes' notice; a steam-pipe communicates with the hold, to be used there in the event of fire in the cargo, and in addition to these ample precautionary provisions there is in the forecastle a donkey engine to run the force-pumps independent of the main engines amidships, so that if the central engines were disabled by fire, the engineers could flood the ship from the forecastle. With such enormous hydraulic power aboard, there would seem to be absolute safety; but further to provide for the contingency of fire, or of a leak over which the twenty-four force-pumps cannot gain mastery, there are on the hurricane deck a large number of metallic life-boats, in each of which are constantly kept several sealed cans and casks of water and bread. Not the least interesting display which the Colorado is able to make in these days of Chesapeake piracies is her armament. She carries two twenty-pound field pieces on her quarter, and two thirty-pounders at the fore, and in her arsenal are Sharp's rifles, common muskets, revolvers, pikes, and axes in abundance, and the ship's crew of 120 men may be armed and marshaled on the hurricane deck on two minute's notice.

abstract: Chickamauga, Rebel Ram, Fate of
snippet: Chickamauga, Rebel Ram, Fate of
lead_paragraph: -- A letter to the Philadelphia Inquirer, dated at Wilmington March 11, states that the fate of the Chickamauga has been definitely ascertained. The light draught gunboat Eolus, Capt. KEYSER, was sent up the Cape Fear River a few days ago. Some thirty odd miles above the city, the hull of the piratical craft was discovered half burned and partially submerged in the brown waters of the Cape Fear. Capt. KEYSER forced his way five miles above the sunken wreck of the Chickamauga. The water grew very shallow, the keel of the Eolus grating over the bed of the river. The trees, too, offered serious impediments to the further progress of the little gunboat. The limbs of the trees growing on either bank extended out over the river, often interfacing their gnarled arms, forming impassable barriers, Capt. KEYSER was forced to return.
headline: {'main': 'FATE OF THE CHICKAMAUGA.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'FATE OF THE CHICKAMAUGA.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Platt-street, No 18
snippet: Platt-street, No 18
lead_paragraph: -- At about 9 o'clock last evening a fire was discovered in the third story of No. 18 Platt-street, occupied by Mr. L. PICOT, commission merchant. The flames spread rapidly to the second and fourth floors, occupied by Messrs. R.H. MCDONALD & CO., dealers in dry-drugs, and to the first floor; but here they were checked. Mr. SAMUEL HASKELL, dealer in oils, drugs, liquors, &c., on the first floor of No. 18, and occupying the whole of the building No. 20, sustained considerable loss from damage by water in both buildings, and the second, third and fourth floors of No. 18 were consumed. In the absence of owners it was impossible to ascertain the losses and insurances.

lead_paragraph: The Committee appointed by the Chamber of Commerce to procure testimonials for Capt. WINSLOW, the officers and crew of the United States sloop-of-war Kearsarge, in recognition of the service rendered to American commerce in the destruction of the rebel steamer Alabama, in June last, have collected for this purpose, from the underwriters, merchants and others in this city, the sum of $25,000, and it is now being distributed by Mr. C.H. MARSHALL, Treasurer of the Committee, at No. 38 Burling-slip, to those who were attached to the Kearsarge at that time.

abstract: LARCENIES. -- JOHN WHITE, a furloughed soldier, appeared before Justice LEDWITH and entered complaint against WILLIAM RICHARDS, a bar-tender in JAMES CHARLTON's den, in Greene-street, and EVA MORTIMER, one of the inmates of the place, testified that she saw RICHARDS abstract $300 from WHITE's wallet while he was drinking at the bar. RICHARDS, whom Officer FOGARTY, of the Eighth Precinct, had apprehended, was committed in default of $1,000 bail, and WHITE was imprisoned in the House of Detention....Officer TUTHILL, of the Eighth Ward, arrested EMMA DALTON for stealing $67 and a gold watch from HENRY CAMPBELL, at a place in Greene-street, and she was committed by Justice LEDWITH, in default of $500 bail.

abstract: Convicts in our Courts
snippet: Convicts in our Courts
lead_paragraph: -- Three English ticket-of-leave men were brought up in the Court of General Sessions yesterday, one of them being indicted for grand larceny, and the others appearing as witnesses. The indicted man escaped conviction for want of evidence, but we are glad to see that City Judge RUSSEL announced his intention of punishing this class of criminals with the utmost severity whenever he has them before him. If nothing can be done to prevent the English from using the City of New-York as a penal settlement on which to plant colonies of thieves, we hope the criminal courts will take cognizance of their previous crimes across the water, and treat them when convicted here as parties guilty of a second offence, entitled to the extreme penalties of the law.

abstract: McLenan, John, the Artist
snippet: McLenan, John, the Artist
lead_paragraph: JOHN MCLENAN died of congestion of the brain on the morning of Sunday last, at his home in Brooklyn. He was of Irish parentage, born in Ohio, and after attaining considerable local reputation in Cincinnati for humorous sketches, and for rapidity of execution, he removed to this city about 1854. Here he has been fully occupied ever since producing very great numbers of comic and serious sketches for newspapers, and of illustrations for books. Many of our readers will remember his spirited sketches in Vanity Fair, and his illustrations of DICKENS' "Tales of Two Cities," and COLLINS' "Woman in White." Those in these two books, particularly, did him great credit.

abstract: Central National Bank, Recovery of Stolen Bonds
snippet: Central National Bank, Recovery of Stolen Bonds
lead_paragraph: If our detective policemen were authorized to draw on the public purse for funds sufficient to cover their necessary expenses in discovering the haunts of thieves and bringing them to justice, it is said that they might within a twelvemonth weed out every counterfeiter's den and gambling-hell in the city. But the Police Commissioners do not intrust their detective officers with money to buy up those more adroit thieves who lead the riff-raff of pickpockets and burglars, and it is only when a large reward is offered that the officers can afford to risk their private means. The $10,000 reward which was offered by the Central National Bank for the restoration of $69,000 in United States bonds that were stolen from their cashier's office on Monday afternoon, was a prize worth the detectives' best efforts. If it had been $5,000, they could hardly have accomplished the work; for they could not have afforded to give the chief of the thieves' organization $5,000 to distribute among his underlings, and this douceur wanting, not a thief would have divulged, and the Central National Bank might have whistled for its bonds. We are not at liberty to disclose the detectives' precise mode of operation; but it can be said that twenty-four hours subsequent to the robbery they were in possession of information which led them to "pipe" an up-town dwelling, and that therein on Tuesday afternoon, they found and seized the bonds. But prior to the seizure, it is said to have been necessary to enter into a compromise, in which the bank had its choice of the thief or the bonds. The officers of the institution, it is further alleged, seeing that there could be no hope of getting both the thief and the securities, took into view the fact that $50,000 of the bonds belonged to their depositors, and elected to take the bonds, and these were deposited in the detectives' safe at the Central Department of Metropolitan Police in less than six hours from the time when the bank officers made known their decision. Three persons have been apprehended on "suspicion of complicity;" but their names are withheld from the public, and will scarcely go beyond a Grand Jury room. Thus the Central National Bank robbery resolves itself into what the light-fingered gentry style "a good thing all round." The bank has recovered its securities, and lost only about $12,000; Detectives YOUNG, MCDOUGALL, GILMORE, RADFORD, KELSO and Capt. JOURDAN have credit for "working up" an intricate case; certain somebodies have each a share of $10,000; the public are gratified with the assurance that three arrests have been made, and the Police Justices may complacently look upon the prisoners as three persons who may never give them trouble for a moment.

abstract: -- The third entertainment of this association, the proceeds of which will be devoted to the fund for building an asylum for the aged and infirm, took place at Niblo's Saloon last evening. A large audience was present. The entertainment consisted of songs by Mr. and Miss GEARY and Mr. BRADSHAW, piano-forte solos by Miss CELIA HOFFEIMER, which elicited considerable applause, and a drama in three acts, entitled "Deceit; or, Feeling and Fashion," which was played in a very spirited manner by the members of the association.

abstract: Congress on Davis's Message
snippet: Congress on Davis's Message
lead_paragraph: It needs no great amount of penetration to discover that the so-called Address of the rebel Congress, which we publish to-day, is the mere echo of DAVIS' recent speeches. The names appended to it can have included only the few hangers-on of the Confederate Executive, since we know that weeks ago there was barely a quorum left in either House, and of that remnant, as the Senate's scathing report on DAVIS clearly shows, a portion, at least, must have thoroughly dissented from the Congressional Address.

abstract: Orange, N. J.; Foote's Boarding School--$15,000
snippet: Orange, N. J.; Foote's Boarding School--$15,000
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning between 1 and 2 o'clock, a large handsome gothic structure, occupied by Mr. E.F. FOOTE, as a private boarding-school, and situated on a private eminence near the Rosedale Cemetery, in Orange, was totally destroyed by fire. The flames spread so rapidly that the inmates, 29 in number, had barely time to escape in their night-dresses. Mrs. FOOTE was compelled to leap from a second-story piazza in order to escape. The clothing and effects of the family and boarders was all consumed, as was also the furniture. The loss will amount to hear $15,000. The residence was owned by Mrs. WILSON, of Brooklyn, and was valued at $9,000; insured for $4,500. The loss in furniture and school books is $2,500, and in clothing, money and valuables belonging to the pupils, between $3,000 and $4,000. The origin of the fire is not known.
headline: {'main': 'Conflagration at Orange, N.J. Narrow Escape of Twenty-Nine Persons.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Conflagration at Orange, N.J. Narrow Escape of Twenty-Nine Persons.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Port au Prince, Hayti; Incendiary; 150 houses; Port au Prince; incendiary fire; 150 houses burned
snippet: Port au Prince, Hayti; Incendiary; 150 houses; Port au Prince; incendiary fire; 150 houses burned
lead_paragraph: The dear people of Nassau have suddenly discovered that there is such a Government as the United States, and that they have always greatly admired and respected said Government. It may be mentioned in this connection, that there are thirty-four fine blockade-running steamers lying idle in Nassau harbor, and more are arriving almost daily from England, only to be sent back without discharging. The warehouses of the city are full of goods intended for the rebels, that are now scarcely worth paying insurance upon. A few supposed pirate steamers are lurking around the Bahamas, but thus far they have done nothing. Young LOCKE, one of the captors of the Chesapeake, is in prison, on charges of forfeiting his bail and selling captured goods, contrary to law. It is gratifying to know what interest the British Islanders take in us -- since the capture of Charleston and Wilmington.

abstract: Signs of his Moving; Glasgow, Tenn.; Railroad Train Burned and Robbed; Congress, Address to the People
snippet: Signs of his Moving; Glasgow, Tenn.; Railroad Train Burned and Robbed; Congress, Address to the People
lead_paragraph: Our war news this morning is rather meager except in details by correspondents, the telegraph bringing us almost nothing. Two or three reports are worthy of note. A dispatch from Washington to the Philadelphia Evening Telegraph says a messenger arrived with news from Gen. SHERMAN to Monday, by the way of City Point. Goldsboro was occupied by our forces on Friday, (Sunday?) and the army moved immediately in pursuit of the enemy. Refugees report that JOHNSTON is moving to Richmond to join LEE.

abstract: no New Step Necessary, by President Lincoln; Understand th y can have Peace; N. Y., Proposing Overtures to Rebels
snippet: no New Step Necessary, by President Lincoln; Understand th y can have Peace; N. Y., Proposing Overtures to Rebels
lead_paragraph: The Tribune again raises the cry for a proclamation of the President presenting overtures to the rebels. It declares that the Southern people must now be fully satisfied that a Southern Confederacy is impossible, and that an offer of liberal terms would probably detach them from their leaders, and bring them back to the Union without further bloodshed. It considers that the proclamation should particularly set forth the Presidential policy on the six following points: -- Union, Amnesty, Confiscation, Emancipation, Reconstruction, Representation in Congress.

abstract: Rents are still excessively high in New-York City; quite as high as the quotations given in an article on the subject in the TIMES of Feb. 18. They have not yet shown any indication of feeling the fall in gold.
lead_paragraph: Rents are still excessively high in New-York City; quite as high as the quotations given in an article on the subject in the TIMES of Feb. 18. They have not yet shown any indication of feeling the fall in gold. The reason is, that the demand for tenements keeps rents up more than the state of the currency keeps them down. We are unable to hear of any provision whatever by builders or capitalists to meet the wants of the middling class of tenants, such as salaried clerks, &c., and well-to-do tradesmen and mechanics. The rich can always buy good accommodations. The poor will always find some den, or hole, or cellar, or attic, or single room. But the man neither rich nor poor, refined in tastes, cleanly in habits, and of respectable associations, cannot afford a great "brown-stone front" house; still less can he afford to imprision a wife or young children in a floor of a dirty tenement-house, or in a filthy and feverous cheap street, that will fester all summer with sickly and deadly stenches. And if he takes lodgings in a boarding-house, or tavern, he simply plants those who depend upon him in the midst of a hot furnace of temptations. There is absolutely no place for him in this city. He must go away, or know that those dearest to him are all the time exto physical posedand moral injury.

abstract: -- There will be a concert at Irving Hall on Thursday evening next which will appeal especially to our German citizens, as the profits will be devoted to the German Ladies' Society in Aid of German Widows and Orphanz. This excellent association is in debt, and needs help. The aid it extends is distributed to poor women and their families, who are often ignorant of our language. MILLS, Miss DE GEBELE, RIMI, SCREIBER, and the Mannerchor will assist at the concert.

abstract: Brooklyn; Schneider, L, Murdered by Slung-shot
snippet: Brooklyn; Schneider, L, Murdered by Slung-shot
lead_paragraph: DIED FROM THE EFFECTS OF A SLUNG-SHOT WOUND. -- On a Saturday evening, some four weeks since, a party of men, headed by JOHN MCCANN, called at the lager-bier saloon of LOUIS SCHNEIDER, No. 458 Columbia-street, and called for drinks. They took several rounds, and refused to pay for them. The landlord declining to give them any more, they left and soon after returned, when they attacked Mr. SCHNEIDER, and beat him in a brutal manner. As alleged, MCCANN struck him on the head with a slung-shot, fracturing his skull. The injured man labored in great pain until yesterday, when he died. MCCANN was arrested shortly after the assault was committed and is now in custody. The Coroner was notified to hold an inquest on the body of deceased.

abstract: Jersey City Treasurer's Report
snippet: Jersey City Treasurer's Report
lead_paragraph: -- The annual report of Mr. P.D. VROOM, City Treasurer of Jersey City, the year ending March 21, shows the total receipts to have been $1,516,663 18, from the following sources: Receipts from taxes, $233,686; loans, $1,164,400; street improvements, $63,658 96; other sources, $54,917 12. The expenditures for the same time were; Fire Department, $16,717 91; police, $32,717 52; schools, $27,450 14; printing, $3,100 95; stationery, $1,486 38, salaries, $15,854 20; loans and bounties, $1,221,488 97; Water Commissioners, $10,168 66; streets, $51,792 07, and other minor expenditures, making the total amount $1,622,062 31. Balance in treasury at the beginning of the new year, $12,606 69.

abstract: Modoc, Monitor; Launch at Greenpoint
snippet: Modoc, Monitor; Launch at Greenpoint
lead_paragraph: Tuesday, at 2:55 P.M., precisely, the splendid light-draught monitor Modoc was launched at the yard of Mr. J.S. UNDERHILL, Greenpoint. About 3,000 ladies, gentlemen and naval officers were present, curiously examining the formidable war craft as she lay on the stocks. Every available place upon and around the vessel was filled, while three or four tugs and innumerable small craft kept plying in the stream, ready to take charge of the vessel when she should glide into the water. Flags were unfurled from every house and vessel. Among the distinguished gentlemen present, we noticed the following: Rear-Admiral GREGORY, Chief-Engineer W.W. WOOD, Commodore RINGGOLD, Capt. WORDEN, Rev. Dr. CLAPP, Rev. Mr. PARTRIDGE, Messrs. ENGLISH, WHITLOCK, ROWLAND, Capt. PERINE, and other eminent shipbuilders. Hardly had the last block been knocked away, when the vessel moved swiftly into the water. At this juncture, Miss AMANDA UNDERHILL, the charming daughter of the builder, amid loud buzzas and waving of handkerchiefs, broke the champaigne bottle across the bows, and said, "In the name of Neptune, I christen thee Modoc! May you, from to-day, triumphantly sail, and over our enemies ever prevail."

abstract: New-York; Ward Meetings to Fill Quotas
snippet: New-York; Ward Meetings to Fill Quotas
lead_paragraph: Our citizens who are liable to draft, as well as those who are exempt, are working in earnest to fill their respective ward quotas, and thus avoid an odious conscription. Meetings have been held in every ward, and a special ward bounty of $100 has been generally agreed upon, and there are instances of additional bounties that individuals have offered, ranging from $25 to $100. The various ward committees believe that if our citizens continue without flagging in the work which they have begun, the District Provost-Marshals may be kept busy, and it may not be necessary to resume the revolutions of the wheel.

abstract: Eastern District New U S Courts; New U S District Courts
snippet: Eastern District New U S Courts; New U S District Courts
lead_paragraph: The United States Courts for the new Eastern District were opened yesterday in Brooklyn, in the Supervisors' Room in the new courthouse, and we give in another column a full report of the proceedings. We understand that there was a large attendance of the members of the bar, and that great interest was shown in the proceedings, as was natural, for they gave Brooklyn Federal Courts of her own, and made her no longer a mere appendage to New-York, as far as these courts are concerned.

abstract: The Australasian has made a fine passage, and has brought great news. Charleston has fallen. abstract: Senate Report on Davis; Rebel Senate on his Message; Rebel Depe dence on
snippet: Senate Report on Davis; Rebel Senate on his Message; Rebel Depe dence on
lead_paragraph: We commend to the special attention of those who wish to see by what ligaments the rebel Confederacy is held together as a political community, the extraordinary commentary of the rebel Senate on JEFFERSON DAVIS' recent message. We publish the Senate's report, as supplying the most comprehensive and telling illustration that the world has yet had of the imposture which the rebel conspirators have sought to dignify by the name of Government.

abstract: The Australasian brings Queenstown dates to the 12th. The English press seem to have anticipated the fall of Wilmington, and no especial surprise was created by the news. The papers are much more interested in discussing the probable condition of the relations of their own country with the United States. The possibility of a heavy bill for damage by pirates evidently disturb the British mind. The question whether any such demand had yet been made was categorically put in the Commons, by Lord CECIL on the 9th, when Mr. LAYARE answered that no such demand had been made within the past six months. Me added that many claims of English subjects for damages growing out of our war had been forwarded to the British Government. A Government officer charged with complicity in the case of the pirate Rappahannock has been placed upon half-pay, being declared no longer worthy of official confidence. LA DUKE DE MORNY, half-brother of the Emperor of France, died on the 10th inst. The Opinlone National has a good article on SHERMAN's campaign, in which it denounces the rebellion very emphatically. Some hard things were said in England in the French Senate, on the discussion of the address, perfide Albion being called "the asylum of assassins ready to attempt the life of the Emperor. Remarks of M. DE BOISSY wishing that both parties in America might fight until both were destroyed, were strongly condemned by other members. M. DE SARTIGKS had an audience of the Fope, when he requested His Holiness to form an army within two years, with the assistance of France. The Emperor of Austria has concluded to raise the seige of Gullicia on the 8th of April. The India Telegraph continues to work satisfactorily.

abstract: Comptroller BRENNAN, in answer to a resolution of the Assembly, reports that the Treasurer of the County of New-York has not complied with the provisions of the law. On the contrary, in the year 1863 he retained the sum of $19,394 24, over and above the $2,000 which he was authorized to receive by the said act. I immediately directed an action to be commenced against him by the Attorney-General for that amount, and the interest thereon. To that action he interposed a defence. The case has been tried before Judge JOHNSON, the referee, and a report recently made against the Treasurer for the sum of $20,500 99. As this result will probably settle the disputed question, I do not think any further legislation necessary. In 1864 he again retained the sum of $21,265 18, over and above the amount which he was authorised to retain by the said act. It is presumed that, under the decision in the former case, this sum will be paid over without further litigation. If it should not be so paid, the same proceedings will be had as in the other case.

lead_paragraph: Isaac M. Singer vs. Catharine Singer. -- A judgment of divorce was granted several years since in this case, and the defendant, Catherine Singer, now moves to have the decree set aside. In opposition to the motion Mr. Singer made his affidavit, in which he testified among other things, that since the decree of divorce had been granted, he had re-married with another woman, and that his family now consisted of himself, wife and two children.

abstract: We have news from New-Orleans to the 17th inst., from which we learn that Gen. CANBY was then near Mobile, and the grand attack on that city would be made within five days. The General, accompanied by Admiral THATCHER and Gen. GRANGER, recently went within four miles of the city, where they drew the fire of several rebel batteries.

abstract: From the figures received at the office of Maj. DODGE, Acting Assistant Provost-Marshal-General, it appears that the work of filling the quota goes on with great deliberation. On Wednesday the number of recruits obtained, including both those received by Mr. BLUNT, and at the District Headquarters, was as follows: for the Fourth District, 3 men; Fifth, 18; Sixth, 38; Seventh, 25, Eighth, 11; Ninth, 3; total for that day in New-York, 98. The figures from yesterday will not vary much from the above.

abstract: John Aitken vs. Wm.H. Burr. -- The plaintiff, a lawyer, having an office at No. 119 Nassau-street, sued the defendant, a stenographer, having an office directly over his, for calling him a copperhead and a traitor, in October, 1864. Counsel for defendant moved to dismiss the complaint, on the ground that there was no cause of action. The Judge was at first strongly inclined to grant the motion, but concluded that the question whether, by the use of the word traitor, the defendant meant to charge the crime of treason, might be left to the jury. Defendant set up provocation on the part of the plaintiff's son, an office boy, in disturbing the building by noise and skylarking, and that, when several times remonstrated with by the janitor and the defendant, he was saucy, and referred to his father in a defiant and threatening way, which excited the defendant, and caused him to use the language complained of. Justification was also set up in the alleged use of disloyal language by the plaintiff during the present war. Proof was given to some extent of the allegations of the defence, and other proof of alleged disloyal language was offered and ruled out, as not having come to the knowledge of the defendant. The jury were nine hours in agreeing upon a verdict of $20 in favor of the plaintiff. Plaintiff tried his own cause; Messrs. Cooper & Roe for defendant.

abstract: Frantic Addresses and Proclamation; Rebel, ineffectual call for
snippet: Frantic Addresses and Proclamation; Rebel, ineffectual call for
lead_paragraph: It is quite plain that the Confederate chiefs are of opinion that the Confederacy can be saved by addresses and proclamations. For the last two years their Congress has issued about two in the Session, abusing the Yankees and advising the people never to give in. But so far as we have been able to learn, they do not produce the slightest impression on anybody. It is well known that there is not the slightest use in ever advising any community to act like desperate men.
