abstract: Morny, Duke de
snippet: Morny, Duke de
lead_paragraph: The Emperor of France has lost one of the most valuable supporters of his dynasty, and probably the most trusted of his personal friends. The Duke DE MORNY died on the 10th of March, in his 54th year. M. DE MORNY was born on the 23d of October, 1811. His mother was Queen HORTENSE, the daughter of JOSEPHINE, and the mother of the reigning Emperor. The late Duke was, therefore, half-brother of NAPOLEON III. He commenced his career as a soldier, having joined the First Regiment of Lancers in 1822. He served with considerable distinction in Africa; but M. DE MORNY's name came first prominently before the world on the occasion of the coup d'etat of Dec. 2, 1851. To him NAPOLEON first disclosed that enterprise, and since then his influence, as a diplomatist, as a legislator, and as President of the Corps Legislatif, has steadily grown, until it exceeded, probably, that of any subject of the Empire. His ruling passion -- aside from his political ambition -- was his acquisitiveness. He was one of the wealthiest men in France.

abstract: Senate Investigating Committee Adj'd
snippet: Senate Investigating Committee Adj'd
lead_paragraph: -- The committee appointed by the State Senate to investigate the affairs of our City Government has adjourned -- to meet again after the adjournment of the Legislature. So far as practical legislation is concerned, it has accomplished nothing. It was originally appointed for two weeks, but has been in session six or eight, and its business is still unfinished. It has disclosed a good deal that is loose, selfish and corrupt in the conduct of our City affairs, but nothing new. All that was known before.

abstract: Stillwell vs. The Mariposa Mining Company. -- The plaintiff in this action is the holder and owner of fifteen unpaid and overdue coupons of the first mortgage bonds of the Mariposa Company. He brought the action to recover the amount due upon them, which he insists should be paid in gold coin. The principal defence of the defendant is, that the plaintiff ought to have proceeded in a foreclosure suit under the laws of, and in the courts of California, and that until he has pursued his remedy there, he cannot bring an action in this State. A decision in the case will probably be made by the court on Saturday. We are informed that a decision in this suit involves the right and power to enforce an obligation to pay co[???]n, as well as the right to consider a coupon as a simple promise to pay, liable to a remedy in an ordinary action without a foreclosure.
lead_paragraph: Stillwell vs. The Mariposa Mining Company. -- The plaintiff in this action is the holder and owner of fifteen unpaid and overdue coupons of the first mortgage bonds of the Mariposa Company. He brought the action to recover the amount due upon them, which he insists should be paid in gold coin. The principal defence of the defendant is, that the plaintiff ought to have proceeded in a foreclosure suit under the laws of, and in the courts of California, and that until he has pursued his remedy there, he cannot bring an action in this State. A decision in the case will probably be made by the court on Saturday. We are informed that a decision in this suit involves the right and power to enforce an obligation to pay co[???]n, as well as the right to consider a coupon as a simple promise to pay, liable to a remedy in an ordinary action without a foreclosure.

abstract: Sanitary Inspection Bureau Active for a Week
snippet: Sanitary Inspection Bureau Active for a Week
lead_paragraph: -- It is only by comparison that we can appreciate the labors of the Bureau of Sanitary Inspection for the past week. The removal of eight hundred odd cartloads of night soil, in six working days, is at the rate of something less than a load for every thousand of the population. But the accumulations extend over a period of three months, and as these accumulations were found to include over one hundred dead horses, thirty-seven dead goats, and nearly two hundred dead dogs, besides over six thousand barrels of offal, we are probably safe in making the two-fold deduction, that much necessary work was done within the week, and that much more remains to be done. It is a question whether we are entitled to felicitate ourselves on the fact that we owe the better part of this spasmodic effort at the abatement of nuisances to the occasion of a public procession -- which will not take place, under the same auspices, for a year to come.

abstract: Slow Passages of
snippet: Slow Passages of
lead_paragraph: It will be seen that the slow passages of the Boston branch line of the Cunard mail steamers has been under notice in the British House of Commons. Mr. FREDERICK PEEL, speaking for the Government, embraced the occasion to indicate that the subsidies now paid to the line would be discontinued at the expiring of the present contract in 1867. This has been recommended in the reports of successive Parliamentary reports. But we have seen opposing influences employed time and again to ignore all these reports, and perpetuate the subsidies. The same may be done again.

abstract: Col. BAKER, Provost-Marshal-General of Missouri, has seized $90,000 in gold and paper money and about $10,000 in notes, deposited in various banks is St. Louis, belonging to the wife of the rebel Major-Gen. EWELL, and the question of confiscating the same is now betore the United States District Court.
lead_paragraph: Col. BAKER, Provost-Marshal-General of Missouri, has seized $90,000 in gold and paper money and about $10,000 in notes, deposited in various banks is St. Louis, belonging to the wife of the rebel Major-Gen. EWELL, and the question of confiscating the same is now betore the United States District Court. A large lot of land belonging to Mrs. EWELL has also been seized. Mrs. EWELL is the daughter of Judge CAMPBELL, a wealthy planter near Nashville, Tenn., and a distinguished Union citizen of that State. Two years ago she armed and equipped, at her own expense, an entire rebel regiment. A year ago she passed South beyond the Federal lines, and proceeded to Richmond, where she afterward married Gen. EWELL. She is now in Canada, where she went for the purpose of receiving her property after it should be converted into cash.

Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: M Blot's Academy; Opening
snippet: M Blot's Academy; Opening
lead_paragraph: The ladies of New-York have been furnished with a new sensation by Monsieur BLOT, a French professor of cooking, who has recently instituted a cooking academy in this city. The reform about to be introduced by the professor will be more acceptable to the people of New-York than any which has heretofore been derived from pleasure-loving and extravagant France. Monsieur BLOT not only claims that his dishes are better than those of Americans, but that they are much healthier and more economical. He also pays much attention to making them attractive when placed upon the table.

abstract: Spring and Summer Fashions; Spring and Summer
snippet: Spring and Summer Fashions; Spring and Summer
lead_paragraph: Opening-day seems to have been anticipated with more than usual eagerness this season; possibly because the back of Winter, as well as of the rebellion, has been broken in advance of the most sanguine anticipations; partly because a complete revolution has taken place in the size and shape of fashionable head-gear; but principally on account of the tide of refugees who have recently poured in upon the metropolis, in all the stages of dilapidation; and in their desire to make a presentable appearance with as little delay as possible, have besieged the doors of well-known milliners, begging piteously to be allowed to see "just one" of the new Spring styles, or make just one purchase in advance of the regular exhibition.

abstract: not heard from supposed fled
snippet: not heard from supposed fled
lead_paragraph: When Vice-President STEPHENS left Richmond for Georgia, soon after the Peace Conference, it was said he was going to fire the hearts of the people of Georgia and rouse them to fresh efforts. He does not seem to be doing it. The Augusta Constitutionalist says he has "been in the State ten days and they have not yet heard from him." It calls on him not to let that silence continue. It expects him to let his voice be heard "ringing out clear and hopeful words." It appeals to him to make himself the Burke of the Confederacy, and gives quite a long list of the many things which the cause needs and demands at his hands. Really it begins to look as if it wouldn't get them. Mr. STEPHENS seems to have withdrawn, in grim and sullen despair, like ACHILLES to his tent. There is very little inducement for him to come out.

abstract: and Southern People,Last Link Brok'n; Congress; The Last of; How it leaves Davis
snippet: and Southern People,Last Link Brok'n; Congress; The Last of; How it leaves Davis
lead_paragraph: The adjournment of the rebel Congress probably makes an end of it forever. It is not likely that a quorum of that body will ever again convene. Long before the regular day for reassembling next Winter, the rebel capital will come into our possession, and the internal communications of the Confederacy will be so broken up by us that no generally accessible point will be left it. A call, in the meantime, for a special session, will hardly be responded to in sufficient numbers for business. The bitter report which was adopted by the Senate just prior to the adjournment, in reply to the late upbraiding message of DAVIS, and the general rejection of the measures he recommended, show such a loss of confidence in him, and such disaffection, as to destroy all prospect of future effective cooperation; and without such a prospect the rebel Congressmen will be slow to perform any extra journeyings at his beck.

abstract: Pirate, at Melbourne
snippet: Pirate, at Melbourne
lead_paragraph: The pirate Shenandoah, having destroyed eleven American merchantmen in the Indian Ocean, has turned up for refitment and provisioning at Melbourne, Australia. We shall hear of her anon, on her return westward, somewhere in the neighborhood of the neutral ports of Cape Colony, South Africa.

abstract: "THE THREE SCOUTS." -- The scene of this stirring narrative is laid in the State of Tennessee during the second year of the rebellion. The events of the war in that region afford material for a variety of spirited sketches, and are here wrought up by the author with his usual skill in dramatic delineation and picturesque effect. His work cannot fail to occupy a high place among the numerous successful stories which have turned the facts of history to more impressive purposes than are often realized by the inventions of fiction. -- New-York Tribune.

abstract: SALE OF RARE COINS. -- During the week a number of valuable coins have been disposed of by Mr. GEORGE A. LEAVITT, at his salesroom, No. 448 Broadway. A silver dollar of 1799 brought $62 50; one of 1838, $36; a half dollar of 1796, $15; one of 1797, $8 50; a dime of 1796, $4 50; half dime of 1794, $9 50; cent of 1797, $24 50; of 1799, $30; of 1806, $35; a Carolina copper, $32; a Lord Baltimore groat, $18; three Granby coppers brought $50, $42 50, and $26 respectively. A number of rare coins are still to be sold. Among them are a New-York doubloon of 1787, which has been once sold for $400; Connecticut and New-York cents of 1787, and some curious gold coins, which are well worthy of attention.

abstract: The Engagement at
snippet: The Engagement at
lead_paragraph: We look in vain in the Richmond papers of Wednesday, or in the telegraphic abstract of Thursday's papers forwarded by Gen. GRANT, for additional light on the scope and results of the engagement of Sunday last, at Bentonsville. The report of deserters, received by way of City Point, although given with some minuteness, we hesitate to regard as trustworthy. These reports represent SHERMAN as having rallied his troops after Sunday's battle and driven the rebels five miles. This story would be more credible if we could come to the conclusion that SHERMAN's army needed rallying after that battle. Certainly, the engagement at the close of Sunday evening, which, even by the rebel accounts, could hardly have lasted an hour and a half, did not leave even the portion of our troops actually engaged, in a condition to need rallying. Much less could that skirmish have affected the spirit or the nerve of SHERMAN's main force.

abstract: Singer Divorce Case,Renewed in Court
snippet: Singer Divorce Case,Renewed in Court
lead_paragraph: Isaac M. Singer vs. Catharine M. Singer. -- The plaintiff in this action is the well-known manufacturer of sewing-machines. In the month of January, 1860, he obtained a divorce from his wife Catharine, on the ground of adultery. The proofs which were produced at that time, as to the wife's being guilty of the crime charged upon her, were of so positive and direct a character that it left no alternative for the court but to grant a decree of divorce, for the only course which, by the laws of this State, an absolute divorce can be obtained. The particulars of the case had some publicity at the time through the daily journals, but the circumstances had nearly passed from mind, until a few weeks ago, when Mrs. Singer, through her counsel, made a motion upon several affidavits to have the judgment opened, and that she be let in to defend.

abstract: Richmond Whig, Files and Material Captured at Scottsville; Population Redundant
snippet: Richmond Whig, Files and Material Captured at Scottsville; Population Redundant
lead_paragraph: Among the Richmond news, which we publish this morning, is the report of a project, under consideration in the Common Council of the city, for ridding it of its redundant population. It seems, from the statement of the Richmond Whig, that there are many non-combatants in the city, in the shape of women and children, and that they are merely consumers in the military estimate of values. The organ of the chivalry, indeed, puts it impressively, that they are "pitiless leeches," but at the same time commends "the delicate character of the effort for their removal." We presume that it is unnecessary to call in question the right of the Richmond Common Council to turn the whole non-combatant population out of doors, if it chooses. But those among us who have been worshipers of Southern -- and especially of Virginia -- chivalry for the best part of their lives, will be apt to feel somewhat perplexed over this crusade against a class, whose helplessness, in the crisis of war, even the savage seldom fails to respect. It is no business of ours; but we think Virginia chivalry is likely to come out of this rebellion considerably the worse to look at. Its airy plumage barely seems to bide the blast of war.

abstract: A coincidence of obstructions caused a very material slackening in the recruiting business yesterday. During Thursday the whole number of recruits obtained in the city was one hundred and twenty-one.
lead_paragraph: A coincidence of obstructions caused a very material slackening in the recruiting business yesterday. During Thursday the whole number of recruits obtained in the city was one hundred and twenty-one. Yesterday, however, the very last bounty at the Park office was paid, and the funds of the County Volunteer Committee gave out: Mr. BLUNT was gone to Albany to endeavor to arrange financial matters; the Ward or District committees are just setting their machinery in motion; and the recruits themselves, having a prudent eye to the state of the money market, and getting an impression that funds were short, did not appear. The number of recruits obtained was accordingly considerably smaller, the figures however act having been accessible in season for this morning's paper. Capt. WAGNER, of the Seventh District, obtained two recruits yesterday; Capt. KOSTER, of the Sixth, eleven. At a late hour last night Mr. BLUNT had not returned, and what he has accomplished at Albany we cannot say.

abstract: A NEW RIVER STEAMBOAT. -- Mr. S. ALLISON has nearly completed a passenger steamboat at his yard in Jersey City, for Mr. SAMUEL SCHUYLER, of Albany, which is intended to run on the North River. Her length is 196 feet keel, 30 feet beam and 9 feet deep. The engine, which is already completed, has a 44-inch cylinder and 9 feet stroke. She will be launched about the 1st of April, and will be completed by the 1st of June.

abstract: American Federation Scheme; Collapse of
snippet: American Federation Scheme; Collapse of
lead_paragraph: By the telegraphic report from Canada it will be seen that the Federation scheme, which was projected under such hopeful auspices nine months ago, has prematurely collapsed. The Government of Nova Scotia has formally, and in definite terms, announced its withdrawal from the compact. And, instead of uniting with Canada, the three maritime Provinces of New-Brunswick, Prince Edward's Island and Nova Scotia, are to form a separate legislative union of their own.

abstract: Our readers have undoubtedly noticed that Mr. GOTTSCHALK, our truly national pianist, contemplates visiting California, and subsequently the Sandwich Islands, Australia, India,  c. In artistic association with Mr. Muzio, Miss LUCY SIMONS and others.
lead_paragraph: Our readers have undoubtedly noticed that Mr. GOTTSCHALK, our truly national pianist, contemplates visiting California, and subsequently the Sandwich Islands, Australia, India, &c. In artistic association with Mr. MUZIO, Miss LUCY SIMONS and others, there can hardly be a doubt about the success of the enterprise. We are, nevertheless, sorry to lose Mr. GOTTSCHALK, and in fact receive but little satisfaction from the four hurried performances which he gives us next week -- commencing at Niblo's Saloon, on Monday. He should have afforded us at least a farewell series of artistic significance. It seems to us, too, that some recognition of his standing should be made by the public. Mr. GOTTSCHALK has worked long and conscientiously amongst his many friends, it will be a matter of no trouble to get up a grand complimentary testimonial concert. Every one will be glad to assist on the occasion, and Mr. GOTTSCHALK will be sent on his way rejoicing. There is yet time to move in the matter.

abstract: Gen. GRANT sends a little war news from Richmond papers of the 23d. They say there has been no fighting in North Carolina since Sunday, thereby intimating that SHERMAN had been effectually checked on that day. They cannot learn that he had attempted...
lead_paragraph: Gen. GRANT sends a little war news from Richmond papers of the 23d. They say there has been no fighting in North Carolina since Sunday, thereby intimating that SHERMAN had been effectually checked on that day. They cannot learn that he had attempted any advance since. HARDEE's victory on the 16th is considered very important by the rebel papers, an opinion that might possibly be of some weight had they not overdone it by representing the fight as most bloody, resulting in a loss of 3,300 Unionists to 450 Confederates -- a difference rather too strong for ordinary credulity. The fight is said to have taken place at Averysboro, a small village on Cape Fear River about midway between Fayetteville and Raleigh, and ten miles west of Bentonville, where another rebel victory (on the 19th,) is said to have been won. The dispatch before us says that SHERMAN is moving in two lines toward Raleigh, and these battles were with the respective columns.

abstract: His Military Administration
snippet: His Military Administration
lead_paragraph: It is not generally known, because it was not desirable until now that it should be known, that Gen. GRANT, as soon as it became necessary to prepare SHERMAN for his march through Carolina, stripped himself of a very large portion of his own troops, in order both to reinforce him and to strengthen the columns at Charleston, Wilmington, Newbern and elsewhere, which were to operate in combination with him, so that the lines at Petersburgh and on the James were occupied for the time by barely enough men to hold them. This, we admit, is a circumstance which now possesses no great military or political importance, but it deserves the attention of the public, as illustrating in a very marked manner the character of the man to whose hands it has been the rare good fortune of the nation to have had the management of its armies confided during the past year. We venture to repeat that there have been few instances in the history of war -- we can ourselves only think of one -- of such discrimination and perspicuity in the choice of subordinates as Gen. GRANT has displayed. He was no sooner placed in the chief command than he brought to the front and placed in high command, in the persons of such men as SHERMAN, SHERIDAN, THOMAS, MCPHERSON, an array of talent such as has been seldom seen in any army; and they have not been in any sense his creatures, the blind, devoted followers of his own fortunes, loving him better than the cause or the country, and ready to ruin either the one or the other to advance his private interests or their own. The public has been spared, under his administration, the pain of seeing the staff, field and corps and divisions led by henchmen of the General-in-Chief, converting the war into a Presidential campaign, and fighting without more thought of principle than highland gillies. Every man whom he has been instrumental in placing in a prominent position, has proved himself not simply an able, but a devoted, self-sacrificing, silent servant of the nation, obeying orders faithfully, holding his tongue diligently, and doing his duty without reference to the effect which his action was likely to have, either on his own interest or those of the people.

abstract: Press on Negro Arming, Bentonsville, >amp;c.; Arming in Richmond; Negroes from Hospitals Recruited
snippet: Press on Negro Arming, Bentonsville, >amp;c.; Arming in Richmond; Negroes from Hospitals Recruited
lead_paragraph: -- The rebel papers, from which we quoted in our yesterday's issue, made emphatic mention of the progress of negro recruiting in Richmond. And the Whig of that city gave new prominence to the fact, that the first company of Virginia negro troops would parade for drill on Wednesday last. It is something, doubtless, to the rebel organs to be able to boast of even one negro company having taken up arms for the enslavement of their kindred. But it takes some of the gilt off this gingerbread, to read, as we do, in the same sheet, that these colored recruits were all taken from the military hospitals, and were mustered into the Confederate army by the Medical Superintendent, who, of course, had the power to make his wishes law -- law which the boldest of these sable janisaries would hardly venture to dispute.

abstract: Thomas A. Parker vs. The Mayor, &c. -- The plaintiff brought the action to recover for services rendered as an officer of the Court of Common Pleas. The defendants claim that by a resolution of the Court of Common Pleas, the plaintiff was dismissed from service on the 1st of November, 1864, and that another officer named Harrington was appointed in his place, and that Harrington has since occupied the position and discharged the duties. Plaintiff claims that he was never legally discharged, and seeks to recover salary since the first of November last. One of the points made by defendant's counsel was, that even admitting the plaintiff had a good cause of action, he had brought his suit against the wrong parties; it should have been brought against the Board of Supervisors of the county, and not against the Mayor and Aldermen. The decision is reserved.
lead_paragraph: Thomas A. Parker vs. The Mayor, &c. -- The plaintiff brought the action to recover for services rendered as an officer of the Court of Common Pleas. abstract: At the opening of the Court yesterday morning, Assistant District Attorney Bedford moved for sentence on Roger Lamb, recently convicted of murder in the first degree. The Clerk then asked Lamb what he had to say why sentence of the law should not be passed upon him.
lead_paragraph: At the opening of the Court yesterday morning, Assistant District Attorney Bedford moved for sentence on Roger Lamb, recently convicted of murder in the first degree. The Clerk then asked Lamb what he had to say why sentence of the law should not be passed upon him. Mr. Abraham S. Cohen, for the prisoner, stated that after conversation with the unfortunate man, and consultation with his associate, Mr. Kentzing, he deemed it his duty to reiterate the statement made by Lamb to him, and of the truth of which he had no doubt, that Lamb killed his wife in a moment when half crazed with jealousy and frenzied with excitement, but he never intended the dreadful consequences of that blow. At this time and place Roger Lamb had nothing further to say why the sentence of the law should not be passed upon him.

abstract: NAVY-YARD AFFAIRS. -- Surgeon B. VREELAND has been ordered to the Kearsarge, new lying at the Charlestown Navy-yard, opposite Boston, where she is undergoing repairs, and is expected to be ready for service in about three weeks. Dr. VREELAND has been attached to the Naval Hospital in this city for the past nineteen months. He was one of the Surgeons who attended upon the unfortunate men who lost their lives in the U.S. steamer Chenango some time last Fall. Surgeon THOMAS W. LEACH has been ordered to the Naval Hospital in place of Dr. VREELAND. He was there before, and did his duty faithfully.

abstract: All the cotton captured by Gen. SHERMAN at Savannah is now on shipboard, and the larger part of it has already arrived here. It amounts to thirty-eight thousand and seventy-six bales -- thirty-two thousand and eighty-eight bales being Upland, and five thousand nine hundred and eighty-eight being Sea Island. The cotton is stored in the Government warehouses on Staten Island. Arrangements have been made for its sale, but the time at which it will be offered has not yet been announced.

abstract: Items
snippet: Items
lead_paragraph: -- One of the most interesting examples of bizarreire, lately deposited in the South Kensington Museum, is a Missal, the binding of which is formed of gold plates, decorated with rubles and translucent enamel: presumed to have been the property of HENRIETTA MARIA. On one side is represented, by little figures in alto-relief, the birth of Eve in Paradise, on the other what is supposed to show the Fountain of Immortal Life, with figures drinking from It. The work is of French origin, circa 1850, and cost the museum £700. Another example of similar character is a circular jewel, formed of gold with precious stones, and elaborately enameled; this is lent by Mr. GLADSTONE. There is also an eseigne mounted with gold, and bearing enameled figures of Venus and two Cupids; this specimen has three pendent jewels. In the case containing these articles, which is at present in the north court of the museum, west of the model of St. Peter's, Rome, will be found the elaborate rosary belonging to Col. Cumming; each bead of this work is made to open, and the hollow spaces within are literally fitted up with figures and accessories of enamel, jewels and gold.

abstract: Prospects of; Liberalism; The Prospects of
snippet: Prospects of; Liberalism; The Prospects of
lead_paragraph: The prospects of French Liberalism are not just now very brilliant. The courts have declared against the party of progress; from neither judges nor juries need it look for justice. The Emperor has declared against the party of progress; he will not tolerate "the exaggerated tendencies of those who provoke changes with the sole object of sapping what he has founded." But, still worse, the party of progress has declared against itself; for it has split into factions. The people can hardly be termed unreasonable, because they expected that the twenty or thirty advocates of freedom whom they had elected to the French Legislature would remain united in solid phalanx, in order the better to meet their opponents. This, however, has not been so. In the face of an overwhelming majority, almost in the very arena of conflict, and when the tug of war was about to cummence, the opponents of Imperialism have became divided. The blandishments of the courtiers were greater than some of them could resist.
headline: {'main': 'The Prospects of French Liberalism.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Prospects of French Liberalism.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We are informed that a few days ago, the remnant of the notorious cavalry regiment, once commanded by Col. JENKINS, and latterly by Col. KEARNS or "Corns." marched into Charleston. West Virginia, from Wytheville, and surrendered themselves, their horses, arms, and equipments to the Federal authorities. They numbered one hundred and twenty-six officers and men. Having given up all hope of success, and believing the rebellion "played out," they thought it useless longer to kick against the pricks, and decided to take refuge under he told flag. They say that the few rebels in arms; in the Kanawha Valley, are preparing to follow there example, and will do so whenever a fair opportunity presents itself, -- Cin. Commercial.

abstract: New-Yorkers are proverbially patient under petty oppressions and extortions. A railroad arrangement, however, which, while pretending to be a public accommodation, stampedes horses and almost dashes people's brains out, right and left, along the streets, can hardly be called a petty oppression. Feats of this kind have more than once been performed by the "dummy" engines of the Hudson River Railroad. Only a few days ago Dr. CARNOCHAN, the eminent surgeon, was riding in Tenth-avenue, when his horse took fright at the slow, heavy, rumbling mass of a "dummy," mysteriously rolling along the track toward him while at some distance, reared up, fell over, upset the carriage, threw out the Doctor, and, running away at a furious rate, smashed the vehicle all to pieces. Had Dr. CARNOCHAN, been caught in the cover of the carriage, he must almost certainly have been killed. As it was, he was, fortunately, flung clear of all entanglements, and, though somewhat bruised and jarred, has been able to attend to his regular business.
lead_paragraph: New-Yorkers are proverbially patient under petty oppressions and extortions. Feats of this kind have more than once been performed by the "dummy" engines of the Hudson River Railroad. Only a few days ago Dr. CARNOCHAN, the eminent surgeon, was riding in Tenth-avenue, when his horse took fright at the slow, heavy, rumbling mass of a "dummy," mysteriously rolling along the track toward him while at some distance, reared up, fell over, upset the carriage, threw out the Doctor, and, running away at a furious rate, smashed the vehicle all to pieces. Had Dr. CARNOCHAN, been caught in the cover of the carriage, he must almost certainly have been killed. As it was, he was, fortunately, flung clear of all entanglements, and, though somewhat bruised and jarred, has been able to attend to his regular business.

abstract: Policy of Falling back
snippet: Policy of Falling back
lead_paragraph: When the rebels were driven from Wilmington, Charleston, and the last of their seaport cities a few weeks ago, we were told by their organs in Richmond and New-York that the retirement was voluntary, and was part of a great policy of falling back which had been previously resolved upon in the secret councils of JEFF. DAVIS and Gen. LEE. This fearful and wonderful policy, it seemed, consisted in evacuating all the cities and centres of population, giving up all the strategical positions, retreating from all the military lines, from the mountain strongholds, the rivers, the seaboard and the railroads, and, after having done all this, taking up a position defiantly somewhere among the swamps, and forests, and deserts of the interior. It was a terrible policy, indeed -- not for us, but for them; though there were people here, who were disturbed by it; and we are amused by its repetition, even to this hour, as it now comes over to us gravely set forth in the London Times.

lead_paragraph: The Washington Star states that B.A. OSBON, the newspaper correspondent who was arrested upon the charge of furnishing for publication contraband information relative to the expedition against Fort Fisher, before the fleet had sailed, has recovered from his sickness, and is still confined in the Old Capitol. It is believed that OSBON will have a trial before one of the military commissions now in session in Washington; which trial will be a short one, however, as it is understood that he admits having furnished the information for publication, but declines to tell from whom he Obtained it.

abstract: Montholon, M, French Minister to United States, Biography
snippet: Montholon, M, French Minister to United States, Biography
lead_paragraph: Our last foreign intelligence announces the appointment of M. DE MONTHOLON represent the Court of Paris in this country, in the place of M. MERCIER, who was appointed July 4, 1860, but has been for some time absent. The Marquis DE MONTHOLON is the son of CHARLES TRISTAN DE MONTHOLON, Count of Lee, who died in 1853. The father was one of the most intimate and trusted of all the Emperor LOUIS NAPOLEON's friends, as he had been of NAPOLEON's. He was a Chamberlain and Brigadier-General to the latter; sought to accompany him to Elba; fought with him in the hundred days, accompanied him to St. Helena, and there witnessed his death. On his return to France he published his Memoires pour servir a l'Histoire de France sous Napoleon, ecrits a Sle. Helene sous sa dictee, in eight octavo volumes. True always to the idees Napoleonees, he accompanied LOUIS NAPOLEON in his attempt at Boulogne, in 1840, and for a short time shared his imprisonment at Ham. He was a member of the Legislative Assembly, in 1849, and witnessed the investment of LOUIS NAPOLEON with the purple. We recall these facts concerning the father of the new French Minister to show that he is likely to be a man of some weight with the Emperor, and that whatever personal abilities he may have, he is possessed of strong personal claims on a man who never overlooks such indebtedness. The new Minister, the son of the Count, and himself a Marquis, was Consul-General at New-York, in 1860, and married a Virginia lady. He has, consequently, a better knowledge of our affairs than most who might have been selected. That encouragement which the rebels took to themselves while France was not represented at Washington will now be dispelled. -- Philadelphia North American.

abstract: how Affected by Peace; for Peace, Lincoln not, Democratic Journals say
snippet: how Affected by Peace; for Peace, Lincoln not, Democratic Journals say
lead_paragraph: The chances are that the last newspaper apologist for the rebellion will be published in New-York, and that it will issue from the office of the confidential organ of the Peace Democracy. It is almost incredible that a journalist, making any pretension to loyalty, should have the hardihood at this hour to declare that the rebellion is in existence to-day, not because JEFFERSON DAVIS controls an armed conspiracy, but because the President of the United States refuses to listen to overtures of peace. Yet, such was the conclusion of the leading Democratic journal of this city, in a review of DAVIS' recent message -- a conclusion, moreover, which is reached by the direct path of reckless and defiant assertion.

abstract: -The rebel Congress, in their recent address, argue strenuously that their people can never be conquered, for this reason among others, that as they say, "our people are preeminently of a proud and haughty spirit." We have no desire to contest the fact which they set forth, but it is plain that if they had not been a little weak in the scriptures, they would have seen that the argument was the other way, for "Pride goeth before destruction, and a haughty spirit before a fall."
lead_paragraph: -The rebel Congress, in their recent address, argue strenuously that their people can never be conquered, for this reason among others, that as they say, "our people are preeminently of a proud and haughty spirit." abstract: Newspapers, and bundles of them sent from the city offices by wagon to the railroad stations and to towns in the vicinity, are constantly stolen, and the loss charged by the local subscribers and newsagents to faults at the newspaper offices. But some of them at least are caused by thieving boys. Mr. T. MOUNTFIELD, who takes papers by wagon hence to Newark, lost during the past week thirteen dollars worth of papers, stolen from him. Yesterday be concealed a man in his wagon, who caught two boys, named ANTONIO DURDARO and JESSIE LOGINMASSEN, in the very act of theft. It seems that such young pe[???]s as these are very safe, since their parents can commonly beg them off at the police court, or they are at most "sent up" for a day or two; and their lawyer, moreover, torments the complainant with adjournments and vain attendances, so that a severe penalty is inflicted for seeking to punish rogues. Boys of this sort, and larger ones who tempt, direct, assist and use them, sleep about Printing-house-equare and that neighborhood, in door-ways and corners; are professedly boot-blacks, errand boys, or the like; can, if they steal a hundred papers, and then sell them at four cents each, gain $4, a day, which they spend in eating, drinking, and going to theatre. This particular nuisance of newspaper stealing could easily be abated. Let these street boys be rigidly driven away from the nests they abuse, both by the police and by those who occupy the buildings. If they cannot stay there they cannot steal there.

abstract: Cold, dry, windy March and April days are thvilest of city weather. Then the obscene reliqual of pavement and gutter, dried and pulverulent, are blown into the clothes, the hair, the ears, the eyes, the nostrils for it must be a very dirty person who opens his mouth to such a simoon. The insufferable sense of filth which a clean person feels at this contamination is quite beyond expression in words.
lead_paragraph: Cold, dry, windy March and April days are the vilest of city weather. Then the obscene reliqual of pavement and gutter, dried and pulverulent, are blown into the clothes, the hair, the ears, the eyes, the nostrils -- for it must be a very dirty person who opens his mouth to such a simoon. The insufferable sense of filth which a clean person feels at this contamination is quite beyond expression in words. The [???]limy, buttery city mud is cleanliness itself compared with this wind-borne nastiness. Who wants his bronchial tubes clogged with pulverized stable manure? Who would receive into his lungs and aerate his very blood with the dried essence of gutter slops and boarding-house swill? But that is street dirt. We say nothing of the really great injuries to all kinds of [???]oods expected for sale, in consequence of this dust nuisance. The moral of all which is, water the streets! Water the streets!

abstract: The United States vs. Paoli Silliek and Four Others. -- This is an application on the part of the master of the Austrian brig Zalanie, for the return of live seamen claimed as deserters from the vessel. The seamen claim that they shipped for a voyage to Malta, but were brought to this country; that they were ill-treated on the voyage, and kept on short rations; that they had not been paid for eight months; and that on the arrival of the brig at this port they left the vessel in broad daylight, taking their chests and clothing with them, and bidding the captain farewell. It was contended that, as they left with the knowledge of the master, and as he made no opposition to it, their departure was with his consent, and was tantamount to a discharge. The Commissioner remanded them until Tuesday, when he will render a decision.
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. Paoli Silliek and Four Others. -- This is an application on the part of the master of the Austrian brig Zalanie, for the return of live seamen claimed as deserters from the vessel. The seamen claim that they shipped for a voyage to Malta, but were brought to this country; that they were ill-treated on the voyage, and kept on short rations; that they had not been paid for eight months; and that on the arrival of the brig at this port they left the vessel in broad daylight, taking their chests and clothing with them, and bidding the captain farewell. It was contended that, as they left with the knowledge of the master, and as he made no opposition to it, their departure was with his consent, and was tantamount to a discharge. The Commissioner remanded them until Tuesday, when he will render a decision.

abstract: Manhattan, American and Mexican Steamship Company, Launch
snippet: Manhattan, American and Mexican Steamship Company, Launch
lead_paragraph: LAUNCH OF THE STEAMSHIP MANHATTAN. -- The steamship Manhattan, (side-wheel,) built for the American and Mexican Steamship Company, by LAWRENCE & FOULES, was launched from the yard of her builders, foot of North Fifth-street, E.D., at 8:30 A.M. yesterday, (Saturday.) The Manhattan is fitted up expressly for passengers, and is intended to run between New-York and Vera Cruz. Her dimensions are: Length of keel, 240 feet; breadth of beam, 37 feet; depth of hold, 25 feet; burden, 2,000 tons. She was towed to the Morgan Iron Works, New-York, to receive her engines, which are 65 feet cylinder and 11 feet stroke. The same builders will soon launch two steamers for HERMAN T. LIVINGSTON & CO., which are intended for coastwise trade. Their dimensions are: Length of keel, 175 feet; breadth of beam, 36 feet; depth of hold, 19 feet; burden, 1,200 tons.

abstract: This regiment, the first colored regiment raised in this city under the auspices of the Union League Club, is now stationed in the vicinity of New-Orleans, and performing important duty. It has recently been on service in Mississippi, and also at Mobile Bay. The friends of the regiment in this city and State will be glad to learn that it is in splendid shape. Its able commanding officer, Col. N.B. BARTRAM, is highly appreciated by his superior officers, and the regiment is often selected for very important and delicate duty. Capt. JNO. E. BARNABY, of the regiment, arrived here a day or two since, having in custody the rebel Brig.-Gen. BANKHEAD, captured a short time since at Rodney, Miss.

abstract: Stonewall, Description of the
snippet: Stonewall, Description of the
lead_paragraph: The correspondent of the Army and Navy Journal, dated Paris, March 2, says: The Stonewall, late Olinde, is still in a Spanish harbor, undergoing repairs. Two Federal frigates, the Sacramento and the Niagara, are lying off the port, waiting for the Confederate to run out. It is not probable that the Stonewall will move just at present, as her Captain is still in Paris, waiting for final instructions. Capt. PAGE is of opinion that his vessel would prove more than a match for either of the powerful frigates told off to watch him. The Niagara only carries 12 guns, but her metal is heavier than that of any other vessel of her class. The Stonewall, amongst other guns, has a 300-pounder, and, besides this, she is protected by 5 1/2 inches of iron. Should a battle take place, some light will be thrown on the intrinsic merits of American and French frigates, and the relative value of wood and iron. The United States Consul tried hard to get the Stonewall seized by the Spanish Government, on the plea that she had escaped from a French harbor, and that three French war steamers had been sent in pursuit of her. A telegram from Paris soon satisfied the Cabinet of Madrid that the Consul had been fabricating. The question of who sold the Olinde to the Confederates is still shrouded in mystery. All the damage she may do will have to be paid for by some one.

abstract: Money having run short again, recruiting on the city quota fell low yesterday, only about a hundred men being obtained in all. On Friday a hundred and thirty-four were enlisted. Supervisor BLUNT did not succeed on his trip to Albany in obtaining any part of the State bounty loan, but...
lead_paragraph: Money having run short again, recruiting on the city quota fell low yesterday, only about a hundred men being obtained in all. On Friday a hundred and thirty-four were enlisted. Supervisor BLUNT did not succeed on his trip to Albany in obtaining any part of the State bounty loan, but will doubtless do so Monday or Tuesday, when recruiting should proceed rapidly, for no one doubts that the men will be forthcoming when the money is at hand. Meanwhile, however, money is at hand for substitutes; and persons intending to furnish that class of solders may therefore bring them on as fast as they like.

abstract: The authorities of Jersey City are in tribula- tion. At the time when Col. BAKER had his model recruiting-office open in Hobokes, Mayor CLEVELAND, imagining that therein he perceived an opportunity to fill the quota of Jersey City, suffered himself to be approached by the keen-scented boun- ly brokers, and the result was that an arrangement was made whereby the Hoboken enlistments were to be turned over to Jersey City.
lead_paragraph: The authorities of Jersey City are in tribulation. At the time when Col. BAKER had his model recruiting-office open in Hobokes, Mayor CLEVELAND, imagining that therein he perceived an opportunity to fill the quota of Jersey City, suffered himself to be approached by the keen-scented boun- ly brokers, and the result was that an arrangement was made whereby the Hoboken enlistments were to be turned over to Jersey City. How many men were thus secured to that city, only the brokers and the city authorities know; but it has leaked out that Mayor CLEVELAND paid the brokers $126,000 for 168 men who were trapped by Col. BAKER, and sent to Fort Lafayette, and that these men, being deserters, cannot be credited to Jersey City, but are claimed by the General Government, and are to be held as as the army's men, for whom credit can be given nobody.

lead_paragraph: LANDLORD UNDER ARREST. -- WILLIAM BOLTE, keeper of a public house at No. 45 Whitehall-street, and HENRY SHOLE, one of his boarders, were apprehended yesterday by policeman OBER, of the First Ward, and Mr. JOHN MURPHY, of No. 59 Greenwich-street, appeared before Justice HOGAN and accused them of stealing a $500 Treasury note. On the evening of the 20th inst., MURPHY was pasting the bill in BOLTE's bar-room, it having been wet and torn, and as he momentarily turned aside, some person snatched it. On the following morning BOLTE, saying that SHOLE had found and exchanged the bill and spent $100 of the money, offered MURPHY $400, and that sum was accepted. Justice HOGAN held the prisoners to bail in $1,000 each.

abstract: Effect on Trade; Proud and Haugh???y Southern People
snippet: Effect on Trade; Proud and Haugh???y Southern People
lead_paragraph: It is related that after the War of 1812, our people, suddenly finding their raw products immensely raised in value, and the imported luxuries, which had been shut out by the blockade, greatly cheapened were like persons at once raised from poverty to affluence. The income of great numbers of the producing classes was, in a day, as it were, trebled or quadrupled. People who had been poor, found themselves suddenly rich. The consequence was, for a time, an unbounded extravagance. Silks, wines, liquors, rich furniture, and other imported luxuries, were bought at a most profuse rate. Having been shut out from indulgences so long, the whole population, who had any meant to purchase, poured forth their means to gratify taste or appetite in a lavish manner, scarcely considering expense, though there hardly existed a currency worthy of the name, south of New-England.
headline: {'main': 'Effect of Peace on Trade.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Effect of Peace on Trade.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: There are now three ordinances before the Common Council, regulating the storage of petroleum and other inflammable oils within the city limits. One was prepared by the Committee on Ordinances, after gathering all the information they were able from the trade and other parties interested in the matter. Another was prepared by Alderman JEREMIAH, who thought that the provision in the first ordinance, compelling dealers to store the oil in cellars communicating with the public sewers was injudicious, as the burning oil running through the sewers would throw off an inflammable gas which might set fire to the buildings above. Alderman JEREMIAH's ordinance is also less restrictive in its character than that prepared by the Committee on Ordinances. A third ordinance has just been presented by Alderman FARLEY, limiting the quantity of crude oil in store to five barrels, of forty-five gallons each, and of refined to fifty-five barrels, except in warehouses standing clear of all other buildings. In which, under certain conditions, any quantity may be kept. It is probable that any one of these ordinances would answer the purpose sought. They would certainly have the effect of compelling the removal from the city limits of a very large quantity of inflammable oils; but the Common Council, after a little spasmodic action, appears to be going to sleep over the matter, and, in the meantime, an element of danger remains in our midst which may, in a few hours lay a large portion of the city in ashes.

abstract: BURNED TO DEATH. At about 6 o'clock yesterday morning, fire was discovered in PATRICK CARR'S room, on the third floor of Mrs. CATHARINE KEARNES' boarding-house, at No. 13 Monroe-street, and the servant who made the discovery, on bursting in the door, found CARR'S body on the floor, horribly disfigured from burning.
lead_paragraph: BURNED TO DEATH. -- At about 6 o'clock yesterday morning, fire was discovered in PATRICK CARR's room, on the third floor of Mrs. CATHARINE KEARNES' boarding-house, at No. 13 Monroe-street, and the servant who made the discovery, on bursting in the door, found CARR's body on the floor, horribly disfigured from burning. The bedding and furniture were consumed; but little injury, however, was done beyond this. It appears that CARR went home, on Saturday evening, smoking a cigar and somewhat under the influence of liquor, and it is presumed that his bed must have been set on fire by his cigar. He was a seaman, twenty-one years of age. An inquest was held, yesterday, by Coroner GAMBLE.

abstract: Thackeray's Vanity Fair; New Edition
snippet: Thackeray's Vanity Fair; New Edition
lead_paragraph: The HARPERS have just issued an edition of Vanity Fair, which we trust is the precursor of a complete library edition of the works of this greatest master of English fiction of the present age. It is a most elegant edition, -- upon fine paper, in clear, tasteful type, reproducing all the illustrations of the original edition, and in every respect among the most beautiful issues of the American press. THACKERAY's reputation with his cotemporaries has not been equal to that of some of his rivals, -- but we are confident his writings will be more highly valued in coming years than those of any novelist of the present day. In his analysis of character, his knowledge of human nature and society, and in the graphic and remorseless truthfulness with which he has delineated the marked features of both, he is without a rival. His style is the perfection of the language. His works will constitute as permanent a part of the treasures of English literature as those of ADDISON, FIELDING or any of the great masters of the past, and no better service could possibly be rendered to the reading public than a complete edition of his works, in the superb style of these three volumes, just issued and containing Vanity Fair. We trust the others will follow in quick succession.

abstract: Tony Butler; Fullerton, Lady; Too Strange Not to be True
snippet: Tony Butler; Fullerton, Lady; Too Strange Not to be True
lead_paragraph: Lady FULLERTON is well known as one of the most accomplished women of the day. Her works of fiction have not been numerous, but they live individually in the minds of all who have read them, and to that large class of the community her name is a sufficient recommendation of any new book. She is one of the very limited number of persons of English birth who have been successful authors in a foreign language. Her Comtesse Bonneval Histoire du Temps de Louis XIV., is received as a classic book in France, like BECKFORD's Vathek, and Lord MAHON's Histoire du Grand Conde. Her familiarity with the literature of continental Europe has probably guided her choice of a story, for the present work. Too Strange Not to be True, is founded on a tradition currentduring the last century, and recorded in M. BOSSU's Travels in Louisiana. It relates to the mysterious fate of a royal personage, reminding one of the more recent momentary excitement that followed the question, "Have we a Bourbon among us?" The older story was based on the startling events that occurredin the dynasty of PETER the Great, of Russia. His eldest son ALEXIS, who afterward fell a victim to his father's severity, married a daughter of the house or Brunswick, the Princess CHARLOTTE SOPHIA, of Brunswick-Wolfenbuttel. The plea of insanity offers the best excuse, for the wayward conduct of the heir to the throne of all the Russias. Among other acts of brutality, repeated attempts to rid himself of his unhappy bride by violence or poison were notorious, and at last it was asserted that she died from the consequences of a ferocious assault in one of his paroxysms of temporary frenzy. According to the romantic version or her fate, however, the death of the Princess was a feigned one, and she was rescued from the lot that seemed to await her by some attached adherents, and after many, adventures succeeded in reaching the French Territory of Louisiana. Here she resided in peace many years, having married the Chevaller D'AUBAN, an officer who held a position in the Colonial Government. She finally returned to Europe on account of his health, and is reported to have died a widow, at an advanced age, after a lengthened residence at Brussels. It is in the New World, among the virgin forests, the floral splendors and atmospheric radiance of the tropics, that Lady FULLERTON introduces her heroins. Her former career is related to her husband, who has recognized the scion of royalty under a humbler garb. It will readily be seen with what facility a story of the kind adapts itselfto the purposes of the novelist. The authoress is one of the recent converts to Catholicism, who had left Protestantism for a more imaginative faith. Accordingly the labors and sufferings of those saintlikemen, the Jesuit missionaries, and their self-denying career among the Indian tribes, meet with their due share of notice. The course of the narrative, whether in Europe or America, is marked by a vraisemblance and fidelity to nature that show that Lady FULERTON writes like a true literary artist. Her aim is always good, and it is skillfully wrought out, with no extravagance of thought or language, but in a stylve remarkable for its purity and simplicity. Too Strange Not To Be True is destined to be widely read.

abstract: on the Offensive
snippet: on the Offensive
lead_paragraph: The rebel General-in-Chief seems to have been seriously deceived as to the scope and bent of certain movements ordered early last week by Gen. GRANT, on the left of our lines. These movements were made the subject of comment in the Richmond papers on Wednesday; and the Whig of that date, while doubtful whether Gen. GRANT's apparent activity was not intended to deceive, pointed out at the same time the probability of his taking advantage of the weather to advance. LEE seems to have attached some weight to the latter conjecture, when he ordered an attack by three divisions upon Fort Steadman before daylight on Saturday morning. The attack, in the first instance, was made with a suddenness and a dash which made it a temporary success. Striking a portion of our lines held by the Third Brigade, First Division of the Ninth Corps, the rebels wheeled, and made an overpowering attack upon Fort Steadman, of which they soon got possession. Having made good their position on the hill adjoining the fort, they turned our guns upon our men, and gaining confidence by the turn fortune had given them, they made a subsequent dash upon Fort Haskill. But here their luck, and probably their spirits, forsook them. Portions of WILCOX's and HARTSUFF's divisions bravely opposed a further rebel advance; and, after one or two attempts by our troops to retake this Fort Steadman, which were only partially successful, the gallant men of the Second Brigade, with the troops of the First Division on either flank, came to the rescue, for a determined and final assault, and finally regained possession, three thousand rebels having fallen in the terrible struggle, and twenty-seven hundred surrendering themselves prisoners.

snippet: Crain, Hon Eli C, Herkimer, N Y.
lead_paragraph: News from Venezuela, dated at Caraccas on the 24th of February, represents the country as in the most wretched state of anarchy. Most of the provinces were isolated from the capital, all mail communication being destroyed by the warring factions. Only two of the legations of the republic -- one in Paris and the other in Lima, Peru -- were in existence. El Federalista, the organ of the Falcon Government, says: "In Apure they are shedding blood, nobody knows why. In Trujilio, called the sovereign State of the Andes, many believe that independence is disorder, murder, arson, &c. In Maracaibo they conceived the idea of an independent republic, and new Secretaries of War and Treasury were appointed, and the Eastern States live without prosperity, and debility ruins them."

abstract: Emancipation in Brazil has, to a certain extent, been a practical matter for a number of years, by the mild laws regarding the manumitting of slaves. But there has arisen a new phase of the subject, and efforts were made last year in the Brazilian Senate for more summarily dealing with slavery. This year there is a determination to bring up the question in the Chamber of Deputies -- the popular branch of the Brazilian Parliament. A number of leading Brazilian gentlemen -- some of them officials -- have desired Rev. J.C. FLETCHER, whose name is known in connection with Brazil, to collect and send to them documents, pamphlets, statistics and works in general bearing on slavery, emancipation, &c. Mr. FLETCHER has already appealed through the New-York press, but informs us that, while he has received some few important contributions, New-York has not responded as the City of Boston has done. Our war has had an immense influence in shaking the slave fabric in every country, and now while the Brazilians, with their enlightened Emperor, are resolved to deal with the subject, let us not be backward in responding to the appeal for information on this subject. A capital opportunity occurs to send these works by the first naturalist of the age, Prof. AGASSIZ, who, while he goes to explore Brazil as a savant, is warm in his sympathies for his fellow man. Anything sent in before noon on Wednesday next, to J.O. WOOD, Esq., at WHEELER & WILSON's, No. 625 Broadway, will be in time.

abstract: BROOKLYN CITY MORTALITY. -- The total number of deaths last week was 136, of which 19 were men, 32 women, 50 boys and 35 girls. The principal diseases were, consumption 20, convulsions 15, dropsy 9, inflammation of lungs, and scarlet fever, 8 each; disease of heart 7, croup, and inflamation of brain, 7 each; diptheria, marasmus, small-pox and apoplexy 4 each; congestion of lungs, tuberculosis, debility and inflammation of bowels, 3 each; typhoid fever, convulsions, accidental injuries and bronchitis, 2 each; remittent fever 1, &c. Under one year of age 30. Natives of United States 101, Ireland 19, Germany 10, England 5, Scotland 1.

abstract: THE QUOTA OF JERSEY CITY. -- The citizens of Jersey City are somewhat, mystified in the matter of the quota as it now stands. Mayor CLEVELAND and the Enlistment Committee claim to have secured 292 men on the quota of the 543 men up to Tuesday last since which time sixteen more men have been obtained. Of the above number 168 men were put through at the Hoboken office, for which $126,000 was paid, and these men are among the the crew of alleged bounty-jumpers secured by Col. BAKER, and at present confined at Fort Lafayette. It is not yet definitely known whether these men will be credited to the quota of Jersey City or not, but it is generally believed that they will not be allowed. On Saturday last. It was officially announced that the deficiencies in the several wards of Jersey City were as follows: First Ward, 37; Second Ward, 86; Third Ward, 43; Fourth Ward, 85; Fifth Ward, 144; Sixth Ward. 49. Total, 444. Provost-Marshal MILLS announces that the examination of the drafted men of Jersey City will commence with the First Ward on the 4th of April, and, if held to service, ten days therefrom will be granted them to furnish substitutes. If the quota is filled by April 14, the drafted men who report will be exempted, and, in like manner, all the other wards.

abstract: DEADLY ASSAULT WITH A SLUNG-SHOT. -- Late on Saturday night, as Mr. PATRICK FRIER, who keeps a clothing store at No. 155 Second-street, E.D., was putting up his shutters, a man named PATRICK ORMOND approached him, and with a deadly weapon believed to be a slung-shot, so belabored him over the head that he was taken up-stairs in an almost insensible condition, where he still lies in a precarious state. It appears that the injured man some time since had some difficulty with a brother of the assailant, and it is supposed that this inhuman assault grew out of it. ORMOND was promptly arrested by Officer TRAVIS, of the Forty-eighth Precinct, and he will be taken before Justice DAILY this morning.

abstract: Before daylight last Saturday morning, three divisions of the enemy made a sudden and determined attack on Fort Steadman, in front of Petersburgh, overpowering the garrison and capturing the fort, where they temporarily established themselves, and turned the guns upon our lines. Our troops on either flank maintained their ground. A determined attack on Fort Haskell was gallantly repulsed with great loss to the enemy.
lead_paragraph: Before daylight last Saturday morning, three divisions of the enemy made a sudden and determined attack on Fort Steadman, in front of Petersburgh, overpowering the garrison and capturing the fort, where they temporarily established themselves, and turned the guns upon our lines. Our troops on either flank maintained their ground. A determined attack on Fort Haskell was gallantly repulsed with great loss to the enemy. After several attempts to retake the hill, a charge was made by the Second Brigade, aided by the troops of the Third Division on either flank, and the rebels were driven out of the fort, with the loss of about 2,700 prisoners, and the whole line was reoccupied, with the guns uninjured. The slaughter of the enemy at the point where they entered our lines, and in front of it, is estimated by Gen. GRANT at not less than 3,000. Our own loss is estimated at 800, and may prove to be less.

lead_paragraph: In the United States Supreme Court, on Saturday, Gen. DIX made a return to the writ of habeas corpus, issued by Judge BETTS, in the case of W.L. BICKLEY. The return states that BICKLEY was committed to Fort Lafayette as a State prisoner, and not as a prisoner of war; and that before the service of the Judge's order, BICKLEY had been transferred to Fort Warren, by order of the Secretary of War, and consequently was not within the jurisdiction of the court.

lead_paragraph: We print this morning from our owns correspondents a very full account of the daring rebel attack upon the Ninth Corps of the Army of the Potomac on Saturday morning, accompanied by further official dispatches from Gen. GRANT. The main features of the battle have already been given in our columns. Early in the morning four divisions of rebels made a rush upon Fort Steadman, and took it after several smart repulses. Gen. WILCOX soon brought up his men, and a desperate contest followed, which resulted in the recapture of the fort. The enemy also took a battery close by, but it was quickly retaken. This is about the substance of the affair. Our losses are officially reported thus:

abstract: The long anticipated and carefully prepared rebel movement, which was to "astonish the world," took place to-day, and I have no doubt, did astonish that part of the world within the limited precincts of rebeldom. A few more such rsuprises will, one would think, be sufficient to bring the leaders of secession to their senses, and convince them of the hopelessness of their struggle to divide and ruin our common country.

abstract: Troops; Review in Richmond; Colored Brigade; The
snippet: Troops; Review in Richmond; Colored Brigade; The
lead_paragraph: The grand spectacle of reviewing the first companies of negro troops formed in Richmond came off, as was anticipated, on Wednesday. It was witnessed, we are told, by a crowd of jubilant citizens, eight or ten thousand strong. Two Surgeons from the hospitals where the negroes were recruited were in command. And the Examiner records, with pardonable emotions of pride, that Surgeon "TURNER's company attracted most attention. They were about twenty strong, and appeared in the square in charge of a sergeant." Furthermore, "they appeared to appreciate their position." They do not seem to have been exactly what might be called picked men. There was, in fact, rather a fine variety of stature, style and coloring observable in the ranks of TURNER's company. "They exhibited," says the Examiner, "all sizes, from three feet to six feet six, while the complexion ranged from black down to ginger-bread and olive," The parade exercises, we have no doubt, were worthy of the occasion, for we find that the enthusiasm of the Richmond populace was altogether unbounded. This colored armament is doubtless one of the surprises in store for SHERMAN -- if he should venture into Virginia.

abstract: The number of deaths reported in this city for the week ending yesterday, was 468 -- 108 men, 108 women, 127 boys and 125 girls an increase of 15 as compared with the previous week, and a decrease of 17 as compared with the corresponding week of last year. The mortality by the principal diseases was as follows: Consumption 93, marasmus 29, convulsions 32, croup 18, diphtheria 13, bronchitis 10, scarlet fever 11, typhus fever 16, inflammation of the lungs 36, small pox 20. The deaths by the last-named disease appear to be steadily decreasing in number. For several weeks past they have averaged 30 per week.

lead_paragraph: The public are aware that the names of Messrs. ALLISON and DCDONALD have been freely coupled with that of the incendiary KENNEDY, in connection with the attempt to burn the city. Mr. ALLISON took the oath of allegiance last week, and is still in the city. Yesterday morning, in compliance with an order from Gen. DIX, Superintendent KENNEDY sent Mr. B.A. MCDONALD to the headquarters where he was at once given his untrammeled freedom. abstract: Seven-Thirty Loan all taken up
snippet: Seven-Thirty Loan all taken up
lead_paragraph: It is a fitting corollary to the victories of the past week that we should be able to report to-day that the whole of the first issue of the seven-thirty loan has been taken up by the people. Herein have we new and solid pledges of the faith of our citizens in the stability and permanence of the National Government. Herein, likewise, have we additional and binding sureties that the interest of the public debt will be regularly met, and faith kept with the public creditors. The investments of the people in this issue within six weeks have reached the enormous sum of one hundred and sixty-one millions -- a fact unprecedented in the history of popular loans.

abstract: and Sherman; Latest Reported Movements; and Grant, latest Movements
snippet: and Sherman; Latest Reported Movements; and Grant, latest Movements
lead_paragraph: The official reports from GRANT and SHERMAN to-day do not essentially change the military aspect either in Virginia or North Carolina. But these reports show that both Generals have had more work on hand than the earlier dispatches made apparent. The battle of Saturday in front of Petersburgh which was supposed to have ended with the terrible assault which regained Fort Steadman for our troops, was renewed at a later hour of the day by a splendid attack of the Sixth Corps on the left of the enemy's line in front of Fort Fisher. The entire line of rebel rifle pits at this point was shortly in possession of our forces, and four hundred and sixty-nine of LEE's men, probably nothing loath, surrendered themselves prisoners. The Second Corps was ordered to make a subsequent attack still further to the left, near Hatcher's Run, and here the ground which our troops speedily gained by their dash and bravery, was hotly but vainly disputed by the rebels under GORDON, until darkness put an end to the struggle. All the ground gained by the Sixth and Second Corps remains in our possession.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, complied from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Mobs not the American Democracy; Territorial Democracy of the United States
snippet: Mobs not the American Democracy; Territorial Democracy of the United States
lead_paragraph: The recent debate in the English House of Commons on the probability of an attack on Canada by the United States, after the close of the struggle with the South, reveals the fact that English statesmen have at last found out that the real power of government in this country lies in the agricultural population. Four years ago it was impossible to persuade them that the "New-York mob" did not exercise a controlling influence on our policy both at home and abroad. In fact during the years 1861-2, hardly a speech was made, or an article written in England on American affairs, in which this was not spoken of as something as well known and recognized as any provision of the Constitution. One might fairly have inferred from much of what one heard and read, that Mr. LINCOLN and Mr. SEWARD were in telegraphic communication, night and day, with our ward politicians, and that no State paper of importance was ever written at Washington without taking the advice of the leading grogshop-keepers and shoulder-hitters of this city. People who disputed or denied this, as Mr. BRIGHT did on one occasion in the House, were received with "laughter, and cries of 'Oh! oh!'"

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. -- The theatrical tendency of the present day is toward effect, action; and a rapid succession of brilliant scenes and costumes are accepted as accomplishing all that the manager requires. The literary merit of a piece is now of little consequence. It is indeed the last thing thought of. If the work will play itself -- that is to say supply a pantomime which, in its quickness, is intelligible without the aid of language, then it may be safely inferred that it possesses the elements of popularity. Such is certainly the case with the new drama of "Corporal Cartouche," produced at this house on Saturday evening. The story tells itself, and is not in any way assisted by the very ordinary dialogue with which it is occasionally padded. Indeed it is a striking illustration of the truth of our remarks that the Corporal himself is most interesting when he is dumb, and only becomes tedious in the last act, where the gilt of speech is restored to him. The drama has the usual pedigree. It is derived from the French, and, has been adapted by "a gentleman of this city,' Mr. S.R. FISK, who somewhat coolly claims the whole merit of the affair. The matter is of no importance to the public. It is enough that a very excellent and spirited drama has been produced in a singularly felicitous manner. With a little curtailment it will unquestionably become a great public favorite. The title role is played by Mr. HENRY PLACIDE. The whole interest of the play is centred on the grand figure of the faithful old soldier thus personated. It is to him that a dying General bequeaths a last trust -- to protect his daughter, and it is while trying to fulfill this, amid the wiles of rascals, that in a fit of passion he loses the power of speech. Being unable to read or write, he is thus reduced to the terrible necessity of witnessing the perpetration of great wrongs, without any power to prevent their execution. The incident is not probable, but it is eminently impressive. In its elaboration the action is kept close, and, as we have before remarked, the story tells itself. The opening scene is of a military character, but beyond this and the title, It is emphatically a domestic drama. Mr. HENRY PLACIDE belongs to the old school of loud-voiced comedians; and, according to the lights of that school, is a fine specimen of its best member s During three acts his business is confined to dumb show, which was as intelligible to us as that sort of thing is apt to be. We were occasionally surprised at the earnestness and feeling which he imparted in this embarrassing manner. In the first act, as the bluff Corporal he was excellent, and in the last scene, where he recovers his voice, he was powerful, although hurried. A pause of astonishment or joy would add materially to the effectiveness of the scene.

Indeed it is a striking illustration of the truth of our remarks that the Corporal himself is most interesting when he is dumb, and only becomes tedious in the last act, where the gilt of speech is restored to him. The drama has the usual pedigree. It is derived from the French, and, has been adapted by "a gentleman of this city,' Mr. S.R. FISK, who somewhat coolly claims the whole merit of the affair. The matter is of no importance to the public. It is enough that a very excellent and spirited drama has been produced in a singularly felicitous manner. With a little curtailment it will unquestionably become a great public favorite. The title role is played by Mr. HENRY PLACIDE. The whole interest of the play is centred on the grand figure of the faithful old soldier thus personated. It is to him that a dying General bequeaths a last trust -- to protect his daughter, and it is while trying to fulfill this, amid the wiles of rascals, that in a fit of passion he loses the power of speech. Being unable to read or write, he is thus reduced to the terrible necessity of witnessing the perpetration of great wrongs, without any power to prevent their execution. The incident is not probable, but it is eminently impressive. In its elaboration the action is kept close, and, as we have before remarked, the story tells itself. The opening scene is of a military character, but beyond this and the title, It is emphatically a domestic drama. Mr. HENRY PLACIDE belongs to the old school of loud-voiced comedians; and, according to the lights of that school, is a fine specimen of its best member s During three acts his business is confined to dumb show, which was as intelligible to us as that sort of thing is apt to be. We were occasionally surprised at the earnestness and feeling which he imparted in this embarrassing manner. In the first act, as the bluff Corporal he was excellent, and in the last scene, where he recovers his voice, he was powerful, although hurried. A pause of astonishment or joy would add materially to the effectiveness of the scene.

abstract: Col. BAKER, of the War Department Special Agency, is daily harrassed by friends of the volunteers who were recently taken at his model recruiting-machine in Hoboken, and he desires to say to all whom it may concern, that these persons, who are now held at Fort Lafayette, are sworn and regularly-mustered solders of the United Stales, and that he has no power whereby he could release one of their number, were [???] disposed to do so. The War Department alo[???] [???] release enlisted men. If, as many of the men's relatives allege, they are not bounty-jumpers and persons of disreputable character, that circumstance cannot operate for their dismissal, since they are not held for crime, but simply as recruits who have volunteered to serve in the army and taken the usual military oath. It may interest these volunteers' friends to know that they await the arrival of a Surgeon of the regular army, and that it is understood to be the Department's intention to send them into the field as regulars.

lead_paragraph: The bill introduced into the Legislature by Mr. REED, of New-York, for the appointment of "General Railroad Commissioners" to exercise supervision over the management of the railroads of the State, so as to secure some attention to the comfort and security of travelers, is hardly likely to get through this session. It will probably call forth some discussion, however, and may form the basis of a similar measure next year, and it is therefore worth while to direct attention to one or two of its defects.
