abstract: -- New-Orleans papers ofthe 12th publish the execution at Natchez, Miss., on the 4th March, by sentence of a general court-martial, approved by Gen. CANBY and Lieut.-Gen. GRANT, of ALEXANDER MCBRIDE and DAVID GEER, privates in the Twenty-eighth Regiment Illinois Infantry, convicted of the murder of Mr. GEORGE W. SARGENT, a citizen of Adams County, Miss., in May, 1864. The culprits were two out of a party of five who, in an attempted robbery by night of Mr. SARGENT'S dwelling, killed him under circumstances of peculiar barbarity. The deceased was between 60 and 70 years old, a gentleman of high standing, and esteemed and respected alike by the citizens of the county and the United States authorities, and unusual interest was taken in the detection and punishment of his assassins. Three of these, however, are yet at large, having deserted and escaped thus far. Mr. SARGENT was a graduate of Harvard College, and had resided much at the North, where he was known and extensively connected. His father was a distinguished Revolutionary officer of the Massachusetts line. Adjutant-General of the United States army at the time of ST. CLAIR's defeat, and the first Governor of Mississippi under appointment of the elder ADAMS.

lead_paragraph: On Friday, March 10, at Matamoras, there was a severe norther, during which there were seven vessels blown ashore near the mouth of the Rio Grande River, among which was the steamer Chihuahua. She is a total loss. This was her fourth attempt to cross the Gulf, she having just arrived from New-Orleans. The steam lighter Mexico turned turtle just outside the bar. All on board were drowned.

abstract: Syracuse, N Y, Provost-Marshal's Office, of $27,000
snippet: Syracuse, N Y, Provost-Marshal's Office, of $27,000
lead_paragraph: In view of the fact that the Government for some time has had pressing need for men, its forbearance in the matter of enforcing the draft in this city has been remarkable. Further indulgence and delay, from the present aspect of recruiting, would simply be folly of the most unjustifiable sort. The men must be forthcoming at once, and as the ten days' trial of the machinery improvised by the various Ward organizations for hastening enlistments has in many instances resulted in nothing more tangible than fair promises, the Assistant Provost-Marshal-General, Maj. DODGE, has felt constrained to order the wheel in motion to-day in the Firth and Ninth Districts, where recruiting since the the temporary suspension has been the tardiest. After the announcement of this decision yesterday afternoon, there were some mutterings of indignation on the part of that unreasoning and ignorant class who brought disgrace upon the city when the draft was attempted in 1863. To show how groundless is this dissatisfaction, we will give a few reasons which to all rightly-constituted minds, should mitigate the terrors of the conscription, if they do not dissipate them entirely:

abstract: It is proposed to present to Gen. GRANT the splendid gray stallion "Duke of Wellington," lately brought from Missouri to this city. The horse is valued at $5,000, and his owner, Mr. JAMES O. SWINNEY, of Brooklyn, offers to give $500 on his own account, the balance to be made up by the friends of Gen. GRANT. The "Duke" was run out of Missouri during STERLING PRICE's raid into that State, last autumn. He can boast or a high pedigree, having been sired by Imp. Hooten. He will be exhibited at Central Park, on Thursday next, at 4 P.M.

lead_paragraph: RECKLESS STREET RAILROADING. -- Yesterday, at 11:15 A.M., the driver of car No. 27 of the Fourth-avenue Railroad, (the conductor's badge being marked three,) drove at full trot, without calling out, reining up or using brakes, and with every appearance of intentional collision, into a private carriage, in Fourth-avenue, just at the corner of Fourteenth-street. The carriage was, of course, violently jerked to one side, and a little child in it only saved from falling under the wheels of both car and carriage, by the grasp of a lady in the back seat. It is a wonder that the horse did not run away. Having done this, the driver of the car instantly drove on faster than ever. The conductor, when spoken to, answered civilly enough, but with a statement that makes the Railroad Company look sufficiently reckless of life. He said, "I have cautioned him for such conduct two or three times before!" It appears, therefore, that such reckless brutalities, at most, elicit a "caution." But why should not our street roads have their part in the carnival of railroad murders?

lead_paragraph: Wi give this morning all except the merely narrative portive of the rebel Gen. HOOD's long report of his conduct while in command of the Army of the Tennessee from July 18, 1864, to Jan. 23, 1865, at which time he was relieved. HOOD makes an elaborate attempt to show that the army was nearly ruined when he took it from JOE JOHNSTON, and shows -- or tries to show -- that he never had the means of making headway against the superior forces of the Union commanders.

abstract: This evening, ELLIOT F. SHEPARD, Esq., will deliver before the association a lecture entitled, "Christian Oratory." This association is doing a good work among the soldiers in transit through our city. For several months it has had charge of the religious services at the Battery barracks. Meetings are held every Sabbath afternoon and evening, as well as on Friday evening. These meeting in the past month have been of more man usual interest; men by scores asking for the prayers of God's people. In a recent prayer meeting, sixty men out of about one hundred and fifty arose for prayer. These soldiers were SHERMAN's, going to join his columns. Such a spectacle is rarely witnessed.

abstract: George W. Blunt, a contraband of the deepest dye, pleaded guilty yesterday to an attempt at grand larceny in stealing a silver watch. The prisoner stated that he found the watch and did not know to whom it belonged. He was sent to the Penitentiary for one year.
lead_paragraph: George W. Blunt, a contraband of the deepest dye, pleaded guilty yesterday to an attempt at grand larceny in stealing a silver watch. The prisoner stated that he found the watch and did not know to whom it belonged. He was sent to the Penitentiary for one year. James Sheridan, a lad only 13 years old, pleaded guilty to arson in the fourth degree, having set fire to a barn in the upper part of the city. In sentencing him his Honor stated that the boy had been once before confined in the Juvenile Asylum, and had attempted to set fire to that institution. He should be obliged to send him to the Penitentiary for three years.

abstract: -- Eight hundred and seventy-five officers and privates of the Department were drilled, yesterday afternoon, by Capt. THERON S. abstract: On Sunday last the Twentieth Corps of Gen. SHERMAN's army met the enemy at Bentonville, instead of Mount Olive, as at first reported, twenty-six miles southwest of Goldsboro, where our advance was checked until the arrival of the Fourteenth Corps, which held the enemy at bay, when the Seventeenth Corps arrived and flanked the enemy, who left in confusion for Raleigh, SHERMAN'S forces entering Smithfield, which is half way between Raleigh and Goldsboro.
lead_paragraph: NEWBENN, N.C., Friday, March 24.

abstract: GOTTSCHALK IN BROOKLYN. -- The first of GOTTSCHALK's farewell concerts was given last night at the Brooklyn Academy, assisted by Miss LUCY SIMONS and HARRY SANDERSON Mr. EBEN. The house was filled by the usual "concert audience," and Mr. GOTTSCHALK was, of course, enthusiastically received. Everything he played was encored, and criticism finds no place where the utmost cordiality subsists between player and audience. Miss SIMONS sang most acceptably and produced a favorable impression. HARRY SANDERSON was always a favorite in Brooklyn, and on this occasion riveted the friendly fetters which bind him to the lovers of music in the City of Churches. The last concert will be given on Saturday night.

abstract: -- The connected story of SHERMAN's progress from Fayetteville to Goldsboro, which we publish to-day, reduces to an intelligible form the disjointed reports of the fighting which attended his advance. Two battles proper, and only two, were fought on the march. HARDEE's Charleston and Savannah troops made a stand at Moore's Cross Roads, a point about half way between Fayetteville and Bentonsville. The resistance offered here was of such a nature that for part of two successive days, (the 16th and 17th,) the cavalry under KILPATRICK and a portion of the Twentieth Corps were engaged in dislodging the rebels from a position of considerable strength. But unless we misjudge the situation, this apparently heavy task was rendered heavier by something much resembling a blunder in the execution of a cavalry flanking movement -- which was turned into a temporary repulse of our troops. The fight which ensued two days later, at Bentonsville, has already been sufficiently described. As soon as JOHNSTON discovered that SHERMAN's real objective point was Goldsboro, he hurried forward the army of observation which he had posted half way between that place and Raleigh, to Bentonsville. The temporary repulse of the advance division of the Fourteenth -- followed by the advance of the entire corps, and the precipitate retreat af JOHNSTON's braves, were all the results reached by that General's strategy, and the road was thenceforth clear to Goldsboro.
lead_paragraph: -- The connected story of SHERMAN's progress from Fayetteville to Goldsboro, which we publish to-day, reduces to an intelligible form the disjointed reports of the fighting which attended his advance. Two battles proper, and only two, were fought on the march. HARDEE's Charleston and Savannah troops made a stand at Moore's Cross Roads, a point about half way between Fayetteville and Bentonsville. The resistance offered here was of such a nature that for part of two successive days, (the 16th and 17th,) the cavalry under KILPATRICK and a portion of the Twentieth Corps were engaged in dislodging the rebels from a position of considerable strength. But unless we misjudge the situation, this apparently heavy task was rendered heavier by something much resembling a blunder in the execution of a cavalry flanking movement -- which was turned into a temporary repulse of our troops. The fight which ensued two days later, at Bentonsville, has already been sufficiently described. As soon as JOHNSTON discovered that SHERMAN's real objective point was Goldsboro, he hurried forward the army of observation which he had posted half way between that place and Raleigh, to Bentonsville. The temporary repulse of the advance division of the Fourteenth -- followed by the advance of the entire corps, and the precipitate retreat af JOHNSTON's braves, were all the results reached by that General's strategy, and the road was thenceforth clear to Goldsboro.

abstract: The draft begins again to-day. The pending amendment to the Thirty Million Bounty Bill was passed yesterday, and in the afternoon Mr. BLUNT received a telegram from State Paymaster-General ...
lead_paragraph: The draft begins again to-day. The pending amendment to the Thirty Million Bounty Bill was passed yesterday, and in the afternoon Mr. BLUNT received a telegram from State Paymaster-General MARVIN, saying so, and adding that he hoped to be able to aid Mr. BLUNT to-day -- that is, (it is presumed) to send down a State Paymaster to pay out the required bounties in the city. Mr. BLUNT, we understand, with two other gentlemen, had an interview with Maj. DODGE yesterday afternoon, but the Provost-Marshal does not consider himself justified in further delay, and, of course, no absolute assurance could be given that bounty money was to be at hand to-day.

abstract: Military Spirit in
snippet: Military Spirit in
lead_paragraph: All the accounts, official and non-official, from our army in front of Petersburgh, agree that LEE's veterans showed in the fight of Saturday, an utter lack of sustained energy. Their dash resolved itself into something like a momentary spasm. And when that was over, their spirits, energy and confidence were gone. The brave but misguided fellows confessed as much as this themselves. LEE's best and bravest troops have lost confidence; and GORDON, their temporary leader, can only hurl impotent curses at their nervelessness. The military spirit of the South is mainly embodied to-day in the few lying journalists that still keep blazing away upon half sheets of brown paper, at the prospect of Yankee subjugation. These fellows are doing the most noisy part of the fighting, and they are all as brave as sheep.

lead_paragraph: The correspondent of the London Star writes from Rome, under date of March 10: "I wrote you last week that Gen. MCCLELLAN had arrived here; he had not come then, though invitations had been given out for a party for Sunday a week ago to meet him. He arrived last Sunday. An American wag says that the reason of his delay was, that he could not make up his mind whether to come to Rome or to go to Sorrento first, and that finally he only decided to come this way when the coachman asked him at Naples which station he should drive to.

abstract: Little, Jacob
snippet: Little, Jacob
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning, Mr. JACOB LITTLE, the well-known financier and stock broker, died at his residence in Union-square, after a long and painful illness. Mr. LITTLE was born in Newburyport, Mass., and came to to this city about the year 1817. He entered the office of Mr. JOSEPH BARKER, then the largest banker in the city, and remained with him for nearly six years, when he commenced business on his own account. In 1825 he became a member of the Board of Brokers, and soon made his influence felt in that body. His stock operations amounted to millions, and were conducted with a boldness and success that astonished his associates. For the last five years Mr. LITTLE took a less prominent part in financial operations.

abstract: -- This evening will be one of unusual interest, as many new candidates for lyric and concert fame will be introduced to the public. The Brothers BARILI will be assisted by their most promising pupils -- ANTONIO's Philharmonic Society, which forms an admirable chorus; Mr. ALFRED PEASE, the well-known and popular pianist; and Master ALFRED BARILI, (son of ETTORE, the baritone,) who will make his debut on this occasion as a pianist, having arrived at the ripe age of ten years. The previous pupils of Mr. ANTONIO BARILI have made their mark in the musical world. We need only cite Miss MORENSI, Mrs. VAN ZANDT, and Miss FRIDA DE GEBELE, and much is expected from the new comers, some of whom, as Mrs. FARNHAM, Miss NORTON, Miss NATALIE, are already favorably known to the concert-going public The programme is well selected, and calculated to develop the talent of all the artists engaged in its interpretation.

abstract: Oath of Allegiance Cheerfully Taken; Loyalty Renewed Among Southern People
snippet: Oath of Allegiance Cheerfully Taken; Loyalty Renewed Among Southern People
lead_paragraph: Our Charleston correspondent states that "the work of administering the oath of allegiance is progressing with an astonishing cegree of rapidity." Applicants present themselves, he says, in such numbers that five offices have had to be opened for their accommodation in different parts of the city. They belong to all classes, and embrace not only those who were in the city at the time of its capture, but many who had fled and have since returned.

abstract: Yosemete Gorge and Big Oak Grove
snippet: Yosemete Gorge and Big Oak Grove
lead_paragraph: -- The General Land Office has received the returns of the survey of these wonderful developments of nature, probable the greatest natural curiosities on the globe. The "Yosemete" is a cleft in one of the lateral spurs of the Sierra Nevada. By some volcanic convulsion the mountains have been torn asunder to the extent of some nine or ten miles in length and a width varying from three to five miles, forming stupendous walls of granite, with a valley at the bases of the same, through which flows the Merced River. By a wise and munificent act, Congress, by a special law, has granted this cleft to the State of California to be forever dedicated as a public resort for health and recreation. By the same act there is also granted to the State what is known as the "Big Oak Grove," some thirteen or fourteen miles south of the cleft. The Grove contains 427 trees, from 275 to 400 feet in height, covering 2,589 acres. These mammoth trees are the cane-bearing evergreen of the redwood genus, and known as the sequoia gigantea, with bark on the largest of them of 18 inches thickness, and bear two different kinds of leaves. One of the largest of the species which has been hewn down indicates an age of from two to three thousand years.

abstract: on Cheerfulness
snippet: on Cheerfulness
lead_paragraph: In Thursday's issue of DAVIS' Richmond organ, there is an exhortation to cheerfulness which is altogether touching. It seems that letters addressed to soldiers in the rebel army by their families, urging desertion, have been intercepted, of late, by the postal authorities. Here are specimens of these unpatriotic missives: Says one girl -- a sister, doubtless: "Father and George think you had better go to the enemy." Another: "Billy and Mother and Jane wants you for to get home." And yet again: "If a big crowd comes, you come too. That is my advice." DAVIS' organ, naturally enough, thinks that this sort of exhortation is discouraging to the conscript mind. The editor, therefore, suggests that the ladies of the Confederacy, in addressing their relatives in the army, should adopt a more cheerful style, as for example, thus: "Be a brave man, dear brother. Be a good soldier, dear husband. We'll bear our privations with fortitude and cheerfulness." An excellent specimen, certainly, of the complete rebel letter-writer. "Write cheerful letters to the soldiers in camp!" once more urges DAVIS' henchman. "Don't wait to think whether you are cheerful or not," says this Richmond Gradgrind; "thinking and imagination ought to have nothing to do with it. Write that you are cheerful -- that is the plain duty before you." And yet, for all this urgent remonstrance, it does seem as if the rebel soldier oftener heard the appeal of "Billy and Mother and Jane," than DAVIS' cheerful substitute.

abstract: Mexico, Western; Directions for Posting Letters
snippet: Mexico, Western; Directions for Posting Letters
lead_paragraph: The news from Mexico to-day would seem to give some confirmation of the Paris reports -- so often repeated -- that the Emperor has ordered the return of a large portion, at least, of the French army. The arrivals of troops withdrawn from the Mexican service have been frequent at Havana of late. And if we are to believe the accompanying intelligence as to the decided stand MAXIMILIAN has taken against the claims and pretensions of the hierarchy, it is clear he is looking for compensation for the loss of the French janisaries, by overtures to the Liberalists of a character ostensibly radical to a degree. His rejoinder to the Bishops is as pointed as the most ultra advocate of secularization could desire.

abstract: Among the news from Europe which we publish to-day, is the report that a fatal blow has been struck at the rebel credit in England. Heavy drafts by the Richmond Government have been dishonored at the principal financial agency, on the ground of want of "advices," which, we presume, means the want of funds. One of the dishonored drafts amounted to Â£27,000 sterling. That seems, at first sight, a comparatively small sum, but at the present gold rates at Richmond, it represents no less than thirteen million five hundred thousand Confederate dollars -- a serious item, no doubt, in the present state of the rebel finances.

abstract: Act Prohibiting
snippet: Act Prohibiting
lead_paragraph: The Legislature has passed a bill declaring it a misdemeanor, punishable by fine or imprisonment, or both, to deface scenery, fences, monuments or buildings, with advertisements of parent nostrums, such as for years have marred the natural beauties on the routes of travel by railroad and river, throughout the State, and grossly offended the good taste of tourists and wayfarers. This shameful and mercenary practice should long since have been prohibited, libeling, as it has, the aesthetic taste of the American people; but now that the tardy machinery of legislation has reached it, we trust that the nuisance will be abated forever.

abstract: On Friday evening last, Mr. JAMES SMITH, of Cincinnati, who was tarrying at the Belmont Hotel awaiting the departure of a steamer for California, went abroad and encountered MARY O'BRIEN, of No. 405 Pearl-street, and with her went to Mrs. GANT's eating-saloon in West Broadway. The syren there robbed him of $1,000, and left him to wake in the morning and make the best of his loss. She then went straightway to her associate, CATHERINE FLETCHER, of No. 62 West Broadway, and the two, it appears, immediately "went on a bender," for, on the same night, both were committed, under assumed names, to a cell in the Fifth Ward Police Station, and thence taken, on Saturday morning, to the Tombs, where they were locked up for one day each for intoxication and disorderly conduct. On entering the Tombs, CATHERINE FLETCHER, fearing that she might be robbed, gave the matron, Mrs. FOSTER, $210, and one of the keepers of the prison $500, offering him $100 to retain the money until her discharge. The Tombs authorities, who knew the prisoner as "read-headed Kate," the former companion of one STEPHEN SHERWOOD, felt assured that a robbery had been committed somewhere, and accordingly they retained the money, instead of restoring it to the prisoner at the time of her discharge on Sunday afternoon, having taken care, during her imprisonment, to notify the police that they had $710 that had undoubtedly been stolen. No clue, however, was obtained of the robbery until late on Saturday, when Officer RICH'D FIELD, of the Fifth Ward, found Mr. SMITH and learned that he had lost $1,000 in Mrs. GANT's eating-house. The officer then sought CAROLINE FLETCHER, and found her on Sunday afternoon, and on inquiring what she had done with the money she had stolen, was told that MARY O'BRIEN committed the theft. He subsequently found that female, and was told by her that CAROLINE FLETCHER had induced her to get drunk and stolen the money from her. He accordingly apprehended both of the females, and they were committed, yesterday, by Justice KELLY in default of $2,000 bail each, and the Justice sent the money to the Commissioners of Charities and Correction, with the request that they withhold it from certain of the females' counsel, who were eagerly seeking to net it into their hands yesterday afternoon. Mr. SMITH was sent to the House of Detention to await the trial of the prisoners.

abstract: LECTURE BY MR. SIMONS. -- Mr. JOHN W. SIMONS will deliver a lecture at Cooper Institute this evening, in aid of the Mackey Fund. Dr. MACKEY, for whose benefit this fund is being raised, is a resident and native of Charleston. During the rebellion he has steadily refused to join the rebel cause, although repeatedly solicited; and tempted by the offer of lucrative offices. His contributions in aid of the sick and wounded Union soldiers in Charleston, have so diminished his once abundant resources, that he is now a poor man. It is to be hoped that the lecture-room will be filled this evening, and that a respectable addition will be made to the fund.

abstract: The world does move. It moved in GALILEO'S day, though inquisitorial heresy-hunters clamorously denied it, and forced its keen-sighted asserter to retract the astounding and dangerous dogma. It moves more swiftly in this day than that. Its motion is marked and illustrated constantly by grand and wondrous changes, radically affecting the condition of society.

abstract: Williamsburgh; Collision and Several Ladies Hurt
snippet: Williamsburgh; Collision and Several Ladies Hurt
lead_paragraph: RUN OVER BY A CAR. -- A newsboy named JOHN W. WITE, was run over by a car in Fulton-street, near Hicks, last evening. He was engaged in selling papers at the time, and, accidentally falling from the front platform, was run over and one of his legs was cut off above the knee. He did not appear to feel much pain at the time, but asked for his hat, which had fallen from his head, and which was given to him. He is about 12 years of age. The police of the Forty-second Precinct took him to the hospital.

abstract: Version of Fort Steadman (Petersburgh) battle; Lee's Version of Battle
snippet: Version of Fort Steadman (Petersburgh) battle; Lee's Version of Battle
lead_paragraph: Gen. LEE, in his report, of the engagements in front of Petersburgh on Saturday, is even less candid than the Richmond journals. He says his troops withdrew from Fort Steadman, because "it was found that inclosed works in the rear, commanding the enemy's main line, could only be taken at a terrible sacrifice of life; and the troops were withdrawn." The Richmond Enquirer, in opposition to this, puts it bluntly, that "the enemy massed his artillery heavily in the neighborhood of the captured fort, was thus enabled to pour, such a terrible enfilading fire upon our ranks, as to cause our troops to fall back to their original position." The Enquirer's account agrees with our own reports, and with the official statement of Gen. GRANT. LEE, then, is chargeable with deliberate deception, which shows his weakness, probably, as much as anything else.

abstract: WEHLI AND DE KATOW IN BROOKLYN. -- STRAKOSCH's combination troupe gave their second concert in Brooklyn last night to a crowded house -- a larger audience, in fact, than has assembled at the Academy since the last Philharmonic. Mr. WYMAN asked the indulgence of the audience for Mr. WEHLI, who, having been recently very thoroughly vaccinated, was quite lame. This in no way interfered with the greed of the people, for every appearance of the suffering artist was but a signal for vociferous applause, and every disappearance, an invitation for renewed demand upon his skill and patience. The performance was thoroughly satisfactory. Mlle. DE KATOW played "Musetti" and a very graceful "Romanesca," responding to her encores with themes from "Martha" and "Trovatore." Madame SALVATTI was valuable as a singer against time, but Mr. PAULICCHI, who has a fine baritone voice, was thoroughly acceptable. DE WEHLI's left-hand performance of a "Lucia" caprice, induced clapping of hands and a stamping of feet unequaled in the annals of this extraordinary people; but as the hour was late, and his arm quite lame, he wisely concluded to dismiss the audience while its appetite was yet keen.

abstract: Duke de la Torre on Slavery in; In Spanish Colonies; Duke de la Torre on
snippet: Duke de la Torre on Slavery in; In Spanish Colonies; Duke de la Torre on
lead_paragraph: The Duke DE LA TORRE -- I come now to the most important question, and I am sorry to see it treated in the terms made use of by the Minister of the Colonies. I refer to slavery. His Excellency has apparently confounded it with the slave trade, whereas they are two distinct questions. In my opinion the subject that most affects slavery is the slave trade, and the greatest scandal we offer to the world consists not in maintaining slavery, but in not having been able to abolish the slave trade. Whilst I was Captain General of Cuba I proposed at four different times that the slave trade should be declared piracy. And why? Because if those who plunder at sea are pirates, others who steal men and sell them as slaves should surely be treated as pirates. In reply I had the mortification of receiving most romantic and sentimental effusions, never permission to adopt efficient measures to abolish this most abominable traffic. But if these steps were not taken then, why not take them now? If the evil undoubtedly exists, why not apply the remedy? And what is the slave trade? It is the most scandalous crime, the most horrible abomination ever practiced. If it were legally permitted, the ships destined for the purpose would only carry the number of unfortunate beings that could be comfortably accommodated; surgeons would accompany them, there would be abundant space and comfort, and the sexes would be separated. But the slave trade is contraband, and a most lucrative contraband, and decency induces me to hesitate from explaining the mode in which these unfortunate beings are transported. These unhappy creatures are stowed together in a ship, and although the passage lasts a month, sometimes two or three months, they are never allowed to move from the one spot; destitute of any garment, men and women are indiscriminately huddled together, many of the latter with child, near their confinement. Thus packed, these unfortunate beings reach the coasts of the island of Cuba. And now can it be said by a Minister of the Crown that no resolution has been taken on this question? that it is not yet decided whether the traffic in slaves is to be a crime or not? [The Minister of the Colonies: That is not the question.] His Excellency said -- these are his words -- "the question concerning the crimes of the slave trade is not quite decided upon." For my part, Gentlemen, I cannot comprehend any greater crime than the slave trade; there is no crime more abominable than that of treating human beings in so cruel a manner. I believe that these people, settled in a sugar plantation in the Island of Cuba, are happier than in their own country; they are carried there against their will, they leave their wives, their children, the dearest objects of their homes, but still they are relatively happier. As to the consequences of the slave-trade, the Minister must know, he is acquainted with the evils it gives rise to; he knows that a state of complete demoralization prevails wherever this abominable traffic is carried on, all sorts of atrocious crimes are committed under cover of the slave trade, and the dagger is often employed as an arbiter to settle the differences and disputes which are of constant occurrence. While I was Captain-General of Cuba, the deaths by small-pox, brought over from Africa, exceeded the number of slaves landed in the same period, so that even there was no increase of population, because less labor was to be had than before. Nor can the Minister be acquainted with the position of the authorities at Havana, destitute as they are of efficient power to stop this trade, or how humiliating it is for the Governors of the island to listen to the complaints of the British Consul about the landing of slaves, sometimes exaggerated, at other times correct. The Spanish authorities have thus to suffer reproaches and indignities which the honor of their country repel. The law is inefficient -- completely inefficient, Neither the Marquis DE LA HABANA, who possesses energy and decision, nor I, who employed as much energy and activity as possible, could put a stop to the trade. The Marquis DE CASTELFLORITE did more than either of us, for he went beyond the law, and yet he was unable to suppress it. If the slave trade is declared piracy, does it give the right to the English to try Spaniards and hang them from the yard-arm? No, for we could make a law by which we alone should have the rigth of trying our countrymen for piracy without the interference of England.

abstract: Sympathy; Judge Smith acquits St Albans Raiders; The, Acquitted at Montreal
snippet: Sympathy; Judge Smith acquits St Albans Raiders; The, Acquitted at Montreal
lead_paragraph: Another Canadian Justice has decided that the St. Albans burglars were guiltless of the crime laid to their charge. More strictly speaking, Justice SMITH, of Montreal, decides that the accused were Confederate soldiers, and that as such, they did not come within the Extradition Treaty. To better clinch the matter, in his own Dogberry way, Justice SMITH further, holds that the Extradition Treaty is no longer binding on the contracting parties. And the cause of this lapse in the contract, is that the "United States Courts refuse to recognize the belligerent character of the Confederates!" Judge SMITH is also made to say (by the telegram) that "he held that Gen. Dix's order to shoot them down recognizes the raiders as belligerents, and not as robbers!"

abstract: Moscheisker's Eye, Ear and Throat Diseases; Beecher's, L.; Autobiography, Correspondence, >amp;c.; Hamilton's Military Surgery; Birks'; The Bible and Modern Thought; Knox's Graduated S S Text Books
snippet: Moscheisker's Eye, Ear and Throat Diseases; Beecher's, L.; Autobiography, Correspondence, >amp;c.; Hamilton's Military Surgery; Birks'; The Bible and Modern Thought; Knox's Graduated S S Text Books
lead_paragraph: This volume completes the collection of materials thrown together by his surviving family, from whence must be gathered the story of the life and career of Dr. BEECHER. It is a misfortune that these materials -- reminiscences, autobiography, letters, documents, &c. -- have not fallen into hands that could make an artistic use of them, instead of being presented crudely to the public, as many of them are of value, and with ordinary constructive skill a portrait of the man and his work might be elaborated from them, that would yield in attraction to scarcely any modern biography. The interest of such a life would extend far beyond the circle to whom the perusal of this work in its present shape will probably be limited. Dr. LYMAN BEECHER, on many accounts, deserves to be held in remembrance. Though the magnetic influence of his eloquence and personal presence has passed away, many institutions and organizations yet feel the impetus originally derived from his vigor and energy; his writings have a large circulation, and members of the remarkable group of children that he, patriarch-like, lived to train up and qualify for mental exertion, are foremost among the leaders of popular opinion at this day, conspicuous through the pen or the pulpit for their hold on the hearts and convictions of men. Never, perhaps, was there a person better adapted for the work that he delighted in than Dr. BEECHER. Fluent and prompt in speech, rejoicing in action, ardent in all his conceptions, and impatient to reduce them to practice, as a pulpit rhetorician and popular reasoner, impressing by vivid argumentation, enriched from boundless stores of illustration -- almost unequaled -- every phase of clerical life found him equipped for its strenuous fulfillment. Until strength failed him, through extreme age, nothing obstructed or retarded his course. He was not a man to be frightened by obstacles, and wherever the scene of action might be -- East or West -- there he was to be found, throwing his whole soul into the performance of the absorbing duty of the moment. The space of time occupied by the volume before us is from 1824 to Dr. BEECHER's death, January, 1863, in his eighty-eighth year. Its opening pages find him still working in a field comparatively narrow for a man of his superabundant energies -- the rural district of Litchfield, in Connecticut. The outward landmarks of his life after this were, his removal to the Hanover Church in Boston, in 1826, his acceptance of the Presidency of Lane Seminary, Ohio, in 1830, and his return to New-England, in 1857. The record of the ceaseless labors -- professional, literary, controversial and social -- that fill up the interval, must be sought in the book itself. To general interest, the second volume is inferior to the first, heavy ecclesiastical matters, documents, &c., overlay the page, with but very little attempt at order or arrangement. As a contribution to the religious history of the last fifty years in New-England, the work has an importance independent of, or rather additional to, its biographical purpose. Some portions are undoubtedly conspicuous for what, in any other family, would be called a singular want of good taste and reticence, on matters of the most private and sacred concern, but as they are made public by the parties themselves, it is evident allowance must be made for strongly marked idiosyncracies of character.

abstract: The draft in the Tenth and Twenty-second Wards was begun and carried forward yesterday, without the least disturbance or excitement of any kind. The drawing-rooms (if we may so term them) of Lieut. WARD and Capt. DUNNING were crowded with deeply-interested guests, watching to hear upon whom the whirligig of fortune should bring about its revenges; but neither the police, the military authorities, nor any one else that can be heard of, knows of even a symptom of undue excitement or resistance. In both these wards the work is to be continued this morning at 10 A.M.

abstract: Lee's Waterloo at Petersburgh
snippet: Lee's Waterloo at Petersburgh
lead_paragraph: Some Western friends of the President were recently mixing with him about SHERMAN's grand march. The conversation turned on the danger which SHERMAN's troops would encounter from the rebels when they approached near enough to Richmond to enable LEE to suddenly, reinforce Jo. JOHNSTON. One of the interlocutors said: "Mr. LINCOLN, as SHERMAN's army advances, the rebel forces necessarily concentrate and increase in number. Before long SHERMAN will drive the columns of JOHNSTON, BRAGG, HOKE, and others, within a few days' march of LEE's main army. May not LEE suddenly march south with the bulk of his army, form a junction with JOHNSTON's troops, and, before GRANT can follow any considerable distance, strike SHERMAN's column with superior force, break his lines, defeat his army, and drive his broken fragments back to the coast, and with his whole army give battle to GRANT, and perhaps defeat him?"

abstract: Bayly, Mrs., Shot by Rowdies in her Liquor-store
snippet: Bayly, Mrs., Shot by Rowdies in her Liquor-store
lead_paragraph: Eugene Hollywood, James Grimes, Arthur O'Keefe and Owen Whitney, entered Thomas F. Bayley's liquor-store, at No. 4 James-street, at about 11 o'clock on Tuesday night, and after indulging in deep potations declined to cancel their bill. The landlord, knowing them as desperadoes, ran to his door and hallooed for the police, when Hollywood sprang upon him and prostrated him on the floor, and as the gang were effecting their escape one of their number fired upon the landlord, but, missing him, lodged a bullet in Mrs. Eliza Bayley's left breast, wounding her, it is feared, mortally. They then fled, but were pursued by Policemen Kennedy, Martin and Price, of the Fourth Ward, and having been captured in Hollywood's saloon, the "Pastime," in East Broadway, they were taken before Capt. Thorne, and by him sent to the Tombs, to await the result of an investigation by Coroner Collin. On Hollywood's person was badge No. 77 of Fire Engine Company No. 2. At an ante-mortem examination yesterday afternoon, voluminous testimony was taken, and the jury found that Mrs. Bayley received her wound at the hands of Eugene Hollywood, and Coroner Collin committed that person and his confederates, O'Keefe, Grimes and Whitney, to await the action of the Grand Jury.

abstract: Conventional meetings took place last evening, to make nominations for the coming election of city officials. Hon. ORESTES CLEVELAND was nominated amid applause, the present incumbent. Mr. CLEVELAND is universally esteemed for the manner in which he discharged his duties during the past twelve months. Mr. DAVID S. MANNERS was nominated as Water Commissioner, Mr. JOSEPH MCCOY for School Superintendent, and Mr. PATRICK JORDAN for Chief Officer of Police. The latter nomination will be strongly opposed by Mr. JOSEPH MCMANUS, a great, favorite with the citizens.

abstract: The battle of Saturday morning, on the lines near Petersburgh, is the opening of the Spring campaign. Gen. LEE has taken the initiative, and no longer waits for Gen. GRANT to attack. That the Army of Northern Virginia should take the offensive just when the enemy are confessing to be daily expecting the evacuetion of Richmond, will very materially confound the plans of Gen. GRANT, as well as astonish the too confident Yankee public.

abstract: Drafting was continued in the Fifth District yesterday, to fill the quota of the Tenth Ward. During the morning the delay referred to yesterday again occurred. Some 21 recruits were mustered in yesterday at this office. The money gave out about 2 P.M., and thus there was an end to recruiting for the day. The number of names drawn yesterday was 281 -- making, with those drawn on Wednesday, 550 -- leaving a balance of 152 to fill the quota, and 874 with the per centage added. The drawing will be resumed to-morrow morning, when, it is presumed, the Tenth Ward will be complete.

abstract: Ackerman vs. Miller; Trade-Marks
snippet: Ackerman vs. Miller; Trade-Marks
lead_paragraph: B.J. Ackerman, et al., vs. X. Anthon Miller, et al. -- This was a motion made on behalf of the plaintiffs, to have a temporary injunction made permanent. An action has been commenced against the defendants, in which plaintiffs seek to recover damages for the improper use of what they term a trade mark of theirs, put upon small packages of the essence of coffee, and sold by defendant The mark consisted of the stamp of the Emperor Napoleon's head, in medallion, together with the printed statement on the packages, that a medal, from which the stamped impression was made, had been granted to plaintiffs as a premium at the Great Exhibition in Paris a few years ago. After hearing the affidavits on each side the Court decided to refuse the motion for a permanent injunction, and to dissolve the temporary one. He thought the impression of the head of Louis Napoleon was public property.

abstract: Maj-Gen. DANIEL BUTTERFIELD, of the army, requests us to say that he is in no way connected with an enterprise known as "Butterfield's Overland Dispatch," now being made into a stock company. Numerous letters from parties solicited to subscribe to the stock make this notice necessary. The error has arisen, so far as the General is concerned, from a similarity of name with the party originating and conducting the enterprise; also from BUTTERFIELD's connection with the original Overland Mail enterprise before the war. The latter was another affair altogether.
lead_paragraph: Maj-Gen. abstract: The "War Department recently felt constrained to utter an order withholding transportation to Hilton Head and certain other points on the Southern coast except to such persons as could show passes from the proper authorities. Nevertheless, a vast multitude of sutlers and army hangers-on continued to press themselves upon the government's vessels, and every man of them bore a passport regularly signed and vised as if from the department. But nobody in Washington could explain the mystery of so many passes being afloat, and it at length became manifest that somebody had been driving a brisk trade in forging the autographs of Secretary STANTON and others. Thereupon the War-office called Col. BAKER's attention to the subject, and directed him to take measures to trap the forger. He did so, and at length established a clear case against WM.H. BULL, a transportation clerk in the Quartermaster's office in this city. BULL was arrested on Wednesday, and sent to the Old Capitol Prison yesterday.

abstract: The
snippet: The
lead_paragraph: From July 1, 1864, to March 25, 1865, the income of the National Government from internal revenue alone amounted to $159,664,846. The receipts from this source for the balance of the current fiscal year, (especially under the amended tax law, which goes into operation on Saturday, April 1,) will be sufficiently liberal to run the aggregate income for the year above $200,000,000, or something over the amount realized in Great Britain in 1864, from excise duties, stamps, taxes and property and income taxes. With capable and vigilant officers engaged in the rigid enforcement of the revised internal revenue law, the coming fiscal year must show even more encouraging results in this respect. The independent Revenue Agencies are of primary importance to the public interests, in discovering, investigating and correcting fraudulent returns of incomes, of monthly work in the various manufacturing establishments, and of monthly sales of gold, stocks, exchange, produce and merchandise, evasions of the license and stamp clause of the internal revenue law, &c. Through their practical working, hundreds of thousands of dollars have been secured to the National Treasury, of which it would otherwise have been deprived.

abstract: MAN OVERBOARB. Late Tuesday night, a German gentleman went on board the Hamilton-avenue ferry-boat at Whiteball, and walked off the forward end of the boat into the river, and was being rapidly carried out into the stream by the current, when,...
lead_paragraph: MAN OVERBOARB. -- Late Tuesday night, a German gentleman went on board the Hamilton-avenue ferry-boat at Whiteball, and walked off the forward end of the boat into the river, and was being rapidly carried out into the stream by the current, when, fortunately, his cries were heard by DAVID VON OSDOLL and JOHN LUDLOW, of the United States Revenue barge office, who at once went to his assistance in a boat. On reaching him he was in an exhausted and sinking condition. He was taken into the Revenue office, where the proper restoratives were applied, and he was soon enabled to proceed on his way. The person rescued was a very corpulent man, and it was only after great exertions and perseverence that his rescuers were enabled to get him into the boat and again out of it.

abstract: Names of the Heroes of; Excursion to City Point and Peace Rumors
snippet: Names of the Heroes of; Excursion to City Point and Peace Rumors
lead_paragraph: In consequence of the storm yesterday our telegraphic news this morning is limited in extent and importance. The public are looking with anxiety toward the James for stirring intelligence; but whether of war or peace they cannot decide. Meantime the air is full of rumor, which everybody repeats and nobody believes. The official paper at Washington admits the conference on between our leading Generals on the James River, but says that nothing is known of its present or prospective results. Secretary SEWARD, accompanied by the Spanish and British Ministers and a few personal friends, has gone to City Point. It is called a mere pleasure excursion, but the eager public will doubtless insist that it is a new feature in the supposed reopening of peace negotiations. The Richmond journals of Monday have the following paragraphs about the movements of our forces: "On Thursday a heavy column of the enemy moved down the Jerusalem plank road. This movement is supposed to be a diversion in favor of SHERMAN, made overland for the purpose of striking Weldon, and at the same time destroying the railroad between that point and Stony Creek." Perhaps this mysterious movement hastened LEE's attempt of Saturday morning. There was nothing from SHERMAN yesterday; according to his own order, his men are having a season of rest. A portion of SHERIDAN's cavalry has ben dismounted. The remainder may soon be heard from in a new direction.

abstract: Have they Rights; Projects and Prospects of
snippet: Have they Rights; Projects and Prospects of
lead_paragraph: We attach little importance to the rumors of renewed peace conferences with the rebel leaders in front of Richmond. In themselves they are not improbable, for there cannot be the least doubt that the rebel cause, even in the eyes of its leaders, is utterly desperate. It has no longer the elements of prolonged resistance. Even a victory in front of Richmond, much as it might gratify their pride, could not restore their fortunes. Under such circumstances DAVIS and LEE, in whom the whole power of the rebels cause is now vested, have a fearful responsibility upon their hands. Considerations of personal safety might prompt them to fight another battle; but the great body of their people will not permit such considerations to control their action. They must act for others as well as themselves, and although DAVIS is, doubtless, selfish, cold-blooded and unscrupulous. Gen. LEE has too high a sense of justice to others to prolong a contest which can only involve others in misery without affording the slightest prospect of success.

abstract: -- The board met last evening. Gen. CROOKE occupied the chair. Some business of importance was transacted, of which the following was most prominent The committee upon the subject reported in favor of renting rooms Nos. 5, 7 and 9, on the first floor of the new court-house to the U.S. Court for Eastern District of New-York, also, the Supreme Court-room on the second floor, for three years, or any lesser term, as may be required, at a yearly rent of $8,000. The Committee on Military Affairs reported in favor of leasing the new armory, corner of Fourth and North Second streeets, E.D., at a rent of $2,000 per annum, for the use of the Forty-seventh Regiment N.Y.S.N.G; a resolution in favor was adopted. The Bounty Committee are, by resolution, directed to pay $300 to every enlisted man as soon as a certified copy of the law recently passed by the Legislature can be obtained. The board soon after adjourned for one week.
lead_paragraph: -- The board met last evening. Gen. CROOKE occupied the chair. The Committee on Military Affairs reported in favor of leasing the new armory, corner of Fourth and North Second streeets, E.D., at a rent of $2,000 per annum, for the use of the Forty-seventh Regiment N.Y.S.N.G; a resolution in favor was adopted. abstract: Prof. AGASSIZ and party leave New-York to day in the Pacific Mall Steamship Company's new steamer Colorado, of 3,195 tons, on the way to South America. The Professor's chief object is to collect facts for the purpose of testing his glacial theory. This theory is, in substance, that at some past period among the geological ages, a very large part of the earth was long covered with two vast caps or saucers of snow and ice, centered at the poles, lapping far down toward the equator, and perhaps in many parts 12,000 or 15,000 feet thick. It is to trace records of their work, or to compare them with the glaciers of to-day that the expedition goes, and it will also make as extensive investigations and bring home as extensive collections as possible, in zoology and other natural sciences. The expense of the trip itself will be defrayed by NATHANIEL THAYER, of Boston, and the preparations, purchase of instruments, &c., were at the cost of the Massachusetts Museum of Comparative Zoology, which is to receive specimens brought home. Very important and interesting results are expected from this expedition, which will probably be absent a year at least. The party, besides Prof. AGASSIZ and his wife, consists of Dr. Colting, Curator of the Lowell Institute, and wife; Mr. Burkhardt, artist; and Messrs. Allen, Anthony, Hart James, St. John and Seaver, assistants.

abstract: At a meeting of the Board of Councilmen yesterday, a communication was received from the Mayor, stating that the Harlem Gaslight Company has notified him that unless a contract is entered into at once with the company, they will feel at liberty to charge such an amount for lighting the public lamps as they may deem just and reasonable, and will not confine themselves to the amount now charged, namely, $50 per lamp. The Mayor recommends the Common Council to enter into yearly contracts with the various gas companies, after advertising for proposals.
lead_paragraph: At a meeting of the Board of Councilmen yesterday, a communication was received from the Mayor, stating that the Harlem Gaslight Company has notified him that unless a contract is entered into at once with the company, they will feel at liberty to charge such an amount for lighting the public lamps as they may deem just and reasonable, and will not confine themselves to the amount now charged, namely, $50 per lamp. The Mayor recommends the Common Council to enter into yearly contracts with the various gas companies, after advertising for proposals.

abstract: THE GOTTSCHALK CONCERTS. The farewell concerts of Mr. GOTTSCHALK and Miss LUCY SIMONS have been unusually attractive and successful. Niblo's Saloon is much too small to accommodate the legions who besiege the box office. The sale of tickets has always to be stopped, and grumbling and complaining are unavoidable.
lead_paragraph: THE GOTTSCHALK CONCERTS. -- The farewell concerts of Mr. GOTTSCHALK and Miss LUCY SIMONS have been unusually attractive and successful. Niblo's Saloon is much too small to accommodate the legions who besiege the box office. The sale of tickets has always to be stopped, and grumbling and complaining are unavoidable. We have rarely heard our great pianist to better advantage than on the three evenings of his recent performances. The clearness, delicacy and strength of his style are, in fact, perfect. They have been illustrated, too, in many new pieces. The best of these, the "Battle-Cry of Freedom," was performed for the first time on Wednesday evening. It is an effective arrangement of a well-known patriotic air, and is mainly valuable for the introduction and the quiet variation which precedes the finale. Mr. GOTTSCHALK played this taking morceau with complete gusto, and was encored as usual. At the concert last evening a large portion of CHICKERING & SONS' ware-room was present to wit: six grand pianos. This alarming manifestation was occasioned by the appearance on the programme of the "Faust" march arranged for that number of instruments by Mr. GOTTSCHALK, and played by that gentleman and Messrs. SANDERSON, FRADEL, MUZIO, LASSCRUE and TRASTOUR. The effect of this piece may be left to the imagination. It brought down the house, and in truth nearly brought down the entire block. At both these entertainments Miss LUCY SIMONS sang with rare skill, and entirely to the acceptance of the audience. Mr. HARRY SANSERSON contributed also, in a large manner, to the brilliancy of the programme.

abstract: Murderers Condemned; Sketch of; Ratzky, Ignatz; Sketch of Him and his Crime
snippet: Murderers Condemned; Sketch of; Ratzky, Ignatz; Sketch of Him and his Crime
lead_paragraph: ISAACS, who has figured in unpleasant prominence at the several executions which have taken place in this city and vicinity for many years past, has visited the Kings County jail in Brooklyn, for the purpose of examining the local instrument of death, and familiarizing himself with the locality and the unfortunates whereat and with whom he may before long officiate in what seems to be his favorite part of hangman. As the most trivial occurrence in life may serve our teachers in holy things for a text, so the visit of this person to the scene of his future melancholy duties, affords us an opportunity for presenting the cases of the four unfortunate men who lie there under the sentence of death for murder in the first degree.

abstract: The End of; The; dangerous to pedestrians; Fire Departm't; Volunteer, the End of
snippet: The End of; The; dangerous to pedestrians; Fire Departm't; Volunteer, the End of
lead_paragraph: There is an end to the Volunteer Fire Department system of New-York. The Senate bill, substituting for that system a paid department, passed the Assembly yesterday by a vote which lacks but one of a two-thirds majority, and which thus relieves the measure effectually of any partizan or even party character.
